The synthesis of 4 nm CoFe2O4 nanoparticles is described in the article. The process involves the use of several chemicals and specific equipment. 

The chemicals required for the synthesis include Fe(acac)3, Co(acac)2, 1,2-hexadecanediol (HDD), oleic acid, and phenyl ether. Specifically, 2 mmol of Fe(acac)3, 1 mmol of Co(acac)2, 10 mmol of 1,2-hexadecanediol, 6 mmol of oleic acid, and 20 mL of phenyl ether are used. 

The process begins with the mixing of these chemicals under a flow of nitrogen. The mixture is then heated to 200 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with vigorous stirring, and then kept at that temperature for 1 hour. After this, the mixture is heated to reflux (265 °C) and kept at this temperature for another 30 minutes. The dark red-brown mixture is then cooled to room temperature by moving the heat source. 

Under ambient conditions, ethanol (40 mL) is added to the mixture, and a dark red-brown material is precipitated and separated via centrifugation at 6000 rpm for 3 minutes. The dark red-brown product is then dissolved in hexane.

The equipment used in this process includes a magnetic stirrer for mixing the chemicals, a heating device to achieve the required temperatures, and a centrifuge for the separation of the precipitated material. 

The article also mentions that the TEM measurements were carried out with a Philips EM 420 (120 kV) under ambient conditions, and the hysteresis loop was obtained at 300 K with a LakeShore 7400 VSM system. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of 4 nm CoFe2O4 nanoparticles involves a specific set of chemicals, precise control of temperature and stirring conditions, and the use of specific equipment for mixing, heating, and separation of the product.

The synthesis of CoFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes, including 13 nm, is described in the provided article. The method involves the co-thermolysis of iron and cobalt acetylacetonates precursors in the solvent of oleic acid. The different shapes and sizes of CoFe2O4 NPs can be produced by simply controlling the amount of Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2.

For the synthesis of 15 nm CoFe2O4 nanoparticles, Fe(acac)3 (8 mmol), Co(acac)2 (4 mmol) and oleic acid (15 mL) were mixed and magnetically stirred under a flow of nitrogen. The mixture was heated to 120 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with vigorous stirring, and then kept at that temperature for 1 h. The obtained solution was then heated to 320 °C, and the solution color gradually became black, indicating that the magnetic nanoparticles were being formed. After refluxing for 4 h, the solution was cooled to room temperature, and a black precipitate was obtained upon addition of 50 mL of isopropyl alcohol and centrifuged. The product was washed with petroleum and ethanol (1/4, v/v) 3 times. Finally, the product was redispersed in hexane.

Under similar reaction conditions, the different size and shape CoFe2O4 NPs could be produced by simply controlling the amount of Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2. For example, the near corner-grown cubic NPs with 25 nm was synthesized using 2 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 1 mmol of Co(acac)2, and the near cubic NPs with 45 nm was prepared using 4 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 2 mmol of Co(acac)2. The amount of Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2 that synthesized star-shaped nanoparticles with 35 nm was same with the amount of that near corner-grown cubic NPs except using 330 °C.

Although the article does not provide specific details for the synthesis of 13 nm CoFe2O4 NPs, it can be inferred from the described methods that adjusting the amounts of Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2, as well as the reaction temperature, could potentially yield NPs of this size.

The synthesis of 4 nm CoFe2O4 nanoparticles is described in the article. The process involves the use of several chemicals and specific equipment. 

The chemicals required for the synthesis include Fe(acac)3, Co(acac)2, 1,2-hexadecanediol (HDD), oleic acid, and phenyl ether. The specific amounts used in the experiment are 2 mmol of Fe(acac)3, 1 mmol of Co(acac)2, 10 mmol of 1,2-hexadecanediol, 6 mmol of oleic acid, and 20 mL of phenyl ether.

The process begins with the mixture of these chemicals, which is then magnetically stirred under a flow of nitrogen. The mixture is heated to 200 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with vigorous stirring, and then kept at that temperature for 1 hour. The solution is then heated to reflux (265 °C) and kept at this temperature for another 30 minutes. The dark red-brown mixture is cooled to room temperature by moving the heat source.

Under ambient conditions, ethanol (40 mL) is added to the mixture, and a dark red-brown material is precipitated and separated via centrifugation (6000 rpm, 3 min). The dark red-brown product is dissolved in hexane.

The TEM measurements were carried out with Philips EM 420 (120 kV) under ambient conditions deposition of the hexane or H2O dispersions of the particles on amorphous carbon coated copper grids. The hysteresis loop was obtained at 300 K with a LakeShore 7400 VSM system.

In conclusion, the synthesis of 4 nm CoFe2O4 nanoparticles involves the use of specific chemicals in precise amounts, specific temperature and time conditions, and specific equipment for measurement and analysis. The process requires careful control of these parameters to successfully produce the nanoparticles.

The synthesis of CoFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes, including 13 nm, is achieved through a precursor-mediated growth method. The precursors used in the synthesis are iron and cobalt acetylacetonates (Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2), and oleic acid is used as the solvent. The amount of these precursors plays a crucial role in controlling the size and shape of the resulting CoFe2O4 NPs.

For the synthesis of 15 nm CoFe2O4 nanoparticles, 8 mmol of Fe(acac)3, 4 mmol of Co(acac)2, and 15 mL of oleic acid are mixed and magnetically stirred under a flow of nitrogen. The mixture is heated to 120 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with vigorous stirring, and then kept at that temperature for 1 hour. The solution is then heated to 320 °C, and the solution color gradually becomes black, indicating that the magnetic nanoparticles are being formed. After refluxing for 4 hours, the solution is cooled to room temperature, and a black precipitate is obtained upon addition of 50 mL of isopropyl alcohol and centrifuged. The product is washed with petroleum and ethanol (1/4, v/v) 3 times. Finally, the product is redispersed in hexane.

The size and shape of the CoFe2O4 NPs can be controlled by adjusting the amount of Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2. For example, near corner-grown cubic NPs with 25 nm size are synthesized using 2 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 1 mmol of Co(acac)2, and near cubic NPs with 45 nm size are prepared using 4 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 2 mmol of Co(acac)2. The amount of Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2 that synthesized star-shaped nanoparticles with 35 nm size is the same as that for near corner-grown cubic NPs except the reaction temperature is 330 °C.

The synthesis of CoFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes, including 24 nm, is achieved through a precursor-mediated growth method. The precursors used in this process are iron and cobalt acetylacetonates (Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2), and oleic acid is used as the solvent. The amount of these precursors plays a crucial role in controlling the size and shape of the resulting CoFe2O4 NPs.

For the synthesis of 15 nm CoFe2O4 nanoparticles, 8 mmol of Fe(acac)3, 4 mmol of Co(acac)2, and 15 mL of oleic acid are mixed and magnetically stirred under a flow of nitrogen. The mixture is heated to 120 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with vigorous stirring, and then kept at that temperature for 1 hour. The solution is then heated to 320 °C, and after refluxing for 4 hours, the solution is cooled to room temperature. A black precipitate is obtained upon the addition of 50 mL of isopropyl alcohol and centrifugation. The product is washed with petroleum and ethanol (1/4, v/v) three times, and finally, the product is redispersed in hexane.

To synthesize near corner-grown cubic NPs with a size of 24.5 nm, 2 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 1 mmol of Co(acac)2 are used under similar reaction conditions. For the synthesis of near cubic NPs with a size of 45.2 nm, 4 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 2 mmol of Co(acac)2 are used. The starlike NPs with a size of 35 nm are synthesized using the same amount of Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2 as the near corner-grown cubic NPs, but the reaction temperature is increased to 330 °C.

The resulting CoFe2O4 NPs are characterized using various techniques. The crystallinity and structure of the CoFe2O4 NPs are confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). The half-peak width of CoFe2O4 NPs decreases with the increase of NPs sizes. The average sizes of the NPs, estimated with Scherrer's formula, are consistent with the sizes observed in the TEM images. The room-temperature hysteresis loop of the ferrites is measured using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). The CoFe2O4 nanoparticles are also characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).

The synthesis of CoFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) of varying sizes, including 32 nm, is achieved through a precursor-mediated growth method. The precursors used in this process are iron and cobalt acetylacetonates (Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2 respectively), and oleic acid is used as the solvent. The amount of these precursors plays a crucial role in controlling the size and shape of the resulting CoFe2O4 NPs.

For the synthesis of 32 nm starlike CoFe2O4 NPs, 2 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 1 mmol of Co(acac)2 are mixed with 15 mL of oleic acid. This mixture is then heated to 120 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with vigorous stirring, and maintained at this temperature for 1 hour. Subsequently, the solution is heated to 330 °C, a higher temperature than used for other shapes, which induces the growth of the starlike shape. The solution is then refluxed for 4 hours. Upon cooling to room temperature, a black precipitate is obtained upon the addition of 50 mL of isopropyl alcohol and centrifugation. The product is then washed with petroleum and ethanol (1/4, v/v) three times, and finally redispersed in hexane.

For the synthesis of other shapes and sizes of CoFe2O4 NPs, the amount of Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2 is adjusted. For instance, near corner-grown cubic NPs with a size of 25 nm are synthesized using 2 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 1 mmol of Co(acac)2, while near cubic NPs with a size of 45 nm are prepared using 4 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 2 mmol of Co(acac)2. The reaction temperature for these shapes is 320 °C.

The resulting CoFe2O4 NPs are characterized using various techniques. The crystallinity and structure of the NPs are confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). The average sizes of the NPs, estimated with Scherrer's formula, are consistent with the sizes observed in the TEM images. The room-temperature hysteresis loop of the ferrites is measured using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). The CoFe2O4 nanoparticles are also characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).

The synthesis of CoFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes, including 45 nm, is achieved through a precursor-mediated growth method. The precursors used in this process are iron and cobalt acetylacetonates (Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2), and oleic acid is used as the solvent. The amount of these precursors plays a crucial role in controlling the size and shape of the resulting CoFe2O4 NPs.

For the synthesis of 45 nm CoFe2O4 NPs, specifically, the experiment uses 4 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 2 mmol of Co(acac)2. These are mixed with 15 mL of oleic acid and the mixture is stirred under a flow of nitrogen. The mixture is then heated to 120 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with vigorous stirring, and kept at that temperature for 1 hour. Following this, the solution is heated to 320 °C, and the solution color gradually turns black, indicating the formation of the magnetic nanoparticles. After refluxing for 4 hours, the solution is cooled to room temperature, and a black precipitate is obtained upon the addition of 50 mL of isopropyl alcohol and centrifugation. The product is then washed with petroleum and ethanol (1/4, v/v) three times. Finally, the product is redispersed in hexane.

The resulting CoFe2O4 NPs are characterized using various techniques. The crystallinity and structure of the CoFe2O4 NPs are confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD). The half-peak width of CoFe2O4 NPs decreases with the increase of NPs sizes. The average sizes of the NPs, estimated with Scherrer's formula, are consistent with the sizes observed in the TEM images. The room-temperature hysteresis loop of the ferrites is measured using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). The magnetization curves display relatively high saturation magnetization. The CoFe2O4 nanoparticles are also characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).

In conclusion, the synthesis of CoFe2O4 NPs of different sizes, including 45 nm, is achieved through a precursor-mediated growth method using iron and cobalt acetylacetonates as precursors and oleic acid as the solvent. The amount of these precursors and the temperature conditions play a crucial role in controlling the size and shape of the resulting CoFe2O4 NPs.

The synthesis of CoFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes, including 45 nm, can be achieved through a precursor-mediated growth method. The method involves the co-thermolysis of iron and cobalt acetylacetonates precursors in the solvent of oleic acid. The different shapes and sizes of CoFe2O4 NPs can be readily tuned by only changing the decomposition amount of Co and Fe precursors.

For the synthesis of 45 nm CoFe2O4 nanoparticles, 4 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 2 mmol of Co(acac)2 are used. The precursors and oleic acid (15 mL) are mixed and magnetically stirred under a flow of nitrogen. The mixture is heated to 120 °C under a nitrogen atmosphere with vigorous stirring, and then kept at that temperature for 1 hour. The obtained solution is then heated to 320 °C, and the solution color gradually becomes black, indicating that the magnetic nanoparticles are being formed. After refluxing for 4 hours, the solution is cooled to room temperature, and a black precipitate is obtained upon addition of 50 mL of isopropyl alcohol and centrifuged. The product is washed with petroleum and ethanol (1/4, v/v) 3 times. Finally, the product is redispersed in hexane.

The different shape (polyhedrons, near corner-grown cubic, near cubic and starlike) and different size (15, 25, 45 and 35 nm) could be readily tuned by only changing the decomposition amount of Co and Fe precursors. For example, the near corner-grown cubic NPs with 25 nm was synthesized using 2 mmol of Fe(acac)3 and 1 mmol of Co(acac)2. The amount of Fe(acac)3 and Co(acac)2 that synthesized star-shaped nanoparticles with 35 nm was the same with the amount of that near corner-grown cubic NPs except using 330 °C.

The TEM measurements were carried out with Philips EM 420 (120 kV) under ambient conditions deposition of the hexane or H2O dispersions of the particles on amorphous carbon coated copper grids. The hysteresis loop was obtained at 300 K with a LakeShore 7400 VSM system. The fluorescence spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu RF-5301 spectrofluorophotometer. UV-vis absorbance measurements experiments were carried out on a UV 1750 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan). The absorbance was acquired on a 721E visible spectrophotometer (Shanghai). The cytotoxicity assay was detected by a microplate reader (Nanjing Huadong Electronics Group Co., Ltd. DG5033A – microplate reader).

The synthesis of 4 nm MnFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) involves several steps and reagents. The reagents include Fe(acac)3 (2 mmol), Mn(acac)2 (1 mmol), 1,2-hexadecanediol (10 mmol), oleic acid (6 mmol), oleylamine (6 mmol), and phenyl ether (20 mL). These were mixed and magnetically stirred under a flow of nitrogen. The mixture was then heated to 200 °C for 30 minutes and then, under a blanket of nitrogen, heated to reflux (265 °C) for another 30 minutes. The black-brown mixture was cooled to room temperature by removing the heat source. 

Under ambient conditions, ethanol (40 mL) was added to the mixture, and a black material was precipitated and separated via centrifugation. In order to remove the excess oleic acid and oleylamine on the surface of NPs, the NPs were washed by petroleum ether and ethanol mixed solution. Finally, the product was dispersed in hexane.

The synthesis of the 16, 18, and 27 nm MnFe2O4 NPs was obtained according to the literature with a little modification. The synthesis method was given in the Supporting Information. 

For the synthesis of DIB-PEH-NH-FA (1a), Folic acid (0.044 g, 0.1 mmol) was dissolved in 3 mL of dry dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) into which 0.040 g (0.15 mmol) of dicyclohexylcarbodiimide (DCC) and 0.014 g (0.12 mmol) of hydroxysuccinimide (NHS) were added. The reaction mixture was stirred for 12 hours at room temperature and then added with DIB-PEG-NH2 (200 mg). After another 12 hours of reaction, the product was precipitated by adding diethyl ether (20 mL) and dried in vacuo.

The synthesis of MnFe2O4-DIB-PEG-NH2 (1c), MnFe2O4 -DIB￾PEG-NH2 -FA (1d), and MnFe2O4 -DIB-PEG-NH-FA, FITC (1e) involved adding 0.02 g of MnFe2O4 NPs in 5 mL of CHCl3 to 0.02 g of 1a. The mixture was stirred 2h in the dark at room temperature. The particles were then collected by centrifugation, washed with CHCl3 and hexane (1:5 V/V), and then dispersed in water and dialysised with H2O for 24 h to remove unreacted organic molecules. Using the similar reaction conditions mentioned above, MnFe2O4 -DIB-PEG￾NH2-FA (1d) and MnFe2O4-DIB-PEG-NH-FA, FITC (1e) were synthesized.

The TEM measurements were carried out with Philips EM 420 (120kV) under ambient conditions deposition of the hexane or H2O dispersions of the particles on amorphous carbon coated copper grids. The hysteresis loop was obtained at 300K with a LakeShore 7400 VSM system. FT-IR characterization was carried out on a Therrno Mattson FT-IR spectrometer. UV-vis absorbance measurements experiments were carried out on a UV 1750 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan). Fluorescent images were taken on Zeiss Leica inverted epifluorescence/reflectance laser scanning confocal microscope.

The synthesis of MnFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes, including 27 nm, is described in the provided text. The synthesis of the 4 nm MnFe2O4 NPs is detailed first. The reagents used include Iron (III) acetylacetonate (Fe(acac)3, 2 mmol), manganese (II) acetylacetonate (Mn(acac)2, 1 mmol), 1,2-hexadecanediol (10 mmol), oleic acid (6 mmol), oleylamine (6 mmol), and phenyl ether (20 mL). These were mixed and magnetically stirred under a flow of nitrogen. The mixture was heated to 200 °C for 30 min and then, under a blanket of nitrogen, heated to reflux (265 °C) for another 30 min. The black-brown mixture was cooled to room temperature by removing the heat source. Under ambient conditions, ethanol (40 mL) was added to the mixture, and a black material was precipitated and separated via centrifugation. To remove the excess oleic acid and oleylamine on the surface of NPs, the NPs were washed by petroleum ether and ethanol mixed solution. Finally, the product was dispersed in hexane.

The synthesis of the 16, 18, and 27 nm MnFe2O4 NPs was obtained according to the literature with a little modification. The synthesis method was given in the Supporting Information. The size and shape of these NPs were controlled by simple tuning the amount of Fe(acac)3 and Mn(acac)2, as described previously. The 16, 18, and 27 nm MnFe2O4 NPs were obtained via thermal decomposition of Fe(acac)3 and Mn(acac)2 in the presence of oleic acid.

To render these nanoparticles hydrophilic, the PEG-3,4-dihydroxy benzyl amine (DIB-PEG￾NH2) was used to replace oleate around the synthesized nanoparticles in CHCl3 solution by the formation of a chelate bond between MnFe2O4 and DIB. The catalysis of peroxidase substrate TMB was tested in the presence of H2O2.

The synthesis of manganese ferrite (MnFe2O4) nanoparticles of about 6 nm size was achieved using the inverse micelle method. The reagents used for this process included MnSO4·H2O and Toluene, which were BDH products, and NaOH purchased from Panreac. Sodium dodecylbenzenesulfonate (NaDBS) and Fe2(SO4)3·5H2O were also used. All these chemicals were of pure grade for analysis and were used without further purifications.

In the synthesis process, aqueous 0.2 mol/L and 0.4 mol/L solutions of Mn(II) and Fe(III), respectively, were mixed to render a 1:2 molar ratio of Mn(II)/Fe(III) in a total volume of 5 mL of the ions solution. This solution was then mixed, under stirring, with 5 mL of 0.4 M aqueous solution of NaDBS followed by the addition of a large excess of toluene equal to 200 mL. The final mixture was maintained under vigorous stirring overnight, until a homogeneous dispersion containing a system of reverse micelle was obtained.

The 1 mol/L NaOH solution (8 mL) was drop-by-drop added to the starting solution, under vigorous stirring, to form colloids. Subsequently, the mixture volume was reduced by evaporation under vacuum. The practically dried product was then submitted to heat-treatment under an argon flow to obtain a fine powder. 

The synthesized product was characterized from X-ray diffraction (XRD), Mössbauer spectroscopy and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) data. The XRD powder pattern of the as-synthesized product showed that the pattern corresponds to the fcc unit cell typical of the spinel structure. According to the observed peak width at the half maximum, the average crystallite size for the obtained powders was about 6 nm. The HR-TEM images confirmed that the used preparative route leads to the formation of MnFe2O4 nanocrystals of about 6 nm diameter.

The synthesis of MgFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out using a hydrothermal method. The specific reagents used in the synthesis included MgCl2 6H2O (2.5 mmol) and FeCl3 6H2O (5 mmol), which were dissolved in ethylene glycol (40 mL) to form a clear solution. This was followed by the addition of NaAc (3.6 g) and polyethylene glycol 20000 (1.0 g). 

The mixture was stirred vigorously until the reactants dissolved, and then sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave with a 50 mL capacity. The autoclave was heated to and maintained at 200 °C for 6 hours, and allowed to cool to room temperature. 

The resulting black products were washed several times with ethanol and deionized water, and dried at 60 °C for 6 hours. The average size of the resulting MgFe2O4 NPs was about 220 nm, as determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis. 

The surface morphology of the MgFe2O4 NPs was investigated by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the MgFe2O4 NPs was carried out with X'Pertpro Philips X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.154056). The magnetic hysteresis loop of the prepared MgFe2O4 NPs was carried out with a vibration sample magnetometer (VSM, Lakeshore cryotronics 730, USA) at room temperature. 

The chemical composition of the as-prepared ferrite NPs products was determined by energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis. Results from EDX spectra of prepared ferrite microspheres show that samples contain Mg, Fe, O for MgFe2O4 MNPs. The results are consistent with that of ICP-AES (data not given). 

In conclusion, the synthesis of MgFe2O4 NPs involves a hydrothermal method using specific reagents and conditions, and the resulting NPs were characterized using various techniques to confirm their size, morphology, and composition.

The synthesis of ZnFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the article. The procedure for synthesizing ZnFe2O4 NFs (nanoflowers) is as follows: Typically 0.14 g zinc sulfate (0.025 M) and 0.16 g anhydrous FeCl3 (0.05 M) were dissolved in 20 mL distilled water and 0.3 g urea (0.25 M) was added to it. Then the whole solution was stirred for 10 min to make the solution homogeneous. The molar ratio of the Zn2+: Fe3+: urea was maintained as 1:2:4. 

The morphology of the as-synthesized ZnFe2O4 was examined by FESEM and TEM analysis. Figure 2a,b display the FESEM images of as-synthesized ZnFe2O4, in lower and higher magnification, respectively. It has been observed from figure 2a,b that ZnFe2O4 has acquired 3D flowerlike morphology. Figure 2c,d demonstrate the TEM images of 3D ZnFe2O4. Highly magnified TEM image (figure 2d) of ZnFe2O4 reveals that the development of 3D flowerlike morphology is due to the self-assembly of 1D nanorods and occurred in presence of ZnSO4. The length and diameter of the individual nanorods are ~ 104 nm and ~ 27 nm, respectively.

The as-synthesized ZnFe2O4 is robust in nature. It has been observed that the flower-like morphology was intact even after annealing at 450 °C. In order to investigate the porous nature of the as-synthesized product, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis has been done. The graph presented in Figure 5a conveys that the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm follows type IV category and the calculated Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area is 70.274 m2/g. According to the pore size distribution curve (figure 5b) the pore width of the material is 2.4 nm i.e. the flower-like robust ZnFe2O4 NF is mesoporous (2-50 nm) in nature.

The as-synthesized material conveys the peroxidase mimicking activity as well as acetone gas sensing property. Then peroxidase mimicking reaction i.e., blue color formation step has been found to be halted selectively by Hg2+ ion which detect and quantify Hg2+ ion in aqueous solution. Thus the as-synthesized low cost material has three fold applications: peroxidase mimicking activity, Hg2+ ion and gas sensing capabilities.

ZnFe2O4 Magnetic Nanoparticles (MNPs) were prepared using a hydrothermal method. The reagents used for the synthesis included ZnCl2 (0.34 g, 2.5 mmol) and FeCl3·6H2O (1.35 g, 5 mmol), which were dissolved in ethylene glycol (40 mL) to form a clear solution. This was followed by the addition of NaAc (3.6 g) and polyethylene glycol 20 000 (1.0 g). The mixture was stirred vigorously for 30 minutes.

After stirring, the mixture was sealed in a teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave with a 50 mL capacity. The autoclave was heated to and maintained at 200 °C for 8 hours and allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting black products were washed several times with ethanol and dried at 60 °C for 6 hours.

The as-prepared ZnFe2O4 MNPs were identified from the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with a suitable spinel structure. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) revealed that ZnFe2O4 MNPs were spherical and dispersive with an average size of about 200 nm. The magnetic property of ZnFe2O4 MNPs was investigated at 298 K using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). The magnetization hysteresis loops appeared S-like and the saturation magnetization was 65 emu·g−1. The variation of zeta potential of ZnFe2O4 MNPs with equilibrium pH was also measured. The obtained zeta potential value of ZnFe2O4 MNPs decreased with the increase of pH, and the isoelectrical point (IEP) was about 4.8. The value of zeta potential is 4.92 mV at pH 4.0, suggesting the surface of ZnFe2O4 MNPs has positive charge at the pH.

ZnFe2O4 Magnetic Nanoparticles (MNPs) were prepared using a hydrothermal method. The reagents used for the synthesis included ZnCl2 (0.34 g, 2.5 mmol) and FeCl3·6H2O (1.35 g, 5 mmol), which were dissolved in ethylene glycol (40 mL) to form a clear solution. This was followed by the addition of NaAc (3.6 g) and polyethylene glycol 20 000 (1.0 g). The mixture was stirred vigorously for 30 minutes.

After stirring, the mixture was sealed in a teflonlined stainless-steel autoclave with a 50 mL capacity. The autoclave was heated to and maintained at 200 °C for 8 hours and allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting black products were washed several times with ethanol and dried at 60 °C for 6 hours.

The as-prepared ZnFe2O4 MNPs were identified from the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with a suitable spinel structure. The magnetic property of ZnFe2O4 MNPs was investigated at 298 K using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM). The magnetization hysteresis loops appeared S-like and the saturation magnetization was 65 emu·g−1.

The variation of zeta potential of ZnFe2O4 MNPs with equilibrium pH was also measured. The obtained zeta potential value of ZnFe2O4 MNPs decreased with the increase of pH, and the isoelectrical point (IEP) was about 4.8. In the synthesis of NiCo2O4 MS, Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O (0.5 mmol) and Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O (1 mmol) were dissolved in ethylene glycol (100 mL) under magnetic stirring to get a transparent solution. The solution transferred into a round bottom flask was heated to 195 °C and held the temperature for 0.5 h in an oil bath. After the solution was cooled naturally to room temperature, the sample was collected and washed by centrifugation for several cycles using absolute ethanol and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C overnight. Then, the NiCo2O4 mesoporous spheres were obtained through calcining the precursor at 300 °C for 5 h with the heating rate of 1°C/min.

The characterization of the synthesized NiCo2O4 MS was carried out using various equipment. A TU-1900 double beams UV-vis spectrophotometer (Beijing Purkine General Instrument Co. LTD., China) was used to implement kinetic experiments and measure absorbance. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the NiCo2O4 MS were obtained using a Tecnai G2 F30 instrument. The surface morphology of NiCo2O4 MS was taken on a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM Hitachi S-4800, Japan). X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of NiCo2O4 MS was carried out with X’Pertpro Philips X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.154056). The chemical state of the coating surface of NiCo2O4 MS was analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PerkinElmer PHI-5702 multi-functional photoelectron spectrometer with Al Kα radiation of 1476.6 eV). ESR (Electron Spin Resonance) measurements were acquired using a JES-FA200 electron spin resonance spectrometer.

The synthesized CdCo2O4 nanosheets are then characterized using various techniques. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) are used to study the surface morphology of the nanosheets. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) analyses are observed to reveal the coexistence of elements Cd, Co, C, and O in the sample. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms are carried out to provide a more detailed characterization of the nanosheets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is measured to confirm the high thermal stability of the nanosheets.

The synthesis of CuWO4 nanoparticles (NPs) was achieved via a chemical precipitation reaction. In a typical experimental procedure, 2 mmol solutions of Cu(NO3)2 and Na2WO4 were prepared separately in 25 ml of distilled water with stirring. The Na2WO4 solution was then added dropwise into the Cu(NO3)2 solution with frequent stirring to form a cream green colored precipitate. 

After the completion of the precipitation reaction, the resultant product was transferred to a 100 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 175 ℃ for 24 hours. It was then allowed to cool to room temperature. The obtained precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed with deionized water and ethanol several times, and dried overnight. Finally, the samples were calcinated at 300⁰ C.

The surface morphology of the CuWO4 NPs was investigated using a Tescan VEGA3 scanning electron microscope (SEM) and Tecnai 20 G2 (FEI make) High-Resolution Transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM). The low and high-resolution SEM and HR-TEM images revealed spherical morphology for CuWO4 NPs with an average particle size of 66 nm. 

The HRTEM images also showed visible lattice fringes for CuWO4 NPs with interplanar spacing of 0.296nm, 0.210 nm, 0.186nm, 0.225nm, 0.251nm, 0.243nm, 0.171nm, 0.201nm, 0.155 nm and 0.579, which are in agreement with the interplanar spacing of the (111), (-121), (130) (210), (0-21), (002), (-130), (211), (300) and (010) facets of triclinic CuWO4 NPs. 

The dispersion of Copper, Tungsten, and Oxygen atoms in the catalyst was analyzed by STEM elemental mapping. The elemental mapping confirmed the presence of Cu, W and O atoms. In addition, the elemental mapping result also revealed the homogeneous existence of Cu, W and O species. 

To identify the crystal structure, phase, and lattice parameters, the synthesized CuWO4 NPs were subjected to X-Ray Diffraction analysis. The high crystallinity of the sample is evident from the strong intensity peaks. Moreover, the diffraction peaks are in agreement with the wolframite structure of the copper tungstate (Reference code: 01-073-1823) with space group of P1 (2). The lattice parameters of the synthesized CuWO4 NPs are a = 4.7026 Å, b = 5.8389 Å and c = 4.8784 Å with α= 91.6770°, β=92.4690° and γ=82.8050°.

The synthesis of Co2V2O7 particles, which could potentially be manipulated to create nanoparticles, is described in the experiment section of the article. The method used is a simple hydrothermal method inspired by the report of Yu et al. 

To prepare Co2V2O7 particles, NH4VO3 (1.0 mmol) was dissolved in deionized water (30 mL) and stirred at 75 oC to obtain a transparent solution. Following this, deionized water (30 mL) containing 1.0 mmol Co(NO3)2·6H2O was added dropwise to the above solution to form a final suspension. The solution pH was then adjusted to 7 by adding 2.0 M NaOH dropwise. 

The resulting suspension was transferred to a sealed autoclave, which was heated at 180 oC for 15 h. The product, which was brown-green in color, was collected by centrifugation, washed several times with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, and then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 oC for 24 h. As a control, other cobalt vanadate samples were obtained by adjusting the solution pH to 3 and 11.

The crystallographic information on the Co2V2O7 particles was obtained by X-ray diffraction (XRD), with the diffraction peaks in good agreement with the characteristic peaks of Co2V2O7 in the standard spectrum. Raman spectroscopy was also used to characterize the prepared materials. The bands at 905 and 845 cm1 were attributed to symmetric and asymmetric stretching of the VO4 units, respectively. Furthermore, the peaks located at 278 and 394 cm1, and 300, 552, and 598 cm1, were assigned to V–O and V–O–V stretching modes, respectively, indicating the successful preparation of Co2V2O7. 

The EDX spectrum of the prepared nanomaterial showed that it comprised 36.74% Co, 28.19% V, and 35.34% O by weight, with a V/O/Co atomic ratio of about 1:1:3.5, which matched well with the molecular formula Co2V2O7. 

However, the article does not provide specific details on how to manipulate the size of the particles to achieve a specific size such as 250 nm.

The synthesis of FeVO4 nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out through a facile hydrothermal method as described in the article. The specific procedure involved the use of 1.0 mmol of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and 1.0 mmol of NH4VO3. The Fe(NO3)3·9H2O was added into 30 mL of Milli-Q water under magnetic stirring. Meanwhile, the NH4VO3 was dissolved in 30 mL of Milli-Q water under magnetic stirring and 80 ◦C heating to obtain a transparent solution. The NH4VO3 solution was subsequently added dropwise into the Fe(NO3)3 solutions slowly under vigorous stirring to form a final suspension. 

The pH of the solution was then adjusted to 4.0 by adding 2.0 M NaOH. The suspension was stirred for another 30 min and then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, maintained at 180 ◦C for 16 h, and then cooled to room temperature naturally. The precipitates were collected and washed several times with Milli-Q water, then with absolute ethanol, followed by drying at 60 ◦C in air for 6 h. The final product was denoted as FeVO4-4 (4 stands for at pH 4.0). 

As a control, some other FeVO4 samples were obtained by adjusting the pH to 1.0, 7.0 and 10.0, which were denoted as FeVO4-1, FeVO4-7 and FeVO4-10, respectively. The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 2000 nm FeVO4 NPs. However, it can be inferred that the size of the nanoparticles can be influenced by the pH value during the preparation process, as different pH values resulted in FeVO4 samples with different morphologies and structures. 

The characterization of the as-prepared samples was performed using various techniques. The crystal structure of the as-prepared samples was recorded by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements on a Rigaku Ultima IV powder X-ray diffractometer. The structure and morphology of the as-prepared samples were observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi S-4800, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-1200, Japan). The chemical compositions of the as-prepared samples was recorded by FESEM equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of the as-prepared samples was carried out with an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer equipped with an Al-anode (ESCALAB 250, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA). The hysteresis loop of the as-prepared samples was recorded by the vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM, Lakeshore 7400, USA). The specific surface areas of the samples were measured based on Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation by an automatic nitrogen adsorption specific surface and pore size distribution analyzer (NOVA4000e, Quantachrome Ins., USA) at 77K after a pretreatment at 473K for 2 h.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 5000 nm CoMoO4 nanoparticles. The synthesis process described in the article is for CoMoO4 nanobelts (NBs), nanosheets (NSs), and three-dimension (3D) hierarchical microspheres (MPs), but not for nanoparticles of a specific size like 5000 nm.

The synthesis of CoMoO4 materials was performed using a hydrothermal method. Specifically, 1.0 mmol of CoCl2·6H2O and 1.0 mmol Na2MoO4·2H2O were dissolved in 30 mL Milli-Q water under vigorous stirring, respectively. Then Na2MoO4 solution was added dropwise into CoCl2 solution slowly under magnetic stirring to form a suspension, which was transferred into a 100-mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave afterwards. The autoclave was sealed, maintained at 160 °C for 16 h, and then cooled to room temperature naturally. The precipitates were collected by centrifugation, thoroughly washing repeatedly with Milli-Q water and ethanol several times, and drying at 60 °C in air for 6 h. Then, CoMoO4 nanobelts were obtained and denoted as CoMoO4 NBs.

Other CoMoO4 materials with different morphologies were prepared by changing “molybdenum” source and additional agent. Belt-like CoMoO4 materials (BLs) with larger size were obtained by a similar way as CoMoO4 NBs except for using 1.0 mmol (NH4)6Mo7O4·4H2O as “molybdenum” source instead of Na2MoO4·2H2O, which were denoted as CoMoO4 BLs. CoMoO4 nanosheets (NSs) were prepared by adding 1.0 mmol urea in the preparation process with other conditions same to CoMoO4 BLs, which were denoted as CoMoO4 NSs. CoMoO4 materials with the structure of three-dimension (3D) hierarchical microsphere (MPs) were obtained by using 5.0 mmol urea in the preparation process with other conditions same to CoMoO4 NSs, which were denoted as CoMoO4 MPs.

The crystal phase and structure of the CoMoO4 samples were analyzed by Rigaku Ultima IV powder X-ray diffractometer (Japan) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). The microstructure and morphology of the samples were observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM).

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 1500 nm AgVO3 nanoparticles. However, it does detail the process for synthesizing AgVO3 nanobelts, which are nanostructures with a variable size from 0.5 up to several μm in length and 100 nm in width. 

The AgVO3 nanobelts were synthesized via a simple hydrothermal method. Initially, 1 mmol of NH4VO3 was dissolved in an aqueous solution of 30 mL and then 0.5 g of PEG10000 was added under vigorous stirring condition at room temperature. Afterward, 30 mL of AgNO3 solution (0.067 M) was gradually added dropwise under vigorous stirring condition, followed by dropwise addition of ammonia with a final pH value of 7. After being stirred for 30 min, the solution was transferred into a 100 mL of Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed and maintained at 160 °C for 24 h. After that, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature naturally. The resulting yellow precipitate was separated by centrifugation and washed three times with water and ethanol respectively, dried at 60 °C for 4 h, and then collected for characterization and detection.

The reagents used in this process, including NH4VO3, AgNO3, ammonia, and PEG10000, were all of analytical reagent grade, and used as received without further purification. Milli-Q water was applied throughout the experiment.

The characterization of the synthesized AgVO3 nanobelts was done using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The XRD pattern of the samples was recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer using monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with 2θ ranging from 10 o to 80 o (40 kV, 40 mA). The SEM was used to characterize the morphologies of the synthesized samples. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were measured on a Hitachi JEM-2010 transmission electron microscope at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV.

Please note that while this method was used to synthesize AgVO3 nanobelts, it may not be directly applicable for the synthesis of 1500 nm AgVO3 nanoparticles. The size and shape of nanoparticles can be influenced by various factors including the concentration of the precursors, the reaction temperature, the reaction time, and the type of surfactants used. Therefore, further optimization and modification of the synthesis process may be required to obtain AgVO3 nanoparticles of a specific size.

The synthesis of CuMnO2 nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the experimental section of the article. The CuMnO2 NPs were prepared using a modified low temperature hydrothermal method. 

The chemicals and reagents used for the synthesis include Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O and Mn(NO3)2∙4H2O, which were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Reagent Co., Ltd and Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd respectively. NaOH was also used and was purchased from Alfa Aesar. Millipore water (18.2 MΩ) was used throughout the experiments.

In terms of the quantities used, 15 mmol Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O and 15 mmol Mn(NO3)2∙4H2O were dissolved in 70 mL deionized water at room temperature. Then 4.40 g NaOH was added to the above solution.

The preparation process involved stirring the mixture to obtain a homogeneous suspension. The solution was then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The reaction was kept at 80 ºC for 24 hours. The obtained reddish brown precipitate was washed with deionized water and absolute alcohol successively, and finally dried at 60 ºC for 24 hours.

The characterization of the synthesized samples was done using a variety of equipment. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern was recorded on a X-ray diffractometer (D/Max-IIIA, Rigaku) with Cu Ka radiation. The morphology, qualitative and semiquantitative element information of the synthesized samples were obtained using a Field-Emission Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss GeminiSEM 500) coupled with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscope (EDX, Bruker X-flesh 5060f). The thickness profile was acquired on a Bruker Multimode 8 atomic force microscope (AFM).

The article does not specify the exact size of the nanoparticles synthesized, but the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis shows the irregular flake-shape structures of CuMnO2 with diameters of 50-150 nm. The atomic force microscope (AFM) was also carried out to measure the topographic morphology of CuMnO2 nanoflakes, indicating that the thickness of CuMnO2 nanoflakes are mainly distributed between 1.5 and 1.7 nm.

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 7 nm Cu0.89Zn0.11O nanoparticles (NPs). It mentions that Zn-doped CuO NPs were obtained by a facile one-step sonochemical synthesis, but it does not provide the exact parameters, equipment, reagents, or mmols used in the synthesis process.

The characterization of the synthesized NPs was extensively described. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern for Zn-CuO and CuO was obtained using a Bruker D8 Advance X-107 ray diffractometer using Cu Kα (λ=1.5418 Å) as the source. XPS analysis was performed with Omicron 95 nanotechnology XPS system, (X-ray source: Al Kα, 1486.6 eV). DLS studies measurements were carried out on a Nano ZS Malvern Zeta sizer instrument. The morphological microstructure was characterized by JEM-1400, JEOL transmission electron microscopy (TEM) model, operated at 120 kV. The sample was prepared by dispersing Zn-CuO NPs in isopropyl alcohol, placing a drop of this suspension on a copper-coated grid and drying the grid in vacuum.

Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurements were carried out to determine the ratio of Cu:Zn in Zn-CuO (Cu0.89Zn0.11O). HR-TEM images were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2100 model operated at an accelerated voltage of 200 kV. HR-SEM measurements were conducted on Magellan 400L HRSEM (FEI, Hillsboro, OR, USA). The absorption studies and reaction kinetics were carried out using a CARY 103 bio-100 spectrophotometer. Fluorescence measurements of 2-hydroxyterephthalic acid were recorded by a Cary Eclipse fluorimeter.

The production of •OH radicals was determined by electron spin resonance (ESR) using a 121 Bruker EPR 100d X-band spectrometer with DMPO as a spin trap. To 80 µL of Zn-CuO (0.1 mg mL-1), 10 µL of DMPO (0.01 M) and 10 µL of H2O2 were added and drawn by a syringe into a gas-permeable Teflon capillary. The capillary was folded twice, inserted into a narrow quartz tube open at both ends, and then placed in the ESR cavity. The blank was measured by replacing H2O2 with deionized water.

In conclusion, while the article provides extensive details on the characterization of the synthesized Zn-CuO NPs, it does not provide specific details on the synthesis process itself.

The synthesis of (CeO2)0.10/CoO nanoparticles (NPs) is achieved through a two-step route composed of a one-pot solvothermal process and heat treatment. The process begins with the addition of Co(NO3)2 powder (1 mmol) into a homogeneous mixture containing glycerin and isopropanol (16 and 60 mL, respectively). This mixture is then vigorously stirred for 1 hour. 

Following this, Ce(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol) is added into the mixture and stirred for another 10 hours. The reaction system is then subjected to heat treatment for 6 hours under 180 °C. The precipitate is purified by washing with water and ethanol and then dehydrated overnight at 60 °C. 

In the next step, the precursor is roasted at 400 °C for 2 hours with protection of N2 flow. The final samples are named as nCeO2/CoO NCs. In addition to this, CeO2 and CoO NPs are also fabricated using the same method. 

It's important to note that the molar ratio of Ce3+/Co2+ salts is regulated during the solvothermal process to successfully synthesize the flower-like heterostructured 0.10CeO2/CoO NCs. The resulting 0.10CeO2/CoO catalyst exhibits high peroxidase-like activity under a pH of 5 and a wider temperature range of 26.5−43 °C. 

The article does not provide specific details on the equipment used in the synthesis process. However, typical equipment for such processes may include a solvothermal reactor, a stirrer, a heating device, and a washing setup.

The synthesis of (CeO2)0.10/CoO nanoparticles (NPs) is achieved through a two-step route involving a one-pot solvothermal process and heat treatment. The process begins with the addition of Co(NO3)2 powder (1 mmol) into a homogeneous mixture containing glycerin and isopropanol (16 and 60 mL, respectively). This mixture is then vigorously stirred for 1 hour. 

Following this, Ce(NO3)3 (0.10 mmol) is added into the mixture and stirred for an additional 10 hours. The reaction system is then subjected to heat treatment for 6 hours under 180 °C. The resulting precipitate is purified by washing with water and ethanol and then dehydrated overnight at 60 °C.

In the final step, the precursor is roasted at 400 °C for 2 hours with protection of N2 flow. The final samples are named 0.10CeO2/CoO NCs. In addition to this, CeO2 and CoO NPs are also fabricated using the same method.

It's important to note that the molar ratio of Ce3+/Co2+ salts is regulated during the solvothermal process to successfully synthesize the flower-like heterostructured 0.10CeO2/CoO NCs. The resulting NPs exhibit high peroxidase-like activity under a pH of 5 and a wider temperature range of 26.5−43 °C. 

The synthesized NPs also retain more than 80% of their initial catalytic activity after repeated use for 6 times or storing for 30 days, making them greatly promising for applications in medical diagnosis. Based on the remarkable performance of 0.10CeO2/CoO NCs, a sensitive and selective colorimetric sensing strategy was established for Cys detection. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of (CeO2)0.10/CoO NPs requires specific reagents, precise molar ratios, and controlled heat treatment processes. The resulting NPs exhibit high peroxidase-like activity and are suitable for use in various applications, including medical diagnosis and colorimetric sensing.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 1500 nm CoO/CeO2 nanoparticles. However, it does detail the synthesis of mesoporous 5%CoO/CeO2 with a pore size of approximately 14 nm. 

The synthesis process involves three steps. In the first step, the core-shell structured composite micelles of PEO-b-PS/inorganic sol were formed, containing hydrophobic PS blocks in the core and hydrophilic PEO segments with metal salt precursors in the shell. In the second step, the composite micelles packed into ordered fcc mesostructure with evaporation of solvent. In the third step, ordered mesoporous 5%CoO/CeO2 was formed by direct calcination in air at 350 ◦C to remove the template and promote framework crystallization.

The reagents used for the synthesis include PEO-b-PS, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, and Co(acac)2. Specifically, 0.05 g of PEO-b-PS was dissolved in 3.5 mL of THF, and 0.15 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 10.2 mg of Co(acac)2 were dissolved in 0.5 mL of absolute ethanol. The two solutions were mixed together under stirring for 1 h, and then the formed homogeneous solution was casted onto Petri dishes, which were held at 40 ◦C for 3 days to evaporate THF, and then heated at 100 ◦C for another 3 days. The solid inorganic-polymer composite was scratched from the plates and crushed into fine powders, which were finally calcined at 350 ◦C in air for 2 h to burn off PEO-b-PS template and promote framework crystallization, and the sample of mesoporous 5%CoO/CeO2 was obtained.

Next, a sufficient amount of ammonia solution is added to the mixture under vigorous stirring to adjust the pH to about 10. The precipitate product is then transferred to a 40-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept in an electric oven at 180 °C for 16 h. The autoclave is then taken out from the oven and left to cool to room temperature. The produced precipitate is collected via centrifugation, washed thoroughly with water and ethanol, and dried at 60 °C overnight.

The characterization of the prepared nanomaterials was done using SEM (MIRA3 TESCAN HV: 20.0 KV from Czech Republic) and TEM (EM 280, Tokyo, Japan). UV-vis detection was carried out on SPECTROD 250-analytikjena spectrophotometer (Germany).

The synthesis of Fe3O4@CeO2 nanoparticles (NCs) involves several steps and requires a variety of materials and reagents. 

Firstly, Fe3O4 hollow nanoparticles (NPs) are prepared through a modified solvothermal reaction. This process requires 0.8 g of FeCl3·6H2O and 2.0 g of NH4Ac, which are dissolved in 40 mL of ethylene glycol with vigorous stirring. Then, 1.0 mL of TMEDA is added. The mixture is stirred vigorously for 2 hours to form a homogeneous yellow solution, which is then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave with a 50 mL capacity. The autoclave is heated to 200 °C and maintained for 10 hours. After cooling to room temperature, the dark product is collected, rinsed with ethanol several times, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C overnight for further experiments.

Next, CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) are synthesized. This involves stirring 0.12 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 0.18 g PVP in 19 mL of deionized water until a colorless transparent solution is obtained. Then, 1 mL of DMF and 0.1 mL H2O2 are added. The obtained solution is transferred to a stainless-steel sealed autoclave with a 50 mL capacity and maintained at 180 °C for 20 hours. The grey product is collected by centrifuge and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C overnight.

Finally, the yolk–shell Fe3O4@CeO2 NCs are acquired using a one-pot coating process. 50 mg of Fe3O4 hollow NPs is dispersed in 80 mL of 0.4 mol/L glucose solution under ultrasonication for 30 minutes. Then, 0.4 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 0.6 g of urea are added to the above mixture. After 30 minutes of sonication, the homogeneous mixture is transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 8 hours. After cooling to room temperature, the dark precipitate is collected and washed with ethanol several times with magnetic separation. Finally, the as-prepared Fe3O4@CeO2 yolk–shell NCs are dried at 60 °C for 20 hours in a vacuum oven.

The synthesized Fe3O4@CeO2 NCs have a mean diameter of 630 nm. The size of the nanoparticles can be controlled by adjusting the parameters of the synthesis process, although the specific adjustments needed to achieve different sizes are not detailed in the article.

The synthesis of Ce-doped Fe3O4 nanoparticles (Ce-Fe3O4 NPs) was carried out via an electrochemical method. The deposition experiments were conducted in a two-electrode electrochemical cell containing a stainless-steel cathode and a graphite anode. The electrolyte used for the experiment was an aqueous solution in which 1 g of iron(II) chloride (FeCl2.4H2O, 99%), 2 g of iron(III) nitrate (Fe(NO3)2.9H2O, 99.95%), and 0.3 g of cerium chloride (CeCl3.7H2O, 99%) were dissolved in 1 L of water.

The cerium ferrite nanoparticles were prepared through direct current (DC) electrodeposition. The parameters for the electrodeposition were set at a current density of 20 mA cm-2, a temperature of 25 degrees Celsius, and a time duration of 30 minutes. After the deposition, the prepared powder was repeatedly rinsed with distilled water and centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 minutes.

Finally, the deposits were scraped from the substrate and evaluated by characterization analyses. The average crystallite size was calculated to be about 10.5 nm for the prepared nanoparticles using the Debye–Sherrer equation. The FE-SEM image of the prepared nanoparticles showed that the prepared sample is composed of spherical shape particles with a mean size of 15 nm. The results of elemental analyses of the electrosynthesized sample based on energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) revealed that the nanoparticles contain Fe, Ce, and O in the mass percentages of 53.34%w, 20.42 %w, and 26.24%w respectively. Based on the results, the sample was determined to be 20% Ce doped Fe3O4.

After cooling to room temperature, the precipitate is collected with a permanent magnet and washed with ethanol and deionized water. Finally, the products are freeze-dried.

The synthesis of Pt/WO2.72 nanoplates was carried out using a one-pot solvothermal method, with some modifications from a previous study. The precursors used for the reaction were WCl6 and H2PtCl6, which reacted with oleic acid and oleylamine in 1-octadecene.

Initially, 100 mg of WCl6, 5 mL of 1-octadecene (ODE), and 3 mL of oleylamine (OAm) were mixed to form a bright yellow solution. Then, 10 mL of ODE and 6 mL of oleic acid (OAc) were added into the mixed solution. Under magnetic stirring, 0.25 mmol of H2PtCl6 in ethanol was added into the above solution. After degassing under a gentle N2 flow at 70 °C for 30 min, the solution was heated up to 240 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min and maintained for 10 h.

After the solution was cooled to room temperature, the product was separated by centrifugation at 8000 rpm, followed by washing five times with ethanol. Finally, the product was redispersed in ethanol and stored for further use.

The morphologies of Pt/WO2.72 were examined using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi S-4800, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL 2000FX, Japan). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on an X’pert XRD spectrometer (PANalytical, The Netherlands) with Cu Kα radiation. UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a Lambda Bio/XLS+ UV–vis spectrophotometer (Perkin Elmer, USA). Fluorescence spectra were recorded on a fluorescence spectrophotometer (Hitachi F-7000, Japan). Raman spectra were recorded on a Raman microscope (LabRAM HR, HORIBA Scientific, France).

The reagents and materials used in the synthesis, including Tungsten(VI) chloride (WCl6, 97%), oleylamine (OAm, > 70%), oleic acid (OAc, technical grade, 90%), 1-octadecene (ODE, technical grade, 90%), and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30%) were purchased from Aladdin Reagent Company (Shanghai, China). H2PtCl4, Na2HPO4, NaH2PO4, ethanol (99%), and iron vitriol (FeSO4) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All solutions were prepared using deionized (DI) water (≥ 18 MΩ).

The synthesis of Ce-doped Fe3O4 nanoparticles (Ce-Fe3O4 NPs) was carried out via an electrochemical method. The deposition experiments were conducted in a two-electrode electrochemical cell containing a stainless-steel cathode and a graphite anode. The electrolyte used for the experiment was prepared by dissolving 1 g of iron(II) chloride (FeCl2.4H2O, 99%), 2 g of iron(III) nitrate (Fe(NO3)2.9H2O, 99.95%), and 0.3 g of cerium chloride (CeCl3.7H2O, 99%) in 1 L of aqueous solution.

The cerium ferrite nanoparticles were prepared through direct current (DC) electrodeposition. The parameters for the electrodeposition were set at a current density of 20 mA cm-2, a temperature of 25 degrees Celsius, and a time duration of 30 minutes. After the deposition, the prepared powder was repeatedly rinsed with distilled water and centrifuged at 3000 rpm for 10 minutes.

Finally, the deposits were scraped from the substrate and evaluated by characterization analyses. The average crystallite size was calculated to be about 10.5 nm for the prepared nanoparticles using the Debye–Sherrer equation. The FE-SEM image of the prepared nanoparticles showed that the prepared sample is composed of spherical shape particles with a mean size of 15 nm.

The results of elemental analyses of the electrosynthesized sample based on energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) revealed that the nanoparticles contain Fe, Ce, and O in the mass percentages of 53.34%w, 20.42 %w, and 26.24%w respectively. Based on the results, the sample was determined to be 20% Ce doped Fe3O4.

This spectrum contains the characteristic bands of nano-sized magnetite, which include two sharp bands at about 575 and 632 cm–1, due to the splitting of the ν1 band of the Fe—O and/or Ce-O, and a wide one at 439 cm–1 due to the ν2 band of the Fe—O and/or Ce-O bonds.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 246 nm Fe3O4 nanoparticles. However, it does describe the process of synthesizing Fe3O4 nanoparticles in general. 

In a typical experiment for the synthesis of Fe3O4 nanoparticles, the solution was prepared by dissolving 0.80 g of FeCl3·6H2O, 2.00 g of NH4Ac and 0.30 g of TBAB in 40 mL of ethylene glycol. The solution was constantly stirred for 30 min and transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (50 mL). Then, the autoclave was sealed and maintained at 200 °C for 10 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the resulting product was collected with a permanent magnet and washed with ethanol and deionized water several times. Finally, the products were freeze-dried.

The Fe3O4 nanoparticles were prepared using a hydrothermal process. TBAB was used as a capping agent for the stabilizer in the hydrothermal process. The presence of Fe3O4 nanoparticles in the preparation adjusted the nucleation and growth rates of MnO2. These crystallites aggregate into a complex structure leading to a perturbed and disorganized Fe3O4-MnO2 lattice rich in defects, dislocations and vacancies, which are active sites for the generation of OH· radicals.

The structure of Fe3O4 nanoparticles was analyzed by the X-ray diffraction (XRD). The diffraction peaks of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles at 2θ = 30.14°, 35.49°, 37.35°, 43.14°, 53.62°, 57.22° and 62.67° corresponded to (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511) and (440), respectively, which could be indexed to Fe3O4 with face-centered cubic structure.

The morphology of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles was observed by TEM. Fe3O4 nanoparticles are uniform spheres and the average diameter is about 350 nm. The Fe3O4 nanoparticles were measured to be reduced in size compared with the parental Fe3O4 nanoparticles. This supported the acidic etching process.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 2000 nm MnO2 nanoparticles. However, it does describe the synthesis of MnO2 microspheres, which may be similar in process. 

In a typical experiment for the synthesis of MnO2 microspheres, 0.68 g of MnSO4 and 0.92 g of (NH4)2S2O8 were dissolved in 40 mL of deionized water. This solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave with a capacity of 50 mL. The autoclave was maintained at a temperature of 120 °C for a duration of 2 hours. After the solution cooled down to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation. The collected precipitate was then washed with ethanol and deionized water several times. Finally, the products were freeze-dried.

The article does not provide specific information on the size of the MnO2 microspheres synthesized using this method. The size of nanoparticles can often be controlled by adjusting parameters such as the concentration of the reactants, the temperature, and the duration of the reaction. However, the article does not provide specific information on how to adjust these parameters to obtain MnO2 nanoparticles of a specific size.

The characterization of the synthesized MnO2 microspheres was performed using various techniques. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected using a Japan Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The morphology and composition were analyzed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JEOL JSM-6330F) at 10 kV and field emission transmission electron microscope (FETEM, FEI, Tecnai G20) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were carried out using a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. The specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods were applied to analyze the pore volume and average size. Magnetization measurements were performed by a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM, LAKESHORE-7304, USA) at room temperature.

Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurements were carried out to determine the ratio of Cu:Zn in Zn-CuO (Cu0.89Zn0.11O). HR-TEM images were obtained using a JEOL JEM-2100 model operated at an accelerated voltage of 200 kV. HR-SEM measurements were conducted on Magellan 400L HRSEM (FEI, Hillsboro, OR, USA). 

The TEM images show the aggregated morphology of Zn-CuO nanocrystals 5-10 nm long. A comparative TEM image of pure CuO is also shown. The rough surface of the aggregated crystals results in an increase in the surface area of the overall nanomaterial which plays a significant role in the enhancement of the enzymatic activity by facilitating the adsorption of the substrate molecules onto the surface.

However, the article does not provide specific details on the reagents, their quantities, or the exact process used in the synthesis of these nanoparticles.

The article describes the synthesis of GeO2 nanozymes, which are a type of nanoparticles, using a hydrothermal strategy. However, the specific size of the nanoparticles produced is not explicitly stated in the article. 

In the synthesis process, GeO2 and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution were used as the initial materials. Specifically, GeO2 (0.9 m) and NaOH solution (0.3 m) were added into 10 mL of water and stirred at 25 °C overnight. Then, 12 mL of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) solution (0.3 m) was poured into the mixed solution. After stirring for another 6 hours, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon bottle and heated at 100 °C for 56 hours.

Subsequently, the impurities were removed from the resulting product by washing with ultrapure water and alcohol, respectively. Finally, the as-prepared GeO2 nanozymes were obtained via vacuum drying at room temperature.

The morphology of the GeO2 nanozymes was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). Small-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded to further compare GeO2 nanomaterials and raw GeO2. The elementary composition and valence state of GeO2 nanozymes were studied using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).

It's important to note that while the article describes the synthesis of GeO2 nanozymes, it does not provide specific details on how to control the size of the nanoparticles to achieve a specific size such as 1000 nm. The size of the nanoparticles produced would likely depend on the specific conditions and parameters used during the synthesis process.

The synthesis of WO3 nanosheets, which range in size from 20 to 40 nm, is described in the article. The bulk WO3·2H2O was prepared by stirring the precursor at room temperature. Specifically, 400 mg Na2WO4·2H2O was dispersed in 300 mL nitric acid solution (4.8 mol L−1) and the mixture was stirred for 72 hours at 25 °C. A yellow solid gradually precipitated and was washed with water several times, and then dried at 50 °C in a vacuum oven.

To obtain the WO3 nanosheets, 50 mg of the bulk WO3·2H2O was dispersed in 50 mL of water and was treated ultrasonically for 24 hours. The dispersion was then centrifuged at 8000 rpm for 5 minutes, and the supernatant was collected for further use. The concentration of WO3 nanosheets was calculated to be 14.5 μg mL−1.

The characterization of the WO3 nanosheets was performed using various techniques. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image was collected with a Tecnai G2F20 (USA, FEI) transmission electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The thickness of WO3 nanosheets were collected by a 5500 atomic force microscope (AFM) (USA, Agilent). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrum was collected by an ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (USA, VG). X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was investigated by an Ultima IV diffractometer (Japan, Rigaku) equipped with Cu Kα radiation (40 kV, λ=1.5418 Å). Raman spectrum was collected by an inVia Raman spectroscope (UK, Renishaw). Dynamic light scattering (DLS) for particle size distribution and zeta potential was collected by a Nano-ZS90 zetasizer (UK, Malvern).

The article does not provide specific details on how to control the size of the WO3 nanoparticles to achieve a specific size such as 30 nm. The sizes of the WO3 nanosheets were ranged from 20 to 40 nm as shown in the TEM images.

The manuscript does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 1 nm WO2.92 nanoparticles (NPs). The synthesis process described in the manuscript is for WOx quantum dots (QDs), not specifically for WO2.92 NPs. 

The WOx QDs were synthesized by a simple and green hydrothermal process using WS2 as the precursor. In brief, 30 mg of commercial WS2 powder was dispersed in 200 mL water (65 °C). After ultrasonication for 17 h, the suspension was filtered using a 0.22 µm microporous membrane resulting in a silver gray filter cake. Then, the resulting filter cake was suspended in 30 mL water, and reacted at 200 °C for 12 h in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. After the solution cooled, the suspension was filtered by a 0.22 µm membrane to remove large stands of the products, yielding a colorless solution. The supernatant containing WOx QDs was obtained.

The transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of the WOx QDs were collected with JEM-2100 TEM instrument (JEOL, Japan). The energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDS) fitted to a TEM operating on a nanoprobe mode was used for elemental analysis. The fluorescence and the absorption spectra were recorded with an Eclipse spectrofluorometer (Varian) and Hitachi UV-2450 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan), respectively. Absorbance at 414 nm was monitored for quantitative analysis. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on ESCALAB 250XI electron spectrometer (Thermo, USA) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation for analysis of the surface composition and chemical states of the WOx QDs.

However, the manuscript does not provide specific details on the size of the synthesized WOx QDs or the specific composition of the QDs (i.e., whether they are WO2.92 or another composition of WOx). Therefore, it is not possible to provide a detailed synthesis process for 1 nm WO2.92 NPs based on the information provided in the manuscript.

The synthesis of W18O49 nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the article. The materials used for the synthesis include Tungsten (VI) ethoxide (W(C2H5O)6) from J&K Scientific Ltd, 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine·2H2O (TMB) from Sangon Biotech, methylene blue·3H2O (MB), 1,4-dicarboxybenzene (TA), hydrogen peroxide (30 wt%), isopropanol, and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, BeiJing Co., Ltd. All the reagents were analysis grade and were used as received without further purification.

The synthesis of W18O49 NPs was carried out according to a previous report (Guo et al. 2012). W(C2H5O)6 was first dissolved in 50 mL of alcohol to form a 7.5 mM solution. Then, the solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 200 °C for 24 hours. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the products were collected by centrifugation and washed repeatedly with water and ethanol, followed by vacuum drying at 60 °C overnight.

The phase compositions of samples were determined by Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns and were recorded on a Rigaku Miniflex II diffractometer using CuKα radiation. The nanocompositions were also determined by Raman shift (Renishaw inVia Raman Microscopy). The size and shape of samples were observed by high transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) (FEI TECNAI G2F20, 200 kV) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FSEM) (Nova NanoSEM 230, 15 kV). The surface charge of W18O49 NPs was examined by zeta-potential measurement using Nanosizer (Malvern Instruments Ltd., Nano-ZS90). N2-sorption isotherms were obtained using ASAP2020 surface area analyzer (TriStar II PLUS 3020, Micromeritics Instrument Corporation). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were performed using a Thermo Scientific-ESCALAB 250XI spectroscopy with aluminum Kɑ radiation. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were obtained on ELEXSYS-II E500 EPR spectrometer.

The article does not specify the exact size of the synthesized W18O49 NPs, but the described method can potentially be adjusted to control the size of the nanoparticles.

The materials required for the synthesis include Tungsten (VI) ethoxide (W(C2H5O)6) from J&K Scientific Ltd, 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine·2H2O (TMB) from Sangon Biotech, methylene blue·3H2O (MB), 1,4-dicarboxybenzene (TA), hydrogen peroxide (30 wt%), isopropanol, and ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent, BeiJing Co., Ltd. All these reagents were of analysis grade and were used as received without further purification.

The synthesis of W18O49 NPs was carried out according to a previous report (Guo et al. 2012). W(C2H5O)6 was first dissolved in 50 mL of alcohol to form a 7.5 mM solution. This solution was then transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 200 °C for 24 hours. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the products were collected by centrifugation and washed repeatedly with water and ethanol. This was followed by vacuum drying at 60 °C overnight.

The characterization of the synthesized NPs was done using various equipment. The phase compositions of samples were determined by Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns recorded on a Rigaku Miniflex II diffractometer using CuKα radiation. The nanocompositions were also determined by Raman shift using Renishaw inVia Raman Microscopy. The size and shape of samples were observed by high transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) (FEI TECNAI G2F20, 200 kV) and field emission scanning electron microscopy (FSEM) (Nova NanoSEM 230, 15 kV). The surface charge of W18O49 NPs was examined by zeta-potential measurement using Nanosizer (Malvern Instruments Ltd., Nano-ZS90). N2-sorption isotherms were obtained using ASAP2020 surface area analyzer (TriStar II PLUS 3020, Micromeritics Instrument Corporation). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were performed using a Thermo Scientific-ESCALAB 250XI spectroscopy with aluminum Kɑ radiation. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were obtained on ELEXSYS-II E500 EPR spectrometer. The catalytic oxidation of TMB and degradation of MB were recorded with a UV-Vis spectrophotometer (UV-2450). Photoluminescence measurements were carried out using a fluorescence spectrophotometer (970CRT).

The article does not specify the exact size of the synthesized W18O49 NPs, nor does it provide specific parameters for synthesizing NPs of a particular size. However, the described method and materials can be used as a basis for further experimentation and optimization to achieve the desired NP size.

The synthesis of gold nanoparticles (GNPs) of different sizes, including 14 nm, was achieved by the citrate reduction method as previously described in the article. The colloidal solutions of 14, 25, 48, and 99 nm diameter GNPs were synthesized using this method. 

The process involved adding 1 mL of 1% HAuCl4 solution (gold chloride tetrahydrate) into 97 mL of ultrapure water and heating it to boiling. Then, 2 mL of 1% trisodium Citrate solution was quickly added to the reaction system, keeping it boiling for 15 minutes. The different sizes of GNPs were obtained by adjusting the proportion of sodium citrate and HAuCl4 in the reaction system. 

For the synthesis of 14 nm GNPs, the volume of 1% HAuCl4 was 1 and the volume of 1% trisodium citrate was 5. For other sizes, the volumes were adjusted accordingly. For instance, for 25 nm GNPs, the volume of 1% HAuCl4 was 1 and the volume of 1% trisodium citrate was 1.5. For 48 nm GNPs, both volumes were 1, and for 99 nm GNPs, the volume of 1% HAuCl4 was 1 and the volume of 1% trisodium citrate was 0.42. 

The Au concentrations were all unified to 47.8 µg·mL−1. The characterization of the synthesized GNPs was done using UV-vis absorption spectra obtained with a Shimadzu UV-3600 spectrophotometer and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis performed on a JEM-2000EX microscope. 

It's important to note that all the reagents used were of analytical grade and ultrapure water obtained from a Millipore Milli-Q water purification system was used throughout the experiments.

The synthesis of a-Fe2O3 nanostructures, including 110 nm nanoparticles, is described in the experimental section of the article. The materials and methods used for the synthesis of these nanomaterials are detailed.

All chemicals used for the synthesis of nanomaterials and enzyme kinetic assay such as iron chloride (FeCl36H2O), urea ((NH2)2CO), caffeine, citric acid, sodium hydrogen phosphate (Na2HPO4) and DMSO (dimethyl sulfoxide) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without any further purification. A stable, chromogenic and non-carcinogenic horse radish peroxidase (HRP) substrate, TMB (3,30,5,50-tetramethyl benzidene), was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) from Samchun Pure Chemicals, South Korea.

The synthesis of a-Fe2O3 nanostructures was carried out using aqueous routes. To begin with, a-Fe2O3 nanorods were synthesized through hydrolysis of iron chloride (FeCl36H2O) by a hydrothermal method with slight modification in the earlier synthesis route. In a typical synthesis procedure, 0.02 M iron chloride solution was prepared in preheated deionized water at 90 1C. After a certain period of time, varying concentrations of HCl were added, which is a key factor in controlling size, leading to the formation of different sized b-FeOOH nanorods. The respective flasks were magnetically stirred at 90 1C for 24 h, culminating into yellow coloured mixtures. Thus obtained yellow coloured mixtures are indicative of the formation of b-FeOOH nanorods and were cooled to room temperature, centrifuged, washed repeatedly with deionized water and ethanol and then dried overnight at 80 1C in an oven.

The as-synthesized b-FeOOH nanorods were then used as a precursor for various uniform a-Fe2O3 nanorods. The b-FeOOH rods were slowly heated at the rate of 2 1C min1 upto 250 1C and maintained for 2 h under static conditions. This procedure transforms the precursors to brown coloured hematite a-Fe2O3 rods. During the transformation, apparent shape and size of the b-FeOOH were maintained in the resulting a-Fe2O3 nanorods. The resultant rods with different lengths were the outcome of different HCl concentrations used during the synthesis procedure and are labelled R-1, R-2, and R-3 according to their length.

In addition, cube-like a-Fe2O3 particles were synthesized using 0.06 mol of iron chloride (FeCl36H2O) and 0.03 mol of caffeine instead of hydrochloric acid or urea in aqueous solution. The flask was magnetically stirred for 24 h at 90 1C. The mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, and the resultant brown product, also indicative of formation of hematite, was isolated through centrifugation with successive washings by deionized water and ethanol and dried at 80 1C overnight.

The as-synthesized a-Fe2O3 nanostructures were characterized by using various analytical techniques. The microscopic features of the samples were elucidated with a transmission electron microscope (TEM, EM 912 Omega) operated at 120 kV and a scanning electron microscope (SEM) (SEM, LEO 1455VP, Hitachi S-4700) operated at an acceleration voltage of 25 kV. X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were obtained with a Rigaku 1200 diffractometer with CuKa radiation using a Ni b-filter at a scan rate of 41 min1. The X-ray source was operated at 40 kV and 30 mA.
