The article describes the synthesis and modification of Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) of different sizes, including 300 nm. The Fe3O4 MNPs were prepared according to the solvothermal method and the co-precipitation method. However, the article does not provide specific details about the solvothermal method used for the synthesis of 300 nm Fe3O4 MNPs.

For the modification of Fe3O4 MNPs, the article provides a detailed procedure. For silica coating and amino modification of Fe3O4 MNPs, 26 mg Fe3O4 nanoparticles were mixed with 20 ml 2-propanol and 40 ml ethanol. Then, 0.5 ml deionized water and 1.5 ml ammonia solution (25% by wt) were consecutively added to the reaction mixture. Under continuous mechanical stirring, APTES and TEOS (tetraethoxysilane) with different ratios (0 or 1:4, total 400 ml) were added into the reaction solutions. The reactions were allowed to proceed at room temperature for 8 hours.

After the coating reaction, the core–shell nanostructures were separated from the reaction medium by centrifuging at 3,000 r.p.m., and dispersed into ethanol. The separation procedure was performed several times. To confirm the reproducibility of the findings, Fe3O4 MNPs were produced in two independent labs, and the behaviour of the MNPs from the two sources was found to be consistent.

In terms of equipment, the article mentions the use of a mechanical stirrer for the reaction mixture, a centrifuge for separating the core-shell nanostructures from the reaction medium, and a spectrophotometer for monitoring the reactions. The article does not provide specific details about the equipment used for the synthesis of the Fe3O4 MNPs.

The synthesis of Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) of approximately 150 nm, 300 nm, and 30 nm in size was performed using the solvothermal method and the co-precipitation method. The size distribution of these MNPs has been characterized previously. For the synthesis of Fe3O4 MNPs with dextran, the same procedure was followed but with the addition of dextran.

For the silica coating and amino modification of Fe3O4 MNPs, 26 mg of Fe3O4 nanoparticles were mixed with 20 ml of 2-propanol and 40 ml of ethanol. Then, 0.5 ml of deionized water and 1.5 ml of ammonia solution (25% by weight) were consecutively added to the reaction mixture. Under continuous mechanical stirring, APTES and TEOS (tetraethoxysilane) with different ratios (0 or 1:4, total 400 ml) were added into the reaction solutions. The reactions were allowed to proceed at room temperature for 8 hours.

After the coating reaction, the core–shell nanostructures were separated from the reaction medium by centrifuging at 3,000 r.p.m., and dispersed into ethanol. The separation procedure was performed several times. To confirm the reproducibility of the findings, Fe3O4 MNPs were produced in two independent labs, and the behaviour of the MNPs from the two sources was found to be consistent.

Before coupling with the antibody, the dextran-modified Fe3O4 MNPs were activated by incubation with NaIO4 (2 mg ml-1) at 37 °C for 20 minutes, washed three times with 0.2 mol l-1 NaAc, pH 4.4, and suspended in 0.1 mol l-1 NaHCO3, pH 9.6. The Fe3O4 MNPs were then incubated with 100 mg ml-1 anti-TnI antibody at 4 °C overnight. NaBH4 was added to a final concentration of 2 mg ml-1 to stop the coupling reaction. After washing with PBS three times, the antibody-coupled Fe3O4 MNPs were stored at 4 °C for the capture–detection immunoassay.

The synthesis of Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) was performed by following the procedure reported by Racuciu et al. with slight modifications. The reagents used for the synthesis included 3.6 gm FeCl3 .6H2O and 1.8 gm FeSO4 .7H2O salts, which were dissolved in 80 mL MilliQ water. At 80 0C, nitrogen gas was purged into the mixture and 20 mL of NH4OH was added slowly (the solution turns black). The temperature of 80 oC was maintained for further 30 min with continuous N2 bubbling.

After this, an external magnet was used to pellet down the NPs and the supernatant was discarded. The washing step was carried out for 4 to 5 times with boiled MilliQ water to remove excess ammonia. To the pellet solution (~30 mL), 2.5 gm of citric acid was mixed and stirred at 90 oC for 2 h. After cooling down to room temperature, Fe3O4 NPs were dialyzed for 24 h in MilliQ water using a 12 KDa dialysis membrane (water was changed every 8 hours). 

After dialysis, the NPs were washed by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 10 min to remove the remnants. In the final step, the Fe3O4 NPs solution was centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 6 min and the supernatant was collected.

The particle size of the synthesized Fe3O4 NPs was measured using a Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) equipped with 20-120 kV (JEM1400 plus, JEOL). Phase identification of Fe3O4 NPs was analysed over the 2θ range from 20 – 900 using X-ray diffraction (XRD) system (Bruker AXS, D8 Discover). The concentration of Fe3O4 NPs for zeta potential measurement was 1 mg/mL in PBS. Further the zeta potential studies of NPs were followed in presence of ATP and ascorbic acid (AA) at pH 7.4. For dispersion, this suspension was gently vortexed for 20 sec and zeta potential was determined using Dynamic Light Scattering (Zetasizer Nano-ZS, ZEN3600) Malvern instruments Ltd. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR) spectra was measured in the range of 500 – 4000 cm-1 using Spectrum Two FT-IR Spectrometer, L160000A, PerkinElmer.

The article does not specify the size of the synthesized Fe3O4 NPs, but the procedure described can be used to synthesize Fe3O4 NPs of various sizes by adjusting the parameters of the synthesis process.

After cooling down to room temperature, Fe3O4 NPs were dialyzed for 24 h in MilliQ water using a 12 KDa dialysis membrane (water was changed every 8 hours). 

After dialysis, NPs were washed by centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for 10 min to remove the remnants. In the final step, the Fe3O4 NPs solution was centrifuged at 4000 rpm for 6 min and the supernatant was collected.

The particle size was measured using a Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) equipped with 20-120 kV (JEM1400 plus, JEOL). Phase identification of Fe3O4 NPs was analysed over the 2θ range from 20 – 900 using X-ray diffraction (XRD) system (Bruker AXS, D8 Discover). The concentration of Fe3O4 NPs for zeta potential measurement was 1 mg/mL in PBS. Further the zeta potential studies of NPs were followed in presence of ATP and ascorbic acid (AA) at pH 7.4. For dispersion, this suspension was gently vortexed for 20 sec and zeta potential was determined using Dynamic Light Scattering (Zetasizer Nano-ZS, ZEN3600) Malvern instruments Ltd. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectrometer (FTIR) spectra was measured in the range of 500 – 4000 cm-1 using Spectrum Two FT-IR Spectrometer, L160000A, PerkinElmer.

The article does not specify the size of the synthesized Fe3O4 NPs, but the described procedure can be used to synthesize Fe3O4 NPs of various sizes by adjusting the reaction conditions and parameters.

The article describes the synthesis of nickel oxide nano-flowers (NiO NFs), not nanoparticles (NPs). The synthesis of NiO NFs involves two main steps: the formation of β-Ni(OH)2 NFs and their subsequent calcination to produce NiO NFs.

In the typical synthesis of β-nickel hydroxide nano-flowers (Ni(OH)2 NFs), 0.8 mL of ethanol amine is added to 4.2 mL of 0.1 M nickel acetate (Ni(OAc)2) solution in a screw-capped test tube of 25 mL capacity to form a blue colored nickel–ethanol amine complex. The resulting blue colored solution is sealed in the screw-capped test tube and subjected to overnight (12 h) heating under modified hydrothermal (MHT) conditions at 110 °C. After a specific time of 12 h, a uniform greenish-white thin film on the glass slide is deposited and the solid film is recovered by decanting the clear supernatant solution. The thin film is then washed several times with water and dried in an air oven for 1 h at 60 °C.

To obtain gray-black nickel oxide nano-flowers (NiO NFs), the greenish-white precursor is annealed at 350 °C for 4 h under ambient conditions in a tube furnace. The morphology of the light-green colored β-Ni(OH)2 NFs was examined using different microscopic techniques. The architectures have an average diameter of 3–5 mm and consist of interconnected, smooth surfaced wavy plates of 15 nm thickness. The morphology of Ni(OH)2 resembles a flower structure.

The morphological analyses were performed with the calcined product of β-Ni(OH)2 NFs, i.e. NiO NFs. The size of the walnuts almost remains the same, but the interplate spacing is different, which has already been mentioned. This increased spacing increases the porous nature of the material, NiO NFs. From the FESEM images, the highly porous nature of the NiO NFs can be observed.

The porous nature of β-Ni(OH)2 NFs and calcined product NiO NFs are evident from FESEM and TEM analyses. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm measurements were studied to investigate their surface porosity. The calculated Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas are 50.363 and 113.707 m2 g−1 for β-Ni(OH)2 and NiO NFs, respectively. The Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method is used for measurement of pore diameter distribution of β-Ni(OH)2 and NiO NFs. The pore size for β-Ni(OH)2 NFs is 3.1 nm, which has been increased to 3.8 nm for NiO NFs.

The article describes the synthesis of nickel oxide nano-flowers (NiO NFs), not nanoparticles (NPs). The synthesis of NiO NFs involves two main steps: the formation of β-Ni(OH)2 NFs and their subsequent calcination to produce NiO NFs.

In the first step, β-Ni(OH)2 NFs are synthesized hydrothermally. Specifically, 0.8 mL of ethanol amine is added to 4.2 mL of a 0.1 M nickel acetate (Ni(OAc)2) solution in a 25 mL capacity screw-capped test tube to form a blue-colored nickel–ethanol amine complex. A glass slide is submerged in this solution, which is then sealed in the test tube and subjected to modified hydrothermal conditions at 110 °C for 12 hours. After this period, a uniform greenish-white thin film forms on the glass slide. This film is recovered by decanting the clear supernatant solution, washing it several times with water, and drying it in an air oven for 1 hour at 60 °C.

In the second step, the greenish-white precursor is calcined to produce gray-black NiO NFs. This involves annealing the precursor at 350 °C for 4 hours under ambient conditions in a tube furnace. The resulting NiO NFs have a flower-like structure, with interconnected, smooth-surfaced wavy plates of 15 nm thickness.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of NiO nanoparticles (NPs) of 15 nm or any other size. The described process specifically produces NiO in a nano-flower (NF) structure, not in a nanoparticle (NP) form. Therefore, a different method would likely be needed to synthesize NiO NPs.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 4800 nm Co3O4/CeO2 nanoparticles. However, it does detail the preparation of Co3O4-CeO2 nanocomposites, which have an average size of approximately 6 nm. 

The Co3O4-CeO2 nanocomposites were prepared by a wet-chemical deposition precipitation method. Initially, 0.02 g of Cobalt(II) chloride hexahydrate (Co(Cl)2.6H2O) were dissolved in 10 mL of distilled water. Subsequently, 0.01 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) and urea were added to the solution under vigorous stirring. Then 100 µL of NH3 (Wt %: 25-28 %) was added to the reaction solution. After stirring for 15 min, 10 ml of 4.6 mM cerium nitrate aqueous solution was mixed with the prepared solution. 

Next, a sufficient amount of ammonia solution was added to the mixture under vigorous stirring to adjust the pH to about 10. The precipitate product was then transferred to a 40-mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept in an electric oven at 180 °C for 16 h. The autoclave was then taken out from the oven and left to cool to room temperature. The produced precipitate was collected via centrifugation, washed thoroughly with water and ethanol, and dried at 60 °C overnight. The pure Co3O4 and CeO2 was synthesized with the same procedure.

The characterization of the prepared nanomaterials was done using SEM (MIRA3 TESCAN HV: 20.0 KV from Czech Republic) and TEM (EM 280, Tokyo, Japan). XRD patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a copper source and a general area detector diffraction system (GADDS). UV-vis detection was carried out on SPECTROD 250-analytikjena spectrophotometer (Germany).

The mimic peroxidase properties of Co3O4-CeO2 were tested by dispersing Co3O4-CeO2 (3 mg) in PBS buffer (0.1 M, pH 6.0) in the presence of 200 μL TMB (0.8 mM) and H2O2 (1.2 mM) with a total volume of 1.0 ml. After the mixed solution was processed at 30 oC for 10 min, the photographs and UV spectra of the mixtures were taken. 

Please note that the synthesis process described above results in nanoparticles with an average size of approximately 6 nm. The article does not provide information on how to adjust this process to produce larger nanoparticles of 4800 nm.

The synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out through a hydrothermal method. The reagents used for the synthesis included cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2•6H2O) and hexamethylene tetramine (HMTA), both used in a quantity of 0.1 mmol. These were dissolved in 16 ml of dimethyl fumarate (DMF) under magnetic stirring for 15 minutes.

The mixture was then transferred into a 21 ml Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave. This autoclave was sealed and heated at 140 ºC for 14 hours, and then air-cooled to room temperature. The black precipitate that formed was collected by centrifugation, washed twice with ethanol and once with water, and then diluted into 1 ml with water for further use.

The phase structure of the synthesized Co3O4 NPs was characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5418 Å). The samples for XRD analysis were prepared by dropping 10 μl Co3O4 suspensions on a 0.5 cm× 0.5 cm silicon wafer and dried under 60 ºC, until an evident film formed by repeating this operation couple times.

The morphology of the Co3O4 NPs was observed by Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) using a FEI TECNAI G2 F20 U-TWIN transmission electron microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The samples for TEM analysis were prepared by adding 8μl Co3O4 suspensions (diluted by 10 times) onto standard holey carbon-coated copper grids, which were then air dried at room temperature. The average diameter of the Co3O4 NPs was found to be 8.3 ± 0.7 nm, as determined from measurement of 70 particles.

The synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) of around 31 nm size, as described in the article, involves a process that combines electrospinning with calcination. The materials used for the synthesis include polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, Mw = 1,300,000), ethanol, Co(NO3)26H2O, and deionized water. The exact amount of Co(NO3)26H2O used can affect the size of the nanoparticles, with the article mentioning that 0.115 g, 0.23 g, and 0.45 g were used in different experiments.

In the typical synthesis of the sol, 1.0 g of PVP is dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol with magnetic stirring. Once the PVP is completely dissolved, an aqueous solution prepared by dissolving 0.45 g of Co(NO3)26H2O in 2 mL of deionized water is added. After the mixture becomes homogeneous, it is transferred to a needle tube with an inner diameter of 0.5 mm. The electrospinning voltage is set at 20 kV and the receiving distance between the needle and collector is 20 cm, while the pumping speed is 0.002 mm/s.

After the electrospinning process, the mat-like fiber is collected and heated at 80 °C overnight. Finally, the dried gel fiber is heated to 300 °C in a tube furnace with a heating rate of 1°C/min and kept at 300 °C for 1 h. Then it is heated to 400°C with a heating rate of 0.5 °C/min, and kept at that temperature for 2 h.

The morphology of the products is characterized using SEM and TEM. The electrospun gel fibers present a belt-like morphology with a width of ca. 4.9±1.5 μm and thickness of 0.6±02 μm. After calcination at 400 °C for 2h, the belt-like morphology is retained while the width of the belt reduces to 1.9±0.6 μm. The belts are composed of nanoparticles and some pores are observed. The HR-TEM image shows continuous parallel lattice fringes and the lattice spacings are ca. 0.24 nm and 0.29 nm, which are consistent with the {311} and {220} interplanar spacings of Co3O4.

The amount of cobalt nitrate in the precursor sol can affect the size of the nanoparticles. As the amount of cobalt nitrate increased from 0.115 g to 0.23g and 0.45 g, the grain sizes of the calcined samples, denoted as F1, F2, and F3, were calculated to be 31.1± 1.1 nm, 48.1 ± 1.9 nm and 26.9 ± 1.1 nm respectively according to the Scherrer equation.

The process involves electrospinning with a voltage of 20 kV, a receiving distance of 20 cm, and a pumping speed of 0.002 mm/s, followed by heating and calcination. The size of the NPs can be controlled by varying the amount of cobalt nitrate used in the precursor sol.

The synthesis of sisal-like architectures of cobalt hydroxide carbonate precursors, which can be transformed to Co3O4 nanoparticles, was first synthesized through a simple hydrothermal method with cobalt nitrate as cobalt source and urea as a precipitating agent. The sisal-like architectures of cobalt hydroxide carbonate precursors can be transformed to Co3O4 by calcination without destroying the structures. 

In a typical synthesis, 0.44 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.18 g of CO(NH2)2 were dissolved into deionized water under magnetic stirring to form a transparent solution. The solution then was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated to 160 °C and maintained at that temperature for 6 h. Subsequently, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature naturally. After that, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation, washed with deionized water and ethanol three times, and dried at 70 °C for 12 h in air to obtain the precursors. The final product was obtained by calcining the precursor to 400 °C for 1 h in the muffle furnace in air with a heating rate of 1 °C/min.

The crystal structure of the product was determined on an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku D/Max 2200 PC) with a graphite monochromator and Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). The morphology of the product was determined using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) (Toshiba, Model S4800) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEM, Model 1011). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a SDT Model Q600 thermogravimetric analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under an air atmosphere. The ultraviolet−visible (UV−vis) absorption spectra were tested using a Model Lambda 35 type UV-vis spectrometer (Perkin−Elmer).

The sisal-like cobalt hydroxide carbonate precursors were synthesized as described and analyzed with SEM and XRD. As shown in Figure 1a, the precursor exhibits sisal-like morphology with the size of ca. 10 μm, and the microstructures are accumulated by nanorods. The diameter of the nanorod is ca. 125 nm from TEM image (Figure 2). 

In conclusion, the synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles involves a hydrothermal method using cobalt nitrate and urea, followed by calcination. The process also requires various equipment for stirring, heating, and analysis, including a stainless steel autoclave, muffle furnace, X-ray diffractometer, scanning electron microscope, transmission electron microscope, thermogravimetric analyzer, and UV-vis spectrometer.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 68 nm Co3O4 nanoparticles. However, it does describe the preparation of porous Co3O4 nanoplates. 

In a typical procedure, 1 g Pluronic F127 and 0.25 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O were respectively dissolved in 50 mL deionized water. Then, the mixture solution was stirred and heated to 80 °C by a water bath. Subsequently, 0.75 mL ammonia solution was added into the above solution. The whole mixture was stirred at 80 °C for another 1 h. The product was collected by centrifugation at 5000 rpm and washed thoroughly with deionized water several times. After drying at 60 °C, the obtained product named Co(OH)2-F was calcined at 450 °C for 2 h under air with a heating rate of 2°C min-1 to form the porous Co3O4 nanoplates (Co3O4-F).

According to the above method, Co(OH)2-P and Co3O4-P were synthesized by replacing Pluronic F127 with P123. In the case of Co(OH)2 and Co3O4, a similar procedure was applied except for adding any soft template.

The apparatus used for the experiment included a Cary 500 UV-Vis-NIR spectrometer (Varian) for UV/Vis absorption measurements, a PHILIPS XL-30 field-emission scanning electron microscope for SEM experiments, a JEM￾2100F high-resolution transmission electron microscope for TEM measurements, and a D8 ADVANCE (Bruker, Germany) X-ray diffractometer for obtaining X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns.

The chemicals used in the experiment, including Pluronic® F127, Pluronic® P123, 3, 3', 5, 5'-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) and glucose oxidase (GOx, from Aspergillus niger, 50 KU, 128.2 KU g-1), were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Ammonia solution (NH3, 25%), Co(NO3)2·6H2O, glucose, fructose, maltose, lactose and sucrose were obtained from Beijing Chemical Reagent Company (Beijing, China). All the chemicals were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Ultrapure water (≥18.2 MΩ cm) was used throughout the study.

The synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) was achieved using a one-step green strategy based on a solution-phase method at room temperature. This method is template-free and surfactant-free. The reagents used in the synthesis include a freshly prepared NaBH4 solution (10 mM) and a clear purple CoCl2 solution (2 mM). The NaBH4 solution was dropwise added into the CoCl2 solution under gentle stirring and further incubation at room temperature overnight.

Upon the addition of the reducing agent NaBH4, the CoCl2 solution rapidly turned grey and produced bubbles, probably due to the reduction of Co2+ to Co and the generation of H2. Subsequently, the grey suspension quickly became black because the newly generated Co was very unstable and could be spontaneously oxidized to CoO swiftly by the dissolved oxygen. Further, some of the black CoO was slowly oxidized to Co2O3 by oxygen, to form Co3O4, indicated by the gradual appearance of a yellowish-brown suspension during continuous stirring at 25 °C for 12 h.

The morphology of the as-synthesized nanostructure was examined by SEM and TEM, which revealed a hierarchical flower-like sphere. The nanospheres were composed of sheets ranging from several nanometers to a dozen nanometers. The formation mechanism of nanoflowers may be because the initial Co3O4 nanosheets have higher surface energy and tend to reduce surface energy during growth, so the nanosheets will further aggregate into spheres. Finally, a graded nanoflower sphere composed of nanosheets is stably formed. The size of Co3O4 nanoflowers is 360 ± 20 nm, indicating that the synthetic method is controllable and reproducible.

The XRD patterns of the synthesized sample can be indexed to the Co2+Co3+2O4. XPS spectrum was employed to confirm the valence states of the sample. The XPS survey spectrum of the sample indicated the co-existence of Co and O in the sample. For Co 2p, four fitted peaks can be observed centered at 780.4 eV, 782.0 eV, 795.8 eV and 797.5 eV, related to Co3+ 2p3/2, Co2+ 2p3/2, Co3+ 2p1/2 and Co2+ 2p1/2, respectively. The O 1s high resolution spectrum region displays three peaks locating at 530.1 eV (for surface lattice oxygen), 531.2 eV (for oxygen vacancies).

In conclusion, the synthesis of Co3O4 NPs involves a one-step green strategy at room temperature using NaBH4 and CoCl2 solutions, with the resultant NPs exhibiting a hierarchical flower-like sphere morphology and a size of 360 ± 20 nm. The synthesized NPs were characterized using SEM, TEM, XRD, and XPS techniques.

The synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) involves a two-step process, which includes the formation of Co(OH)2 nanoflowers and the generation of Co3O4 nanoflowers via annealing treatment of the Co(OH)2 nanoflowers. 

In a typical synthesis, CoCl2$6H2O (analytical pure, AR, 2 mmol) was added into 20 ml of deionized water with stirring for 10 min to generate solution A. Meanwhile, L-arginine (C6H14N4O2, >99% purity, 10 mmol) was dissolved into 20 ml deionized water with stirring for 10 min to generate solution B. Solution B was then added dropwise into solution A with stirring for 30 min. This mixture was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave, heated at a designated temperature (such as 120 C, or 150 C, or 180 C) and maintained at that temperature for a designated time (such as 10 h, or 5 h, or 15 h). After the autoclave cooled down to room temperature naturally, the pink sediment Co(OH)2 was collected and washed with deionized water and then absolute alcohol three times, followed by drying at 80 C for 3 h. The black Co3O4 powder was then obtained after heat treating the pink Co(OH)2 powder at 300 C for 1 h.

The reaction between CoCl2$6H2O and L-arginine [H2N–C(¼NH)–NH–(CH2)3–CH–(COOH)NH2], which is basic with a pK ¼ 12.5,14 is shown in eqn (2):
CoCl2 + H2N–C(¼NH)–NH–(CH2)3–CH–(COOH)NH2 + 2H2O / Co(OH)2 + 2[H2N–C(¼NH)–NH–(CH2)3–CH (COOH)–NH3 + ]Cl− (2) And the Co3O4 was obtained after annealing of Co(OH)2, as shown in eqn (3):15 6Co(OH)2 + O2 / 2Co3O4 + 6H2O (3)

The Co(OH)2 nanoflowers undergo a three-stage growth process, similar to the nucleation–growth–assembly (N–G–A) mechanism. The first stage of Co(OH)2 nanoflowers formation is the nucleation process, that is, the initial reaction between Co2+ and L-arginine [C6H14N4O2, HN2–C(¼NH)–NHCH2CH2CH (COO−)–NH3 + ] ions is too fast to generate the Co(OH)2 nuclei. The second stage of Co(OH)2 nanoflowers formation is the oriented growth to form Co(OH)2 nanoplates with a lateral thickness of 30 nm. The third stage of Co(OH)2 nanoflowers formation is the self-assembly of nanoplates via hydrogen bonding aggregation, leading to the generation of the hierarchical structure – gillyflower-like Co(OH)2 superstructures.

The synthesis of CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the provided text. The synthetic protocol for preparing CeO2 NPs is provided in ESS 1.1. The cerium precursor used for the synthesis is Cerous chloride heptahydrate (CeCl3⋅7H2O, purity 98.5%), which was purchased from Loba chemicals. The synthesis also involves the use of Liquid Ammonia (NH4OH, purity 99%) acquired from Fisher Scientific. 

The morphology of the synthesized CeO2 NPs was observed using Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM; JSM-7600F, JEOL) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM; Technai G2 F30 model 300kV, FEI). The phase identification and structure information was acquired from X-ray diffractometer (Ultima IV, Rigaku) with CuKα radiation (λ = 0.1542 nm) analysed over the Bragg’s angle from 20° to 80°. 

The TEM and FE-SEM images examined for ~50 nanorods using ImageJ [23]. Log normal function to length histogram reveals mean length (x) of 197±13.4 nm and 214.85±6.4 from TEM and FE-SEM images, respectively. 

The synthesis of CeO2 NPs was realized via co-precipitation using CeCl3·7H2O. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns confirms crystalline nature and corresponds to (111) plane in agreement with XRD results. The nanorods grow through Ostwald ripening process. In this work, Cl￾in cerium precursor salt favours nanorod formation which accords to Wu et. al. observations [25]. Employing PIS (precipitant into precursor salt) approach at high pH (~10.5) owed to low Ce(OH)3 solubility (Ksp) expedite nano rod nuclei formation, later at high temperature (60ºC) Ostwald ripening contribute to formation of CeO2 nanorods. 

However, the text does not provide specific details on the exact quantities of the reagents used in mmols for the synthesis of the CeO2 NPs.

The synthesis of CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the provided text. The synthetic protocol for preparing CeO2 NPs is provided in ESS 1.1. The TEM and FE-SEM images examined for ~50 nanorods using ImageJ revealed a mean length of 197±13.4 nm and 214.85±6.4 from TEM and FE-SEM images, respectively. 

The CeO2 NPs were synthesized using an aqueous route with Cerous chloride heptahydrate (CeCl3⋅7H2O, purity 98.5%) as the precursor. The process involved co-precipitation, which was realized with CeCl3·7H2O. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns confirmed the crystalline nature of the NPs. The nanorods were found to grow through the Ostwald ripening process, which involves the continual consumption of smaller particles forming larger crystals. 

The role of counter anions in controlling the size and morphology of CeO2 NPs was also noted. In this work, Cl- in the cerium precursor salt was found to favor nanorod formation. The PIS (precipitant into precursor salt) approach was employed at high pH (~10.5) due to the low solubility of Ce(OH)3, which expedited the formation of nano rod nuclei. Later, at high temperature (60ºC), Ostwald ripening contributed to the formation of CeO2 nanorods.

The equipment used for the characterization of the NPs included a Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM; JSM-7600F, JEOL) and a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM; Technai G2 F30 model 300kV, FEI). Phase identification and structure information were acquired from an X-ray diffractometer (Ultima IV, Rigaku) with CuKα radiation (λ = 0.1542 nm) analyzed over the Bragg’s angle from 20° to 80°. 

It should be noted that the observations made in this work are not inclusive to all co-precipitation reactions for CeO2 NPs. However, they do reveal the significant role of precursor salt, temperature, and pH in tailoring the size and morphology of CeO2 NPs.

The synthesis of CeO2 nanostructures, including nanocubes and nanorods, is described in the article. However, the article does not specify the synthesis of 32 nm CeO2 nanoparticles. 

For the synthesis of CeO2 nanostructures, 20mL of Ce(NO3) 3·6H2O solution (0.1mol/L) was added dropwise into NaOH solution (0.1mol/L for nanocubes and 12mol/L for nanorods). The mixed solution was then transferred and sealed in a 50mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, with subsequent heating for 24h. The heating temperature was kept at 140 °C for nanocubes and 100 °C for nanorods. After the reaction, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation (9000 rpm, 5min) and washed alternately with ethanol and deionized water several times, and then dried at 60 °C in the air.

The phase structure of the samples was identified by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418Å). NIST SRM™ 640e was used to obtain the instrumental broadening profile. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a spectrometer (Axis Ultra DLD-600W, Kratos Analytical Ltd.) using Al Kα radiation as the excitation source. The morphologies of the samples were observed using high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100F STEM/EDS, JEOL Corp, Japan). The Raman spectra of the samples were recorded by a Raman spectrometer with a 325nm laser excitation (VERTEX 70, Bruker, Germany). The UV-Vis spectra of the samples were recorded with an ultraviolet–visible spectrometer (Shimadzu Corp., UV-2550 PC).

The peroxidase mimetic activity of CeO2 was evaluated by monitoring the redox reaction between TMB and H2O2 in the presence of the CeO2 nanostructures. Typically, 1mL acetate buffer solution (50mM, pH=4.0) containing 25μg CeO2, 0.5μmol TMB, and 1mol H2O2 was added in a cuvette. The reaction was monitored using an ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy (Shimadzu Corp., UV-2550 PC) at a wavelength of 652 nm. The measurement was recorded at an interval of one minute and the temperature was kept at 25 °C. 

All the non-linear curve fittings (XRD, XPS and Michaelis-Menten Kinetic) were processed using software Fityk (version 1.3.0). All the experiments were repeated at least triplicated to obtain the standard deviation.

After the reaction, the precipitate was collected by centrifugation (9000 rpm, 5min) and washed alternately with ethanol and deionized water several times, and then dried at 60 °C in the air.

The phase structure of the samples was identified by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418Å). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on a spectrometer (Axis Ultra DLD-600W, Kratos Analytical Ltd.) using Al Kα radiation as the excitation source. The UV-Vis spectra of the samples were recorded with an ultraviolet–visible spectrometer (Shimadzu Corp., UV-2550 PC).

The peroxidase mimetic activity of CeO2 was evaluated by monitoring the redox reaction between TMB and H2O2 in the presence of the CeO2 nanostructures. The reaction was monitored using an ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy (Shimadzu Corp., UV-2550 PC) at wavelength of 652 nm. The measurement was recorded at an interval of one minute and the temperature was kept at 25 °C. In order to obtain the apparent kinetic parameters, experiments varying concentrations of the substrates were carried out. The measurement was recorded at an interval of 10 seconds in order to obtain a higher accuracy. All the rest reaction conditions were unchanged. More details on the calculation of apparent kinetic parameters can be found in the Supplementary Information. The SOD mimetic activity of CeO2 nanostructures was determined with colorimetric assay kits (Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, China).

The synthesis of CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the provided text. The hydrothermal temperature and time played important roles in the CeO2 NPs synthesis, which were demonstrated to optimize experiments. The synthesis conditions were optimized through adjusting the reaction temperature from 120 to 180 C at intervals of 20 C and the reaction time from 12 to 24 h at intervals of 4 h, respectively. 

The XRD patterns of the samples prepared under the different reaction conditions were analyzed. The surface residue is gradually eliminated as the temperature increases, and the CeO2 NPs were obtained under 180 C. The XRD patterns of samples under the same reaction temperature (180 C) and the reaction time varied (12 h and 24 h), the diffraction peaks observed show a good match with CeO2 (JCPDS 81-0792). 

The prepared CeO2 NPs has a cubic, fluorite-type structure and high purity. The average diameters of the four CeO2 samples prepared under the 180 C, evaluated by means of the Scherrer formula,32 are about 16, 15, 20, 12 nm for the CeO2 NPs obtained from the reaction times of 12 h, 16 h, 20 h, 24 h, respectively. This suggests that the CeO2 NPs with the smallest size obtained under reaction condition at 180 C for 24 h. 

The CeO2 NPs obtained under different hydrothermal reaction conditions were also investigated through FT-IR spectra. The adsorption bands of sample (120 C, 24 h) were similar to the spectrum of propane diacid, which could not be decomposed completely below 180 C. In the FT-IR spectra, the Ce–O stretching band around 400 cm1 confirms the formation of CeO2 when the reaction temperature reaches up to 180 C. 

The surface of the as-prepared CeO2 NPs is negatively charged due to nitrate groups which were encircling by positive proton forming double electrical layer in redispersion. To further confirm this, the TG was used to identify the chemical species on surfaces of the prepared CeO2 NPs. The TG profile exhibits slight weight loss stages in the temperature range between 35 and 900 C. The first stage of weight loss below 150 C was assigned to desorption of the adsorbed water, and the decomposition of nitrate group species caused the weight loss between 300 and 400 C, as suggested by the FT-IR outcomes. 

The UV-vis spectroscopy of CeO2 suspension was also used to verify their well redispersed properties. According to Beer’s law, absorbance at the characteristic peak was in a linear relationship with concentration when a homogeneous solution was formed. A good linear relationship (R ¼ 0.9995) exists between the absorbance at 304 nm and the concentration of CeO2 NPs redispersion. 

The morphology of the obtained CeO2 NPs under the optimal reaction conditions was examined by transmission electron microscope (TEM). The crystallite size is distributed in a narrow range between 8 and 14 nm, which is in good agreement with the results of XRD analysis. The electron diffraction rings, together with the data cited from the JCPDS card show the (111), (200), (220) and (311) diffraction rings, confirming the nanocrystallinity and the fluorite structure. 

The Ce 3d electron core level XPS spectrum for as-prepared CeO2 NPs are shown. The XPS spectrum from cerium is complex and splits into Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2 with multiple shake-up and shake-down satellites. The peaks between 875 and 895 eV belong to the Ce 3d5/2 while peaks between 895 and 910 eV correspond to the Ce 3d3/2 levels. These results are consistent with previously published results of CeO2 NPs. Higher intensity peaks corresponding to Ce4+ were observed in sample, indicating a higher Ce4+/Ce3+ ratio. XPS analysis reveals that a slight reduced surface of the CeO2 NPs could be obtained by simple hydrothermal synthesis at the optimal reaction condition.

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 17 nm CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs). However, it does describe the preparation of CeO2-MMT nanocomposites and CeO2 NPs in general. 

The preparation of CeO2-MMT nanocomposites begins with dissolving 0.5 g MMT in 30 mL distilled water under vigorous stirring for 18 hours to form a homogeneous suspension. Then, 0.217 g (approximately 0.5 mM) Ce(NO3)3·6H2O solution, which serves as a precursor providing Ce3+ cation, is added dropwise into the solution under continuous stirring for another 2 hours. Following this, 2 mL hydrogen peroxide (30%) is cautiously added into the obtained solution. After stirring the solution for one more hour, the mixture is sealed in a polytetrafluoroethylene-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 150 degrees Celsius for 6 hours. The solution is then naturally cooled to room temperature, separated by centrifugation, and washed with deionized water three times. Finally, the products are collected and dried under atmospheric conditions at 60 degrees Celsius for 10 hours. The CeO2-MMT nanocomposites are then obtained and used in the following experiments.

For comparative investigation, CeO2 NPs and CeO2-MMT hybrids are also prepared. The preparation of CeO2 NPs is similar to that of the CeO2-MMT nanocomposites, but without the presence of MMT. The CeO2-MMT hybrids are prepared by mixing MMT with CeO2 NPs in distilled water under vigorous stirring for 3 hours.

The article does not provide specific details on the size of the CeO2 NPs produced in these experiments. However, it does mention that the CeO2 nanoparticles decorated on the layers of MMT in the CeO2-MMT composites have a mean size of approximately 10-25 nm. The pure CeO2 NPs without MMT are prone to aggregation due to the absence of a support. The aggregated CeO2 NPs have a relatively better physical dispersity on the layers of MMT when MMT is used as the support under continuous stirring for a relatively long time at room temperature. These dispersed CeO2 nanoparticles on layers of MMT are named as the CeO2-MMT nanohybrids.

The article does not provide specific instructions for synthesizing 17 nm CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs). However, it does describe the general process of preparing CeO2 NPs and CeO2-MMT nanocomposites. 

Firstly, 0.5 g MMT was dissolved in 30 mL distilled water under vigorous stirring for 18 hours to form a homogeneous suspension. After that, 0.217 g (ca. 0.5 mM) Ce(NO3)3·6H2O solution as a precursor serving Ce3+ cation was dropwise added into the above solution under continuously stirring for another 2 hours. Then, 2 mL hydrogen peroxide (30%) was cautiously dropwise added into the obtained solution. After the solution being stirred for one more hour, the mixture was sealed in a polytetrafluoroethylene-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 150°C for 6 hours. Subsequently, the solution was naturally cooled to room temperature, separated by centrifugation and washed with deionized water for three times. Finally, the products were collected and dried under atmospheric condition at 60°C for 10 hours. The CeO2-MMT nanocomposites were obtained and used in the following experiments.

For comparative investigation, the preparation of CeO2 NPs was similar to that of the CeO2-MMT nanocomposites in the absence of MMT. The CeO2-MMT hybrids were prepared by mixing MMT with CeO2 NPs in the distilled water under vigorous stirring for 3 hours.

The microstructure and morphology of the CeO2-MMT composites, the pure CeO2 NPs and hybrid materials were imaged by TEM. From the images, it can be seen that the CeO2 nanoparticles with the mean size of ca. 10-25 nm were well decorated on the layers of MMT. However, the pure CeO2 NPs without MMT were easy to aggregate, due to the absence of a support. 

The article does not provide specific details on how to control the size of the CeO2 NPs to 17 nm. The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 100 nm CeO2 nanoparticles. However, it does describe the preparation of CeO2 nanorods and H2TCPP–CeO2 nanocomposites.

CeO2 nanorods were prepared according to a previous report. In a typical procedure, Ce(NO3)3 (8 ml, 0.05 M) was added rapidly to H2O2 (8 ml, 30.0%) solution and stirred for ca. 10 min. The suspension was transferred into a 25 ml Teflon-lined autoclave, which was heated at 250 °C for 3 h. The system was then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The final product was washed with deionized water, and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Then CeO2 nanorods were obtained.

Subsequently, the CeO2 nanorods was dissolved into 5 mM H2TCPP solution (pH = 8) was treated to an ultrasonic water bath for 1.5 h. The sample (H2TCPP–CeO2) was washed with NaOH solution (pH = 8) and dried at room temperature in air. The target product was successfully obtained and studied in the subsequent experiment.

The morphology and size distribution of the nanorods were imaged by transmission electron microscope (TEM JEM-2100, JEOL, Japan). The crystal structures of the products were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (D/Max2500PC, Rigaku, Japan). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were taken in KBr pressed pellets on a NICOLET 380 FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet Thermo, USA). UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a MAPADA UV-3200PC spectrophotometer (Shanghai, China). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a PHI Quantera SXM spectrometer with an Al Kα = 280.00 eV excitation source, and binding energies were calibrated by referencing the C1s peak (284.5 eV) to reduce the sample charge effect.

The CeO2 nanorods were prepared using a hydrothermal method. Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) was rapidly added to a hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) solution and stirred for approximately 10 minutes. The suspension was then transferred into a 25 ml Teflon-lined autoclave, which was heated at 250 °C for 3 hours. The system was then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The final product was washed with deionized water, and dried at 60 °C for 12 hours to obtain the CeO2 nanorods.

The H2TCPP–CeO2 nanocomposites were prepared by dissolving the CeO2 nanorods into a 5 mM H2TCPP solution (pH = 8) and treating it in an ultrasonic water bath for 1.5 hours. The sample was then washed with a NaOH solution (pH = 8) and dried at room temperature in air to obtain the target product.

The morphology and size distribution of the nanorods were imaged by a transmission electron microscope (TEM JEM-2100, JEOL, Japan). The crystal structures of the products were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (D/Max2500PC, Rigaku, Japan). The synthesis of CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) of approximately 54 nm in size is described in the article. The materials and reagents used for the synthesis include Cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, 99.99%, Sigma-Aldrich), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30%), polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP, (C6H9NO)n), N,N- dimethylformamide (DMF, C3H7NO), and deionized water. All reagents used in this study were of analytic grade and used without any further treatment.

The synthesis process is as follows: 0.12 g of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 0.18 g PVP were stirred in 19 mL of deionized water until a colorless transparent solution was obtained. Then 1 mL of DMF and 0.1 mL H2O2 were added. The obtained solution was transferred to a stainless-steel sealed autoclave (50 mL capacity) and maintained at 180 °C for 20 h. The grey product was collected by centrifuge and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C overnight.

The instruments used for characterization of the nanoparticles include Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI, Tecnai G20) for observing the morphology of the samples, X-ray diffraction (XRD, Germany Bruker D8 advance X-Ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation) for examining the crystal structure, Fourier transfer infrared (FT-IR) spectra for obtaining the samples, and a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer for performing N2 adsorption-desorption experiments and estimating the surface area.

The TEM images revealed that the mean size of the CeO2 NPs was about 54 nm. The XRD patterns of the CeO2 NPs were checked at 28.5°(111), 33.0°(200), 47.4°(220), 56.3°(311), 76.6°(331), 78.9°(420) and 88.3°(422), being well consistent with the database (JCPDS card no. 34-0394), demonstrating that the CeO2 NPs were formed in the coating process. The FT-IR exhibited the band at 490 cm−1 in the sample of CeO2 NPs, assigned to the stretching vibration of Ce–O–Ce. The BET surface area of the CeO2 NPs was 14.5 m2/g.

The synthesis of Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) with a diameter of approximately 590 nm is described in the article. The Fe3O4 hollow NPs were prepared through a modified solvothermal reaction. 

The reagents used for the synthesis included 0.8 g of iron(III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O) and 2.0 g of ammonium acetate (NH4Ac). These were dissolved in 40 mL of ethylene glycol with vigorous stirring. Then, 1.0 mL of N,N,N,N-tetramethylethylenediamine (TMEDA) was added to the mixture. The mixture was stirred vigorously for 2 hours to form a homogeneous yellow solution.

This solution was then transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave with a 50 mL capacity. The autoclave was heated to 200 °C and maintained at this temperature for 10 hours. After cooling to room temperature, the dark product was collected and rinsed with ethanol several times. The product was then dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C overnight for further experiments.

The resulting Fe3O4 NPs showed a regular spherical shape with an average diameter of 590 nm. An obvious hollow structure was observed in the Fe3O4 NPs, which was further identified by high magnified transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images.

In summary, the synthesis of Fe3O4 NPs involves a solvothermal reaction using iron(III) chloride hexahydrate, ammonium acetate, ethylene glycol, and N,N,N,N-tetramethylethylenediamine. The reaction takes place in a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave at 200 °C for 10 hours. The resulting product is then collected, rinsed with ethanol, and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C overnight.

The synthesis of cerium oxide nanoparticles (CeO2 NPs) of different sizes, including 6 nm, was achieved using the solution combustion method. This method involved varying the concentration of the oxidizer (cerium nitrate hexahydrate) and fuel (glycine). 

The specific materials used for the synthesis included cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce (NO3)3. 6H2O, Himedia) and glycine (H2NCH2CO2H, Fisher Scientific). The process began with a 100 mL aqueous solution of cerium nitrate (1 M) and glycine (0.6 M). 

The X-ray diffraction pattern of the synthesized cerium oxide nanoparticles was obtained using different fuel-oxidizer ratios (Φ = 0.6 and 1.1). The peaks obtained for CNP-6 were found to be broader in comparison to CNP-12. The mean crystallite size and lattice strain were estimated using the Williamson-Hall equation. 

When the fuel-oxidizer ratio increased, the adiabatic flame temperature in the combustion process also increased. As a result, a mean crystallite size of 6 nm and 12 nm was obtained at a low fuel ratio (Φ = 0.6) and high fuel ratio (Φ = 1.1), respectively. 

The scanning electron micrograph of the as-prepared cerium oxide nanoparticles (CNP-6 and CNP-12) was obtained, showing the presence of agglomerated, porous cerium oxide structure. The porous structure in the combustion method arose from the liberation of large amounts of gases like nitrogen and carbon dioxide. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of cerium oxide nanoparticles of different sizes, including 6 nm, was achieved by varying the concentration of the oxidizer and fuel in the solution combustion method. The size of the nanoparticles was controlled by adjusting the fuel-oxidizer ratio, with a lower ratio resulting in smaller nanoparticles. The synthesized nanoparticles were characterized using X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscopy.

The synthesis of water-soluble cupric oxide nanoparticles (CuO NPs) of approximately 6 nm in size was achieved via a quick-precipitation method. The reagents used for this process were cupric acetate, sodium hydroxide, and glacial acetic acid. 

Initially, 150 ml of 0.02 M copper acetate aqueous solution was mixed with 0.5 ml glacial acetic acid in a round-bottomed flask equipped with a refluxing device. The solution was heated to boiling with vigorous stirring. Then, 10 ml of 0.04 g ml-1 NaOH aqueous solution was rapidly added into the above boiling solution, where a large amount of black precipitate was immediately formed. 

The precipitate was then centrifuged, washed three times with absolute ethanol, and dried in air at room temperature. The morphology and size distribution of the nanoparticles were studied by using a transmission electron microscope (TEM) of Tacnai-12 (Philip, Netherlands). The crystal phase was investigated by X’Pert Pro MPD X-ray diffractometer (Panalytical, Netherlands). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were taken in KBr pressed pellets on an AVATR 330 FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet Thermo, USA).

The average size of the CuO nanoparticles was estimated from the diffraction peak (200/111) by using the Scherer formula as about 6 nm. The TEM image reveals that the product consists of spherical particles with a regular morphology and a significantly narrow size distribution. The average particle diameter is found to be approximately 6.3 ± 0.7 nm, which is in good agreement with that estimated by the Scherer formula from an XRD result.

The FTIR spectrum of the as-prepared CuO nanoparticles presented high frequency modes at about 585, 535, and 480 cm-1 which can be assigned to the vibrations of Cu(II)–O. The frequency mode due to Cu2O at about 610 cm-1 is not seen, which further proves that the as-prepared nanoparticles comprise of a purely CuO phase, without any trace of Cu2O being present. 

The UV-vis absorption spectrum was used in order to resolve the excitonic or interband transitions of the CuO nanoparticles. The absorption peak of the CuO nanoparticles dispersed in distilled water is at about 280 nm. The band gap of the as-prepared CuO nanoparticles is estimated to be 3.11 eV from the UV-vis absorption spectrum, which is larger than the reported value for bulk CuO (Eg = 1.85 eV). The increased band gap is attributed to the quantum size effects for semiconductors when the particles become comparable to the de Broglie wavelength of a charge carrier.

The synthesis of porous CuO micro-/nanostructures was carried out using a precursor route previously reported by the group. The chemicals used in the experiment were of analytical reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. The chemicals included 3,3',5,5'-Tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, copper nitrate, urea, hydrogen peroxide, sodium acetate, and acetic acid, all of which were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Deionized water was also used in the experiment.

In the synthesis process, 2.3 g of Cu(NO3)2•3H2O and 1.7 g of CO(NH2)2 were orderly dissolved into 25 mL of distilled water. The obtained mixture was then vigorously stirred for 30 min and then sealed into a 30 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated to 180 ℃ and maintained at that temperature for 5 h. The as-formed precipitate, Cu2(OH)2CO3 precursor, was separated by centrifugation, washed with distilled water and ethanol for several times, and dried in vacuum. Control experiment shows that the Cu2(OH)2CO3 precursor can be obtained with reaction time of 5－12 h. 

Porous CuO micro-/nanostructures were obtained by further calcining the precursor in air at 450 ℃ for 4 h. The morphology and size of the product were examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, H-4800) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL-2100). UV-vis spectra were obtained on a UV-3000 spectrophotometer. The electron spin resonance (ESR) measurement was performed on an EMX-10/12 electron-spin resonance spectrometer. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the CuO sample was tested using an ASAP 2010 sorption analyzer.

The article does not specify the exact size of the nanoparticles synthesized, but it mentions that the porous structural feature with pores size of 20－30 nm was observed in the SEM and TEM images of the obtained CuO sample. The BET investigation of the CuO product provides a surface area of about 18 m2/g, with main pore size of about 20 nm and pore volume of 0.13 cm3/g. This is consistent with the TEM observation. The surface area is quite larger than that of commercial CuO powder (ca. 0.1 m2/g).

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 500 nm MnO2 nanoparticles (NPs). However, it does describe the synthesis of MnO2 nanowires (NWs) using genetically engineered M13 filamentous phages as biotemplates. 

The genetically engineered M13 filamentous phages were prepared according to previous work. Briefly, tetraglutamine (-EEEE) and tetraarginine (-RRRR) were respectively displayed on the N-terminus of the pVIII protein on M13 (producing so-called M13-E4 and M13-R4). Then, the engineered M13 was amplified by superinfection of helper phage M13KO7 and purified facilely with PEG/NaCl.

To prepare one-dimensional MnO2 NWs, the genetically engineered M13 filamentous phages were used as biotemplates. After incubation of M13 with Mn2+, MnO2 crystals were generated on phage scaffolds by the spontaneous oxidation of Mn2+ in alkaline solution at room temperature. MnO2 nanocrystals were uniformly mineralized along the length of the phage and the mineralized phages remained the filamentous morphology with the diameter of 30−60 nm. The proposed synthesis strategy is green, facile, and efficient. The nanostructure of MnO2 NWs can be manipulated by controlling the reaction conditions. However, the nucleation and growth of MnO2 at 4 °C resulted in the assembly of discrete NPs on the phage scaffolds, suggesting the significance of synthesis temperature.

The chemicals and materials used in the synthesis include M13KO7 helper, polyethylene glycol (PEG), manganese acetate (MnAc2), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30%), and glucose. These were purchased from various suppliers. All other reagents were of the analytical grade and all aqueous solutions were prepared with Milli-Q water (18.2 MΩ cm).

The article does not provide specific details on the quantities (mmols) of the reagents used in the synthesis of MnO2 NPs or NWs.

The synthesis of MnO2 NFs (nanoflakes) was achieved through a BSA-directed synthesis method. In this process, MnO2 crystals were nucleated and formed by the wet-chemistry method, where Mn2+ was spontaneously oxidized into MnO2 crystals in the alkaline solution in air and BSA served as the skeleton of nucleation and the stabilizer of MnO2 crystals. 

To obtain 2D morphology, the concentration of manganese ion was adjusted. When the concentration of manganese ion was moderate (2 × 10−3 m), the MnO2 NFs with small size (about 50 nm) and thin thickness were obtained. The atomic force microscope (AFM) image of MnO2 NFs illustrated that the thickness of MnO2 NFs was about 3 nm. 

The influence of BSA dosage on morphology was also studied. With the increase of the dosage of BSA (from 0.1 to 1 mg), the lateral dimension of NFs decreased from above 200 nm to about 50 nm. For the excessive dosage of BSA, no MnO2 precipitates formed and only transparent solution was obtained. Meanwhile, the irregular flocculent morphology appeared, probably because the excessive dosage of BSA provided superabundant nucleation sites and restricted the aggregation of MnO2 crystals. 

To confirm the formation of MnO2, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data of typical products were recorded. By deconvolution of Mn 2p peaks, the peaks were fitted into one 2p 1/2 peak at 653.9 eV and two 2p 3/2 peaks at 643.4 and 642.2 eV, which accorded well with XPS patterns of MnO2 and testified that MnO2 was the only existing form of the manganese in NFs. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of MnO2 NFs was achieved through a BSA-directed synthesis method, with the concentration of manganese ion and the dosage of BSA being key factors in controlling the size and morphology of the resulting NFs. The formation of MnO2 was confirmed through XPS analysis.

The synthesis process involved the chemical precipitation of MnO2 crystals in an alkaline solution containing BSA. Subsequently, the pH value of the mixture solution was adjusted to about 10 with NaOH solutions. After reaction for 7 h, the products were centrifuged, washed with water, dried, and stored at 4 °C.

With the increase of the dosage of BSA (from 0.1 to 1 mg), the lateral dimension of NFs decreased from above 200 nm to about 50 nm. For the excessive dosage of BSA, no MnO2 precipitates formed and only transparent solution was obtained.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 2000 nm V2O5 nanoparticles. However, it does detail the synthesis of V2O5 nanowires, which are a type of nanoparticle. 

The V2O5 nanowires were prepared using a hydrothermal method. For the synthesis of V2O5 nanowires, the water-soluble vanadium (IV) oxosulfate (VOSO4) was oxidized with potassium bromate (KBrO3) by stirring for 30 min at room temperature. After lowering the pH using nitric acid, the reaction was kept at 180 °C for 24 hours. After cooling to room temperature and extensive washing, the dark-yellow precipitate was dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight and analyzed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD).

The powder XRD pattern of the V2O5 nanowires shows the presence of orthorhombic V2O5 (Shcherbianite, PDF–003–0207). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images showed freshly synthesized V2O5 nanowires to have a variable size from 500 nm up to several μm in length and 100 nm in width. A high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image of such a crystalline nanowire with lattice fringes of 0.516 nm corresponding to orthorhombic V2O5 was also presented. The fast Fourier transform (FFT) indicates single-crystalline behavior. Complementary analytical data on V2O5 nanowires using energy-dispersive analysis of X-rays (EDX) confirmed that only vanadium and oxygen were present.

It's important to note that the size of the nanoparticles can be influenced by the conditions of the synthesis process, such as the reaction time, temperature, and the concentration of the reagents. However, the article does not provide specific details on how to control the size of the nanoparticles to achieve 2000 nm V2O5 nanoparticles.

The synthesis of VOxQDs, or Vanadium Oxide Quantum Dots, was carried out using a one-pot solvothermal method. The precursor used for the synthesis was VCl3. The solvents used in the process were either DI water or ethanol. To achieve VOxQDs with uniform distribution and similar size, the reaction conditions were optimized.

The typical procedure for the synthesis was as follows: Firstly, VCl3 (0.2 g) was added with 20 mL solvent and thoroughly mixed. Secondly, the mixture was subjected to ultrasonic treatment at 200 W power for 15 minutes and then was respectively heated at 120 °C, 140 °C, 160 °C, 180 °C and 200°C for 10 hours, respectively. Then the mixture was cooled naturally and centrifuged at 12000 rpm for 10 min. Finally, the VOxQDs were obtained by collecting the supernatant.

The most favorable temperature and solvent for VOxQDs synthesis were found to be 180 °C and ethanol. The average diameter of the VOxQDs was 3.39 ± 0.57 nm, as determined by statistics of the 100 particles. Higher temperature of 200 °C wouldn’t result in the further significant change in particle size and distribution.

The equipment used in the process included a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope instrument for Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), a FS5–TCSPC–1189–0317-A3732–1 spectrophotometer for measuring the PL spectra, and a Mapada UV-1800PC spectrophotometer for recording the UV absorption spectra.

In conclusion, the synthesis of VOxQDs nanoparticles requires VCl3 as a precursor, DI water or ethanol as a solvent, and a temperature of 180 °C for optimal results. The process involves ultrasonic treatment, heating, and centrifugation. The resulting nanoparticles have an average diameter of 3.39 ± 0.57 nm.

The article does not provide specific instructions for synthesizing 150 nm VO2 nanoparticles. However, it does describe the synthesis of VO2(A) nanoplates under certain conditions. 

The synthesis was performed under mild hydrothermal conditions using a 2.0 M VO(acac)2 solution. The solution was hydrolyzed at 220 C for 24 hours. The phase identity of the product was confirmed by PXRD (Powder X-ray Diffraction). The chemical state and the compositions of the VO2(A) nanoplates were also confirmed by XPS (X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy).

The morphology of the VO2(A) nanoplates was observed in the TEM (Transmission Electron Microscopy) and SEM (Scanning Electron Microscopy) images. The VO2(A) nanostructures were composed of uniformly plate-like nanoparticles with an average width measuring 30–50 nm, length of 100–200 nm, and thickness of 20–30 nm. The TEM image also confirmed the plate-like morphology which is typically 20–40 nm wide and 100–200 nm long, in agreement with SEM observation. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image demonstrated the well-resolved lattice fringes with an interlayer spacing of about 0.60 nm, corresponding to the (110) lattice plane of VO2(A).

To investigate the growth processes of VO2(A) tetragonal crystalline nanoplates, a series of experiments were conducted to track the evolution of morphologies and phases as a function of temperature and time by FESEM (Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope) and PXRD. Temperature played an important role in controlling the size, shape, and crystal structures of the nanoparticles. By varying the hydrothermal synthesis temperature, the nanoparticles exhibited distinctly different shapes and morphologies, which is consistent with the evolution of crystalline structures.

In order to further understand the formation of the VO2(A) phase, in situ PXRD experiments were carried out using different heating rates. It was found that varying heating rate had no effect on the synthesis mechanism. VO2(A) nucleated and grew directly from solution following the complete hydrolysis of VO(acac)2 with no other intermediate phases observed.

However, the article does not provide specific instructions or parameters for synthesizing 150 nm VO2 nanoparticles. Further research and experimentation would be needed to determine the specific conditions required to synthesize VO2 nanoparticles of this size.

The synthesis of uranium oxide nanoparticles (UO2 NPs) was reported by Cao et al. in 2006, and further developed by Hudry et al. They developed an organic-phase synthesis method for producing size-controlled, nearly monodispersed UO2 nanocrystals. This nonaqueous technique was applied to the synthesis of nano thorium oxide, plutonium oxide, and thorium/uranium mixed oxide nanocrystals. Hydrothermal techniques for nano-sized uranium oxide have also been developed. 

Chen et al., for example, reported a facile hydrothermal route to phase-controlled synthesis of uranium oxide nanostructures with high yield using organic amines as both reducing and structure-directing reagents. They then converted synthesized UO2 particles to porous U3O8 aggregates through calcination at 800 °C for 2 h in air. Shi et al. conducted numerous experiments on uranium oxide synthesis by exploring this method. In one such study, they synthesized porous, three-dimensional hierarchical uranium-containing and uranium oxide microspheres by a simple, template-free hydrothermal method with uranyl nitrate hexahydrate, urea, and glycerol as the uranium source, precipitating agent, and shape-controlling agent, respectively. 

In addition to these methods, the use of ionic liquids (ILs) as templates and reactants for fabricating inorganic materials are also quite interesting. For example, porous inorganic nanomaterials and mesoporous silica have been synthesized successfully with ILs templates. Visser et al. synthesized nanostructured uranium oxides with ellipse- to disk- to star-shaped morphologies using ILs templating agents and a low-temperature synthesis route, and demonstrated that the structure of the ILs has little impact on the final product. 

In this study, the synthesis of uranium oxide nanocrystals with various morphology structures was controlled through a one-step hydrothermal approach with ILs. The porous-hollow nano-UO2 was demonstrated to have highly intrinsic peroxidase-like activity. 

All ionic liquids were purchased from Kekaite Co., Lanzhou, China. Reagent-grade depleted uranyl acetate dehydrate, o-Phenylenediamine (OPD), bovine serum albumin (BSA), were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. 3,3,5,5-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB), corn protein, casein phosphopeptides (CPP), lactoalbumin hydrolysate (LH) and collagen protein were purchased from Macklin Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All other chemicals, including hydrazine hydrate and H2O2 were of analytical grade and purchased from KeLong Reagent Co., Chengdu, China. 

The synthesis procedure for UO2 nanocrystals was followed according to the method, control experiments were carried out by adjusting the species of ILs, hydrothermal temperature, hydrothermal time, and precipitating agent (i.e., NaOH, N2H4·H2O, or urea). The peroxidase-like activity of the porous-hollow nano-UO2 was performed at varied temperatures and pH using 4.8 mg·mL−1 with 0.4 mM TMB or OPD and 4.5 mM H2O2 as substrate. The pH of the reaction system was adjusted using 0.2 M acetic acid buffer. The kinetics analysis for the reaction was carried out by recording the absorption spectra in a time-scan mode at 652 nm.

The synthesis of uranium oxide nanoparticles (UO2 NPs) was reported by Cao et al. in 2006, and further developed by Hudry et al. They developed an organic-phase synthesis method for producing size-controlled, nearly monodispersed UO2 nanocrystals. This nonaqueous technique was applied to the synthesis of nano thorium oxide, plutonium oxide, and thorium/uranium mixed oxide nanocrystals. 

Hydrothermal techniques for nano-sized uranium oxide have also been developed. Chen et al., for example, reported a facile hydrothermal route to phase-controlled synthesis of uranium oxide nanostructures with high yield using organic amines as both reducing and structure-directing reagents. They then converted synthesized UO2 particles to porous U3O8 aggregates through calcination at 800 °C for 2 h in air. Shi et al. conducted numerous experiments on uranium oxide synthesis by exploring this method. In one such study, they synthesized porous, three-dimensional hierarchical uranium-containing and uranium oxide microspheres by a simple, template-free hydrothermal method with uranyl nitrate hexahydrate, urea, and glycerol as the uranium source, precipitating agent, and shape-controlling agent, respectively. UO2 and U3O8 nanoparticles have also been synthesized successfully via basic hydrothermal process without any surfactant or template.

In addition to these methods, the use of ionic liquids (ILs) as templates and reactants for fabricating inorganic materials are also quite interesting. For example, porous inorganic nanomaterials and mesoporous silica have been synthesized successfully with ILs templates. Visser et al. synthesized nanostructured uranium oxides with ellipse- to disk- to star-shaped morphologies using ILs templating agents and a low-temperature synthesis route, and demonstrated that the structure of the ILs has little impact on the final product. In effect, the utility of ILs as templates for fabrication of nano uranium oxides with various surface morphologies is indeed possible, with favorable results. 

Inspired by this method, the researchers controlled the synthesis of uranium oxide nanocrystals with various morphology structures through a one-step hydrothermal approach with ILs in this study. Simultaneously, the porous-hollow nano-UO2 was demonstrated firstly have highly intrinsic peroxidase-like activity. 

All ionic liquids were purchased from Kekaite Co., Lanzhou, China. Reagent-grade depleted uranyl acetate dehydrate, o-Phenylenediamine (OPD), bovine serum albumin (BSA), were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. 3,3,5,5-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB), corn protein, casein phosphopeptides (CPP), lactoalbumin hydrolysate (LH) and collagen protein were purchased from Macklin Co. Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All other chemicals, including hydrazine hydrate and H2O2 were of analytical grade and purchased from KeLong Reagent Co., Chengdu, China. 

Powder XRD analyses were performed on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation, and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) observations were performed with a Hitachi S-4800 scanning electron microscope. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption measurements were performed using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument after degassing the samples at 200 °C for 4 h. UV/visible absorption spectra were recorded on a Shimadzu UV-2450 spectrometer with 1.0 cm path length. 

The specific parameters for the synthesis of UO2 NPs, including the molar ratios of uranyl acetate dihydrate and ILs, the precipitating agent, and the hydrothermal temperature and time, were adjusted in control experiments. The details of these experiments are provided in the Electronic Supporting Material (ESM) of the original article.

The synthesis of iridium nanoparticles (Ir NPs) was carried out by a simple chemical reduction process. The precursor used was sodium hexachloroiridate(III) hydrate, with ascorbic acid serving as a protecting agent and sodium borohydride as the reducing agent. After heating and stirring at 95 °C for 15 minutes, the resulting homogeneous light brown Ir NPs dispersion was obtained with good stability and reproducibility. 

The obtained Ir NPs were thoroughly characterized by various methods. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images indicated that the as-prepared Ir NPs showed a narrow size distribution with the average diameter of 2.4 nm. UV-vis spectrum of Ir NPs showed an absorption peak at 280 nm, indicating the formation of Ir NPs. XPS spectra of Ir 4f in Ir NPs were presented in the Fig. S1.† A pair of doublet peaks at 61.0 and 64.0 eV were observed, revealing that Ir in Ir NPs is mostly metallic Ir(0). Furthermore, inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) disclosed that the exact concentration of Ir NPs is 25 mg mL−1.

The article does not provide specific details on the quantities of the reagents used in the synthesis process, such as the mmols of sodium hexachloroiridate(III) hydrate, ascorbic acid, and sodium borohydride. However, the process involves heating and stirring the mixture at 95 °C for 15 minutes, which suggests that the reaction conditions are critical for the formation of the Ir NPs. The characterization of the nanoparticles also suggests that the synthesis process was successful in producing nanoparticles with the desired properties.

The synthesis of magnetite nanoparticles (MNPs) was achieved through a coprecipitation method. The reagents used for this process included 2.5 g of iron(II) chloride tetrahydrate (FeCl2·4H2O) and 5 g of iron (III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), which were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water. Then, 11 mL of aqueous ammonia solution was added to the solution under constant stirring at 500 rpm at room temperature and mixed for 1 minute. The magnetite nanoparticles were collected using a magnet and washed using deionized water until a neutral pH level was achieved.

The magnetic separation process included repeated stages: Particle deposition by applying a magnetic field, decantation, adding water, and mechanical resuspension of the sediment. The resulting black precipitate was mixed with 100 mL of deionized water and subjected to ultrasonic treatment (30 kHz, 110 W) under constant stirring for 2 hours. The solution of magnetite nanoparticles was then cooled down to room temperature. The ensuing solution of magnetite nanoparticles exhibited magnetic liquid properties, thus, when a magnetic field was applied, the particles did not separate from the water. The mass fraction of magnetite in the resulting colloid solution was 2% wt.

The precipitate was washed with deionized water by magnetic separation to eliminate nonmagnetic by-products and excess of ammonia. The resulting material was dispersed in 15 MOhm deionized water and subjected to ultrasonic treatment for 2 hours. Ultrasonication of the particles in water led to the disintegration of the aggregates formed during the coprecipitation process, and intense hydroxylation of the particle surface. As a result, a black stable colloidal system with a magnetic fluid-like behavior was formed. Dynamic light scattering showed that the solution consisted of monodisperse nanoparticles with a hydrodynamic radius of 35 ± 3 nm. The kinetic stability of the resulting colloidal solution was confirmed by electrophoretic light scattering, which shows that zeta potential was 36 ± 2 mV.

To further study the composition and physical properties, the colloidal solution was dried in a vacuum for several hours to avoid oxidation. The thermogravimetric study revealed that the mass fraction of magnetite nanoparticles in the solution was >2%. The X-ray diffraction pattern of the material corresponded to the crystal phase of magnetite, peaks referred to JCPDS file No. 19-0629. According to the Scherrer equation, the crystallite size was 10.9 nm. The analysis of particles via TEM and SEM proved a narrow particle size distribution with the diameter of crystallites 10 ± 3 nm. Upon solvent removal, MNPs underwent sol-gel transition and formed a mesoporous xerogel matrix with the total surface area of 120 m2/g and a mean pore diameter of 8 nm. Such xerogels were stable in water solutions without any signs of resuspension. The magnetization curve of the material showed superparamagnetic behavior with magnetization up to 78 emu/g at 8 kOe.

The synthesis of Cu2O nanoparticles (NPs) with a diameter of around 200 nm was achieved using a facile strategy as described in the article. The process involved the use of sodium hypochlorite as a green oxidant, which oxidized urea to CO2 as a carbon source to prepare the fine-particle crosslinked Cu-precursors. These precursors could then be further reduced by sodium ascorbate into pure Cu2O nanospheres (NPs) with a porous morphology at room temperature.

The study revealed that the introduction of an appropriate amount of MgCl2 into the raw materials could tune the pore sizes and surface area, but had no influence on the phase purity of the resulting Cu2O NPs. The TEM analysis showed that the particles exhibited a distribution with the diameter varying from 150 to 240 nm and mainly concentrated on 200 nm.

The characterization of the synthesized Cu2O NPs was performed using various techniques. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-1011, JEOL), scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Gemini, Carl Zeiss), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100, JEOL) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) were used to characterize the morphologies and structure of the as-synthesized Cu2O. The crystal structure of the as-prepared catalysts was analyzed through X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8, Germany). Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained on a Tensor II FTIR spectrometer (Bruker Optics, Germany). X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (ESCALAB 250). BET surface area and pore size measurements were conducted via N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms on a Micro-meritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, NexION 350X, PerkinElmer) was performed to estimate the content of copper and magnesium in the samples.

The study also explored the possible growth mechanism of the Cu2O NPs. Sodium hypochlorite was used as an oxidant to react with urea to produce sodium chloride, CO2, and N2. After adding an appropriate amount of CuCl2 and MgCl2, Cu–Mg-precursors were formed and the gas bubbles produced from the oxidation reaction of sodium hypochlorite and urea were entrained in the precursor, which may facilitate the formation of precursors with a loose structure. The XRD pattern showed that this network-like Cu–Mg-precursor is a mixed crystal phase including Cu2(OH)3 Cl (JCPDS card no. 50-1559), Cu2CO3(OH)2 (JCPDS card no. 41-1390) and Mg2(OH)3Cl (JCPDS card no. 12-0410).

In conclusion, the synthesis of Cu2O NPs with a diameter of around 200 nm was achieved using a simple and economical strategy involving the use of sodium hypochlorite as a green oxidant and urea as a carbon source. The introduction of MgCl2 into the raw materials allowed for the tuning of the pore sizes and surface area of the resulting Cu2O NPs.
