The synthesis of Cu2O nanoparticles (NPs) with a diameter of around 200 nm was achieved using a facile strategy involving sodium hypochlorite as a green oxidant and urea as a carbon source. The fine-particle crosslinked Cu-precursors were prepared by oxidizing urea to CO2, which could then be further reduced by sodium ascorbate into pure Cu2O NPs with a porous morphology at room temperature. The study reveals that the introduction of an appropriate amount of MgCl2 into the raw materials can tune the pore sizes and surface area, but has no influence on the phase purity of the resulting Cu2O NPs.

The morphology of the Cu2O samples prepared with the precursor in a molar ratio of CuCl2 : MgCl2 = 10 : 1 was firstly investigated by Transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-1011, JEOL), scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Gemini, Carl Zeiss), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100, JEOL) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED). The crystal structure of the as-prepared catalysts was analyzed through X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8, Germany). Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained on a Tensor II FTIR spectrometer (Bruker Optics, Germany). X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (ESCALAB 250). BET surface area and pore size measurements were conducted via N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms on a Micro-meritics ASAP 2020 instrument. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, NexION 350X, PerkinElmer) was performed to estimate the content of copper and magnesium in the samples.

In order to examine the role of MgCl2 in the microstructure of the Cu2O NPs, Cu2O NPs were synthesized by using the precursor in a molar ratio of CuCl2 : MgCl2 of sole CuCl2, 20 : 1, 10 : 1, and 5 : 1, respectively, while keeping the other conditions constant. The corresponding Cu2O samples are labeled as Cu2O-(sole CuCl2), Cu2O-(20 : 1-Mg), Cu2O-(10 : 1-Mg), and Cu2O-(5 : 1-Mg), respectively. The XRD patterns demonstrate that all final products are pure Cu2O NPs, and no diffraction peaks related to magnesium are observed in the XRD patterns.

The BET surface area and the average pore size of Cu2O-(sole CuCl2) are calculated to be 13.03 m2 g1 and 7.29 nm. Meanwhile, the NPs prepared using the precursor in a molar ratio of CuCl2 : MgCl2 = 5 : 1, Cu2O-(5 : 1-Mg) NPs, show a BET surface area of 21.32 m2 g1 and an average pore diameter of 12.01 nm. These results clearly indicate that introduction of Mg2+ ions into the Cu-precursor has an influence on the porous structure evolution of Cu2O NPs.

The synthesis of ultrasmall RuO2 nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out using the solvothermal method. The reagents used in the synthesis included chitosan (CS) and ruthenium(III) chloride trihydrate (RuCl3·3H2O). 

Initially, a solution of CS was prepared by dissolving it in 3% acetic acid to a concentration of 3 mg/mL. Then, RuCl3·3H2O (25 mg) was added to the CS solution (3 mg/mL, 20 mL), and the mixture was stirred for 30 minutes. This mixed solution was then transferred to a round-bottomed flask.

The flask containing the solution was then subjected to heat at a temperature of 120 °C for a duration of 6 hours. This heating process resulted in the formation of a dark green solution, which was the product of the reaction. 

The resulting solution was then purified by dialysis against distilled water at room temperature for a period of 48 hours. The molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) for the dialysis process was 3500. 

The equipment used in the synthesis process included a round-bottomed flask for the reaction, a stirrer for mixing the reagents, a heating device for the solvothermal process, and a dialysis setup for the purification of the product. 

The article does not specify the exact size of the RuO2 NPs produced in this synthesis process. However, the term "ultrasmall" used in the article suggests that the NPs were likely to be in the range of a few nanometers. The exact size and morphology of the NPs can be determined using characterization techniques such as transmission electron microscopy (TEM). 

In conclusion, the synthesis of ultrasmall RuO2 NPs involved the use of CS and RuCl3·3H2O as reagents, a solvothermal process for the reaction, and dialysis for the purification of the product. The size of the NPs was likely to be in the range of a few nanometers, although the exact size was not specified in the article.

The synthesis of Au/CeO2 CSNPs (nanoparticles) is a two-step process. 

The first step involves the synthesis of Au seed. In this process, 5mL of 5mM HAuCl4.3H2O, 5mL (0.2 M) CTAB and 0.6 mL (0.1M) NaBH4 (ice cold) are added, respectively. HAuCl4 is reduced by NaBH4 and gives a brown color solution. This solution is aged for 4 days and further used to synthesize Au/CeO2 CSNPs.

The second step is the synthesis of Au/CeO2 CSNPs. This process is based on the method reported by Li, Benxia, et al[35] with slight modifications. In brief, 0.6mM of Au seed is re-dispersed into 0.025 M (8mL) CTAB solution followed by 0.8 mL of EDTA-NH3 solution is added to this mixture. (EDTA-NH3 solution is prepared by adding 0.45 mL of 25% NH3 solution by dissolving 10 mM of EDTA in 40 mL of Milli-Q water). Next, 0.6mM of Ce(NO3)3.6H2O solution is added to the above solution. The total volume of solution is adjusted to 10 mL. This solution is mixed by repeated by gentle inversion for 1 min and then kept in an oven at 90° C for 5 hours. The resultant Au/CeO2 CSNPs is centrifuged at 10,000g for 5 min. The precipitate is re-dispersed into 1 mL water for further use.

The characterization of nanoparticles is done using various methods. Absorbance spectra of AuNPs, CeO2 NPs, and Au/CeO2 CSNPs are acquired using a UV–visible spectrophotometer (Biotek, Synergy HT spectrophotometer). Zeta potential and hydrodynamic diameters of nanoparticles are carried out using dynamic light scattering measurement (DLS) from Zeta sizer nano (Malvern instruments) using a laser with a wavelength of 633 nm. The size and shape of nanoparticles are analyzed by using a transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with 20-120 kV (JEM1400 plus, JEOL). Samples used for TEM imaging are dialyzed for purification. The Fourier Transformed Infra-Red (FTIR) spectroscopy of AuNPs, CeO2 NPs, and Au/CeO2 CSNPs is carried out by using Spectrum two FT-IR spectrometer (L160000A, PerkinElmer). 

The average particle size of Au/CeO2 CSNPs is ~75 nm. The hydrodynamic size of Au/CeO2 CSNPs was found to be 187.5 nm, ~ 112 nm higher than average particle size distribution obtained from TEM. This could also be ascribed due to the loose agglomeration of Au/CeO2 CSNPs. The zeta potential value of Au/CeO2 CSNPs was measured to be +30.0 mV that is slightly higher than the stable suspension regime of zeta potential values suggesting that these nanostructures are in stable colloidal suspension at relatively physiological pH (7.2). The positive zeta potential values at physiological pH also suggest that the CTAB molecules are adsorbed on surfaces of CeO2 giving them a positive charge.

The ZnCo2O4 nanosheets (NSs) were fabricated according to a previously established strategy with minor modifications. The deep eutectic solvent (DES) was prepared by dissolving 0.28 g of potassium hydroxide (KOH) in 44 g of polyethylene glycol (PEG-200) and stirring for 1 hour at 80 °C. Then, 2 mM of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate [Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O] and 1 mM of zinc nitrate hexahydrate [Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O] were dissolved in 5 mL of DES, and mixed well under stirring. After reaction at 80 °C for 2 hours, deionized water (5 mL) was injected into the resulting solution and left to stand for 0.5 hours. 

Finally, white precipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed six times with water and ethanol to remove unreacted reagents. After drying in an oven, a white powder was obtained as the final product. The material was characterized by TEM and SEM to observe the morphology and microstructure. The material is ultrathin, corrugated and interlinked with each other to build a sheet-like shape. 

The XRD characteristic peaks appear at 32◦ and 60◦ indicate the crystal nature of ZnCo2O4, which can be ascribed to the (220) and (511) lattice planes. These results prove that this simple method can successfully prepare nano-phase and well-crystalline ZnCo2O4 NSs. 

To investigate the chemistry composition and structure of the synthesized material, ZnCo2O4 was further researched by EDX, XPS and FTIR. The EDX result reveals that the Zn, Co, O and C elements coexist in the sample, the presence of C element probably caused by the remnant of PEG. The results are also proved by the XPS spectrum, the peaks located at 1022 eV, 781 eV and 531 eV should be ascribed to the Zn2p, Co2p and O1s satellite signal, respectively. 

The physical properties of the prepared ZnCo2O4 were observed by TGA. The obtained sample presents high thermal stability and up to about 200 °C. In addition, the morphology of the nanosheets remains intact after two months and has been tested to have excellent catalytic activity. 

Please note that the article does not specify the size of the nanoparticles synthesized.

Then, 2 mM of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate [Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O] and 1 mM of zinc nitrate hexahydrate [Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O] were dissolved in 5 mL of DES, and mixed well under stirring. After reaction at 80 °C for 2 hours, deionized water (5 mL) was injected into the resulting solution and left to stand for 0.5 hours. 

Finally, white precipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed six times with water and ethanol to remove unreacted reagents. After drying in an oven, a white powder was obtained as the final product. The material was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to observe the morphology and microstructure. The material is ultrathin, corrugated and interlinked with each other to build a sheet-like shape. 

The nanosheets were further researched by energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). The FTIR spectrum shows the stretching band can be seen at 668 cm− 1 and 537 cm− 1 originate from M-O (M = Co, Zn).

In conclusion, the synthesis of ZnCo2O4 nanosheets involves the use of a deep eutectic solvent (DES), potassium hydroxide (KOH), polyethylene glycol (PEG-200), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate [Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O], and zinc nitrate hexahydrate [Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O]. The process involves stirring, heating, and centrifugation steps, and the final product is characterized using various analytical techniques such as TEM, SEM, EDX, XPS, FTIR, and TGA.

The synthesis of LaCoO3 nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out using a sol-gel method based on citrate complexation. The reagents used in the synthesis included cobaltous nitrate (Co(NO3)3·6H2O) and lanthanum nitrate (La(NO3)3·6H2O), both of which were used without any further purification. Citric acid (0.004mol) was slowly added to the aqueous solution of Co(NO3)3·6H2O (0.002mol) and La(NO3)3·6H2O (0.002mol). After this process, the mixed solution was stirred at 80 ℃ for 2 hours.

The obtained nitrate-citrate complex gel was then heated at 160 ℃ overnight. After grinding, the obtained solids were calcined in a muffle furnace with a heating rate of 5 ℃· min-1 in air at 400 ℃ for 3 hours, and then at 700 ℃ for 3 hours. The resulting product was LaCoO3 NPs.

The morphology and composition of the synthesized LaCoO3 were characterized by a scanning electron microscope (SEM) and an Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS). The average size of the as-prepared nanoparticles was found to be about 70 nm. The existence of La, Co, and O elements was confirmed by EDS. The crystal structure of the LaCoO3 perovskite was examined using powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns recorded on a Bruker D8 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5418Å). 

The high-resolution TEM image reveals that the lattice fringes (0.171 nm) and (0.135 nm) of these nanoparticles match well with the (311) and (122) plane of LaCoO3, respectively. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of LaCoO3 is shown in Fig. 1e, which is well consistent with those XRD results. The particle size distribution histogram was shown in Fig. 1f, which also indicates that the average diameter is about 70 nm. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of LaCoO3 NPs involves a sol-gel method using cobaltous nitrate and lanthanum nitrate, followed by a series of heating and grinding processes. The resulting NPs were characterized using various techniques to confirm their composition, structure, and size.

The synthesis of LaNiO3 nanoparticles was performed via a conventional sol-gel strategy. Lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (1.5 mmol), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (1.5 mmol), and citric acid (12 mmol) were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water, followed by adding 1.5 mL of ethylene glycol. The resulting transparent solutions were condensed at 90 °C into a gel under stirring, which were then decomposed at 180 °C for 5 hours to form solid precursors. 

The solid precursors were then decomposed at 400 °C for 2 hours to obtain foam-like precursors via removing the organic components. The precursors were further annealed at 700 °C for 5 hours with a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute to obtain the final LaNiO3 nanoparticles. The obtained LaNiO3 nanoparticles were denoted as LaNiO3-SG. 

In addition, the synthesis of porous LaNiO3 nanocubes was also described. The lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (1.0 mmol), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (1.0 mmol), and glycine (4 mmol) were dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water, followed by the adding 0.3 g of PVP. After stirring for 30 min, the pH of the solution was adjusted to about 7.0 via slowly adding ammonium hydroxide. The resulting solution was transferred into a 40 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 24 hours. The resulting product was centrifuged and washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times, which was then dried at 60 °C for overnight. The precursor powder was finally annealed at 650 °C for 2 hours with a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute to obtain the final porous LaNiO3 nanocubes.

The size of the nanoparticles or nanocubes was not directly controlled in the synthesis process, but the resulting LaNiO3 nanocubes had a size of about 600 nm as shown in the SEM and TEM images. The size of the nanoparticles or nanocubes can be influenced by the conditions of the synthesis process, such as the concentration of the reagents, the temperature, and the duration of the heating process. However, the specific conditions for controlling the size of the nanoparticles or nanocubes were not detailed in the article.

The solid precursors were then decomposed at 400 °C for 2 hours to obtain foam-like precursors via removing the organic components. The precursors were further annealed at 700 °C for 5 hours with a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute to obtain the final LaNiO3 nanoparticles. The obtained LaNiO3 nanoparticles were denoted as LaNiO3-SG. 

For the synthesis of porous LaNiO3 nanocubes, lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (1.0 mmol), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (1.0 mmol), and glycine (4 mmol) were dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water, followed by the adding 0.3 g of PVP. After stirring for 30 min, the pH of the solution was adjusted to about 7.0 via slowly adding ammonium hydroxide. The resulting solution was transferred into a 40 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 24 hours. The resulting product was centrifuged and washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times, which was then dried at 60 °C for overnight. The precursor powder was finally annealed at 650 °C for 2 hours with a ramp rate of 5 °C/minute to obtain the final porous LaNiO3 nanocubes.

The size of the nanoparticles or nanocubes was not directly controlled in the synthesis process, but the resulting LaNiO3 nanocubes had a size of about 600 nm as shown in the SEM and TEM images. The size of the nanoparticles or nanocubes can be influenced by the conditions of the synthesis process, such as the concentration of the reagents, the temperature, and the duration of the heating process. However, the specific conditions for controlling the size of the nanoparticles or nanocubes were not detailed in the article.

The synthesis of CeVO4 nanoparticles (NPs) involves a series of steps as described in the article. The precipitates were collected by filtration, washed with Milli-Q water and absolute ethanol several times, and dried at 60 °C in air for 6 hours. The CeVO4 nanorods were obtained and denoted as CeVO4-2 NRs (‘-2’ stands for using 2.0 mmol EDTA).

In addition, other CeVO4 samples with different morphologies were prepared under the same conditions mentioned above except for using different concentration of EDTA, which were denoted as CeVO4-1.5, CeVO4-2.5 and CeVO4-3, respectively. The article does not provide specific details on the initial synthesis process, but it does mention that the process involves the use of different concentrations of EDTA.

The crystal phase and structure of the as-prepared samples were examined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements on a powder X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Ultima IV, Japan) under the following conditions: 40 kV, 30 mA, and graphite-filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). The microstructure and morphology of the as-prepared samples were observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi S-4800, Japan). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were recorded on a field-emission transmission electron microscope (JEOL JEM-2100, Japan) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV, equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) for elemental analysis. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were determined by an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo ESCALAB 250, USA) equipped with an Al-anode at a total power dissipation of 150 W (15 kV, 10 mA).

The specific surface areas were measured according to Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation via an automatic nitrogen adsorption specific surface and pore size distribution analyzer (NOVA 4000e, Quantachrome Ins., USA) at 77 K after a pretreatment at 473 K for 2 h. The zeta potential measurements were carried out on a zeta potential measuring instrument (Zetasizer Nano-ZS, Malvern Instruments Ltd., UK), which was examined six times (each time being the average of 100 runs) at pH 4.0, and the mean values and standard deviations were calculated automatically on the basis of Smoluchowski’s equation.

In conclusion, the synthesis of CeVO4 NPs involves a series of steps including filtration, washing, drying, and various measurements using different types of equipment. The process also involves the use of different concentrations of EDTA. The size of the NPs can be controlled by adjusting the concentration of EDTA used in the synthesis process.

The synthesis of Tb2(MoO4)3 nanoplates, including those of around 300 nm size, is described in the manuscript. The process involves the use of certain reagents and equipment, and follows a specific procedure.

The reagents used for the synthesis include an aqueous solution of Tb(III) nitrate (0.05 M) and a sodium molybdate (0.05 M) aqueous solution. After complete mixing of the reagents, the precipitated terbium(III) molybdate is filtered and washed with distilled water three times to remove the soluble ions remaining on the surface of precipitate particles. The SEM image of the as-prepared Tb2(MoO4)3 nanoplates shows a typical plate-like architecture with uniform diameter. The diameters of the individual nanoplates are in the range of 20−50 nm, and their length is 200−500 nm with a smooth surface and relatively sharp edges. The Tb2(MoO4)3 nanostructures possess folded edges with parallel lines which correspond to the different layers of Tb2(MoO4)3 nanostructures.

The manuscript does not provide specific details on how to control the size of the nanoplates to achieve a specific size such as 300 nm. These parameters can be optimized through experimental trials to achieve the desired nanoparticle size.

The synthesis of Pt nanoparticles was carried out using a citrate reduction method. The platinum chloride (H2PtCl66H2O) was heated for 1 hour at 100 °C, and then 1% trisodium citrate was added dropwise. During the reduction of platinum ion, the absorption peaks of platinum ions were monitored at the wavelength range of 200–300 nm using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (PerkinElmer, USA). 

The Pt nanoparticles were purified using a dialysis membrane (Spectrum Laboratories, USA) with a molecular weight cut-off of 1 KDa. After this, the Pt nanoparticles were lyophilized and stored under vacuum. The image of Pt nanoparticles was observed using a HR-TEM from JEOL Co. (Japan).

The morphology of Pt nanoparticles was observed to be spherical from the HR-TEM images. The diameter of the Pt nanoparticles was estimated to be around 2–3 nm from the HR-TEM images and 2.06 nm from the dynamic laser scattering (DLS) measurement. The zeta potential of Pt nanoparticles was measured to be -47.6 ± 3.8 mV at pH 7, which indicated a well-dispersed colloidal condition of Pt nanoparticles at a physiological pH condition. 

The crystal structure of the synthesized Pt nanoparticle was characterized using XRD spectroscopy. The XRD peaks of the synthesized Pt nanoparticles were determined to coincide with the known XRD spectrum of Pt nanoparticles. 

In summary, the synthesis of Pt nanoparticles involves the reduction of platinum chloride using trisodium citrate, monitoring the reduction process using UV-vis spectroscopy, purification of the nanoparticles using a dialysis membrane, and characterization of the nanoparticles using HR-TEM, DLS, and XRD spectroscopy. The resulting Pt nanoparticles were found to be spherical with a diameter of around 2-3 nm.

The synthesis of Pt NCs (nanoclusters) was carried out in an aqueous solution using a simple reflux reaction. The yeast extract was selected as the template for NC synthesis because it contains many biomolecules, such as amino acids and proteins, which provide abundant active sites that can efficiently bind and reduce metal ions. The aqueous solution of Pt NCs shows a beige color and exhibits a bright blue emission under the irradiation of a UV lamp (365 nm). The emission spectrum of prepared Pt NCs shows a maximum at 448 nm upon excitation at 370 nm.

In a typical synthesis, 4 mL, 20 mM H2PtCl6·6H2O aqueous solution were added to a yeast extract aqueous solution (16 mL, 200 mg). Then the resulting mixture was refluxed for another 12 hours under vigorous stirring at 100 oC. The light yellow reaction solution gradually changed to brown color. After that, the crude products were first purified by centrifugation to remove the precipitate from the supernatant (15000 rpm, 20 min). Another purification step to remove the unreacted small molecule components was performed by ultrafiltration (3k Da pore size Amicon ultracentrifugal filter units) with a cycle at 4000 g for 30 min. After the purification, Pt NCs were stored at 4 oC in the dark and used for the following experiment. The final concentration was calculated to be about 4 mM based on Pt atoms and the weight to volume concentration was about 15 mg/mL.

Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) revealed that as-prepared Pt NCs were mostly spherical in shape and the average size was 3.0 ± 0.3 nm. The crystal lattice fringes of Pt NCs was 0.23 nm (HRTEM, inset in Figure 1b), which corresponds to the (111) lattice plane of Pt crystals. X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) was then performed to investigate the valence states of key elements in our as-prepared Pt NCs. As shown in Figure 1c, the peaks located at 73.2 eV in wide scan survey of XPS correspond to Pt 4f, revealing the presence of Pt.

The zeta-potential of Pt NCs in aqueous solution at room temperature was measured using a CHI 842D workstation (Chenhua, China). The reaction kinetic measurements were performed by using 100 µL of Pt NCs with 500 µM TMB as substrate, or 10 mM H2O2. The reaction solution was diluted to 3 mL by 0.1 M, pH 5.0 PBS (phosphate buffer saline) solution. The each absorbance was recorded at 652 nm in scanning.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 8 nm Au nanoparticles. However, it does describe the synthesis of Au nanoparticles using three different methods, each resulting in nanoparticles with different surface charges. 

For the synthesis of citrate AuNPs, 150 µL of 100 mM HAuCl4 solution was added to 14.85 mL of Milli-Q water and heated until it started refluxing. Then, 1.0 mL of 38.8 mM trisodium citrate was added dropwise with vigorous stirring, and the solution was boiled for 5 minutes until it turned dark red.

For the synthesis of CTAB AuNPs, 5 mL of HAuCl4 (2 mM) aqueous solution was mixed with 5.0 mL (0.2 M) CTAB solution and allowed to mix at 37 °C until the solution developed a dark yellow color. Then, reduction was accomplished by adding 600 µL of ice-cold NaBH4 (0.1 M) dropwise. The vials were stirred vigorously for ~ 24 h and kept occasionally opened to release any evolved hydrogen gas. The suspension was in red color and allowed to age for 5 days. This seed solution was used for the experiment.

For the synthesis of PEG AuNPs, 100 µL of 100 mM HAuCl4 was added to 5.9 mL of Milli-Q water and heated with stirring until it started refluxing. Then it was mixed with 4 mL of PEG solution (325 mg mL−1-PEG 6000 MW.) and allowed to mix for 3 min. 300 µL of NaOH 1% was added dropwise to this solution under vigorous stirring with heating until the transparent solution turned into a ruby red color.

The size of the nanoparticles was measured using a transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with 120 kV (Jeol, JEM1400 plus) on a carbon-coated copper TEM grid. The zeta potential studies of AuNPs were carried out using dynamic light scattering (Zetasizer Nano-Zs, ZEN3600 Malvern Instruments Ltd) using a laser with a wavelength of 633 nm. The particle size distribution histogram was obtained by measuring the size of 200 individual nanoparticles from 15 different images using the software (image-J).

For the synthesis of CTAB AuNPs, 5 mL of HAuCl4 (2 mM) aqueous solution was mixed with 5.0 mL (0.2 M) CTAB solution and allowed to mix at 37 °C until the solution developed a dark yellow color. Then, reduction was accomplished by adding 600 µL of ice-cold NaBH4 (0.1 M) dropwise. The vials were stirred vigorously for ~ 24 h and kept occasionally opened to release any evolved hydrogen gas. The suspension was in red color and allowed to age for 5 days. This seed solution was used for the experiment.

For the preparation of PEG AuNPs, 100 µL of 100 mM HAuCl4 was added to 5.9 mL of Milli-Q water and heated with stirring until it started refluxing. Then it was mixed with 4 mL of PEG solution (325 mg mL−1-PEG 6000 MW.) and allowed to mix for 3 min. 300 µL of NaOH 1% was added dropwise to this solution under vigorous stirring with heating until the transparent solution turned into a ruby red color.

The characterization of AuNPs was carried out using UV–Vis absorption spectra acquired using Biotek (Synergy HT spectrophotometer) at room temperature in a quartz cuvette of 1 cm path length. Particle size was measured using a transmission electron microscope (TEM) equipped with 120 kV (Jeol, JEM1400 plus) on a carbon-coated copper TEM grid. Zeta potential studies of AuNPs were carried out using dynamic light scattering (Zetasizer Nano-Zs, ZEN3600 Malvern Instruments Ltd) using a laser with a wavelength of 633 nm.

The article describes the synthesis of CeO2 nanorods and H2TCPP–CeO2 nanocomposites, but it does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 200 nm CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs). 

The synthesis of CeO2 nanorods was carried out using a two-step method. The first step involved the preparation of CeO2 nanorods. Cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) was rapidly added to a hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) solution and stirred for approximately 10 minutes. The resulting suspension was transferred into a 25 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 250 °C for 3 hours. The system was then allowed to cool to room temperature naturally. The final product was washed with deionized water and dried at 60 °C for 12 hours to obtain CeO2 nanorods.

In the second step, the CeO2 nanorods were functionalized with 5,10,15,20-Tetrakis(4-carboxyl pheyl)-porphyrin (H2TCPP). The CeO2 nanorods were dissolved into a 5 mM H2TCPP solution (pH = 8) and treated in an ultrasonic water bath for 1.5 hours. The sample (H2TCPP–CeO2) was washed with NaOH solution (pH = 8) and dried at room temperature in air to obtain the H2TCPP–CeO2 nanocomposites.

The morphology and size distribution of the nanorods were imaged by transmission electron microscope (TEM JEM-2100, JEOL, Japan). The crystal structures of the products were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (D/Max2500PC, Rigaku, Japan). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were taken in KBr pressed pellets on a NICOLET 380 FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet Thermo, USA). UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a MAPADA UV-3200PC spectrophotometer (Shanghai, China). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a PHI Quantera SXM spectrometer with an Al Kα = 280.00 eV excitation source, and binding energies were calibrated by referencing the C1s peak (284.5 eV) to reduce the sample charge effect.

However, the article does not provide specific details on the size of the synthesized CeO2 nanorods or the H2TCPP–CeO2 nanocomposites. The TEM images showed freshly synthesized CeO2 nanorods with a variable size from 24 nm up to several hundred nm in length and average 21 nm in width. The morphologies of H2TCPP–CeO2 nanocomposites were also similar to those of CeO2 nanorods.

The synthesis of CeO2 nanorods, which can be considered as a type of nanoparticles (NPs), is described in the article. The CeO2 nanorods were prepared using a two-step method. 

In the first step, cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) was used as the starting material. An 8 ml solution of 0.05 M Ce(NO3)3 was rapidly added to an 8 ml solution of 30.0% hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). This mixture was stirred for approximately 10 minutes. The resulting suspension was then transferred into a 25 ml Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 250 °C for 3 hours. After the system was allowed to cool to room temperature naturally, the final product was washed with deionized water and dried at 60 °C for 12 hours to obtain CeO2 nanorods.

In the second step, the CeO2 nanorods were functionalized with 5,10,15,20-Tetrakis(4-carboxyl pheyl)-porphyrin (H2TCPP). The CeO2 nanorods were dissolved into a 5 mM H2TCPP solution (pH = 8) and treated in an ultrasonic water bath for 1.5 hours. The sample was then washed with a NaOH solution (pH = 8) and dried at room temperature in air to obtain the H2TCPP–CeO2 nanocomposites.

The morphology and size distribution of the nanorods were imaged by a transmission electron microscope (TEM JEM-2100, JEOL, Japan). The crystal structures of the products were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (D/Max2500PC, Rigaku, Japan). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were taken in KBr pressed pellets on a NICOLET 380 FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet Thermo, USA). UV–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a MAPADA UV-3200PC spectrophotometer (Shanghai, China). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a PHI Quantera SXM spectrometer with an Al Kα = 280.00 eV excitation source, and binding energies were calibrated by referencing the C1s peak (284.5 eV) to reduce the sample charge effect.

The synthesis of iron oxide nanoparticles was carried out according to a modified procedure by Kim et al. The materials used include sodium citrate dihydrate, ferrous chloride tetrahydrate, iron chloride hexahydrate, carboxymethyl dextran (CMD), polylysine (PLL), poly(ethyleneimine) (PEI), heparin, and others. 

The unmodified iron oxide nanoparticles (Nnat) were synthesized by preparing a solution containing 0.76 mol/L of ferric chloride and 0.4 mol/L of ferrous chloride (molar ratio of ferric to ferrous was approximately 2:1) in pH 1.7 water under nitrogen protection. The iron solution was then added drop-wise to 1.5 mol/L NaOH under vigorous mechanical stirring. This reaction mixture was gradually heated (1 C/min) to 78 C and held at this temperature for 1 h under stirring and nitrogen protection. After separation of the supernatant with a permanent magnet, the wet solid was treated with 0.01 mol/L HCl and then sonicated for 1 h. The acidified suspension was filtered through 0.45 mm and 0.22 mm membranes. Concentration was then adjusted to 0.7 mg Fe/mL.

For the synthesis of citrate- and glycine-modified iron oxide nanoparticles (Ncit, Ngly), to 200 mL of 1 mg/mL sodium citrate, 200 mL of 0.7 mg Fe/mL iron oxide nanoparticles were added under stirring. The mixture was sonicated for 20 min and then further stirred for 2 hours. After ultrafiltration to remove free sodium citrate, the concentration was adjusted to 0.35 mg Fe/mL. An analogous procedure was used to obtain glycine-modified nanoparticles (Ngly).

Polylysine- and poly(ethyleneimine)-coated iron oxide nanoparticles (NPLL, NPEI) were prepared by adding 100 mL of 1 mg/mL PLL solution to 100 mL of 0.35 mg Fe/mL Ncit under stirring. The mixture was sonicated for 20 min and then further stirred for 2 h. The NPLL product was obtained by removing free PLL via ultrafiltration. An analogous procedure was used to obtain PEI-modified nanoparticles (NPEI).

Carboxymethyl dextran- and heparin-coated iron oxide nanoparticles (NCMD, Nhep) were synthesized by adding 100 mL of 1 mg/mL CMD solution to 100 mL of 0.35 mg Fe/mL Ngly under stirring. The mixture was sonicated for 20 min and then further stirred for 2 h. The NCMD product was obtained by removing free CMD via ultrafiltration. An analogous procedure was used to obtain heparin-modified nanoparticles (Nhep).

The synthesized nanoparticles were characterized using a NICOMP 380 ZLS dynamic light scattering (DLS) instrument for size measurements and zeta potential measurements. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was conducted using a JEOL 3011 high-resolution electron microscope. A thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA) was employed to determine coating content of nanoparticles. Superparamagnetic properties were assessed at 25 C using a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID). Iron content of nanoparticles was measured by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES).

The iron solution was then added drop-wise to 1.5 mol/L NaOH under vigorous mechanical stirring. This reaction mixture was gradually heated (1 C/min) to 78 C and held at this temperature for 1 h under stirring and nitrogen protection. After separation of the supernatant with a permanent magnet, the wet solid was treated with 0.01 mol/L HCl and then sonicated for 1 h. The acidified suspension was filtered through 0.45 mm and 0.22 mm membranes. Concentration was then adjusted to 0.7 mg Fe/mL.

For the synthesis of citrate- and glycine-modified iron oxide nanoparticles (Ncit, Ngly), to 200 mL of 1 mg/mL sodium citrate, 200 mL of 0.7 mg Fe/mL iron oxide nanoparticles were added under stirring. The mixture was sonicated for 20 min and then further stirred for 2 hours. After ultrafiltration to remove free sodium citrate, the concentration was adjusted to 0.35 mg Fe/mL. An analogous procedure was used to obtain glycine-modified nanoparticles (Ngly).

Polylysine- and poly(ethyleneimine)-coated iron oxide nanoparticles (NPLL, NPEI) were prepared by adding 100 mL of 1 mg/mL PLL solution to 100 mL of 0.35 mg Fe/mL Ncit under stirring. An analogous procedure was used to obtain PEI-modified nanoparticles (NPEI).

The mixture was sonicated for 20 min and then further stirred for 2 h. The NCMD product was obtained by removing free CMD via ultrafiltration. An analogous procedure was used to obtain heparin-modified nanoparticles (Nhep).

The synthesized nanoparticles were characterized using various techniques. Particle size and zeta potential were measured on a NICOMP 380 ZLS dynamic light scattering (DLS) instrument. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was conducted using a JEOL 3011 high-resolution electron microscope. A thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA) was employed to determine coating content of nanoparticles. Superparamagnetic properties were assessed at 25 C using a superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID). Iron content of nanoparticles was measured by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on an Optima 2000 DV instrument. FTIR was performed on lyophilized samples after compression into w1 mm thick discs containing spectroscopic grade potassium bromide.

The synthesis of iridium nanoparticles (Ir NPs) with an average diameter of 3.5 ± 0.5 nm was achieved through a simple hydrothermal process using Iridium (III) chloride (IrCl3) as a precursor and tannic acid as a stabilizer. The process was carried out in an aqueous solution. 

The detailed procedure is as follows: IrCl3 solution (5.00 mL, 2.0 mM) was added to tannic acid solution (5.00 mL, 2.0 mM) under vigorous stirring. The color of the mixed solution immediately changed into faint yellow, indicating the formation of an Ir-tannic acid complex. After boiling the mixture solution for 30 minutes, freshly prepared NaBH4 solution (1 mL, 0.5 M) was added and the mixture was stirred for 3 hours. The color of the solution changed from faint yellow to deep brown gradually, indicating the formation of the colloid Ir NPs. Finally, the obtained Ir NPs were stored at ambient temperature for use.

The characterization of the Ir NPs was performed using various instruments. Absorption spectra and peroxidase kinetics assay were carried out on a UV–vis spectrophotometer with a 1 cm quartz cuvette (UV-2700, Japan Shimadzu Co., Ltd). High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEM-2100, Japan electron optics laboratory co., Ltd) was performed at 200 kV to visualize the prepared Ir NPs, and Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis of the Ir NPs were carried out with JEM-2100 (HR) microscope. The samples for TEM measurement were prepared by slow evaporation of the Ir NPs solution on a carbon film supported by 300-mesh Cu grids. The hydrodynamic diameter of the Ir NPs was measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS) and the Zeta potential was determined by using the Zeta potential analyzer (Brookhaven instruments Corporation). The oxidation state of iridium and the interaction with tannin acid were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a PHI Quantum 2000 Scanning ESCA Microprobe. Phase identification of the Ir NPs were conducted with X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8, Bruker AXS Co., Ltd) using Cu-K radiation source (= 1.54051Å) over the 2 range of 3–90◦. All Electron Spin Resonance (ESR) measurements were carried out using a Bruker EMXplus-10/12 spectrometer at ambient temperature.

The reagents used in the synthesis and characterization of the Ir NPs, including Iridium (III) chloride trihydrate (IrCl3·3H2O), tannic acid, sodium borohydride (NaBH4), were all of analytical grade and were used without further purification. Milli-Q ultrapure water (18.2 M) was used throughout all experiments.

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of Fe2O3 nanoparticles (NPs) of 250 nm or other sizes. It mentions a novel starch-assisted gel formation method used for the preparation of carboxyl group-functionalized iron oxide nanoparticles (C-IONPs), but the detailed synthesis procedure, including the exact reagents, their quantities, and the specific steps involved in the synthesis, are not described in the provided text.

The characterization of the synthesized C-IONPs was performed using various techniques. The surface morphology and particle size of C-IONPs were investigated using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). A TESCAN MIRA3 FEG-SEM with an in-beam detector was used for SEM analysis, while TEM images were obtained with a JEOL 2100 TEM, operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 KV. The surface composition of the samples was analyzed by X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS spectra were recorded using an AXIS Supra photoelectron spectrometer (Kratos Analytical, UK) with an aluminum anode to produce X-rays [Al Kα (hV = 1486.7 eV)]. 

The hydrodynamic size of C-IONPs was measured by Dynamic Light Scattering (DLS) using a DynaPro Plate Reader III (Wyatt Technology, CA, USA) at 25 °C, and the results were analyzed by DYNAMICS software (Wyatt Technology). Magnetic measurements were performed using a Mini cryogen-free 5 T system (Cryogenics Ltd. London, UK). The magnetization of the IONPs and C-IONPs was measured using a vibrating-sample magnetometer at room temperature (295 K) with a sensitivity of 10−6 emu and a maximum magnetic field of 5 T. The crystalline structure of the synthesized nanoparticles was characterized by X-ray Diffraction (XRD) using a Rigaku CuKα radiation source at 40 kV and 30 mA, within the range of 20−75° at a rate of 1°/min.

However, without the specific details of the synthesis procedure, it is not possible to provide a comprehensive answer on what is needed for the synthesis of 250 nm or other size Fe2O3 NPs.

For the synthesis of MnOx NPs, sodium citrate (100 mM, 200 mL) and KMnO4 (300 mM, 200 mL) were mixed in a 500-mL round-bottom flask fitted with a reflux condenser. This mixture was then heated for 12 hours under continuous stirring at 70 °C. The solution color changed to dark brown, indicating the formation of MnOx nanoparticles. The as-synthesized MnOx nanoparticles were then purified via three centrifugation/washing cycles. The purified MnOx NPs were vacuum dried for 24 hours and finally calcined at 300 °C for 6 hours.

For the synthesis of MFNPs, KMnO4 (100300 mM, 200 mL) was mixed with AIC (100 mM, 200 mL) and heated for 12 hours with continuous stirring at 70 °C in a round bottom flask fitted with a reflux condenser. The solution color changed to dark brown as a result of the formation of MFNPs. The as-synthesized MFNPs were centrifuged at a relative centrifugation force (RCF) of 10,000 g for 20 minutes and washed thrice with DI water. The synthesized MFNPs with different KMnO4/AIC molar ratio of 1:1, 2:1, and 3:1 are referred to MFNPs1:1, MFNPs2:1, and MFNPs3:1, respectively. The purified MFNPs were dried under vacuum for 24 hours, and then the black powder was calcined at 300 °C for 6 hours.

The article does not provide specific details on how to control the size of the nanoparticles. The size of the nanoparticles can be influenced by various factors such as the concentration of the reactants, the temperature, and the duration of the reaction. The article mentions that MnOx NPs have a wide range of particle size (30100 nm) and without any specific shape. The size of the nanoparticles might be controlled by adjusting the parameters of the synthesis process, but the article does not provide specific instructions on how to do this.

After the heating process, the as-synthesized Fe3O4 nanomaterials were then dispersed in ultrapure water (200 mL) and further purified via three centrifugation/washing cycles. The purified Fe3O4 NPs were dried by vacuum drying for 24 hours and stored in airtight containers.

The context also does not specify the type of vacuum dryer used or the conditions under which the nanoparticles were stored. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of Fe3O4 NPs involves heating AIC in a muffle furnace, dispersing the resulting nanomaterials in ultrapure water, purifying the dispersion through centrifugation/washing cycles, and drying the purified nanoparticles by vacuum drying. The resulting Fe3O4 NPs have sizes in the range of ~20–50 nm and a cubic spinel structure.

The synthesis of CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) of varying sizes, including 10 nm, is discussed in the provided text. The synthesis process involves several key parameters, including precursor concentration, reaction temperature, and the use of capping agents like polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP).

The precursor concentration plays a significant role in determining the size of the resultant NPs. As the precursor concentration decreases, the average size of the CeO2 assemblies is significantly reduced. For instance, only 5.6-nm nanoparticles were observed when the precursor concentration was reduced to 13.89 mM. Reducing the precursor concentration comparably decreases the rate constant of cluster-cluster aggregation, which can significantly decrease the average size of assemblies.

The reaction temperature is another pivotal factor in nanocrystal synthesis. Over a temperature range of 120–200 oC, the morphological evolution from a flower to a cube is observed when the solvothermal temperature increases. The products obtained at different reaction temperatures have the same cubic fluorite structure. The statistical results show a significant impact of high temperature on size distribution.

Capping agents like PVP are usually used to direct the growth of nanocrystals and improve their dispersity. In the absence of PVP, the products prepared exhibit the same cubic fluorite structure as the above-mentioned CeO2 nanocrystals. However, they are 9.2-nm CeO2 nanocubes with a disappointed dispersity and size uniformity. Therefore, PVP molecules are indispensable to a high dispersity and perform as a promoter during the formation of nanoflowers.

The synthesis parameters were kept as 55.57 mM precursor concentration reacted at 180 oC for 30 h, except from the absence of PVP. The text does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 10 nm CeO2 NPs, but it can be inferred that adjusting the precursor concentration, reaction temperature, and the presence of PVP can influence the size of the resultant NPs.

The synthesis of CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) of varying sizes, including 5.6 nm, is discussed in the provided text. The synthesis process involves several factors, including precursor concentration, reaction temperature, and the presence of certain reagents.

The precursor concentration plays a significant role in the size of the resultant nanoparticles. As the precursor concentration decreases, the average size of the CeO2 assemblies is significantly reduced. For instance, only 5.6-nm nanoparticles were observed when the precursor concentration was reduced to 13.89 mM. Reducing the precursor concentration comparably decreases the rate constant of cluster-cluster aggregation, which can significantly decrease the average size of assemblies.

The reaction temperature is another pivotal factor in nanocrystal synthesis. Over a temperature range of 120–200 oC, the morphological evolution from a flower to a cube is observed when the solvothermal temperature increases. The products obtained at different reaction temperatures have the same cubic fluorite structure. The statistical results show a significant impact of high temperature on size distribution.

Capping agents are usually used to direct the growth of nanocrystals and improve their dispersity. In the absence of polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), the products prepared exhibit the same cubic fluorite structure as the CeO2 nanocrystals. However, they are 9.2-nm CeO2 nanocubes with a disappointed dispersity and size uniformity. Therefore, PVP molecules are indispensable to a high dispersity and perform as a promoter during the formation of nanoflowers.

In addition, the text mentions the use of DMF as a weak reductant in the synthesis of nanomaterials, where DMF can be transformed into carbamic acid. DMF is supposed to serve as a reductant to reduce CeO2 nanoflowers and then to elevate the concentration of oxygen vacancies. An appropriate temperature as well as higher precursor concentration can effectively increase Ce(Ⅲ) cations. The properly high temperature might promote the reducing process of CeO2, while much higher temperature will result in a significant size increase which might dramatically decrease the concentration of oxygen vacancies.

In conclusion, the synthesis of CeO2 NPs involves a delicate balance of precursor concentration, reaction temperature, and the presence of certain reagents such as PVP and DMF. The size of the resultant NPs can be controlled by adjusting these parameters.

The synthesis process described in the article results in CuCo2O4 nanorods with a width of 200-400 nm and a length of 1.0-2.0 μm. The nanorods are formed through a calcination reaction of a bimetal-organic framework (MOF) precursor, specifically Cu/Co-MOF. 

The preparation process of CuCo2O4 nanorods consists of the formation of the bimetal-organic framework and the following transformation from MOF to metal oxides by calcination. The bimetal-organic framework was prepared using the metal ionic Co2+ and Cu2+ as metallic nodes, 2-methylimidazole as ligand and deionized water as solvent through a coprecipitation reaction. The obtained product has a rod-like structure with a smooth surface, and is about 200-500 nm in width and 1.0-3.0 μm in length. 

To investigate the influence of calcination temperatures, the products of Cu/Co MOF were heated at different temperatures and their XRD patterns were recorded. After calcination at 300 ℃, 350 ℃ and 400 ℃, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Cu/Co-MOF totally vanish, and a series of new peaks appear. The calcined products of Cu/Co MOFs at 300 ℃ and 350 ℃ show a series of consistent diffraction peaks belonging to the characteristic crystallite of Co3O4. The peaks at 31.2, 36.9, 38.6, 44.8 and 65.2 are indexed to the crystal plane of (220), (311), (222), (400) and (440), and meanwhile, no second phase exists, which demonstrates that Cu ion can replace the site of Co ion of Co3O4 to form CuCo2O4.

The morphology of CuCo2O4 obtained at 300 ℃ was characterized by SEM and TEM. The calcined sample shows inherited nanorod shape from its precursor, but a slight shrink in size is observed due to the decomposition of organic ligand. In the amplified SEM image, there are numerous dispersed small nanoparticles on the surface of the nanorods, inducing a rough surface not consistent with the smooth surface of their precursors. 

The equipment used in the process includes a field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, SU-8010, Hitach, Japan), a transmission electron microscope (TEM, Tecnai G220, FEI, USA) and a high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEM-2100Plus, JEOL, Japan) for imaging the obtained products. The composition and crystal analysis were confirmed from X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns using a multipurpose X-ray diffraction instrument (Empyrean, PANalytical B. V., Holland). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to measure the elemental composition and electronic state on an ESCALAB 250 spectrometer (Thermo Fisher, USA). The N2 isothermal adsorption and desorption curves were obtained from an ASAP 2020 analyzer (Micromeritics, USA). The absorbance measurement was performed on a UV-vis spectrophotometer (TU-1901, Beijing Persee, China).

MnCo2O4 submicrospheres were prepared via a hydrothermal reaction followed by an annealing process. Initially, 1 mmol of manganese sulfate hydrate (MnSO4·H2O) and 2 mmol of cobalt sulfate hydrate (CoSO4·7H2O) were dissolved into 65 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) and 10 mL of distilled water. The mixture was stirred magnetically for an hour to obtain a pink solution, after which 30 mmol NH4HCO3 powder was added slowly. After stirring for another 30 minutes, the resulting homogeneous solution was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 200 ◦C for 20 hours. 

The precipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed with distilled water and ethanol three times, followed by vacuum drying at 40 ◦C overnight. Finally, the precursor was calcined at 600 ◦C in air for 10 hours with a ramping rate of 2 ◦C min−1 to harvest MnCo2O4 products.

The equipment used in this process included a magnetic stirrer, a stainless-steel autoclave, a centrifuge, a vacuum dryer, and a calcination oven. The reagents used were manganese sulfate hydrate, cobalt sulfate hydrate, ethylene glycol, distilled water, and NH4HCO3. 

Please note that this method was used for the synthesis of MnCo2O4 submicrospheres and not specifically for 60 nm MnCo2O4 nanoparticles. The size of the particles produced may vary depending on the specific conditions and parameters of the experiment, which are not detailed in the article.

The synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) was achieved using a one-step green strategy based on a solution-phase method at room temperature. This method is template-free and surfactant-free. The reagents used in the synthesis include a freshly prepared NaBH4 solution (10 mM) and a clear purple CoCl2 solution (2 mM). The NaBH4 solution was dropwise added into the CoCl2 solution under gentle stirring and further incubation at room temperature overnight.

Upon the addition of the reducing agent NaBH4, the CoCl2 solution rapidly turned grey and produced bubbles, probably due to the reduction of Co2+ to Co and the generation of H2. Subsequently, the grey suspension quickly became black because the newly generated Co was very unstable and could be spontaneously oxidized to CoO swiftly by the dissolved oxygen. Further, some of the black CoO was slowly oxidized to Co2O3 by oxygen, to form Co3O4, indicated by the gradual appearance of a yellowish-brown suspension during continuous stirring at 25 °C for 12 h.

The morphology of the as-synthesized nanostructure was examined by SEM and TEM, which revealed a hierarchical flower-like sphere. The nanospheres were composed of sheets ranging from several nanometers to a dozen nanometers. The formation mechanism of nanoflowers may be because the initial Co3O4 nanosheets have higher surface energy and tend to reduce surface energy during growth, so the nanosheets will further aggregate into spheres. Finally, a graded nanoflower sphere composed of nanosheets is stably formed. The size of Co3O4 nanoflowers is 360 ± 20 nm, indicating that the synthetic method is controllable and reproducible.

The XRD patterns of the synthesized sample can be indexed to the Co2+Co3+2O4. The XPS spectrum was employed to confirm the valence states of the sample, indicating the co-existence of Co and O in the sample. For Co 2p, four fitted peaks can be observed centered at 780.4 eV, 782.0 eV, 795.8 eV, and 797.5 eV, related to Co3+ 2p3/2, Co2+ 2p3/2, Co3+ 2p1/2, and Co2+ 2p1/2, respectively. The O 1s high-resolution spectrum region displays three peaks locating at 530.1 eV (for surface lattice oxygen), 531.2 eV (for oxygen vacancies).

In conclusion, the synthesis of Co3O4 NPs involves a one-step green strategy at room temperature using NaBH4 and CoCl2 solutions, with the resultant NPs exhibiting a hierarchical flower-like sphere morphology and a size of 360 ± 20 nm.

The synthesis of MoO3 nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the provided text. The process involves the controlled catalytic oxidative dissolution of micrometer-sized molybdenum powders. 

To begin with, 10 mL of H2O was added to 1.0 g of molybdenum and stirred well at room temperature. Following this, 10 mL of H2O2 (30%, v/v) and 2 mL of acetic acid (99.5%, v/v) were gently injected into the molybdenum solution. The solution was then stirred until the color changed from black to yellow at 0°C. The reaction mixture was stirred continuously overnight at 37°C. 

The obtained MoO3 NP solution was finally filtered through a 0.22 µm microporous membrane, dialyzed against purified water for 72 hours and stored at 4 °C away from light. 

The characterization of the synthesized MoO3 NPs was performed using various techniques. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were measured on a TecnaiG2 F30 HRTEM (Netherlands, FEI). The TEM image shows that the MoO3 NPs are well dispersed with an average diameter of 2.0-4.0 nm. 

X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectroscopy was performed on an X’Pert PRO X-ray powder diffractometer (Netherlands, PANalytical). The XRD spectrum of the MoO3 NPs showed peaks at 12.82°, 25.75°, and 39.06°, which were assigned to the (020), (040), and (060) planes, respectively. 

Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded with an iS50 Fourier transform (FT)-IR spectrophotometer (Thermo). The FT-IR spectrum showed three main peaks at 560, 875, and 984 cm-1, which can be assigned to the bending mode of the Mo-O-Mo entity, the Mo-O-Mo stretching vibration of Mo6+, and the terminal Mo=O bond, respectively. 

The UV-vis absorption spectrum of the MoO3 NPs was collected using a UV-2600 ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectrophotometer (Shimadzu). The spectrum exhibits a narrow absorption band between 200 and 300 nm. 

The text does not specify the exact parameters for synthesizing 3 nm MoO3 NPs. However, the described procedure resulted in NPs with an average diameter of 2.0-4.0 nm.

The article mentions two methods for synthesizing polymer-coated cerium oxide nanoparticles: an in situ procedure and a stepwise method. In the in situ procedure, the polymer is present in solution at the time of the initial formation of the cerium oxide nanocrystals. This influences both the nucleation and the growth of the initial nanocrystal, resulting in nanoparticles with a small nanocrystal core surrounded by a thin polymeric coating. 

In the stepwise method, the polymer is added at a specific time after the initial formation of the nanocrystals. This method has been reported for the synthesis of polymer-coated iron oxide nanoparticles and yielded nanoparticles with a thicker polymer coating than those from the in situ process.

The use of a polymer with a smaller molecular weight in the synthesis of polymer-coated nanoceria allows the formation of nanoparticles with an even thinner coating than those obtained with dextran using either the in situ or the stepwise method.

The use of a polymer with a smaller molecular weight in the synthesis of polymer-coated nanoceria is advantageous, because it allows the formation of nanoparticles with an even thinner coating than those obtained with dextran (10 kDa) using either the in situ or the stepwise method. For the in situ nanoceria preparations coated with poly(acrylic acid) (isPNC), the average hydrodynamic diameter of the nanoparticles was 5 nm; whereas for the stepwise preparation (swPNC), a value of 12 nm was obtained.

However, the article does not provide specific details on the quantities of reagents used, the exact timing for the addition of the polymer, or the equipment used in the synthesis process.

The synthesis of MnOx microspheres, which can be considered as nanoparticles (NPs), is described in the article. The process involves a multi-stage, template-assisted protocol using carboxyl functionalized monodisperse-porous polymethacrylate microspheres as the template. 

The first step involves the synthesis of monodisperse-porous poly(methacrylic acid-co-ethylene dimethacrylate), or poly(MAA-co-EDMA), microspheres. This is achieved using poly(glycidyl methacrylate) particles as the seed latex, via a multi-stage microsuspension polymerization. 

For the synthesis of MnOx microspheres, poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres are dispersed in an aqueous KMnO4 solution (25 mL, 20 mg mL1) and the pH is adjusted to 8.0 using 0.5 M NH4OH solution. The medium is stirred at 300 rpm for 24 hours at room temperature for the adsorption of the formed manganese oxide nanoparticles by the template material. HNO3 solution (3.5 mL, 20% w/w) is added and the resulting dispersion is further stirred at 300 rpm for 24 hours at room temperature. 

The polymer/manganese oxide composite microspheres are isolated from the reaction medium by centrifugation at 5000 rpm for 5 minutes. The product containing large-size, monodisperse polymer/manganese oxide composite microspheres (ca. 3.7 mm) and small-size sub-micron particles is redispersed within aqueous medium containing sodium dodecyl sulfate (20 mL, 1% w/w) by sonication for 30 seconds (180 W, 50 Hertz). 

The composite microspheres are then dried at 80 1C for 24 hours in a vacuum-oven. For obtaining monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres by the removal of the polymeric template, the composite microspheres are calcined at temperatures ranging between 380 and 560 1C for 4 hours, in an air atmosphere, with a heating rate of 1 1C min1.

The mean size of the poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres is one of the most important parameters controlling the mean size of the MnOx microspheres. Porous poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres with different mean size values were synthesized by changing the monomer/seed latex ratio in the multistage microsuspension polymerization protocol. 

In these runs, satisfactory overall monomer conversions (i.e. higher than 82% w/w) were obtained. MnOx microspheres in the size range 3.2–5.1 mm were obtained by using poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres in the size range 4.5–7.1 mm. As seen in the article, MnOx microspheres with higher size were obtained by using larger poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres as the starting material. However, no significant change in the porous properties of MnOx microspheres was observed by changing the mean size of the starting material. 

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 4500 nm MnO2 NPs. However, the described method can potentially be adjusted to achieve this size by modifying parameters such as the size of the starting poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres and the conditions of the calcination process.

The synthesis of MnOx microspheres, which can be considered as nanoparticles (NPs), is described in the article. The process involves a multi-stage, template-assisted protocol. The template used is carboxyl functionalized monodisperse-porous polymethacrylic acid-co-ethylene dimethacrylate (poly(MAA-co-EDMA)) microspheres, which are 5.3 mm in size. 

The synthesis of MnOx microspheres begins with the dispersion of poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres in an aqueous KMnO4 solution (25 mL, 20 mg mL1). The pH is adjusted to 8.0 using 0.5 M NH4OH solution. The medium is stirred at 300 rpm for 24 hours at room temperature for the adsorption of the formed manganese oxide nanoparticles by the template material. HNO3 solution (3.5 mL, 20% w/w) is added and the resulting dispersion is further stirred at 300 rpm for 24 hours at room temperature. 

The polymer/manganese oxide composite microspheres are isolated from the reaction medium by centrifugation at 5000 rpm for 5 minutes. The product containing large-size, monodisperse polymer/manganese oxide composite microspheres (ca. 3.7 mm) and small-size sub-micron particles is redispersed within aqueous medium containing sodium dodecyl sulfate (20 mL, 1% w/w) by sonication for 30 seconds (180 W, 50 Hertz). 

A centrifugation–decantation protocol involving successive centrifugations at 1000 rpm for 1 or 2 minutes is followed to remove the small-size by-product from the large-size, monodisperse microspheres. The composite microspheres isolated by centrifugation are dried at 80 1C for 24 hours in a vacuum-oven. 

For obtaining monodisperse-porous MnOx microspheres by the removal of the polymeric template, the composite microspheres are calcined at temperatures ranging between 380 and 560 1C for 4 hours, in an air atmosphere, with a heating rate of 1 1C min1. 

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 4500 nm MnO2 NPs. The article mentions that MnOx microspheres in the size range 3.2–5.1 mm were obtained by using poly(MAA-co-EDMA) microspheres in the size range 4.5–7.1 mm.

The Co3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) were prepared using a simple hydrothermal method as described in the manuscript. The synthesis process involved several steps and required specific reagents and equipment.

The reagents used for the synthesis included Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O, ethanol, water, and 25% ammonia solution. The chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and used as received. The exact quantity of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O used was 0.50 g. The solution was prepared using 15 mL of ethanol and 10 mL of water. 2.5 mL of 25% ammonia was added to this solution.

The synthesis process began with the dissolution of 0.50 g of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O in the solution of ethanol and water. The 25% ammonia was then added drop by drop under vigorous stirring. This mixture was stirred in air for about 10 minutes to form a homogeneous fuscous slurry.

This suspension was then transferred into a 48 mL autoclave, sealed, and maintained at 150 °C for 3 hours. After this, the autoclave was cooled to ambient temperature naturally. The resulting black solid products were separated by centrifugation and washed with water three times. These products were then dried at 60 °C under vacuum for 4 hours, and collected for characterization.

The morphology and size of the synthesized Co3O4 NPs were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The SEM images were taken with a SU8000 scanning electron microscope (Hitachi, Japan). TEM measurements were performed on a Hitachi H-800 transmission electron microscope (Hitachi, Japan) at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The N2 adsorption and desorption isotherm was obtained at 77 K using ASAP 2020 Physisorption Analyzer (Micromeritics, USA).

The synthesized Co3O4 NPs were found to be uniform and had narrow size distributions. The nanoparticles in the TEM image were squares, indicating that the nanoparticles were nanocubes. The average edge length was about 19 nm. The standard deviation for Co3O4 particle size was ≈4%, excluding agglomerate particles. The surface area of the Co3O4 NPs using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was calculated to about 57.7 m2 g-1.

The synthesis of ultrasmall RuO2 nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out using the solvothermal method. The reagents used in the synthesis included chitosan (CS), acetic acid, and ruthenium(III) chloride trihydrate (RuCl3·3H2O). 

Initially, chitosan was dissolved in 3% acetic acid to form a 3 mg/mL solution. Then, 25 mg of RuCl3·3H2O was added to the chitosan solution and stirred for 30 minutes. This mixture was then transferred to a round-bottomed flask. 

The mixed solution was heated to 120 °C for 6 hours. After the heating process, a dark green solution was obtained. This solution was then purified by dialysis with distilled water at room temperature for 48 hours. The molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) for the dialysis process was 3500.

The characterization of the synthesized RuO2NPs was performed using various techniques. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to observe the morphology of the NPs. The elemental concentration of Ru was measured by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The hydrodynamic particle size of the NPs was recorded using a Malvern Zetasizer Nanoseries. UV−vis absorption spectroscopy was used to study the optical properties of the NPs.

The article does not specify the exact size of the synthesized RuO2NPs. However, the term "ultrasmall" is used to describe the NPs, suggesting that they are likely to be in the nanometer range. The exact size of the NPs would likely depend on the specific conditions of the synthesis, such as the concentration of the reagents, the temperature, and the duration of the heating process.

The synthesis of Rhodium nanoparticles (RhNPs) was carried out according to the experimental procedure described in a previous work. The RhNPs were synthesized by reducing 0.25 mM of RhCl3·3H2O with 2.5 mM borohydride in the presence of 0.25 mM citrate ions as stabilizers and mixing for 10 min under stirring.

The characterization of RhNPs was performed with Atomic force microscopy (AFM) and Dynamic light scattering (DLS). AFM images were obtained in tapping mode with a Multimode Nanoscope 3D using Tap300G silicon cantilevers with a force constant of ≈20–75 N m−1 and tip radius < 10 nm. DLS measurements were performed on a Malvern Zetasizer Nano ZS instrument, using a red laser at 25 °C.

The AFM images show relatively uniform RhNPs without aggregates. Based on the topographical height profile (section analysis) the size of the particles lied between 4.0 and 8.0 nm with an average size of 6.5 nm (depth profile analysis) while the average hydrodynamic diameter of the particles, calculated by DLS, was equal to 9.2 nm.

The concentration of RhNPs was calculated according to the method described previously assuming the complete reduction of RhCl3 and that each nanoparticle has a spherical shape with a uniform face centered cubic (fcc) structure. The molar concentration of RhNPs of 7 nm size was calculated to be 1.4 nmol L−1 which corresponds to 8.4 × 1011 nanoparticles per mL (nps mL−1) of solution.

The synthesis of MoS2 NFs (nanoflakes), which are similar to nanoparticles, is described in the provided text. The MoS2 NFs were synthesized by a simple, one-step hydrothermal route in an ethylene glycol/water mixed solvent. The process began with 13 mg of an unspecified substance being dissolved into 15 mL of an aqueous solution containing 10 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) and 5 mL of deionized water. After stirring for 10 minutes, the solution was poured into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated up to 180 degrees Celsius for 12 hours.

The resulting precipitate was then centrifuged and washed with ethanol and deionized water three times. After washing, the precipitate was lyophilized for further use. The size of the synthesized MoS2 NFs was found to be approximately 390 nm, as shown by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) imaging.

The MoS2 NFs were then modified by PEI, PAA, PVP, and Cys at room temperature. Typically, 10 mg of MoS2 NFs was dispersed in deionized water by sonification for 10 minutes. For PAA modified MoS2 NFs (PAA-MoS2 NFs), 180 mg of 50% PAA solution were added into the MoS2 NFs solution. For PEI (PEI-MoS2 NFs), PVP(PVP-MoS2 NFs), and Cys modified MoS2 NFs (Cys-MoS2 NFs), 90 mg of PVP, PEI, and Cys powders were respectively dissolved into the MoS2 NFs solution. After sonification for another 10 minutes, all the solutions were magnetically stirred for 12 hours in the dark.

The mixtures were then centrifuged and washed with deionized water five times to remove unbounded molecules. The final products were centrifuged and lyophilized for further analysis. The characterization of the MoS2 NFs was carried out using various analytical methods including Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM), Raman spectroscopy, Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, and X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS). 

The text does not specify the exact amount of the initial substance (in mmols) used for the synthesis of the MoS2 NFs.

The synthesis of MoS2 NFs (nanoflakes), which are similar to nanoparticles, is described in the provided text. The MoS2 NFs were synthesized by a simple, one-step hydrothermal route in an ethylene glycol/water mixed solvent. The size of the synthesized MoS2 NFs was approximately 390 nm.

The synthesis process began with 13 mg of an unspecified substance being dissolved into 15 mL of an aqueous solution containing 10 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) and 5 mL of deionized water. After stirring for 10 minutes, the solution was poured into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated up to 180 oC for 12 hours. The resulting precipitate was then centrifuged and washed with ethanol and deionized water three times, and then lyophilized for further use.

The surface of the MoS2 NFs was then modified by PEI, PAA, PVP, and Cys at room temperature. Typically, 10 mg of MoS2 NFs was dispersed in deionized water by sonification for 10 minutes. For PAA modified MoS2 NFs (PAA-MoS2 NFs), 180 mg of 50% PAA solution were added into the MoS2 NFs solution. For PEI (PEI-MoS2 NFs), PVP(PVP-MoS2 NFs), and Cys modified MoS2 NFs (Cys-MoS2 NFs), 90 mg of PVP, PEI, and Cys powders were respectively dissolved into the MoS2 NFs solution. After sonification for another 10 minutes, all the solutions were magnetically stirred for 12 hours in the dark. Then the mixtures were centrifuged and washed with deionized water five times to remove unbounded molecules. The final products were centrifuged and lyophilized for further analysis.

The synthesized MoS2 NFs were characterized using various analytical methods. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image was obtained by the TecnaiG2 T20 U-TWIN transmission electron microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX, HORIBA EMAX-250). Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) image was obtained by the S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi High Technologies, Japan). Raman spectra were recorded by Raman spectrometer (Horiba LabRam HR 800). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Thermo Fisher iN10-IZ10 spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out with an ESCALab220i-XL spectrometer using a twin-anode Al Kα (1486.6 eV) X-ray source. All the spectra were calibrated to the binding energy of adventitious C1s peak at 284.8 eV. Zeta potentials of MoS2 nanomaterials were measured by a Zeta potential/Particle system (PSS Nicomp TM 380, Santa Barbara, CA, USA). 

The text does not specify the exact substance that was initially dissolved into the aqueous solution to begin the synthesis process.

The Raman spectrum demonstrated a mixture phase of raw MoS2 NFs which consists of 1T and 2H phase. After being modified with PVP, PEI, PAA, and Cys, the sizes and morphologies of these MoS2 did not change. The pure MoS2 NFs and modified MoS2 NFs were further analyzed by FT-IR spectra. The XPS analysis revealed more details of raw MoS2 NFs and modified MoS2 NFs. The MoS2 NFs were synthesized by a simple, one-step hydrothermal route in an ethylene glycol/water mixed solvent. The process began with 13g of an unspecified substance being dissolved into 15 mL of an aqueous solution containing 10 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) and 5 mL of deionized water. After stirring for 10 minutes, the solution was poured into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated up to 180 oC for 12 hours. 

The as-obtained precipitate was then centrifuged and washed with ethanol and deionized water three times and lyophilized for further use. The size of the synthesized MoS2 NFs was approximately 390 nm, as shown by the Transmission electron microscope (TEM) image. 

For surface modification of MoS2 NFs, MoS2 NFs were modified by PEI, PAA, PVP, and Cys at room temperature. Typically, 10 mg of MoS2 NFs was dispersed in deionized water by sonification for 10 minutes. For PAA modified MoS2 NFs (PAA-MoS2 NFs), 180 mg of 50% PAA solution were added into the MoS2 NFs solution. For PEI (PEI-MoS2 NFs), PVP(PVP-MoS2 NFs), and Cys modified MoS2 NFs (Cys-MoS2 NFs), 90 mg of PVP, PEI, and Cys powders were respectively dissolved into the MoS2 NFs solution. After sonification for another 10 minutes, all the solutions were magnetically stirred for 12 hours in the dark. 

Then the mixtures were centrifuged and washed with deionized water five times to remove unbounded molecules. The final products were centrifuged and lyophilized for further analysis. The characterization of the MoS2 NFs was done using various analytical methods including Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), Raman spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). 

The text does not provide specific information on the mmols of the reagents used in the synthesis process.

The synthesis of MoS2 NFs (nanoflakes), which are similar to nanoparticles, is described in the provided text. The MoS2 NFs were synthesized by a simple, one-step hydrothermal route in an ethylene glycol/water mixed solvent. The process began with 13g of the substance being dissolved into 15 mL of an aqueous solution containing 10 mL of ethylene glycol (EG) and 5 mL of deionized water. This solution was stirred for 10 minutes.

After stirring, the solution was poured into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated up to 180 oC for 12 hours. The as-obtained precipitate was then centrifuged and washed with ethanol and deionized water three times. The precipitate was then lyophilized for further use.

The surface modification of the MoS2 NFs was carried out at room temperature. Typically, 10 mg of MoS2 NFs was dispersed in deionized water by sonification for 10 minutes. For PAA modified MoS2 NFs (PAA-MoS2 NFs), 180 mg of 50% PAA solution were added into the MoS2 NFs solution. For PEI (PEI-MoS2 NFs), PVP(PVP-MoS2 NFs), and Cys modified MoS2 NFs (Cys-MoS2 NFs), 90 mg of PVP, PEI, and Cys powders were respectively dissolved into the MoS2 NFs solution. After sonification for another 10 minutes, all the solutions were magnetically stirred for 12 hours in the dark.

The mixtures were then centrifuged and washed with deionized water five times to remove unbounded molecules. The final products were centrifuged and lyophilized for further analysis. The size of the synthesized MoS2 NFs was found to be ~390 nm, as shown by the Transmission electron microscope (TEM) image.

The characterization of the synthesized MoS2 NFs was carried out using various analytical methods. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image was obtained by the TecnaiG2 T20 U-TWIN transmission electron microscope equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrum (EDX, HORIBA EMAX-250). Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) image was obtained by the S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi High Technologies, Japan). Other methods used for characterization included Raman spectrometer (Horiba LabRam HR 800), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra recorded on a Thermo Fisher iN10-IZ10 spectrometer, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements carried out with an ESCALab220i-XL spectrometer.
