The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 20 nm Au nanoparticles (AuNPs), including the exact equipment, reagents, and mmols used. However, it does mention that in this study, monodisperse AuNPs with 15-20 nm in diameter are eco-friendly fabricated using cyclodextrin (CD) molecules as both reducing agents and stabilizers. This is different from previous approaches for the fabrication of macrocycle-AuNP hybrid nanomaterials, where harsh reagents and/or conditions such as NaBH4, NaOH, thiols, etc. were commonly used. These reagents are not only environmentally unfriendly, but their extremely high binding affinity and/or strong interactions might passivate/block the surface properties of AuNPs.

The article also mentions that the specific properties/applications of AuNPs depend on a series of factors including particle size, shape, surface chemistry, aggregation state, and preparation method. For example, a relatively large size (> 10 nm) is essential for distinct surface plasmon resonance (SPR) band, while catalytic activity is commonly believed to be the privilege of ultra-small AuNPs (~ 2 nm).

In terms of the hybrid materials, pre-existing researches mainly concentrate on their host-guest interaction based properties/functions/applications. Considering that macrocyclic supramolecules possess unique topological structures, their interactions with AuNPs might unusually modulate the particle surface chemistry and result in novel properties and corresponding potential applications.

In this study, the researchers first demonstrate a three-in-one nano-platform for sensing, self-assembly, and cascade catalysis enabled by CD modified AuNPs (CD@AuNPs). The CD@AuNPs can act as building blocks and assemble into well-defined one- and two-dimensional (1D/2D) superstructures with the assistance of tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (TCPP) as mediator.

The synthesis of β-CD protected Cu-NCs (Copper Nanoclusters) was carried out using a specific procedure. The reactants concentration including N2H4, NaOH, Cu (NO3)2, 6-SH-β-CD and reaction time, reaction temperature were investigated to obtain the optimal synthetic conditions. 

In a typical synthesis, 2 mL of 5 mM 6-SH-β-CD and 250 μL of 20 mM Cu(NO3)2 solution were first dissolved in 1 mL of Milli-Q water by stirring for 10 min at 45 °C. Then, 1.6 mL of 0.1 M NaOH was added and homogenized by stirring for 2 min. After that, 15 μL of N2H4 (50 wt%) was added, and the mixture was heated at 45 °C for 5 h. 

The Cu-NCs were then purified via dialysis to remove unreacted Cu2+. The formation of water-soluble and blue-emitting Cu-NCs was characterized using TEM, FTIR, fluorescence, absorption spectra and Raman spectra. The as-prepared β-CD protected Cu-NCs was diluted 50 times for TEM detection. The TEM image showed the β-CD protected Cu-NCs displayed an average diameter of 2 nm.

The optical properties of Cu-NCs were characterized by fluorescence and absorption spectra. The maximum fluorescence excitation and emission wavelength of β-CD-protected Cu-NCs were 360 nm and 450 nm. Compared to the absorption peak of β-CD at 220 nm, a new absorption peak at 270 nm was presented in the absorption curve of the β-CD protected Cu-NCs. 

The long time stability of β-CD protected Cu-NCs was also investigated. The fluorescence intensity of the Cu-NCs changed less than 5 % of its initial intensity after one month’s storage in the refrigerator which indicated its excellent aqueous stability. 

The UV–Vis absorption measurements were performed on a Lambda 35 UV analyzer. The fluorescence intensity was recorded on a LS55 fluorescence spectrometer. The TEM images of the prepared samples were examined using a TecnaiG20 transmission electron microscope. Fourier Transform Infra-Red (FTIR) spectra were taken with a spectrum on a FTIR spectrophotometer at room temperature. The Raman spectra were recorded on a LabRAM HR Raman Spectrometer.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 420 nm or other size boron nitride nanoparticles (BN NPs). The text mainly discusses the characterization, modification, and application of c-BN particles, but it does not detail the synthesis process or the parameters involved in creating these particles of a specific size. 

The characterization of c-BN is discussed in the article. The XRD pattern of the sample demonstrates the presence of c-BN. The corresponding scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis shows that c-BN particles are of irregular-particle shape. A statistical analysis of 250 particles according to SEM data reveals that the diameter of c-BN particles is mainly distributed in 100-800 nm with the average size of approximately 420 nm. Complementary analytical data on c-BN particles using energy-dispersive analysis of X-rays (EDX) confirm that only boron and nitrogen are present.

The modification of c-BN is also mentioned. C-BN was modified by ion implantation and thermal annealing, respectively. In an ion Implantation experiment, the sample was treated by ions at energy of 200 keV and doses of 1×1015 cm-2, using an ion implanter. The implanted ion species are helium, boron and nitrogen, respectively. In an annealing experiment, c-BN was subjected to heat treatment at 800°C for 2 hours. The annealing is done in a nitrogen atmosphere and air, respectively.

The article also discusses the peroxidase-like activity of c-BN particles. They are capable of catalyzing typical peroxidase reactions, using 3 typical peroxidase substrates, including 3,3'-Diaminobenzidine (DAB), o-Phenylenediamine (OPD) and 3,3,5,5-Tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) in the presence of H2O2 to produce a brown, orange, and blue color reaction, respectively.

However, the specific synthesis process, including the equipment, reagents, and mmols used to create 420 nm or other size BN NPs, is not detailed in the provided text.

The synthesis of hierarchical BiOBr microspheres, which are composed of nanosheets, is described in the article. The process involves a solvothermal method. 

The materials required for the synthesis include Bismuth nitrate (Bi(NO3)3$5H2O), 1-buty-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([Bmim]Br), and ethylene glycol (EG). These were purchased from Kelong Chemical Reagents Company (Chengdu, China). All chemicals used in this study were of commercially available analytical grade and used without further purification.

The preparation of the hierarchical BiOBr microspheres was carried out as follows: 1 mmol of Bi(NO3)3$5H2O was dissolved in 15 mL of ethylene glycol to form a clear solution by ultrasound, followed by the addition of 1 mmol of [Bmim]Br ionic liquid. The mixture was then transferred into a 20 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave which was sealed and heated at 160 C for 12 hours. After the heat treatment, the autoclave was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, and the products (IL–EG–BiOBr) were collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol and deionized water thoroughly, and dried at 60 C in air. 

For comparison, BiOBr products were synthesized under the same conditions by replacing [Bmim]Br with KBr (EG–BiOBr) or EG solvent with water (IL–water–BiOBr). The BiOBr products were also synthesized by a similar hydrothermal method using both water as solvent and KBr as bromide source (water–BiOBr).

The synthesized BiOBr microspheres were characterized using various techniques. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were recorded on a Rigaku Dmax/Ultima IV diffractometer with monochromatized Cu Ka radiation (l ¼ 0.15418 nm). The morphology was observed with a JEOL JSM-6510LV scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G20). The elemental composition of the samples were characterized by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, Oxford instruments X-Max). UV-vis diffused reflectance spectra of the samples were obtained for the dry-pressed film samples using a UV-vis spectrophotometer (UV-3600, Shimadzu, Japan). BaSO4 was used as a reflectance standard in a UV-vis diffuse reflectance experiment.

The article does not specify the size of the synthesized BiOBr nanoparticles, but it mentions that the BiOBr product was composed of nanosheets assembled cotton-like solid spheres with diameters of about 1–2 mm. The detailed structure of the sample was further characterized using high-resolution TEM (HRTEM). The lattice spacing of the planes is 0.269 nm, as marked in the image, agreeing well with the spacing of the (110) planes of BiOBr.

The synthesis of BiOI nanostructures, including those with a size of approximately 20 nm, is described in the article. The BiOI nanostructures were synthesized from Bi3+ ions and iodide ions (I-) in aqueous solution through the reaction Bi3+ + I- + H2O - BiOI(s) + 2H+ at room temperature. 

For the preparation of BiOI nanostructures, 50 mM Tris–borate (pH 7.0, 1 mL), Bi(NO3)2 (10 mM, 50 mL), and potassium iodide (10 mM, 50 mL) were sequentially added to DI water (3.9 mL) under continuous stirring, and subsequently reacted at ambient temperature for 2 h in the dark. 

The BiOI nanostructures were characterized using various techniques. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the BiOI nanonetworks were obtained using a Tecnai 20 G2 S-twin transmission electron microscope. Samples for X-ray diffraction (XRD) were prepared by depositing the BiOI nanostructure solution on glass slides. XRD measurements were carried out at room temperature using a Rigaku 18 kW rotating anode source X-ray diffractometer (operated at 50 kV and 100 mA) with a Cu Ka1 line (l = 1.54 Å). Samples for scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were prepared by depositing the BiOI nanostructure solution on a Si(100) wafer prior to measurement with a field emission SEM (JSM-6500F, JEOL, Ltd, Tokyo, Japan). 

The TEM, AFM, and SEM images reveal that BiOI has a nanonetwork-like structure that is formed through the connection of high-density small nanoplates (B20 nm) with thickness around B5 nm. The slow growth rate of BiOI and the hydrolysis of iodide result in the formation of BiOI having a nanonetwork structure. The yields of these nanostructures were all almost the same (B60%). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns reveal that the BiOI nanostructures have typical tetragonal crystal structures and are predominantly exposed along the {001} facet. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of BiOI nanostructures, including those with a size of approximately 20 nm, involves the reaction of Bi3+ ions and iodide ions in an aqueous solution at room temperature, with the use of specific reagents and under specific conditions. The resulting nanostructures are characterized by various techniques to confirm their size, structure, and other properties.

For determination of the concentrations of metal ions using ICP-MS, the BiOI nanostructure samples were prepared in 2% HNO3. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a VG ESCA Scientific theta probe spectrometer.

The TEM, AFM, and SEM images reveal that BiOI has a nanonetwork-like structure that is formed through the connection of high-density small nanoplates (approximately 20 nm) with a thickness around 5 nm. The slow growth rate of BiOI and the hydrolysis of iodide result in the formation of BiOI having a nanonetwork structure. The yields of these nanostructures were almost the same (approximately 60%). The XRD patterns reveal that the BiOI nanostructures have typical tetragonal crystal structures and are predominantly exposed along the {001} facet. Quantitative analysis using XPS, ICP-OES or ICP-MS reveals that the ratios of Bi to I in the BiOI nanostructures are higher than 1. This finding is consistent with the results of XRD, which shows that Bi2O3 is present in the BiOI nanostructures.

The synthesis of BiOI nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the article through a facile coprecipitation method. The process involves the use of several reagents and specific conditions. 

In a typical procedure, 10.0 mmol of Bi(NO3)3⋅5H2O was added into 40 mL ethylene glycol (EG) under magnetic stirring to form a transparent solution. Meanwhile, 10.0 mmol of KI was dissolved in 40 mL water under magnetic stirring to obtain a transparent solution. Then the KI solution was added dropwise into the Bi(NO3)3 solutions slowly under vigorous stirring to form a final suspension. Afterwards, the pH value of the suspension was adjusted to 7.0 by 2.0 M NaOH. Then the suspension was sequentially stirred for 24 h. Finally, the precipitates were collected and washed several times by water and absolute ethyl alcohol (EA), followed by drying at 60 °C in air for 6 h. The final products BiOI nanoflowers were obtained, which were denoted as BiOI-F.

In addition, other BiOI samples were prepared as control. By using EA as the solvent instead of EG, BiOI microspheres were synthesized in a similar way with BiOI-F, which were denoted as BiOI-S. BiOI large plates were prepared by a facile hydrothermal method. Typically, 10.0 mmol of Bi(NO3)3⋅5H2O was dispersed in 40 mL water mixed with 20 mL NaOH aqueous solution (0.75 M) with ultrasonic for 30 min to form a uniform suspension. Then 20 mL KI aqueous solution (30.0 mmol) was added to the above suspension under stirring. The suspension was stirred for another 60 min and then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, maintained at 180 °C for 24 h, and cooled to room temperature naturally. The precipitates were collected by filtration, washed with water and absolute ethyl alcohol several times, respectively, dried at 60 °C in air for 6 h. And BiOI large plates were obtained and denoted as BiOI-LP.

As increasing the NaOH amount to 1.0 M and 1.5 M during the reaction, BiOI nanoplates and Bi5O7I nanobelts could be obtained, which were denoted as BiOI-NP and Bi5O7I-B, respectively. 

The article does not specify the exact size of the nanoparticles synthesized, but the FESEM images reveal that the hierarchical flower-like nanostructures were self-assembled by many nanoplates with a thickness of 10 nm and a width of 100 nm.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 2500 nm Co4N nanoparticles. However, it does detail the preparation of Co4N nanowires (NWs), which might be similar in some aspects. 

The materials and reagents used in the synthesis of Co4N NWs include Na2HPO4, NaH2PO4·2H2O, H2O2 (30%), ethanol, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), Co(NO3)2·6H2O, NH4F, and urea. These were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Terephthalic acid (TA) was purchased from Aladdin Reagent Company (Shanghai, China). 3,3′,5,5′-Teramethylbenzidine (TMB), glucose, and glucose oxidase (GOx) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, USA). All solutions were prepared using deionized (DI) water (>18 MΩ).

The apparatus used in the synthesis includes field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM; Hitachi S-4800, Tokyo, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEOL 2000) for observing the morphologies of Co4N and the precursor. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on an X’pert XRD spectrometer (Philips, Guildford, Surrey, UK) with a Cu Kα X-ray source. UV–Vis absorption spectra were recorded on a Lambda Bio/XLS+ UV–vis spectrophotometer (Perkin Elmer, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) profiles were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Physical Electronics 5600 spectrometer using Al Ka radiation at 13 kV as the excitation source.

The Co4N NWs were prepared by nitridation using Co(OH)(CO3)0.5·xH2O as the precursor. Briefly, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.291 g), NH4F (0.093 g), and urea (0.30 g) were dissolved in 35 mL of deionized water under vigorous stirring for 30 min. The solution was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, and the temperature was maintained at 120°C for 6 h. The obtained precursor Co(OH)(CO3)0.5·xH2O was washed three times with DI water and dried in vacuum at 60°C. Nitridation was carried out by treating Co(OH)(CO3)0.5·xH2O at 500 °C for 2 h in a tube furnace under flowing NH3, affording 50 mg Co4N powder in the crucible.

The peroxidase-like activity of Co4N NWs was investigated by the catalytic oxidation of the peroxidase substrate TMB in the presence of H2O2. In a typical experiment, catalytic oxidation was carried out at 25 °C by mixing 15 µL of Co4N (2.0 mg mL−1) with 2.0 mL of phosphate buffer solution (PBS, 20 mM, pH 4.0) in a quartz cuvette, followed by the addition of 80 µL of TMB (20 mM) and 30 µL of H2O2 (2.0 M). The mixture was stirred with an extremely small magnetic bar for 10 min, affording a blue color solution. After stirring was completed, Co4N NWs settled to the bottom of the cuvette, and the upper clear blue solution was used for absorption measurement. The blue color was spectrophotometrically monitored by measuring the absorbance change at 652 nm. All catalytic experiments were carried out under daylight, unless otherwise stated. 

Please note that the synthesis of nanoparticles might require different conditions and parameters, and the information provided here is specific to the synthesis of Co4N NWs as described in the article.

The synthesis of CoOOH nanoflakes, which are essentially nanoparticles (NPs) with an average flake size of about 100 nm, is described in the article. The procedure is based on a previous report with some modifications.

The reagents used for the synthesis include Cobaltous chloride (CoCl2·6H2O) and sodium hypochlorite pentahydrate (NaClO·5H2O) which were bought from Tokyo Chemical Industry (TCI) Co. Ltd. (Tokyo, Japan). Sodium hydroxide (NaOH) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All chemicals were used as received without further purification. Ultrapure water was produced by the Millipore Milli-Q water purification system (Billerica, MA, USA) and had an electric resistance of >18.25 MΩ.

The synthesis process is as follows: 125 μL of 1.0 M NaOH solution were added to 500 μL of 10 mM CoCl2 solution with stirring. After sonicating for 10 min, 25 μL 0.9 M sodium hypochlorite (NaClO) solution were added to the mixture and sonication was performed for another 30 min. Subsequently, the CoOOH nanoflakes were isolated by centrifugation, washed several times with ultrapure water, and re-dispersed into ultrapure water for further experiments.

The characterization of the synthesized CoOOH nanoflakes was carried out using various equipment. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) were carried out on a field-emission 2100F TEM (JEOL, Japan) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The morphology of the nanoflakes was examined by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, S-4800, Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of CoOOH nanoflakes were identified via a D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Billerica, MA, USA) with Cu-Ka radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Fourier transform infrared absorption (FT-IR) spectra were taken with a Nexus 870 FT-IR spectrophotometer (Thermo Electron, Waltham, MA, USA). Dynamic light scattering (DLS) and zeta potential were measured using a Zetasizer 3000 HS particle size analyzer (Malvern Instruments, Malvern, UK) at room temperature. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). Adsorption spectra were collected by a UV-1800 UV-visible absorption spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan).

The article does not provide specific mmol quantities for the reagents used in the synthesis. However, the concentrations and volumes of the solutions used are specified, which could potentially be used to calculate the mmol quantities.

The synthesized CoOOH nanoflakes were found to have a uniform single-layered hexagonal plate-like shape, with an average flake size of about 100 nm. Once dissolved in water, the hydration size increased to about 134 nm, as measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS). Flake aggregation was not observed after long-term storage for several months since the flakes possess a large positive zeta potential of +22.12 mV. The chemical compositions of the nanoflakes were analyzed by EDS, XPS, XRD, and FT-IR.

The synthesis of Cu2-xSe@PSS NCs, where the size of the nanoparticles (NPs) ranged from 26 nm to 53 nm with an average size of 40 nm, was described in the article. The process involved several steps and the use of various reagents and equipment.

Firstly, all of the glassware used in the procedure was immersed in aqua regia for 8 hours and cleared with water prior to use. The Cu2-xSe@PSS NPs were prepared with a minor modification. Initially, 1.6 mL of 10 mg/mL PSS (Sodium polystyrene sulfonate, MW 70kD) purchased from Alfa Aesar Company in America and 5.5 mL of water were added into the round bottom flask. Then, 0.1 mL of 0.1 M SeO2 obtained from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China) and 0.3 mL of 0.4 M Vc (Ascorbic acid) purchased from Sigma Company in America were injected within 10 minutes under vigorous agitation.

Following this, the mixed solution of 0.1 mL of 0.4 M CuSO4•5H2O (Copper sulfate) acquired from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China) and 0.4 mL of 0.4 M Vc was added into the above solution. The reaction was considered complete when the solution turned green after about 10 hours at 30 °C. Finally, the mixed solution was centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 10 minutes and dialyzed for 24 hours.

The nanostructure and morphology of the Cu2-xSe@PSS NPs were characterized using various apparatus. The UV-vis absorption spectra were measured with a U-3600 spectrophotometer (Hitachi Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). Scanning electron microscopy images and transmission electron microscopy images were captured using an S-4800 scan electron microscope (SEM) (Hitachi, Japan) and a transmission electron microscope (TEM) (JEM-2100, Japan), respectively. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement was performed with a Shimadzu XRD-7000. Elemental analysis was performed on an ESCALAB 250 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) (Tyoto, Japan).

The article does not provide specific details on how to control the size of the nanoparticles to exactly 40 nm. However, it is generally understood in nanoparticle synthesis that factors such as the concentration of the reagents, the temperature, and the duration of the reaction can influence the size of the nanoparticles.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 8000 nm or other size Fe3(PO4)2 nanoparticles (NPs). However, it does detail the synthesis of Ferrous (II) phosphate nanoflowers (Fe3(PO4)2·8H2O NFs) which might be similar in process. 

The Fe3(PO4)2·8H2O NFs were synthesized by a facile coprecipitation technology. Three feeds were prepared for the synthesis. Feed 1 was the aqueous solution of 0.1% polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP); Feed 2 was the aqueous solution of 0.188 mM ferrous sulfate (FeSO4·7H2O); Feed 3 was the aqueous solution of 0.125 mM sodium phosphate tribasic (Na3PO4). 

The process began with the addition of 10 mL of Feed 2 to 40 mL of Feed 1. After stirring for 20 minutes, another 10 mL of Feed 3 was added to the mixture of Feed 1 and Feed 2. The mixture was then incubated for 2 days under ambient conditions. The navy blue solid product obtained by centrifugation was washed several times with water and ethanol, respectively, and finally dried at 40 ℃ under vacuum. The water used for the whole preparation process was purged with N2. All the above operations were conducted under the N2 atmosphere to avoid Fe2+ being oxidized by the air.

The phase characterization of the as-prepared product was performed by Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Bruker D8 advanced diffractometer by Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5418 Å). The morphological investigations were carried out with field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Su8100, Hitachi, Japan). Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) was recorded using an attached Oxford Link ISIS energy-dispersive spectrometer. 

Please note that the size of the nanoparticles might be influenced by the conditions of the synthesis process, such as the concentration of the reagents, the stirring speed, the temperature, and the duration of the reaction. The synthesis of Fe₃(PO₄)₂(OH)₂ was carried out in a stainless steel (50 ml) Teflon-lined vessel under autogenous pressure. In a typical process, 5 mmol of FeCl₂·4H2O and 10 mmol NaH₂PO₄·H₂O were dissolved in 33 ml mixed solution (Vglycol : VH₂O=1:1), followed by a vigorously stirring to obtain a homogeneous solution, into which 2 mL ammonia was added slowly. After the autoclave cooling down to room temperature naturally, the product was collected by centrifugation, and then washed with ethanol for three times.

The size and morphology of the resulted product was observed by the FE-SEM. It is seen that the obtained Fe₃(PO₄)₂(OH)₂ are monodispersed crystals in a shape of octahedron with diameter in ca. 3–8 μm. The elemental mapping analyses are provided in Fig. 1. The elemental mapping analysis pictures are shown in Fig. C-F confirm the coexistence and homogenous dispersion of Fe, P, and O elements within Fe₃(PO₄)₂(OH)₂.

The synthesis of FeSe nanoparticles (NPs) of approximately 6 nm in size was achieved through the solvothermal decomposition of a precursor complex. The precursor complex used was [Fe3(μ3-O)(μ2-O2CCH2Cl)6(H2O)3]NO3·H2O. This was reacted with sodium selenite in a 1:3 molar ratio at 150 °C under pressure for 12 hours. This process resulted in the formation of FeSe as a black powder. The reaction between the aqueous solution of the precursor complex and sodium selenite leads to the reduction of iron(III) to iron(II) and the concomitant formation of FeSe. 

The concentrations of iron and selenide ions have to be controlled very carefully during the deposition of nanoparticles. This can be easily achieved using a complex with high stability and a moderately stable selenium source. In this case, a water-soluble trinuclear oxo-bridged [Fe3(μ3-O)(μ2-O2CCH2Cl)6(H2O)3]+ core was employed as a precursor complex, and sodium selenite was used as the selenium source. 

In the reaction system, the water-soluble trinuclear iron core facilitated the slow release of iron ion and thus controlled its concentration. The existence of any anion of a strong acid often made it difficult to form metal chalcogenides, so the water-soluble iron core with chloroacetate anion, as a substitute of common iron salts, is a better precursor in many ways. Another important advantage of this precursor complex is the pH of its aqueous solution that lies in between 2.5 and 3.0, which is also suitable for the deposition of iron chalcogenides.

The crystallinity and purity of the FeSe NPs were examined by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique. The diffraction patterns of the powder materials can be indexed into pure FeSe phase crystallizing in the P4/nmm space group. The observed peaks are in good agreement with those reported for pure tetragonal phase of FeSe (JCPDS card no. 850735). The surface morphologies of the as-synthesized FeSe NPs were investigated by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM). The FeSe NPs displayed quasi-spherical morphology with average diameter of 6 nm.

The synthesis of β-MnOOH nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the article. In a typical synthesis of β-MnOOH, 4 mmol of Mn(CH3COO)24H2O and 2 g of sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) were dissolved into a 60 mL of glycerol/H2O mixed solution (glycerol:H2O = 1:5 (v/v)) at room temperature to form a mixed solution under vigorous stirring. The mixture was stirred in air for about 10 min before 10 mL of N2H4H2O and 10 mL of 8 M sodium hydroxide were added. After being continuously stirred for 10 min, the reaction mixture was transferred into a 100 mL of Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, sealed, and heated at 140 °C for 24 h. 

After the reaction was complete, the resulting solid product was collected by filtration, washed with water and absolute ethanol, and then dried at 60 °C for 24 h in air. The samples synthesized with different starting raw materials (without SDS and glycerol, without glycerol, without SDS, with SDS and glycerol, and without hydrazine) at 140 °C for 24 h were denoted as M140-1, M140-2, M140-3, M140-4, and M140-5, respectively. In the presence of hydrazine, SDS, and glycerol, the samples were also prepared at different temperatures (120, 160, and 180 °C) for 24 h and denoted as M120, M160, and M180, respectively.

The characterization of the synthesized NPs was performed using X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurement on an Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 A) with 2 ˚ θ ranging from 10° to 80° (40 kV, 40 mA). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken from a Hitachi S-4800 SEM (Japan). Transmission electron microscopic (TEM) observations were performed under a Hitachi 7650 transmission electron microscopy (Japan). The samples were also subjected to energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) during the SEM measurement.

The article does not specify the exact size of the synthesized NPs, but it mentions that the average lateral size of the irregular hexagonal nanoplates was found to be about 200 nm and the particle size distribution is uniform. The estimated D002 of the as-prepared β-MnOOH has a value of ca. 17 nm.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 100 nm MoSe2 nanoparticles. However, it does describe the preparation of few-layered MoSe2 nanosheets from commercial MoSe2 powders. 

In the experimental section, it is mentioned that MoSe2 powders were purchased from Alfa Aesar. These powders were used to prepare few-layered MoSe2 nanosheets via a simple liquid exfoliation method. Briefly, commercial MoSe2 powders (2 g) were dissolved in a 45 vol % ethanol/water mixture (200 mL) and ultrasonicated for 8 hours at 80% amplitude at 10℃. The solution was then centrifuged two times at 5000 rpm for 5 minutes and the supernatant was obtained by decantation. The suction filtration was carried out to remove ethanol and the filtered residue was redispersed into DI water by bath sonication for 10 minutes. Followed by centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 3 minutes, the supernatant was collected as the few-layered MoSe2 nanosheets solution for further characterizations.

Materials characterization was performed using a Rigaku D/Max-IIIA X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation for X-ray powder diffraction (XRD). Ultraviolet-Visible (UV-Vis) absorption spectra of the samples were obtained using a UV 3150 spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images were acquired using an FEI Tecnai G2 F30 transition electron microscope equipped with a field-emission gun. The Raman spectra were collected by a Renishaw In Via spectrometer using a 514 nm laser for excitation. The thickness profile was acquired on a Bruker Multimode 8 atomic force microscope (AFM). Fluorescence spectroscopy was performed on Hitachi F-4500 Fluorescence spectrophotometer.

The article does not provide specific details on the size of the MoSe2 nanosheets produced, nor does it provide a method for controlling the size of the nanosheets. Therefore, it is not possible to provide a method for the synthesis of 100 nm MoSe2 nanoparticles based on the information given in the article.

The article describes the synthesis of stable copper nanoparticles (Cu NPs) using humic acid as a reducing and stabilizing agent. The nanoparticles were prepared by a facile annealing process. The products were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction, scanning electron microscope, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy.

The Cu NPs were adhered on the surface of or well wrapped by humic acid, which was confirmed by the TEM image. Stable Cu NPs were successfully prepared, and the high stability property of Cu NPs may be mainly due to the stabilizing and reducing properties of humic acid. 

Cu NPs obtained at different raw mass ratios of copper acetate and humic acid were characterized by FESEM. As the ratio increased, the distribution density of Cu nanoparticles changed little, indicating that Cu2+ ions can be well distributed in humic acid to form uniformly distributed Cu NPs. However, the size of Cu nanoparticles gradually increased. While the ratio is up to 2.5:2.5, the size of Cu nanoparticles almost kept the same.

The FTIR spectra of three products were employed to confirm the changes of humic acid during the synthesis of Cu NPs. The absorption band at 3450 cm-1 is ascribed to the stretching of O-H and N-H, the peak at 1350 cm-1 is due to the stretching vibration of C-O, the peaks at 1460 cm-1 and 1650 cm-1 are assigned to the vibration of C-H and C-C respectively, and the 2300 cm-1 absorption peak represents the stretching of C≡N. 

In the calcinated humic acid, the intensity of peaks at 3450 cm-1 and 1500 cm-1 become weakened, but at 2300 cm-1, little enhancement could be observed, which indicates that C-H and O-H in the humic acid changed little. A new peak appearing at 2300 cm-1 confirms that C≡N bond was formed after the humic acid was calcinated in N2 atmosphere. 

In the final product, humic acid is only transformed to partially polymerized humic acid at 600 ºC. The Raman spectra demonstrate that two obvious bands at 1330 cm￾1 and 1600 cm-1 are attributed to the carbon material. The Raman shift at 2800 cm-1 comes from the humic acid according to the Raman spectra of humic acid. The Raman and TGA spectra further confirm that humic acid is not completely converted to carbon material.

In conclusion, the synthesis of Cu NPs involves the use of humic acid as a reducing and stabilizing agent, copper acetate, and an annealing process. The raw mass ratios of copper acetate and humic acid, as well as the calcination of humic acid in N2 atmosphere, play crucial roles in the formation and size of the Cu NPs.

The synthesis of stable copper nanoparticles (Cu NPs) was achieved through a facile annealing process using humic acid as both the reducing and stabilizing agent. The nanoparticles were prepared by annealing a mixture of copper acetate and humic acid at 600 ºC for 2 hours. The raw mass ratios of copper acetate and humic acid were varied to investigate their influence on the catalytic activity of the products. The ratios ranged from 1.0:2.5, 2.5:2.5, 5.0:2.5 to 7.5:2.5. 

The prepared Cu NPs were characterized using various techniques. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was used to confirm the formation of Cu NPs. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to observe the morphology of the Cu NPs. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was employed to confirm the changes of humic acid during the synthesis of Cu NPs. 

The FTIR spectra of three products were employed to confirm the changes of humic acid during the synthesis of Cu NPs. The absorption band at 3450 cm-1 is ascribed to the stretching of O-H and N-H, the peak at 1350 cm-1 is due to the stretching vibration of C-O, the peaks at 1460 cm-1 and 1650 cm-1 are assigned to the vibration of C-H and C-C respectively, and the 2300 cm-1 absorption peak represents the stretching of C≡N. 

The stability of the Cu NPs was further tested by measuring the XRD and SEM images of the Cu NPs before and after participating in the catalytic reaction. The XRD pattern of Cu NPs after the catalytic reaction was matched well with that of the freshly prepared Cu NPs and that of Cu NPs after exposing to air for 6 months, indicating the stability of Cu NPs during the catalytic reaction process. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of stable Cu NPs was achieved using humic acid as a reducing and stabilizing agent. The prepared Cu NPs showed remarkable intrinsic peroxidase-like activity and excellent stability, making them suitable for various applications such as the detection of glucose in human body and pear juice.

The synthesis of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) of around 3 nm in size is described in the provided text. The process involves the use of glutathione-capped Pd nanoparticles, which are synthesized with varying sizes from 1.4 to 3.5 nm. The molar ratio of [Na2PdCl4]/[GSH] greatly affects the physicochemical properties of the nanoparticles, including their sizes, surface charge states, and enzymatic activities.

The synthesis of GSH-capped Pd nanoparticles is carried out using Na2PdCl4 as the precursor, and DMAB as the reducing agent. The physicochemical properties of GSH-Pd are investigated by varying the molar ratio of [Na2PdCl4]/[GSH] in the synthesis process. GSH-Pd prepared at the [Na2PdCl4]/[GSH] ratio of 3 exhibits an average diameter of 1.4 nm. The particle size gradually increases up to 3.5 nm as the [Na2PdCl4]/[GSH] ratio increases from 3 to 60. Therefore, GSH-Pd prepared at different molar ratios of [Na2PdCl4]/[GSH] are denoted as GSH-Pd1.4 ([Na2PdCl4]/[GSH]=3), GSH-Pd2.6 ([Na2PdCl4]/[GSH]=6) and GSH-Pd3.5 ([Na2PdCl4]/[GSH]=60), respectively.

In terms of characterization, UV-vis spectroscopy was performed on a Varian Cary300 spectrophotometer using a quartz glass cuvette with 1 cm path length. Transmission Electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out on a JEM-2010FEF equipment (JEOL, Japan). All the average sizes were obtained by measuring more than 100 dispersive nanoparticles. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on the PHI5000 Versaprobe. In the sample preparation, 30 µL of as-prepared GSH-Pd solution was dropped onto a clean silicon wafer, and then dried under nitrogen gas atmosphere. This process was repeated thrice.

The deconvolution spectra of Pd 3d orbitals display two typical bands: the band at the binding energy of 336.9 eV corresponding to Pd2+ species and that at 334.9 eV corresponding to metallic Pd0. It is demonstrated that GSH-Pd1.4 contains 70% Pd2+ and 30% Pd0 species, respectively. With the particle size increasing from 1.4 to 3.5 nm, the proportion of Pd0 species increases significantly from 30% to 72%, whereas the fraction of Pd2+ species decreases from 70% to 28%.

In conclusion, the synthesis of Pd NPs of around 3 nm in size involves the use of Na2PdCl4 as the precursor, DMAB as the reducing agent, and GSH as the capping agent. The molar ratio of [Na2PdCl4]/[GSH] is adjusted to control the size of the nanoparticles. The synthesized nanoparticles are then characterized using UV-vis spectroscopy, TEM, and XPS.

It is demonstrated that GSH-Pd1.4 contains 70% Pd2+ and 30% Pd0 species, respectively. With the particle size increasing from 1.4 to 3.5 nm, the proportion of Pd0 species increases significantly from 30% to 72%, whereas the fraction of Pd2+ species decreases from 70% to 28%. 

The synthesis process is carried out under nitrogen gas atmosphere. The sample preparation involves dropping 30 µL of as-prepared GSH-Pd solution onto a clean silicon wafer, and then drying it under nitrogen gas atmosphere. This process is repeated thrice. 

Characterization of the synthesized nanoparticles is performed using various techniques. UV-vis spectroscopy is performed on a Varian Cary300 spectrophotometer using a quartz glass cuvette with 1 cm path length. Transmission Electron microscopy (TEM) is carried out on a JEM-2010FEF equipment (JEOL, Japan). All the average sizes are obtained by measuring more than 100 dispersive nanoparticles. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) is performed on the PHI5000 Versaprobe. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICPMS) is carried out on an Agilent 7700CE to determine the concentration of Ag+ in the lake water.

The synthesis of Pt nanoparticles in this study was achieved through the reduction of K2PtCl4 by DMAB or NaBH4 in the presence of BSA. Firstly, 10 μM BSA dissolved in 10 mM PBS buffer (pH 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 6.0, 7.0, 8.0, respectively) were firstly incubated with K2PtCl4 at the [K2PtCl4]/[BSA] ratio of 30. After incubation for 2 h at 25 °C, freshly prepared DMAB or NaBH4 aqueous solution was added to the mixture at the [reductant]/[precursor] ratio 5, to start the reduction reaction at 25 °C. The obtained BSA–Pt can be used as the nanozyme after 5 h reaction.

The chemicals used in this process, including BSA (purity497%), dimethylamine borane (DMAB) and NaCl were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. K2PtCl4, CuCl2  2H2O, Pb(CH3COO)2  3H2O, Hg(ClO4)2  3H2O, Na2PdCl4 and HAuCl4  3H2O were purchased from Alfa Aesar. H2O2 (30 wt%) was purchased from J&K Scientific, and TMB was purchased from Heowns. Other reagents such as sodium borohydride (NaBH4), CoCl2  6H2O, MnCl2  4H2O, CdCl2  5/2H2O, ZnCl2, MgCl2  6H2O, CaCl2, FeCl3  6H2O, Ni(NO3)2  6H2O, Na2HPO4 and NaH2PO4, were purchased from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Company. All the chemical reagents except BSA were of the purity higher than 99.9%, and used without further treatment. The water used in all experiments was distilled for three times.

The size distribution and the peroxidase-like activity of Pt nanoparticles are greatly associated with the reducing agent and the pH value used in the synthesis process. Importantly, Hg2þ is able to down-regulate the enzymatic activity of Pt nanoparticles. It is the first report to explore a colorimetric Hg2þ sensing system on the basis of peroxidase mimicking activities of Pt nanoparticles. BSA-stabilized Pt nanozymes demonstrate the ability to sense Hg2þ ions in aqueous solution without significant interference from other metal ions.

The synthesis of Pt nanoparticles in this study was achieved through the reduction of K2PtCl4 by DMAB or NaBH4 in the presence of BSA. The BSA was chosen as the nucleation template to synthesize the Pt nanoparticles using K2PtCl4 as the precursor. The BSA was dissolved in 10 mM PBS buffer (pH 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 6.0, 7.0, 8.0, respectively) and was firstly incubated with K2PtCl4 at the [K2PtCl4]/[BSA] ratio of 30. After incubation for 2 h at 25 °C, freshly prepared DMAB or NaBH4 aqueous solution was added to the mixture at the [reductant]/[precursor] ratio 5, to start the reduction reaction at 25 °C. The obtained BSA–Pt can be used as the nanozyme after 5 h reaction.

The characterizations of the synthesized Pt nanoparticles were done using CD, UV–vis, TEM and XPS. It was demonstrated that the size distribution and the peroxidase-like activity of Pt nanoparticles are greatly associated with the reducing agent and the pH value used in the synthesis process. The average diameter of the synthesized Pt nanoparticles was found to be 2.0 nm.

The chemicals used in the synthesis process included BSA (purity >97%), dimethylamine borane (DMAB) and NaCl which were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. K2PtCl4, CuCl2  2H2O, Pb(CH3COO)2  3H2O, Hg(ClO4)2  3H2O, Na2PdCl4 and HAuCl4  3H2O were purchased from Alfa Aesar. H2O2 (30 wt%) was purchased from J&K Scientific, and TMB was purchased from Heowns. Other reagents such as sodium borohydride (NaBH4), CoCl2  6H2O, MnCl2  4H2O, CdCl2  5/2H2O, ZnCl2, MgCl2  6H2O, CaCl2, FeCl3  6H2O, Ni(NO3)2  6H2O, Na2HPO4 and NaH2PO4, were purchased from Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Company. All the chemical reagents except BSA were of the purity higher than 99.9%, and used without further treatment. The water used in all experiments was distilled for three times.

The synthesis of 80 nm chitosan-modified popcorn-like Au–Ag nanoparticles (CSPNPs) can be conveniently achieved by ascorbic acid reduction of hydrogen tetrachloroaurate in the presence of chitosan and silver nitrate. The process is carried out at room temperature without the need for seeds and surfactants. 

To prepare 80 nm CSPNPs, 150 μL of 29 mM HAuCl4 solution is added to 20 mL ultrapure water, and then 100 μL 10 mg/mL of chitosan (dissolved in 5% acetic acid) is added under stirring. One minute later, 60 μL of 6 mM silver nitrate is injected into the solutions, and 80 μL of 0.1 M ascorbic acid is added immediately. After the introduction of ascorbic acid, a colorless stage would maintain for about 5 s, followed by the emergence of blue color within 1 min indicating the formation of CSPNPs. No obvious color changes could be observed after 1 min. The mixture is kept stirring for 3 h. 

The final products are purified using centrifugation at 3500 rpm for 15 min, and then washing and redispersing in ultrapure water. This process is repeated three times. The size of CSPNPs with a high monodispersity can be adjusted by changing the amount of regents. 

The composition of 80 nm CSPNPs with the original Ag/Au mole ratio of 0.08:1 was investigated by ICP-AES, EDX. To conduct ICP-AES detection, CSPNPs were isolated by centrifugation at 3500 rpm in 15 min, washed three times and subsequently dissolved in aqua regia. ICP-AES data shows an Ag/Au mole ratio of 0.07:1, which indicates the exact amount of Au/Ag in the solution. EDX result shows an Ag/Au mole ratio of 0.06:1. These results are consistent with the hypothesis. 

The as-prepared CSPNPs are environment friendly and biocompatible, because chitosan is a natural and nontoxic polysaccharide. From the SEM image, some “nanodots” with the size of about 10 nm, just like the petals of popcorns, can be observed on the surface of CSPNPs. TEM image further confirms the result. 

Instruments used in this process include a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) (SIGMA) microscope for obtaining Scanning Electron Microscope images, a Nano-ZS ZEN3600 particle sizer (Malvern Instruments) for measuring Zeta potentials of CSPNPs, an Inductively Coupled Plasma-Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES, IRIS Intrepid II XSP, Thermo Electron Corporation) for determining concentrations of Au/Ag, and a JEOL JEM-2010 microscope for performing Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDX) measurements for CSPNPs.

The synthesis of 80 nm chitosan-modified popcorn-like Au–Ag nanoparticles (CSPNPs) can be conveniently achieved by ascorbic acid reduction of hydrogen tetrachloroaurate in the presence of chitosan and silver nitrate. The process is carried out at room temperature and does not require the use of seeds and surfactants.

To prepare 80 nm CSPNPs, 150 μL of 29 mM HAuCl4 solution is added to 20 mL ultrapure water. Then, 100 μL of 10 mg/mL chitosan (dissolved in 5% acetic acid) is added under stirring. One minute later, 60 μL of 6 mM silver nitrate is injected into the solutions, and 80 μL of 0.1 M ascorbic acid is added immediately. After the introduction of ascorbic acid, a colorless stage would maintain for about 5 s, followed by the emergence of blue color within 1 min indicating the formation of CSPNPs. No obvious color changes could be observed after 1 min. The mixture is kept stirring for 3 h.

The final products are purified using centrifugation at 3500 rpm for 15 min, and then washing and redispersing in ultrapure water. This process is repeated three times. The size of CSPNPs with a high monodispersity can be adjusted by changing the amount of regents. For instance, when the volume of CS is changed to 200 μL and 40 μL, 50 nm and 120 nm CSPNPs can be synthesized, respectively.

The composition of 80 nm CSPNPs with the original Ag/Au mole ratio of 0.08:1 was investigated by ICP-AES, EDX. To conduct ICP-AES detection, CSPNPs were isolated by centrifugation at 3500 rpm in 15 min, washed three times and subsequently dissolved in aqua regia. ICP-AES data shows an Ag/Au mole ratio of 0.07:1, which indicates the exact amount of Au/Ag in the solution. EDX result shows an Ag/Au mole ratio of 0.06:1. These results are consistent with the hypothesis. Due to the fact that CS possesses the positively charged –NH3
þ group under acidic conditions, zeta potential of the CSPNPs (80 nm) was positive (þ38.47 mV).

The instruments used in this process include a UV-2550 UV–vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu) for recording the absorption spectra of different reaction solutions, a confocal microscope (Jobin–Yvon HR-800) for SERRS measurements, a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) (SIGMA) for obtaining Scanning Electron Microscope images, a Nano-ZS ZEN3600 particle sizer (Malvern Instruments) for measuring zeta potentials of CSPNPs, an Inductively Coupled Plasma-Atomic Emission Spectrometry (ICP-AES, IRIS Intrepid II XSP, Thermo Electron Corporation) for determining concentrations of Au/Ag, and a JEOL JEM-2010 microscope for Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDX) measurements.

The article does not provide a detailed procedure for the synthesis of BiAu nanoparticles. However, it does mention that Bi–Au NPs were prepared from 13.3 nm Au NPs (0.75 nM) and bismuth ions (Bi3+; 10 mM) in 5.0 mM Tris-borate (pH 7.0). Bismuth readily conjugated to the Au NPs through metallophilic interactions or reduction reaction. The Bi–Au NPs exhibited high catalytic activity for the hydrogen peroxide (H2O2)-mediated oxidation of Amplex Red (AR, 10-acetyl￾3,7-dihydroxyphenoxazine).

The article also mentions that the catalytic effect of Au NPs is significantly enhanced by Bi3+ at room temperature, as compared to other tested metal ions including Na+, K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Cr3+, Mn2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Pd2+, Pt4+, Cu2+, Ag+, Au3+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, and Pb2+. The Bi3+-stimulated catalytic ability of Au NPs was found to be much stronger (>5-fold) than that of Hg2+ in a previous report.

The formation of Bi–Au alloys on the surface of Au NPs was confirmed by conducting highly reproducible surface-assisted laser desorption/ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometry (SALDI–TOF MS) analyses. The peaks [Au1Bi1]+, [Au2Bi1]+, [Au1Bi2]+, [Au3Bi1]+, [Au2Bi2]+, [Au4Bi1]+, and [Au3Bi2]+ ions strongly support the formation of Bi–Au alloys on the Au NPs surfaces.

There was no statistical difference in the average particle diameter or size distribution between the Au NPs and Bi–Au NPs, as observed from the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images. This reveals that there is only a monolayer or submonolayer of Bi on the surface of Au NPs. The lattice d-spacing and X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Bi–Au NPs were almost the same as those of Au NPs, revealing that the core structure of Au NPs did not change.

The content of Bi species on the Au NPs was quantified using inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), obtaining a value of approximately 4500 Bi atoms/ions per Au NP, which was close to the surface atoms of the 13 nm Au NPs (B6600 atoms per particle). This result reveals a near monolayer of Bi–Au alloys on Au NP surfaces. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra reveal that the binding energy (BE) values for the Au 4f7/2 and Bi 4f7/2 electrons in the Bi–Au NPs were 84.2 eV and 159.5 eV, respectively. The results revealed that a high number of Bi3+ ions and Au+/Au0 coexisted on the particle surface, which greatly affected the surface properties of Au NPs.

The synthesis of CoS nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out according to the procedure of Wu et al. with slight modifications. The cobalt source was cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2.6H2O) and the sulfur source was thiourea (CN2H4S). The mixed solution was prepared by dissolving CoCl2.6H2O (594.8 mg) into a mixture solution of ultrapure water (20 mL) and ethylene glycol (5 mL), and then thiourea (761.2 mg) was added. After stirring for 10 min, the mixed solution was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, and heated for 15h at 180°C.

The synthesis of erythrocyte-like Cu1.8S nanoparticles (NPs) with a mean diameter of approximately 160 nm was achieved through a simple solvothermal chemistry process. The process involved the use of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), which is commonly used as a stabilizer in pharmaceutical products. 

The specific procedure for the synthesis of Cu1.8S nanospheres in ethylene glycol (EG) was as follows: 0.44 g of Copper(II) chloride (CuCl2), 0.19 g of thioacetamide, and 1.25 g of PVP were dispersed with stirring in 15 mL of EG. The resultant mixture was then heated at 75 C in a water-bath for 4 hours. The product was purified through a 1 kDa dialysis membrane for 2 days to remove any residual ions and small molecules. The product was then stored at 4 C for further use. The solid Cu1.8S nanospheres were concentrated by freezing at -80 C and then dried under vacuum.

The morphology of the nanoparticles was characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). The lattice fringes of the Cu1.8S NPs were clearly observed to be 0.19 nm by HRTEM, corresponding well to the (110) plane spacing of hexagonal Cu1.8S (JCPDS no. 47-1748). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) images showed that the height of the copper sulfide NPs was approximately 4–6 nm. Elemental analysis by energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry in the scanning electron microscope (SEM-EDXS) indicated that the NPs were copper deficient with a non-stoichiometric formula of Cu1.8S.

In conclusion, the synthesis of Cu1.8S NPs involves a solvothermal process using Copper(II) chloride, thioacetamide, and PVP as reagents, and ethylene glycol as the solvent. The process requires careful control of temperature and time, and the use of specific equipment for characterization and purification. The resulting nanoparticles exhibit a unique erythrocyte-like structure and are copper deficient, making them suitable for various applications.

The synthesis of FeS nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes, including those with an average size of 4.6 nm, was described in the study by S.K. Maji et al. The process involved the decomposition of a single-source precursor complex [Fe(ACDA)3] in structure-directing solvents such as ethylene glycol (EG), ethylenediamine (EN), and ammonia (NH3).

For the synthesis of FeS NPs with an average size of 4.6 nm, the precursor complex was mixed with ethylene glycol (EG). Specifically, 1.0 g of Fe(ACDA)3 was mixed with 20 mL of EG and sonicated for 10 minutes. The mixture was then heated to boiling at 120 °C for 15 minutes, resulting in the formation of a black compound. The product was separated by centrifuging, washed repeatedly with methanol, and finally with diethyl ether. After air drying, the product was annealed under nitrogen atmosphere at 450 °C for 30 minutes.

The composition and purity of the FeS NPs were first examined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a Philips PW 1140 parallel beam X-ray diffractometer with Bragg-Bretano focusing geometry and monochromatic Cu K radiation. The morphological characterization was carried out using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) with a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope working at 200 kV. The absorption spectra and photocatalytic studies were carried out on a JASCO V-530 UV-VIS spectrophotometer. Room-temperature photoluminescence measurements were performed using a Photon Technology International fluorometer.

The study also described the synthesis of FeS NPs using other solvents, such as ethylenediamine (EN) and ammonia (NH3), which resulted in NPs of different sizes and shapes. However, the specific process for the synthesis of 4.6 nm FeS NPs involved the use of ethylene glycol (EG) as the solvent.

The synthesis of FeS nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes, including those with an average size of 4.6 nm, was carried out using a single-source precursor complex [Fe(ACDA)3] [HACDA= 2-aminocyclopentene-1-dithiocarboxylic acid]. The precursor complex was decomposed in structure-directing solvents such as ethylene glycol (EG), ethylenediamine (EN), and ammonia (NH3).

For the synthesis of FeS NPs with an average size of 4.6 nm using EG as a solvent, 1.0 g of the precursor complex was mixed with 20 mL of EG and sonicated for 10 minutes. The mixture was then heated to boiling at 120 °C for 15 minutes, resulting in the formation of a black compound. The compound was then separated using a procedure that involved cooling the mixture to room temperature, adding 20 mL of methanol, stirring for 5 minutes, and then centrifuging to separate the precipitated product. The solid product was washed repeatedly with methanol and finally with diethyl ether. After air drying, the product was annealed under a nitrogen atmosphere at 450 °C for 30 minutes.

The phase purity, morphology, structure, and properties of the FeS NPs were studied using various techniques. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Philips PW 1140 parallel beam X-ray diffractometer with Bragg-Bretano focusing geometry and monochromatic Cu K radiation ( = 1.540598A). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and selected area diffraction (SAED) patterns were collected using a JEOL JEM-2100 microscope working at 200 kV. Absorption spectra and photocatalytic studies were carried out on a JASCO V-530 UV-VIS spectrophotometer. Room-temperature photoluminescence measurements were performed using a Photon Technology International fluorometer.

The photocatalytic activity of FeS NPs for the degradation of Methylene Blue (MB) was tested at 20 °C using 40 mL aqueous solution of MB (1.65 × 10−5 M) and 20 mg of catalyst with continuous stirring. The suspension containing MB and NPs was magnetically stirred in the dark for 30 minutes to reach adsorption–desorption equilibrium. The suspension was then irradiated with a tungsten halogen lamp (200W) placed vertically at a distance of 15 cm. After a given interval of illumination, 3 mL of the aliquot was withdrawn from the mixture and centrifuged, and the concentration of the dye in the centrifugate was measured.

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 7 nm ZnS nanoparticles (NPs). However, it does discuss the characterization and properties of H2TCPP-ZnS nanocomposites, which are composed of nanoparticles with diameters around 5–10 nm. 

The crystallinity and phase purities of H2TCPP-ZnS nanocomposites were examined by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique. Powder XRD profiles demonstrated the pure phases and good chemical stability of the nanocomposites. The as-prepared ZnS NPs exhibited a highly sphalerite structure. The relative broad feature of the peaks (FWHM) indicates the presence of smaller crystallites. The diffraction peaks at 28.6◦, 47.6◦, 56.4◦, 69.6◦ and 79.6◦ corresponded to the [111], [220], [311], [400], and [331] crystal planes of the cubic lattice, respectively.

The size and morphology of the products were imaged by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The TEM image of the as-prepared H2TCPP-ZnS nanocomposites showed that they are composed of nanoparticles with ca. 5–10 nm in diameter. The HRTEM image of H2TCPP-ZnS nanocomposites displayed clear lattice fringes of the prepared nanocrystals, suggesting the good crystalline nature of ZnS. The interplanar spacing is ca. 0.310 nm, corresponding to the [111] lattice plane of cubic ZnS. 

XPS was also employed to analyze the formation of porphyrin functionalized ZnS nanoparticles. The wide scan XPS spectra of the H2TCPP-ZnS nanocomposites shows photoelectron lines at a binding energy of 161.92, 284.86, 399.73, 531.57, 1024.71 eV attributed to S2p, C1s, N1s, O1s and Zn2p3, respectively. The high-resolution XPS spectra of Zn and S in 2p region showed the binding energies of Zn 2p3 with strong peaks at 1024.71 eV, indicating the presence of the typical Zn2+ in the H2TCPP-ZnS nanoparticles. The binding energy of S 2p peak is at 161.92 eV, indicating the presence of S2− in the prepared samples. 

The mechanism of the formation of the NPs has been proposed. After H2TCPP molecules were dissolved into pure water by tuning pH values, H2TCPP molecules were dissociated into H2TCPP4− anions. Then, coordination bonding interaction between the O atoms of the carboxyl groups from H2TCPP molecules and the Zn2+ cations in the aqueous solution occurred. The slow decomposition of the thioacetamide generates H2S gases, which diffuse into the reaction solution, generate S2− and precipitate the Zn ions gradually, resulting in the formation of ZnS crystal nuclei. Thus, the ZnS crystal nuclei formed in the complex of Zn2+ – H2TCPP4− and grew up slowly as the experiment process. 

However, the article does not provide specific details on the quantities of reagents used, the exact conditions under which the synthesis was carried out, or the equipment used in the synthesis process.

The synthesis of Chitosan (CS) modified silver halide (AgX, X = Cl, Br, I) nanoparticles (NPs), including AgI NPs, was carried out using a precipitation method. The initial step involved mixing 20 mL of 0.1 M AgNO3 aqueous solution with 20 mL of 0.5% (m/v) chitosan solution. This mixture was stirred for 30 minutes. Following this, 20 mL of 0.15 M KX (X = Cl, Br, I) aqueous solution was added into the above solution and stirred for 3 hours. After this process, a dispersion containing CS-AgX nanoparticles was formed.

The size of the nanoparticles was determined using Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). The TEM images of the CS-AgX nanoproducts demonstrated that they were nanoparticles with diameters of 30−70 nm. The mean size of CS-AgCl, CS-AgBr, and CS-AgI was 48.2, 42.6, and 40.0 nm, respectively.

To conjugate the CS-AgI with folic acid (FA), free folic acid (20 mg, 0.0227 mmol) was first dissolved in 10 mL 50 mM MES buffer (pH 6.0). The solution of FA was then mixed with a 2 mL aqueous solution of (EDC) (10 mmol) and sulfo-NHS (10 mmol). After agitating overnight at room temperature in the dark, the solution of CS-AgI (10 mL) was added to the above mixture. The resulting solution was stirred at room temperature for 24 hours. The final reaction mixture was purified by dialysis using a 3500 molecular weight cut off dialysis bag, against ultrapure water to remove the residual impurities.

The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-synthesized silver halides (CS-AgX) samples were also analyzed. It was observed that all the peaks of the sample coincide with the standard face-centered cubic AgCl (JCPDS file 31-1238), face-centered cubic AgBr (JCPDS file 06-0438), and hexagonal β-AgI phase (JCPDS file 78-1613).

The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy of CS modified AgX NPs, such as CS-AgI, revealed the existence of amino groups (3400 cm−1, N−H stretching vibration) and acetylated amino groups (1648 cm−1, carbonyl stretching vibration), suggesting that CS was introduced on the surface of AgI. The spectroscopy of CS-AgI revealed a new absorption peak at around 1560 cm−1, suggesting the formation of an Ag−N bond, possibly indicating the means of attachment of CS to AgI.

The synthesis of CuCo2S4 nanoparticles (NPs) was achieved through a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method assisted with dextran to control the particle size and hydrophilicity. Dextran with a high molecular weight of 500 kDa was employed to form small and uniform CuCo2S4 NPs with an average size of about 30 nm. 

The synthesis process involved several steps. Firstly, 0.5g Dextran of different molecular weight (10 kDa, 70 kDa, 500 kDa) were added into 30 mL deionized water under vigorously magnetic stirring. Then, CuCl2·2H2O (0.25 mmol), CoCl2·6H2O (0.5 mmol) and thiourea (1.5 mmol) were added with stirring. After that, 100 µL ethylenediamine was slowly added to get a dark brown solution. 

The resulting solution was transferred to a sealed 40 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160°C for 20 hours. After the reaction was completed, the autoclave naturally cooled to room temperature. Black precipitates were obtained by centrifugation and washed with ethanol and deionized water three times separately. The final products were obtained by drying in a lyophilizer for 6 hours. 

For comparison, naked CuCo2S4 nanoparticles were also prepared without adding dextran. In addition, CuS and CoS nanoparticles were also prepared with the same experimental conditions. 

The synthesized CuCo2S4 NPs were characterized using various techniques. The specific surface area of CuCo2S4 NPs was 39.6 m2g-1, evaluated by Brunauer – Emmett – Teller (BET) analysis. The characteristic peaks in X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern revealed their well-crystallized cubic spinel CuCo2S4 phase. Further observation of the microstructure by high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) showed a clear crystalline lattice with an interplane distance of 0.237 nm, corresponding to the d-spacing of the (004) planes of cubic spinel CuCo2S4 crystal. The energy- dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) spectrum confirmed the existence of Cu, Co, and S elements in the as-prepared CuCo2S4 NPs. Fourier-transform infrared spectra showed the existence of dextran on the CuCo2S4 NPs.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 4400 nm LaFeO3 nanoparticles. However, it does detail the synthesis of LaFeO3 microspheres, which may be relevant. 

The synthesis of LaFeO3 microspheres was carried out via a hydrothermal method, followed by calcination. The reagents used in the synthesis included 24 mmol of citric acid (C6H8O7), 4 mmol of La(NO3)3·6H2O, and 4 mmol of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O. These were dissolved in 40 mL DDW (double-distilled water) under magnetic stirring at room temperature for 20 minutes. 

The solution was then placed in an 80 mL stainless-steel Teflon-lined autoclave and maintained at 180 °C for 12 hours. After this, the reaction products were centrifuged and washed with DDW and anhydrous ethanol several times. The products were then dried at 60 °C for 5 hours and underwent an annealing process at 800 °C for 3 hours. 

The morphology of the perovskite LaFeO3 was characterized by SEM (Scanning Electron Microscopy) and TEM (Transmission Electron Microscopy). Before calcination, LaFeO3 precursor illustrates microsphere-like structure with diameter about 5.4 ± 0.4 μm. After calcination, the LaFeO3 sphere maintained its architecture while the diameter of the spheres declined to 4.4 ± 0.3 μm, along with the appearance of mesopores on the surface. 

The EDS (Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy) elemental mapping displays that La, Fe, and O elements are homogeneously distributed throughout all the region of the mesoporous microspheres. The EDS spectrum reveals the La, Fe, and O atomic ratio is close to 1:1:3, further verifying the successful formation of LaFeO3. 

Surface area and porosity of mesoporous LaFeO3 microspheres were studied by nitrogen adsorption/desorption studies. The surface area of mesoporous LaFeO3 microspheres is 10.12 m2·g−1, while the average pore size is 32.65 nm. 

In conclusion, while the article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 4400 nm LaFeO3 nanoparticles, it does detail a method for the synthesis of LaFeO3 microspheres. This method involves a hydrothermal process, followed by calcination, and uses citric acid, La(NO3)3·6H2O, and Fe(NO3)3·9H2O as reagents.

The synthesis of Cu2ZnSn(SxSe1-x)4 nanocrystals (CZTSSe NCs) was performed using a solvothermal method. The materials used for the synthesis included Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O, Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O, SnCl2, Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), monoethanolamide (C2H7NO, MEA), thioacetamide (C2H5NS, TAA), and Se powders. The specific quantities used were 0.36 mmol Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O, 0.25 mmol Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O, 0.205 mmol SnCl2, and 1.0 g PVP. These were dissolved in 15 mL MEA under vigorous stirring to form solution A.

Meanwhile, TAA and Se powders were dissolved in 15 mL MEA to form solution B. The relative amount of TAA and Se was found to influence the solubility of Se powder in MEA. Then solution B was added dropwise into solution A slowly under magnetic stirring to form a suspension. This suspension was then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was sealed, maintained at 180 °C for 48 h, and then cooled to room temperature naturally.

The precipitates were collected by centrifugation and washed with acetone several times and dried at 60 °C in air for 6 h. The Cu2ZnSn(SxSe1-x)4 nanocrystals were finally obtained and denoted as CZTSSe-x (‘x’ stands for the molar ratio of S/(S + Se), and x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1). To obtain different CZTSSe NCs, the content of S in the final CZTSSe NCs was varied by changing the molar ratio of TAA and Se in solution B and maintaining the total molar amount of Se and S a constant at 1 mmol.

The synthesized CZTSSe NCs were characterized using various techniques such as X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) specific surface area analysis, and zeta potential measurements.

The synthesis of bimetallic PdCu nanoparticles was achieved through a microwave-assisted wet-chemical synthetic approach. The specific size of the nanoparticles, such as 5 nm, is not explicitly mentioned in the provided text. However, the process of synthesis is detailed.

The metal precursor mixture was prepared by combining 5 mL of 0.1 M K2PdCl4 solution and 5 mL of 0.1 M CuSO4 solution. This 10 mL mixture was quickly injected into a 250 mL three-neck flask containing 50 mL of 0.1 M NaBH4. The three-neck flask was placed in an XH-100A microwave synthesizer (Beijing Xianghu Science and Technology Development Co., Ltd.) for the reaction to occur.

The reaction was performed at 60 degrees Celsius for 5 minutes, with a microwave power of 600 W. The resulting product, black PdCu, was collected by centrifugation and washed with water and ethanol alternately several times. For comparison, pure Pd was also prepared under identical conditions, but without CuSO4 in the synthesis system.

The synthesized PdCu was characterized by XRD measurements, which were conducted to differentiate the bimetallic PdCu from the pure Pd counterpart. The synthesized PdCu only produced recognizable Pd diffraction signals with much wider FWHM and lower intensity, and no other impurity peak, such as metallic Cu and its oxides, was observed in the PdCu XRD pattern. This indicated that the Cu entity had been immersed into the Pd lattice facilitated by microwave irradiation.

The insertion of Cu atoms with a smaller atomic radius caused the crystal defects of Pd, which reduced the crystallinity of PdCu, thus resulting in the lower intensity and wider FWHM. These diffraction peaks had an apparent shift to larger 2θ positions compared with the pure Pd, which also resulted from the incorporation of Cu atoms into the Pd lattice in place of Pd atoms.

In conclusion, a bimetallic PdCu material with Cu and Pd atoms interpenetrated well was obtained via the microwave-assisted synthetic method. The synthesized PdCu had a unique coral-like structure, which provided abundant active sites and surfaces for reaction, and was more stable compared to independent nanoparticles.

The synthesis of bimetallic PdCu nanoparticles was achieved through a microwave-assisted wet-chemical synthetic approach. The chemicals and materials used in the synthesis include K2PdCl4 and NaBH4, which were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. CuSO4 was provided by Sinopharm Chemical Regent Co., Ltd. Deionized water was utilized throughout the study. All other chemicals were of analytical grade and used as received.

In detail, 10 mL of the metal precursor mixture consisting of 5 mL 0.1 M K2PdCl4 solution and 5 mL 0.1 M CuSO4 solution was quickly injected into a 250 mL three-neck flask containing 50 mL 0.1 M NaBH4 with a wild stir. The three-neck flask was in an XH-100A microwave synthesizer (Beijing Xianghu Science and Technology Development Co., Ltd.) for reaction. The reaction was performed at 60o C for 5 min, along with a microwave power of 600 W. 

The black PdCu product was collected by centrifugation and washed with water and ethanol alternately for several times. For comparison, pure Pd was also prepared under identical conditions, with no CuSO4 in the synthesis system. 

The synthesized PdCu only produces recognizable Pd diffraction signals with much wider FWHM and lower intensity, and no other impurity peak, such as metallic Cu and its oxides, is observed in the PdCu XRD pattern. This phenomenon indicates that the Cu entity has been immersed into the Pd lattice facilitated by microwave irradiation. The insertion of Cu atoms with a smaller atomic radius causes the crystal defects of Pd, which reduces the crystallinity of PdCu, thus resulting in the lower intensity and wider FWHM. 

The coral-like structure of PdCu has the following advantages: (1) in comparison with independent nanoparticles that are prone to agglomeration, the interconnected structure in the synthesized PdCu nanozyme makes it more stable; (2) the branches in the coral-like structure provide abundant active sites and surfaces for reaction; (3) besides, the unique structure can be easily obtained by the microwave-assisted wet-chemical approach, with no surfactant or capping agent required. 

However, the article does not specify the size of the synthesized PdCu nanoparticles.

The synthesis of Pt nanoparticles (PtNPs) is described in the experimental section of the article. The Pt nanoparticles were prepared first by mixing 0.4 mL 3 mM H2PtCl6 solution with 40 µL of β-casein aqueous solution with a desired concentration in 2.96mL10mM PBS buffer (pH=7). After stirring 90 min at 45℃, 0.6 mL of ice cold 10 mM NaBH4 was added under stirring. After the complete reaction (5 h), the solution was dialysed with water for 24 h to remove excess β-casein.

The chemicals and materials used for the synthesis include β-Casein, which was purchased from Sigma (>99%). Hydrogen tetrachloroaurate tetrahydrate (H2PtCl6·6H2O, 99%), 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) and 2,2′-azinobis (3-ethylbenzthiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) diammonium salt (ABTS) were purchased from Sigma. All other reagents used were of analytical grade from Beijing Company, and ultrapure Millipore water (18.2 MΩ) was used as the solvent. All glassware was washed with aqua regia (HCl: HNO3 in 3:1 ratio by volume), and rinsed with ethanol and ultrapure water. β-Casein powders were dispersed in water under stirring at 50 ◦C, and the dispersions were stored at 4◦C overnight to allow complete hydration.

The Pt nanoparticles were characterized using various techniques. The reduction of platinum ions ([PtCl6]2-) can be confirmed by UV/vis spectroscopy. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image indicates that the synthesized PtNPs are sphere-like shape and the average size of the nanoparticles is calculated to be about 3.8 nm, as judged from image analysis of 200 individual particles. According to the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of Pt nanoparticles, the measured lattice fringe spacing is 0.23 nm, which is consistent with the (111) interplane spacing of face centered-cubic Pt NPs.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data revealed that Pt, carbon, nitrogen and oxygen are present at the surface of PtNPs, indicating that the PtNPs are capped by protein. The binding energy of the electron on the Pt 4f7/2 orbital of the nanoparticles can be deconstructed into Pt2+ and Pt0 components with the binding energies of 72.2 eV (63.74%) and 71.0 eV (36.26%), respectively. The obtained PtNPs are found to be stable over 6 months and do not show any signs of aggregation at 4 ◦C. Here, β-casein can stabilize PtNPs by both the electrostatic effect and the steric effect.

The synthesis of Prussian blue nanoparticles (PBNPs) with a cubic shape and an edge length of approximately 15.3 nm was achieved using a one-step coprecipitation method. The process involved the use of certain chemicals and materials, as well as specific equipment for the synthesis and subsequent characterization of the nanoparticles.

The chemicals and materials used for the nanoparticle synthesis included FeCl3·6H2O, K4[Fe(CN)6]·3H2O, and citric acid. The volume of 20 mL of the aqueous 1.0 mmol L−1 FeCl3 and 0.5 mmol L−1 citric acid was heated to 55 °C and mixed with 20 mL of 1.0 mmol L−1 K4[Fe(CN)6] and 0.5 mmol L−1 citric acid under vigorous stirring. The resulting mixture was stirred for 10 minutes and then cooled down to room temperature.

For the characterization of the synthesized nanoparticles, various techniques were employed. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to reveal the cubic shape of the PBNPs and to measure the length of the edge of the PBNP cubes. Dynamic light scattering, atomic force microscopy (AFM), gel electrophoresis, and UV/VIS spectroscopy were also used for nanomaterial characterization.

The catalytic properties of the PBNPs were measured at laboratory temperature in 96 well microtiter plate using the Synergy 2 reader from BioTek. The final concentration of PBNPs was 6.7 × 10−12 mol L−1. The rate of oxidation of TMB to the yellow product (vTMB450) after the addition of sulfuric acid was more typically measured in previous studies.

In conclusion, the synthesis of Prussian blue nanoparticles (PBNPs) of a specific size involves a one-step coprecipitation method, the use of specific chemicals and materials, and the application of various characterization techniques. The process also requires the measurement of the catalytic properties of the nanoparticles using specific equipment and conditions.
