The synthesis of IrNPs (Iridium Nanoparticles) involves several steps and requires specific reagents and equipment. 

The first step is the preparation of sacrificial Ag nanoplates. For this, 0.152 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, MW = 29 kDa) is dissolved in 26.25 mL of deionized (DI) water. Then, 250 µL of 10 mM AgNO3, and 300 µL of 30 mM sodium citrate are added to a transparent 50 mL borosilicate glass vial. Following this, 60 µL of 30% hydrogen peroxide and 250 µL of 100 mM NaBH4 aqueous solution are subsequently added. After 3 hours of incubation, the solution color changes to blue and proceeds to the growth step without purification. 

In the growth step, 1 mL of 100 mM L-ascorbic acid and 330 µL of 75 mM citrate are added to the as-synthesized Ag nanoseed solution-contained 50 mL vial. The growth solution is prepared, which is composed of 20 mL of 1 mM AgNO3 and 125 µL of 100 mM citric acid. The prepared growth solution is added dropwise to the seed solution at the rate of 0.2 mL·s-1, followed by the color change to deep blue with the additional incubation for 15 min.

The next step is the synthesis of IrNPs by hydrothermal galvanic replacement. 20 mL of as-synthesized Ag nanoplates and 3 mL of 10 mM IrCl3 stock solution are homogeneously mixed in a Teflon-lined autoclave vessel. Using the stainless steel autoclave, the mixture is heated for 1 hour at 200 °C with gentle magnetic stirring. After the reaction, the product is cooled down to room temperature naturally, and the dark-brown colored product is purified by centrifugation for 10 min at 9000 rpm. To remove the unreacted precursors and dissolved ions, the product is further washed for 3 times with deionized water. Finally, purified IrNPs are re-dispersed in 5 mL of deionized water for further use.

The morphology of IrNPs is characterized by energy-filtering TEM (LIBRA 120, Carl Zeiss, Germany). HR and HAADF-STEM/EDS mapping are accomplished by a Tecnai F20 (FEI, USA). XPS analysis is performed by photoelectron spectrometer system (K-Alpha+, ThermoFisher Scientific, USA). XRD is performed by SmartLab (Rigaku corporation, Japan). UV-Vis-NIR spectra are obtained by Lambda-465 (PerkinElmer, USA), BioPhotometer D30 spectrophotometer (Eppendort Co., Hamburg, Germany), and SynergyMx (Biotek, UK). Hydrodynamic diameter and zeta potential are identified by Zetasizer Nano ZS (Malvern, UK). Cell images are obtained by Ti-inverted fluorescence microscope (Nikon Co., Japan) and a CoolSNAP cf charge-coupled device (CCD) camera (Photometrics, USA) with Metamorph image analysis software (Molecular Devices, USA).

The TEM image of IrNPs shows particles with rough surface morphology and a transverse diameter of ~90 nm. The structure and composition of IrNPs, including the crystallinity and elemental oxidation states, are further verified through X-ray techniques and high-angle annular dark field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM).

The synthesis of IrNPs (Iridium Nanoparticles) with a transverse diameter of approximately 90 nm was achieved through a hydrothermal galvanic replacement process. The initial step involved the homogeneous mixing of 20 mL of as-synthesized Ag nanoplates and 3 mL of 10 mM IrCl3 stock solution in a Teflon-lined autoclave vessel. The mixture was then heated for 1 hour at 200 °C with gentle magnetic stirring using a stainless steel autoclave. This temperature was chosen to achieve a spontaneous replacement reaction and subsequent secondary growth of IrNPs due to the high-energy environment.

After the reaction, the product was cooled down to room temperature naturally, and the dark-brown colored product was purified by centrifugation for 10 minutes at 9000 rpm. To remove the unreacted precursors and dissolved ions, the product was further washed three times with deionized water. Finally, the purified IrNPs were re-dispersed in 5 mL of deionized water for further use.

The morphology of the IrNPs was characterized by energy-filtering TEM (LIBRA 120, Carl Zeiss, Germany). HR and HAADF-STEM/EDS mapping were accomplished by a Tecnai F20 (FEI, USA). XPS analysis was performed by a photoelectron spectrometer system (K-Alpha+, ThermoFisher Scientific, USA). XRD was performed by SmartLab (Rigaku corporation, Japan). UV-Vis-NIR spectra were obtained by Lambda-465 (PerkinElmer, USA), BioPhotometer D30 spectrophotometer (Eppendort Co., Hamburg, Germany), and SynergyMx (Biotek, UK). Hydrodynamic diameter and zeta potential were identified by Zetasizer Nano ZS (Malvern, UK).

The structure and composition of IrNPs, including the crystallinity and elemental oxidation states, were further verified through X-ray techniques and high-angle annular dark field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM). According to the deconvoluted Ir 4f and Ag 3d X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), IrNPs are composed of metallic Ir (Ir0: 60.8 and 63.8 eV for 4f7/2 and 4f5/2, respectively) and Ag (Ag0: 367.3 and 373.3 eV for 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively), and a small quantity of IrO2 (Ir4+: 61.6 and 64.8 eV for 4f7/2 and 4f5/2, respectively) due to surface oxidation. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the IrNP film on Si wafer also indicated the alloyed nature of the nanoparticles.

The article describes the synthesis of Carbon Quantum Dots (CQDs), which are a type of carbon nanoparticles. The synthesis process begins with the collection of 500 µL latexes from the E. milii plant. These latexes are then dissolved in 100 mL of ultrapure water and ultrasonicated for 15 minutes in a beaker. The resulting suspended solution is poured into a 250 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 3 hours. After this, the mixture is cooled down to room temperature.

The brown carbonaceous material obtained from this process is then centrifuged at 14,000 rpm for 20 minutes to remove larger particles. The supernatant is pipetted out and the light brown solution obtained is purified against a dialysis membrane for 24 hours. The concentration of the purified CQDs is adjusted to 0.5 mg/mL and kept in an incubator at 4 °C for further use.

The prepared CQDs are characterized using various spectroscopic techniques. The absorbance spectra are measured by a UV-visible spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific, Evolution 301). The fluorescence spectra are analyzed by the Varian Cary Eclipse Fluorescence Spectrophotometer. Transmission Electron Microscopy micrograph is collected from the TEM, TECHNAI G2 20 S–TWIN. Zeta potential is measured by NanoPlus HD. The X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) spectrum is collected from the Rigaku MiniFlex 600, at a scanning rate of 3° min−1. The evolved functional groups are explored by the use of Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) Spectrum conducted by the FTIR, Perkin Elmer Spectrum 100. X-Ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) is conducted by the X-Ray Photoelectron Spectrophotometer (XPS, AMICUS, Kratos Analytical, A Shimadzu).

The article does not specify the size of the CQDs synthesized, but the Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) micrograph and the High-Resolution TEM (HRTEM) micrograph can be used to determine the size of the nanoparticles. The article also does not provide information on the mmols of the reagents used in the synthesis process.

The synthesis of Ti3C2 nanosheets, which have a diameter mainly distributed in 35–155 nm with the average size of 103 nm, is described in the article. The synthesis process is a two-step procedure. 

In the first step, Al atoms are extracted from Ti3AlC2 precursors by KOH, breaking the metallic bonding between adjacent Ti3C2 layers. After the extraction of Al layers, gaps are produced from the edges that spread inside. The following ultrasonication was introduced to ensure complete delamination. 

The etching process of Ti3C2 nanosheets may abide by the following simplified reactions:
Ti3AlC2 + KOH + H2O = Ti3C2 + KAlO2 + 3/2H2 (1)
Ti3C2 + 2H2O = Ti3C2(OH)2 + H2 (2)

The resulting Ti3C2 nanosheets are most probably terminated with –OH functional groups. XPS spectra indicate the existence of Ti–C (464.4 cm1) and Ti–O (458.5 cm1) bonds, as well as the O 1s signal (530.3 cm1), which is evidence for the formation of Ti3C2(OH)2 after treatment. 

In addition, the FTIR spectrum illustrates a broad band centered at 3400 cm1 and another peak at 1639 cm1, verifying the surface termination of hydroxyl groups and the resonance peak of CQO groups. The synthesis of HS-PtNPs, or Heparin-capped Platinum Nanoparticles, is described in the provided text. The process begins with HS powder, accurately weighed at 0.05 g, which is added to 50 mL of 0.1% (v/v) acetic acid solution. This mixture is stirred sufficiently to completely dissolve the HS powder, resulting in a 0.1% (m/v) HS solution.

Next, 2 mL of 10 mM H2PtCl6 is added to 47 mL of the HS solution. This mixture is then vortexed in the dark for 30 minutes. Following this, 1 mL of freshly prepared 0.1 M sodium borohydride solution is added dropwise, a process that is completed within 5 minutes. The mixture is then stirred in a dark place for 90 minutes to prepare the HS-PtNPs. The final products are stored at around 4 °C in the dark.

The HS-PtNPs are formed by reducing H2PtCl6 in HS using NaBH4. It was found that bare PtNPs exhibit weak stability and show distinct aggregation in solution, while the as-synthesized solution exhibited excellent colloidal stability when HS was introduced into the preparation process. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) spectrum indicated an existence of Pt in the HS-PtNPs.

The average diameter of HS-PtNPs was found to be 4.8 ± 0.6 nm, as shown by the TEM image. The high resolution TEM (HRTEM) image shows that HS-PtNPs possessed a 0.30 nm continuous lattice spacing. The formation of Pt in HS-PtNPs was further verified by XPS. As shown in this characteristic spectrum, the Pt4f7/2 peak could be deconvoluted into two different peaks, which were centered at binding energies of 75.0 and 78.9 eV, and attributed to Pt4+ and Pt0, respectively. The relative intensities of the Pt species suggested that HS-PtNPs were composed of 57% metallic Pt4+ species and 42% Pt0 species.

The synthesis process was conducted using a Nicolet Avatar 360 FT-IR spectrophotometer, a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer, an RP-C18 (250 × 4.6 mm, 3 µm; Agilent) for high performance liquid chromatographic separation and other impurities, and an electrochemical workstation (CHI660C, Shanghai Chenhua Device Company, China) for electrochemical measurements.

The synthesis of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the article under the section "Preparation and characterization of Pd-DTT". The Pd-DTT nanozyme was synthesized via reducing the K2PdCl4 precursor with NaBH4, during which a certain amount of DTT was added as a stabilizer and modifier. The detailed procedure is as follows: 10 mL DTT (1 mM) and 10 mL K2PdCl4 (25 mM) were first mixed in 10 mL deionized water and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then, 10 mL NaBH4 (125 mM) was dropwise added to the above mixture. The solution was kept under a mild stir for 0.5 h. The products were washed with deionized water and collected. After being dried in a vacuum oven at 50oC for 12 h, the Pd-DTT nanozyme was obtained. 

The characterization of the synthesized Pd-DTT was done using several methods. The crystal structure of the obtained products was characterized by XRD. The shape of Pd-DTT was observed by TEM. A large number of Pd nanoparticles with a mean diameter of 3.8 nm are observed. The high-resolution TEM image displays that the interplanar spacing of the synthesized Pd-DTT is 0.227 nm, which is in consistent with the theoretical value (0.224 nm). These particles are linked each other because of the interaction between Pd and the dual sulfydryl groups in DTT. 

The FTIR spectra of DTT and Pd-DTT were compared. In Pd-DTT, the peaks at 2970 and 2930 cm-1 are attributed to the alkyl groups in DTT, indicating that DTT has been successfully anchored onto Pd nanoparticles. However, the peak at 2550 cm-1 originating from the dual sulfydryl groups in DTT cannot be identified in Pd-DTT. This supports that the dual sulfydryl groups in DTT have bound to two Pd particles, forming a Pd─DTT─Pd structure. 

In the full XPS, the elements O, Pd, C and S can be well observed, also indicating the successful modification of DTT on Pd surface. The fine Pd 3d XPS and other characterization methods were performed on an ESCALAB-MKII spectrometer (Thermo-Fisher Scientific). 

In conclusion, the synthesis of Pd nanoparticles involves the reduction of K2PdCl4 precursor with NaBH4, with DTT serving as a stabilizer and modifier. The synthesized Pd-DTT nanozyme was characterized using XRD, TEM, FTIR, and XPS.

The synthesis of Pd@Ir core-shell cubes/octahedra, which are nanocrystals, is described in the provided text. The core-shell structured Pd@Ir nanocrystals were synthesized according to the published literature. 

Firstly, 100 mg of PVP and 60 mg of AA were dissolved in 10 mL of EG. Then, the mixture was added to a three-necked flask, which had been preheated in an oil bath at 100 °C for one hour. Then, 0.8 mL of 14 nm Pd cubic seeds (4.0 mg mL-1) was added. Meanwhile, the reaction temperature was increased quickly, and when the temperature reached to 200 °C, 4 mL of Na3IrCl6ïxH2O solution (0.5 mg mL-1, dissolved in EG) was injected into the flask at a rate of 0.5 mL h-1. The reaction was continued for 10 min after the end of the injection. The flask was transferred to an ice water bath to stop the reaction. The product was collected by centrifugation through washing several times with water. Finally, the sample was dispersed in water for storage and analysis.

The characterization of Pd@Ir core-shell cubes/octahedra was done using TEM (Tecnai G20 spirit BioTwin, FEI, USA) and HRTEM (Tecnai G2 F20, FEI, USA) to characterize the morphology of the nanostructures. EDX elemental mapping was performed using a Talos F200X microscope (FEI, USA). The contents of metal elements were determined by ICP-MS (Element 2, Thermo Finnigan, Germany).

The synthesis of the 14 nm Pd cubic seeds used in the process is also described. 105 mg of PVP, 60 mg of AA, 5 mg of KBr and 185 mg of KCl were dissolved in 8 mL of ultrapure water at room temperature, and the mixture was preheated at 80 °C for 10 min. Then, 3 mL of Na2PdCl4 solution (57 mg) was added. The reaction was kept at 80 °C for 3 h and then cooled to room temperature. After that, the sample was washed with acetone once and water three times via centrifugation. Finally, the obtained Pd cubic seeds were stored in water. The 14 nm Pd cubes were synthesized by a similar method, except that only 300 mg of KBr was introduced. 

The synthesis of 14 nm Pd octahedra is also described. 8 mL of 13 mg mL-1 PVP aqueous solution, 100 M of formaldehyde and 300 M of 6 nm Pd cubic seeds (1.8 mg mL-1) were placed in a three-necked flask and preheated at 60 °C for 10 min. Then, 3 mL of 8 mg mL-1 Na2PdCl4 aqueous solution was added by pipette. The reaction temperature was maintained at 60 °C for 3 h. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was washed several times with water and acetone. Finally, the as-prepared Pd octahedra were dispersed in ethylene glycol (EG) for further use.

The synthesis of SeNPs (selenium nanoparticles) of 38.7 nm or other sizes was achieved through a modified process as described in the literature. The materials used for the synthesis were all of analytical grade and used without further purification. These included ethanol, acetic acid, sodium hydroxide (NaOH), glutathione (GSH), and sodium selenite (Na2SeO3) which were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Bovine serum albumin (BSA) was purchased from Biosharp (Hefei, China) and TMB was purchased from Aladdin (Shanghai, China). Double-distilled water was used throughout the whole experiment.

The process of preparation of the SeNPs involved mixing 5 mL of 10 mmol/L Na2SeO3 with 400 mg BSA under vigorous stirring, and then adding 20 mL of 10 mmol/L GSH into the mixture. The color of the mixture turned into orange-red after 130 µL of 1 mol/L NaOH was rapidly injected, indicating that the SeNPs were formed. The colloidal was then dialyzed using a dialysis bag (MW cutoff 3500) against double-distilled water for 48 hours with the water changing every 24 hours to separate the oxidized glutathione (GSSG). The obtained solution was then centrifuged to abandon the suspension, while the red precipitate was dispersed into distilled water and stored at 4 °C.

SeNPs with different sizes can be synthesized by adding different amounts of BSA into the redox system. The as-obtained SeNPs were characterized by TEM, XRD, DLS, XPS, IR, and UV–Vis absorption. TEM sample was prepared by placing a drop of the colloidal dispersion onto a copper grid coated with a perforated carbon film, followed by evaporating the solvent at room temperature. The TEM graphs were obtained on a Tecnai (G2 20, FEI Co., Netherlands) at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The average particle size and the distribution were determined from about 200 particles of the enlarged micrographs. The mean hydrodynamic diameter of SeNPs in aqueous solution was obtained using a DLS instrument (LB-550, Horiba, Ltd. Japan). 

In conclusion, the synthesis of SeNPs of 38.7 nm or other sizes involves a series of steps including the mixing of Na2SeO3 with BSA, the addition of GSH, the injection of NaOH, dialysis, and centrifugation. The size of the SeNPs can be controlled by adjusting the amount of BSA added into the redox system. The synthesized SeNPs are then characterized using various techniques such as TEM, XRD, DLS, XPS, IR, and UV–Vis absorption.

The synthesis of Iridium nanoparticles (IrNPs) with an average diameter of 2.5 ± 0.5 nm was carried out using sodium citrate as the stabilizer and NaBH4 as the reducing agent. The preparation process was conducted under a nitrogen atmosphere to prevent the influence of oxygen. 

The detailed procedure is as follows: Sodium citrate solution (3 mL, 0.034 M) was mixed with iridium chloride solution (20 mL, 1 mM). NaOH solution (1 M) was added dropwise to adjust the pH of the mixture to 7–9. The mixture was refluxed under vigorous stirring for 20 minutes and the color of the solution changed to faint yellow. Freshly prepared NaBH4 solution (1 mL, 0.1 M) was added and the mixture was stirred for 30 minutes with the heater switched off. The color of the solution gradually changed to black, indicating the formation of colloidal IrNPs.

The colloidal IrNPs were purified by adding the appropriate amount of ethanol and centrifuging the mixture at 3357 rcf for 5 minutes. The precipitate was washed three times with ethanol, and the obtained product was dried in a vacuum at 45 °C. A stock solution (1.5 mg·mL−1) was prepared by dissolving the powders in ultrapure water and stored at room temperature for subsequent use. The concentration of Ir was measured to be 4.94 mM according to the ICP-MS results.

The morphology and size of the IrNPs were characterized using High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD). The HRTEM images showed that the IrNPs exhibit good monodispersity and the average diameter is about 2.5 ± 0.5 nm. The XRD patterns indicated the presence of {200}, {220}, and {311} facets of iridium, which are associated with higher catalytic activity.

In conclusion, the synthesis of IrNPs involves the use of sodium citrate as a stabilizer and NaBH4 as a reducing agent, with the process carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere. The resulting IrNPs have an average diameter of 2.5 ± 0.5 nm and exhibit excellent oxidase-like property.

The synthesis of MnFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out using the co-precipitation method, as reported by Zhang et al. with some modifications. The metal precursors, FeCl3 and MnCl2, were dissolved in 5 mL of deionized water at concentrations of 0.8 and 0.4 M, respectively. These solutions were slowly mixed in a 250-mL stopped bottle under magnetic stirring and heated to 100 ◦C in a water bath. 

Afterward, 7 M NaOH was added to the mixture to reach a 0.2 M ratio between metal cations and OH-. A dark brown precipitate was formed and digested for two hours at 100 ◦C. The particles were magnetically separated and washed with deionized water three times. The obtained particles were frozen to − 80 ◦C and then freeze-dried. The dried NPs powder was stored for further assays.

The acquisition of micrographs and elemental distribution of MnFe2O4 NPs was carried out by Scanning electronic microscopy - Energy dispersive X-Ray spectroscopy (SEM-EDS) in a HITACHI SU3500 microscopy (Japan) at 15.0 kV. Transmission Electronic Microscopy (TEM) analysis was done in a JEOL JEM 2100 LaB6 TEM at 200 kV. The size distribution of MnFe2O4 NPs was calculated from TEM images employing ImageJ software. The nanoparticle size was measured from TEM images, which showed a narrow size distribution of 3.16 ± 0.62 nm.

The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis of MnFe2O4 NPs was performed using a STADI-P (Stoe®, Darmstadt, Germany) diffractometer operating at room temperature, 50 kV, 40 mA and using MoKα1 (λ = 0.7093 Å) radiation. The X-rays photons were collected by a Mythen 1 K (Dectris®, Baden, Switzerland) detector. Data were recorded in a powdered sample loaded into a 0.3-mm-diameter special glass 14 capillary (Hilgenberg, Malsfeld, Germany), in the 2θ range from 5.0◦ to 60.485◦, with step sizes of 0.015º and a counting time of 100 s at each 0.785◦. 

The FTIR spectrum of MnFe2O4 NPs was obtained in a Cary-630 spectrometer equipped with an attenuated total reflectance (ATR) accessory. The infrared spectra with 32 scans per sample (4000–400 cm− 1 at 4 cm− 1 resolution) were collected at room temperature.

The synthesis of MnFe2O4 nanocrystals, including those of approximately 150 nm in size, was achieved through a simple co-precipitation method as described in the article. The process began with the addition of a NaOH solution to a metal precursor solution of Mn2+ and Fe2+ ions at a temperature of 70 degrees Celsius. This resulted in the production of a green colored metal hydroxide, which subsequently transformed into dark-brown colored MnFe2O4 nanoparticles at 858C.

The analysis of the product was conducted using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), which revealed the formation of nanocrystals of nearly 100–200 nm in size (average 150 nm) having octahedron morphology. The high-resolution TEM image showed the lattice planes, which can be indexed to 220 having a distance of 0.29 nm.

The formation of nanooctahedra (NOh) was quite unexpected as it is typically difficult to control the size and morphology of nanomaterials without the use of a surface-directing agent or aggressive reaction conditions. However, the present method indicates that optimization of the reaction conditions during the synthesis can lead to morphology tuning. For the first time, it was observed that the addition of base to the metal precursor solution at 708C is crucial to tune the morphology to NOh.

The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the NOh can be indexed to the FCC structure of MnFe2O4 (JCPDS card no. 74-2403). The appearance of sharp and well-defined peaks indicates that the material is highly crystalline in nature. The FT-IR spectrum shows a band in the region of 400–500 cm1 corresponding to Mn-O and Fe-O stretching frequencies. The electron-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrum shows peaks corresponding to Mn, Fe and O, confirming the purity of the material. The distribution of Mn, Fe and O in NOh can be visualized by X-ray mapping images of NOh. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of MnFe2O4 nanoparticles of approximately 150 nm in size can be achieved through a simple co-precipitation method involving the addition of a NaOH solution to a metal precursor solution of Mn2+ and Fe2+ ions at specific temperatures. The resulting product can be analyzed and confirmed using various methods such as SEM, TEM, XRD, FT-IR spectrum, and EDX spectrum.

The synthesis of AuPt nanostructures, including Au0.75Pt0.25 nanoparticles, is described in the article. The method involves co-reduction of Au3+ and Pt2+ in aqueous solutions. The composition of the nanoparticles can be easily tuned by adjusting the molar ratios of added Pt2+ to Au3+. 

For the synthesis, desirable volumes of 17mM AuCl4− and 24mM PtCl4 2− are mixed in 2mL H2O according to the calculated Au/Pt molar ratio in the bimetallic alloy. For Au0.75Pt0.25 nanoparticles, the Au/Pt molar ratio would be 3/1. A 40μl 0.1M AA (L-ascorbic acid) solution is then added into the homogenous solution and shaken vigorously. The solution is placed in a 30 °C water bath for 2 hours. The color of the solution becomes dark brown, suggesting the formation of AuPt bimetallic nanoparticles. 

Afterwards, 0.1 mL 0.1M CTAB (cetyltrimethylammonium bromide) is added into the solutions. The same procedure is used to prepare pure Au and Pt nanoparticles except without the addition of either PtCl4 2− or AuCl4−. The samples are then purified by centrifugation at 12000 rounds per minute for 10 minutes and the precipitation is re-dispersed in water. 

The synthesized nanoparticles are named as AuxPt1-x alloy nanoparticles, where x represents the added Au/Pt ratio. In the case of Au0.75Pt0.25 nanoparticles, the Au/Pt ratio is 3/1. 

The article does not specify the size of the nanoparticles synthesized using this method. However, the size of nanoparticles can often be controlled by adjusting the reaction conditions, such as the concentration of the precursors, the reaction temperature, and the reaction time. 

The characterization of the nanoparticles is performed using a UV-VIS-NIR Spectrometer (Varian Cary 5000) and a matched quartz cuvette with a path length of 1 cm. The crystal structures of the AuPt alloy nanoparticles are also studied.

The samples were purified by centrifugation at 12000 rounds per min for 10 min and the precipitation was re-dispersed in water. The AuxPt1-x alloy NPs were named as Au0.75Pt0.25, Au0.5Pt0.5, Au0.4Pt0.6, Au0.25Pt0.75, Au0.15Pt0.85 and Au0.09Pt0.91 alloy NPs, respectively, according to the added Au/Pt ratio.

The synthesis of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) of approximately 1.7 nm in size was achieved through a one-pot reaction in an aqueous solution, utilizing Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) as both a reductant and a stabilizer. This method is described as simple, green, and economical. The use of sodium borohydride, a common reducing agent that is harmful to organisms and the environment, was avoided. Additionally, PVP as a stabilizer is cheaper and more eco-friendly compared to other substances like polyamidoamine dendrimers, heparin, and mercaptans.

In a typical synthesis procedure, sodium acetate trihydrate was added into 40 mL of Chloroplatinic acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6⋅6H2O) solution (62 mg, 0.12 mmol) to adjust the pH value to 7.0. Then, 20 mL PVP solution (Mw = 30,000, 2.7 g) was added dropwise under vigorous stirring. After stirring for 2 hours, the obtained light yellow solution was immersed in an oil bath and heated to reflux for 4 hours at a temperature of 110 ◦C. The resulting black colloid was centrifuged using 15 mL ultracentrifugal filter devices (Millipore Amicon Ultra-15, 50 kDa) to remove the residual PVP and washed by ultrapure water several times. The concentration of the resulting PVP-stabilized Pt nanoclusters (PVP-Pt NCs) was adjusted to 1 mg/mL (counted as Pt content) for further use.

The PVP-Pt NCs were found to be monodisperse and mostly quasi-spherical, with no agglomeration observed. This was attributed to the steric hindrance effect of the PVP stabilizer on the surface of the Pt nanoclusters. The average size of the PVP-Pt NCs was approximately 1.7 nm, as determined by statistically analyzing more than 200 nanoparticles from Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) images. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image showed that the crystal lattice space of the PVP-Pt NCs was 0.224 nm, corresponding well to the (111) facet of metallic Pt.

The chemical states of the as-prepared PVP-Pt NCs were investigated using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The strong peaks of Pt 4f, C 1s, N 1s, and O 1s were clearly observed, with the C, O, and N elements mainly coming from PVP molecules. The peaks of binding energies at 70.7 and 74.1 eV corresponded to the 4f7/2 and 4f5/2 of metallic species of Pt(0), respectively. The peaks at 71.7 and 76.1 eV could be ascribed to the oxidized species of Pt2+. No Pt4+ species were observed in the PVP-Pt NCs, indicating the complete reduction of H2PtCl6. The PVP-Pt NCs remained uniform and showed no apparent precipitate after six months of placement, suggesting good water solubility.

The synthesis of MnO2 nanoparticles (NPs) with a size of around 4.5 nm was achieved using bovine serum albumin (BSA) as a template. The process involved several steps and parameters, including the use of specific reagents, equipment, and conditions.

In a typical process, 25 mg BSA with 10 mL of 0.01 mol L1 PBS buffer was transferred into a 20 mL reaction flask, then 50 mL of 100 mmol L1 MnAc2 aqueous solution was added. The mixed solution of Mn2+–BSA emulsion was kept stirring for 2 min at room temperature, and then 50 mL of 1 mol L1 NaOH aqueous solution was added to the as-prepared solutions. After NaOH addition, the color of the solution immediately changed to an orange color. Finally, the BSA-MnO2 NPs were obtained after stirring for 6–8 h. The solution was then dialyzed in double distilled water for 48 h and centrifuged at 18 500 rpm for 30 min to remove unreacted MnAc2 and NaOH. The final solution was stored at 4 C in a refrigerator when not in use.

The biomineralization of MnO2 with BSA may be a multistep process involving Mn(II) binding, oxidation by oxygen, nucleation and crystal growth with uniform orientation. As shown in Fig. 1a, BSA provided amino acid residues for specific affinity with Mn(II). MnO2 was achieved by oxidation of Mn(II) in air, and the deposition/crystallization of MnO2 should occur selectively only on the specific sites of BSA. During the process, oxygen was important. When the reaction was bubbled with high purity nitrogen, no MnO2 NPs were formed, indicating that oxygen may participate in the reaction to form the Mn–O bond. The addition of NaOH was also necessary. No NPs were obtained without NaOH, indicating that pH is very important.

The UV-vis absorption spectrum was used to investigate the formation of MnO2 NPs. Firstly, as shown in Fig. S2a, ESI,† when the pH was greater than 11.62, the BSA-Mn2+ was mostly transformed into BSA-MnO2 NPs. Secondly, different reaction temperatures were investigated (Fig. S2b, ESI†). It was found that MnO2 NPs formed very quickly when the temperature was at the range from 20 C to 50 C; a higher temperature, however, could cause BSA inactivation. Thirdly, ionic strength was investigated using different concentrations of NaCl (Fig. S2c, ESI†), and 0.01 mol L1 ionic strength was best due to the solubility of BSA. Lastly, the molar ratio of BSA and Mn2+ precursor was critical for controlling the size of the NPs. As shown in Fig. S2d, ESI,† decreasing the concentration of BSA led to the sedimentation of the MnO2 NPs. Thus, the molar ratio of 3.7 : 100 for BSA and Mn2+ precursor, respectively, was used.

The synthesis of Au@PtAg nanostructures, which includes nanoparticles (NPs), is described in the article. The process involves two main steps: the synthesis of gold nanorods (NRs) and the synthesis of Au@PtAg nanostructures.

For the synthesis of gold nanorods, a seed-mediated method is used. CTAB-capped Au seeds are synthesized by the chemical reduction of HAuCl4 with NaBH4. Specifically, 7.5 mL of CTAB (0.1 M) aqueous solution is mixed with 100 mL of HAuCl4 (24 mM) and diluted with water to 9.4 mL. Then, 0.6 mL of ice-cold NaBH4 (0.01 M) is added with magnetic stirring. After 3 minutes, the stirring is stopped and the seed solution is kept undisturbed at 30 degrees Celsius for 2–5 hours. The seeds can be used within 2–5 hours after preparation. 

After that, the growth solution of the Au NRs is prepared, which consists of CTAB (0.1 M, 100 mL), HAuCl4 (25.5 mL, 1.96 mL), AgNO3 (0.01 M, 1.0 mL), H2SO4 (0.1 M, 2 mL), and AA (0.1 M, 0.8 mL). Then 240 mL of seed solution is added to the above growth solution to initiate the growth of the Au NRs. After 12 hours, the Au NRs are purified by centrifugation at 12,000 rpm for 10 minutes. The precipitate is collected and redispersed in deionized water. The volume used is 100 mL.

For the synthesis of Au@PtAg nanostructures, a PtCl4 22 aqueous solution (2 mM) is prepared as follows: 0.0688 g of K2PtCl4 is dissolved in 2 mL of 0.2 M aqueous HCl solution and then diluted to 100 mL with deionized water. 1 mL of the above Au NR solution is mixed with 23.5 mL of 2 mM PtCl4 22 solution. Then, 5 mL of AA (0.1 M) is added. The mixture is shaken vigorously and placed in a 30 degrees Celsius water bath. Within 5–6 hours, the color of the solution changes from pink-red to gray, suggesting the formation of the Pt shell. The calculated Pt/Au molar ratio is 0.1. The products are denoted as Au@Pt0.1 NRs.

For the synthesis of Au@PtAg nanostructures, the above solution (2 mL) is mixed with different volumes (0, 2, 2.67, 3.2, 4, 5.3, 8, 12, 24, 40 mL) of 10 mM AgNO3 and 40 mL of 2 mM PtCl4 22. The corresponding Ag/Pt ratios are 0, 0.25, 0.33, 0.4, 0.5, 0.67, 1, 1.5, 3 and 5. After that, 8 mL of AA (0.1 M) is added. The mixtures are then shaken vigorously and placed in a 30 degrees Celsius water bath. Within several minutes, the colors of the solutions change from gray to darker gray. After 1 hour, 1 mL of 0.1 M CTAB is added to stabilize the Au@PtAg NRs. The products are purified by centrifugation (12,000 rpm for 10 minutes). The precipitate is then redispersed in deionized water.

The Au@PtAg nanostructures are then coated with PSS. 1.0 mL of Au@PtAg suspension is purified by centrifugation (12,000 rpm for 5 minutes). The precipitate is then redispersed in 1.0 mL of water and mixed with 50 mL of 20 mg mL21 PSS solution (containing 60 mM NaCl). The suspension is placed in a 30 degrees Celsius water bath for at least 3 hours. The synthesis of Au@PtAg nanostructures, including those with a Ag/Pt ratio of 0.33, involves several steps as described in the article. 

Firstly, gold nanorods (NRs) are synthesized via a seed-mediated method. CTAB-capped Au seeds are synthesized by the chemical reduction of HAuCl4 with NaBH4. Specifically, 7.5 mL of CTAB (0.1 M) aqueous solution is mixed with 100 mL of HAuCl4 (24 mM) and diluted with water to 9.4 mL. Then, 0.6 mL of ice-cold NaBH4 (0.01 M) is added with magnetic stirring. After 3 min, the stirring is stopped and the seed solution is kept undisturbed at 30 uC for 2–5 h. The seeds can be used within 2–5 h after preparation. 

After that, the growth solution of the Au NRs is prepared, which consists of CTAB (0.1 M, 100 mL), HAuCl4 (25.5 mL, 1.96 mL), AgNO3 (0.01 M, 1.0 mL), H2SO4 (0.1 M, 2 mL), and AA (0.1 M, 0.8 mL). Then 240 mL of seed solution is added to the above growth solution to initiate the growth of the Au NRs. After 12 h, the Au NRs are purified by centrifugation at 12 000 rpm for 10 min. The precipitate is collected and redispersed in deionized water. The volume used is 100 mL.

For the synthesis of Au@PtAg nanostructures, a PtCl4 22 aqueous solution (2 mM) is prepared as follows: 0.0688 g of K2PtCl4 is dissolved in 2 mL of 0.2 M aqueous HCl solution and then diluted to 100 mL with deionized water. 1 mL of the above Au NR solution is mixed with 23.5 mL of 2 mM PtCl4 22 solution. Then, 5 mL of AA (0.1 M) is added. The mixture is shaken vigorously and placed in a 30 uC water bath. Within 5–6 h, the color of the solution changes from pink-red to gray, suggesting the formation of the Pt shell. The calculated Pt/Au molar ratio is 0.1. The products are denoted as Au@Pt0.1 NRs.

For the synthesis of Au@PtAg nanostructures, the above solution (2 mL) is mixed with different volumes (0, 2, 2.67, 3.2, 4, 5.3, 8, 12, 24, 40 mL) of 10 mM AgNO3 and 40 mL of 2 mM PtCl4 22. The corresponding Ag/Pt ratios are 0, 0.25, 0.33, 0.4, 0.5, 0.67, 1, 1.5, 3 and 5. After that, 8 mL of AA (0.1 M) is added. The mixtures are then shaken vigorously and placed in a 30 uC water bath. Within several minutes, the colors of the solutions change from gray to darker gray. After 1 h, 1 mL of 0.1 M CTAB is added to stabilize the Au@PtAg NRs. The products are purified by centrifugation (12 000 rpm for 10 min). The precipitate is then redispersed in deionized water.

Finally, the Au@PtAg nanostructures are coated with PSS. 1.0 mL of Au@PtAg suspension is purified by centrifugation (12 000 rpm for 5 min). The precipitate is then redispersed in 1.0 mL of water and mixed with 50 mL of 20 mg mL21 PSS solution (containing 60 mM NaCl). The suspension is placed in a 30 uC water bath for at least 3 h. After that, centrifugation (12000 rpm 5 min) is executed once to remove the excess PSS and the precipitate is redispersed in water or buffer solution for further use.

The characterization of the as-prepared photocatalysts was done using various instruments including X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Rigaku Ultima IV), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi S-4800), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100) equipped with the selected area electron diffraction (SAED), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250), BET specific surface area (NOVA 4000e), and zeta potential (Zetasizer Nano-ZS).

The article does not provide specific instructions for adjusting the size of the nanoparticles to 2000 nm. However, it is generally understood in the field of nanoparticle synthesis that factors such as the concentration of the reagents, the temperature of the reaction, and the duration of the reaction can influence the size of the resulting nanoparticles.

The synthesis of Ch-PtNPs, or Chitosan-Platinum Nanoparticles, is described in the provided text. The TEM image in Fig. 1C revealed that Ch-PtNPs had good dispersity with an average particle diameter of 2.1±0.3 nm. This result could be well supported by the hydrodynamic diameter measurement (Fig. S2). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image indicated a continuous lattice spacing of 0.20 nm (Fig. 1C inset), which corresponds to the (200) planes of Pt. The significant Pt signals observed in the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) spectrum suggested that the nanoparticles incorporated into the Ch were Pt (Fig. S3).

The synthesis process is as follows: 2 mL of 10 mM H2PtCl6 was mixed with 47 mL of 0.2% Ch and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Then, 1 mL of a newly prepared solution of NaBH4 (0.2 M) was injected within 5 min and stirred for 90 min at room temperature. The as-synthesized Ch-PtNPs could be stored at 4 °C in the dark for at least one year with negligible changes in their colloidal stability and catalytic activity.

In the XPS results shown in Fig. 1D, the Pt 4f7/2 peak could be deconvoluted into two different components at binding energies of 72.38 and 72.91 eV, corresponding to Pt0 and Pt2+, respectively. The relative amounts of Pt0 and Pt2+ in the Ch-PtNPs were determined to be 55% and 45%, respectively. Remarkably, the oxidation state in the Ch-PtNPs was quite different from that of other previously reported PtNPs, which commonly consisted of Pt0 and Pt4+ species.

In conclusion, a simple, one-step approach for synthesizing PtNPs using Ch as the stabilizer and NaBH4 as the reducing agent was introduced. Interestingly, unlike some previously reported stabilizing molecules, Ch did not affect the catalytic active sites of PtNPs. Kinetic studies indicated that the Ch-PtNPs have a higher affinity for TMB than other types of oxidase mimics.

The article describes the synthesis of TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) using a modified procedure. The specific size of the nanoparticles is not mentioned in the synthesis process, but the characterization of the nanoparticles indicates that they are spherical in shape with an average size of about 3−5 nm. 

For the synthesis, 4.5 mL of tetra-n-butyl titanate was added into 75 mL of distilled water dropwise and then the mixture was stirred for 2 hours at room temperature. Subsequently, the solution was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 433 K for 24 hours. The acquired products were filtered and washed with distilled water several times and dried at 333 K for 12 hours.

The as obtained TiO2 NPs were redispersed in water by ultrasonication. TiO2−CA NPs were acquired by mixing 250 μL of catechol (CA, 1.0 × 10−4 mol/L) and 1 mL of TiO2 NPs solution (1.5 mg/mL) for a moment and then centrifuged and redispersed in 1 mL of ultrapure water.

The characterization of the nanoparticles was performed using a variety of techniques. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were performed using a JEOL JEM-2100 transmission electron microscope. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were captured on a Hitachi S-4800 high-resolution scanning electron microscope. The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) pattern was obtained by an X’Pert Philips materials research diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation and employing a scanning speed of 0.02° s−1 in the 2θ range of 20 to 75°. Fourier transform-infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet FT-IR 6700 spectrometer.

The article does not provide specific details on how to control the size of the nanoparticles during synthesis. However, it was found that the size of TiO2 NPs influenced the phototriggered oxidase-like activity of the formed TiO2−CA. As the size of TiO2 NPs decreases, the catalytic activity of the formed TiO2−CA increases. This can be explained that the surface sites available for the formation of the charge transfer complex decrease when the sizes of TiO2 NPs increase. The binding of enediol-ligands to TiO2 NPs occurs only with smaller particle sizes (D < 20 nm).

The synthesis of yolk-shell Au@HCNs (Au nanoparticles encapsulated by hollow carbon nanospheres) is described in the article. Firstly, a wine-red solution of Au nanoparticles was prepared according to the previous literature. The exact concentration or mmols of the Au nanoparticles is not specified in the article. These Au nanoparticles were then capped with a SiO2 shell by tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) hydrolysis through the Stöber process, yielding Au@SiO2 nanospheres. 

Next, the Au@SiO2 nanospheres were impregnated with dopamine in Tris-HCl buffer (pH=8.5). After that, the Au@SiO2@polydopamine (PDA) nanocomposites were obtained by polymerization of dopamine molecules on the surface of Au@SiO2 slowly. The exact concentration or mmols of dopamine and Tris-HCl buffer used is not specified in the article.

Subsequently, the obtained Au@SiO2@PDA nanoparticles were carbonized in N2 at 800 °C for 2 hours. Finally, the silica core was etched with NaOH, giving rise to a yolk-shell structure of Au particles encapsulated by hollow carbon nanospheres, abbreviated as Au@HCNs. The exact concentration or mmols of NaOH used is not specified in the article.

It is worth emphasizing that the dopamine used in the experiments provides a nitrogen source, and the nitrogen atoms incorporated in the carbon shell are considered to be an effective method to regulate the properties of carbon, which expands the potential applications of the carbon materials. For purposes of comparison, N-doped hollow carbon nanospheres (HCNs) were also synthesized as the control group.

The successful encapsulation of Au in the hollow carbon spheres was further confirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image demonstrates that the diameter of Au nanoparticle was about ~ 10 nm and the carbon shell thickness was 6 ~ 7 nm. The lattice spacings of Au nanoparticles were 0.235 nm and 0.204 nm, which were consistent with Au (111) and Au (200) planes, respectively. The energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) line scan of Au@HCNs suggested that the shell mainly contained C and N, and the dark nanoparticle inside the shell was Au.

The synthesis of Co3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes and morphologies, including nanoplates, nanorods, and nanocubes, is described in the article. 

For the synthesis of Co3O4 nanoplates, 1.3 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 100 mL of water and mixed with 100 mL of solution containing 0.6 g of hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA), under continuous stirring. A few drops of 1 M NaOH solution were then added in the above solution to obtain pH 10. The solution was vigorously stirred for 2 h, and then transferred into the autoclaves, sealed, and maintained at 110 °C for 15 h. After these processes, the autoclaves were naturally cooled to room temperature, and the synthesized products were washed with water, ethanol, and acetone sequentially and dried at room temperature. The synthesized products were then calcined at 200 °C for 2 h.

The Co3O4 nanorods were prepared by dissolving 1.66 g of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O in 20 mL of ethylene glycol, and the solution was gradually heated to 160 °C. At a continuous flow of nitrogen, 67 mL of aqueous 0.2 M sodium carbonate solution was added at the rate of 1.1 mL min−1 under vigorous stirring. Then the slurry was further stirred and aged for 1 h. After centrifugation, the solid was washed with water, dried at 50 °C overnight under vacuum, and then calcined at 450 °C for 4 h in air.

The Co3O4 nanocubes were synthesized by dissolving 0.50 g of Co(CH3COO)2·4H2O in the solution of 10 mL of water and 15 mL of ethanol. Under vigorous stirring, 2.5 mL of 25% ammonia was added drop by drop to the above solution. The solution was stirred for about 15 min in air, and the solution was transferred into an autoclave with 48 mL volume, sealed, and heated to 150 °C for 3 h. Then, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature naturally. The black products were obtained by centrifugation, washed with water several times, and dried at 60 °C overnight under vacuum.

The size and morphology of the Co3O4 nanomaterials were measured by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with a SU-8000 SEM (Hitachi, Japan) and transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F30, USA). The composition and phase of the Co3O4 nanomaterials were obtained by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) with a X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å).

The synthesis of platinum nanoparticles (Pt NPs) of approximately 1 nm in size was achieved using apoferritin (apoFt) as a nanoreactor. The process began with a solution of apoFt (1 mM, 2.5 mL) mixed with K2PtCl4 (24 mM, 126 mL). To increase the electrostatic interaction between Pt ions and the interior surface of apoFt, the solution was adjusted to pH 8.5 using 0.2 M NaOH, followed by stirring for 2 hours at room temperature. 

After this, a solution of NaBH4 (0.2 M, 150 mL) was added to the mixture and stirred for 3 hours at room temperature. This reduction process resulted in the formation of zero-valent Pt NPs. The color of the solution changed to dark brown, with the intensity varying depending on the amount of Pt ions used. The absorption spectra also changed during reduction. The initial protein solution showed one peak at 280 nm; two small absorption peaks appeared at 305 and 380 nm after mixing with Pt ions. Finally, the two small peaks were replaced with a broad absorption spectrum, which is typical for Pt colloids after reduction reactions.

To avoid any by-product, the PteFt composite was purified by size-exclusion chromatography (Sephacryl S-300), using deionized water as elution buffer, and the first peak was collected at 280 nm monitored by Ultraviolet Detector. The TEM images showed that the Pt NPs were largely monodispersed and roughly spherical. The Pt NPs have an average diameter of 1.87 ± 0.40 nm as shown in the histogram.

In the absence of apoFt, a black amorphous precipitate was observed. In contrast, the PteFt preparation remained a clear, dark brown solution for weeks at room temperature. High-resolution TEM images indicated a continuous lattice spacing of 0.224 nm, which corresponds to the (111) facet of an fcc Pt crystal. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopies (EDX) confirmed that it was Pt, but not iron in the protein cage. These results suggest the specific formation of Pt NPs inside the apoFt nanocage. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of Pt NPs of approximately 1 nm in size was achieved using a solution of apoFt and K2PtCl4, adjusted to pH 8.5 and reduced with NaBH4. The resulting PteFt composite was purified by size-exclusion chromatography and confirmed to contain Pt NPs through TEM imaging and EDX spectroscopy.

The synthesis of RuO2 nanoparticles (NPs) with an average diameter of 4.0 nm was described in the article. The process was carried out using a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 electron microscope operated at 200 kV for transmission electron microscopy (TEM) experiments. The kinetics of the catalytic processes were investigated by UV–visible spectrophotometry on a V-570 UV/VIS/NIR spectrophotometer (JASCO Corp., Japan). Electrochemical experiments were carried out using a CH Instruments model 660 A electrochemical workstation.

The synthesis process was as follows: RuCl3 (0.10 g) was dissolved into methanol (25 mL). The solution was stirred magnetically and heated to 50 8C. An aliquot (10 mL) of NaOH (0.50m) in methanol was added dropwise. After the addition of water (25 mL), the reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave (200 mL) and annealed at 150–1908C for 10–12 h. 

The RuO2 NPs were collected and purified by multiple centrifugation/decantation/dispersion cycles with methanol, and were dried, overnight, at 100 8C in vacuum. Energy dispersive X-ray and X-ray photon spectroscopic analyses indicated that the NPs are essentially pure RuO2. 

Bioconjugation was done by first coating the RuO2 NPs with 2,2’-bipyridine-4,4’-dicarboxylic acid. Amine-terminated oligonucleotide DPs were then coupled to the carboxyl groups through 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-carbodiimide/N-hydroxysuccinimide chemistry. 

The article does not provide specific information on the mmols of the reagents used in the synthesis process.

The synthesis of CoFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) with an average diameter of 164.8 ± 20.7 nm was achieved through a solvothermal method. The morphology of the NPs was precisely regulated by varying the pH of the precursor solution. To enhance the biocompatibility and aqueous stability, PEGylation was concurrently realized upon the addition of NH2−PEG3400-COOH as a surfactant additive.

The specific procedure for the synthesis of the CoFe2O4 NPs involved the following steps: FeCl3·6H2O and CoCl2·6H2O were dissolved in ethylene glycol, and NaAc was then added to the solution. Subsequently, NaOH was added dropwise to the previous system until a pH value of 12 was obtained. The mixture was transferred into a tetrafluoroethylene vessel, which was sealed in a stainless-steel autoclave. The autoclave was heated at a rate of 2 °C/min and maintained at 200 °C for 6 hours. The product of CoFe2O4 was magnetically isolated, followed by being washed twice with absolute ethyl alcohol and thrice with DI water.

To conjugate PEG, the CoFe2O4 NPs were mixed with NH2−PEG3400-COOH (32 μg/mL, 1:1 by weight), and the reaction proceeded under stirring at 25 °C for 24 hours. Finally, the CoFe2O4 NPs were magnetically separated and thoroughly washed with DI water prior to any use.

The synthesized CoFe2O4 NPs exhibited a well-defined flower-like structure with a narrow size distribution. The large surface area of the NPs would provide more active sites for catalytic reactions. Moreover, these NPs displayed admirably high dispersity without significant aggregation. The hydrated size of the NPs was determined to be ∼280.1 nm through dynamic light scattering (DLS), and the slightly enlarged size under aqueous condition was within the effective range of enhanced permeation and retention (EPR) taking effect. The crystal structure of the NPs matched that of pristine CoFe2O4 from the X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern, indicating a high crystalline purity of the NPs but with a bit of crystalline cobalt impurity doping. Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was performed to testify the effective conjugation of PEG onto CoFe2O4.

The synthesis of Eu2O2S nanoparticles was carried out using a solvothermal route. The solvent used was a long chain primary amine, oleylamine, which also acted as a strong electron donor at elevated temperature and as a surfactant in the nanoparticle synthesis. The precursor complex [(Et3NH)]+[Eu(acda)4] was obtained by reacting one equivalent of europium(III) nitrate with four equivalents each of 2-aminocyclopentene-1-dithiocarboxylic acid (Hacda) and triethylamine. 

The synthesis was carried out in an open atmosphere. The FT-IR spectra obtained for the three types of nanoparticle in the range of 4000–400 cm1 clearly revealed the absence of any adsorbed organic materials. All the syntheses were carried out in an open atmosphere. 

Different structure-modifying capping agents were used at an elevated temperature to control the shape and size of the nanoparticles. When oleic acid and octadecene were introduced into the system as the surfactant along with oleylamine, the material crystallized in the form of ultra-thin 3D hexagonal nanoplates with a surface diameter of 8–12 nm and thickness of 0.3 nm. 

On the other hand, when the surfactant oleic acid and 1-octadecene were replaced by trioctylphosphine, this resulted in a notable change in shape resulting in nanosphere formation. The average spherical diameter of the particles was about 13 (2.5) nm. 

When the choice of both reacting amine and surfactant is constrained to oleylamine, the outcome is the formation of short rod-like particles of dimensions of 3.0 (1) nm x 7.0 (1) nm in addition to the formation of smaller nanocrystals.

The synthesis of Eu2O2S nanoparticles was carried out using a solvothermal route. The solvent used was a long chain primary amine, oleylamine, which also acted as a strong electron donor at elevated temperature and as a surfactant in the nanoparticle synthesis. The precursor complex [(Et3NH)]+[Eu(acda)4] was obtained by reacting one equivalent of europium(III) nitrate with four equivalents each of 2-aminocyclopentene-1-dithiocarboxylic acid (Hacda) and triethylamine. 

Different structure-modifying capping agents were used at an elevated temperature to achieve nanoparticles of different morphologies. All the syntheses were carried out in an open atmosphere. The FT-IR spectra obtained for the three types of nanoparticle in the range of 4000–400 cm1 clearly revealed the absence of any adsorbed organic materials.

When oleic acid and octadecene were introduced into the system as the surfactant along with oleylamine, the material crystallized in the form of ultra-thin 3D hexagonal nanoplates with a surface diameter of 8–12 nm and thickness of 0.3 nm. It has been reported that alkylamines show weaker binding capacity to metal centers on the surface of the nanoparticles compared to that of carboxylic acids of similar chain length. Therefore, it has been anticipated that more strongly adsorbed oleic acid leads to surface stabilization and the formation of hexagonal nanoplates.

On the other hand, when the surfactant oleic acid and 1-octadecene were replaced by trioctylphosphine, this resulted in a notable change in shape resulting in nanosphere formation. When trioctylphosphine is rapidly injected into the reaction vessel, it readily binds to the surface of growing nanoparticles more effectively than oleylamine and rejects the chance of preferential growth in a favored direction by reducing surface energy. The nanoparticles with their surfaces protected by this phosphine ligand easily also discourages agglomeration. The average spherical diameter of the particles is about 13 (2.5) nm.

When the choice of both reacting amine and surfactant is constrained to oleylamine, the outcome is the formation of short rod-like particles of dimensions of 3.0 (1) nm x 7.0 (1) nm in addition to the formation of smaller nanocrystals. These irregular shape distribution and significantly low particle size are perhaps due to the weaker binding capacity of oleylamine to the metal surface by the non covalent interaction, preventing aggregation.

The synthesis of Eu2O2S nanoparticles (NPs) of approximately 13 nm in size is described in the provided article. The process involves solvothermal decomposition of a precursor complex, followed by the use of various surfactants to modulate the shape and size of the nanoparticles.

The precursor complex used in the synthesis is [NHEt3]+[Eu(acda)4], where acda is the anion of 2-aminocyclopentene-1-dithiocarboxylic acid. This complex is prepared by mixing Eu(NO3)35H2O and Hacda in methanol, followed by the slow addition of a methanol solution of triethylamine. The resulting deep orange microcrystalline solid is then filtered and washed with cold methanol.

For the synthesis of Eu2O2S nanoplates, a mixture of oleylamine, oleic acid, and octadecene is stirred and heated to 80 1C until a clear orange colored solution is formed. The precursor complex is then added and the mixture is heated to 280 1C for 1 hour. After cooling to room temperature, dry ethanol is slowly added to precipitate the light yellow product. The solid is then dispersed in toluene and reprecipitated with ethanol. This process is repeated four times to ensure the product is free from reactants.

To synthesize Eu2O2S nanospheres, oleylamine is first heated to 280 1C. A homogeneous suspension of the precursor complex in trioctylphosphine is then rapidly injected into the vigorously stirred oleylamine. After 1 hour, the reaction mixture is cooled to room temperature and dry ethanol is added to deposit a creamy product. This product is then centrifuged, dispersed in toluene, and reprecipitated with ethanol, repeating the process as described for the nanoplates.

For the synthesis of Eu2O2S rod-like particles, oleylamine is used both as the solvent and stabilizer. The precursor complex is suspended in oleylamine and heated at 120 1C for 20 minutes to form a clear solution. The temperature of the solution is then rapidly increased to 280 1C and maintained for 1 hour. After cooling to room temperature, the product is isolated in the same way as described for nanoplates.

The physical measurements of the synthesized nanoparticles are performed using various techniques such as Powder XRD patterns, Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FE-SEM), Infrared spectroscopy, Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), UV-Vis spectrophotometry, and BET surface area analysis.

The synthesis of Eu2O2S nanoparticles (NPs) of different sizes and shapes is described in the article. The precursor complex [NHEt3]+[Eu(acda)4] is used for the synthesis, where acda is the anion of 2-aminocyclopentene-1-dithiocarboxylic acid. The precursor complex is synthesized by mixing [Eu(NO3)35H2O] (0.86 g, 2 mmol) in 5 mL methanol and Hacda (1.26 g, 8 mmol) in 20 mL methanol. Subsequently, a methanol solution of triethylamine (0.81 g, 8 mmol) is slowly added with stirring to the above solution. A deep orange microcrystalline solid begins to deposit almost immediately. The product is filtered and washed with cold methanol after 0.5 h of stirring.

For the synthesis of Eu2O2S nanoplates, a stirred mixture of oleylamine (6 mL), oleic acid (2 mL), octadecene (2 mL), and 0.4 g of the precursor complex are used. The temperature of the mixture is maintained at 80 1C until a clear orange colored solution is formed. It is then heated to 280 1C for 1 h, during which the color of the solution fades to become a pale yellow colloid. After cooling to room temperature, dry ethanol is slowly added with stirring to precipitate the light yellow product, which is obtained by centrifugation (20 min at 9000 rpm). The solid is dispersed in toluene and reprecipitated again with ethanol. The process is repeated four times to make the product free from reactants. It is then dried in vacuum.

For the synthesis of Eu2O2S nanospheres, oleylamine is first heated to 280 1C in a flask and maintained at this temperature. A homogeneous suspension of the precursor complex (0.4 g) in trioctylphosphine is rapidly injected to the vigorously stirred oleylamine through a cannula. After 1 h, the reaction mixture is cooled to room temperature and dry ethanol (40 mL) is added to deposit a creamy product. This is centrifuged, dispersed in toluene and reprecipitated with ethanol. The process is repeated as stated above.

For the synthesis of Eu2O2S rod-like particles, oleylamine is used both as the solvent and stabilizer. The precursor complex (0.4 g) is suspended in oleylamine (8 mL) and heated at 120 1C for 20 min to form a clear solution. The temperature of the stirred solution is then rapidly increased to 280 1C and maintained for 1 h. After cooling to room temperature, the product is isolated in the same way as described for nanoplates.

The average spherical diameter of the particles is about 13 (2.5) nm. The shape modulation was further extended by replacing the surfactant oleic acid and 1-octadecene by trioctylphosphine. This resulted in a notable change in shape resulting in nanosphere formation. When trioctylphosphine is rapidly injected into the reaction vessel, it readily binds to the surface of growing nanoparticles more effectively than oleylamine and rejects the chance of preferential growth in a favored direction by reducing surface energy. The nanoparticles with their surfaces protected by this phosphine ligand easily also discourages agglomeration.

The synthesis of porous ruthenium selenide nanoparticles (P-RuSe2) was carried out using KIT-6 silica templates. The chemicals and materials used for the synthesis included RuCl3·xH2O, selenium powder, ethanol, n-butanol, hydrofluoric acid (40%), hydrochloric acid (37%), o-phenylenediamine (OPD), and polyethylene oxide–polypropylene oxide–polyethylene (PEO-PPO-PEO), all of which were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Hydrogen peroxide (30%), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), 2,2′-azinobis(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) (ABTS), and 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine dihydrochloride (TMB) were obtained from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemical reagents were utilized as received without any further purification. All aqueous solutions were prepared using deionized water (18.2 MΩ•cm, Millipore).

The synthesis of P-RuSe2 involved several steps. First, 1 g of RuCl3·xH2O was dissolved into 10 mL of ethanol. Then, 1 g of calcined KIT-6 template was added into RuCl3 solution under stirring. The temperature of the solution was raised to 60 °C and stirred until ethanol evaporated. After loading into KIT-6 templates, the RuCl3 salt was placed in one crucible, and 0.5 g selenium powder was placed in another crucible. These two crucibles were loaded into a quartz tube furnace, where the selenium powder was placed upstream. Then, the sample was heated to 550 °C at a ramp rate of 2 °C/min and maintained at 550 °C for 2 h under a forming gas of 10% H2 in argon. Finally, P-RuSe2 was obtained by removing KIT-6 silica templates with HF solution (1 M).

The characterization of P-RuSe2 was carried out using various instruments. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained using a Zeiss Ultra55 microscopy. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected on a JEM-200CX microscope at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data was obtained on a Rigaku Ultima diffractometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data was collected on a PHI 5000 VersaProbe electron spectrometer. UV–visible absorption spectra were recorded with a TU-1900 spectrophotometer. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm was measured using a Quantachrome Autosorb-IQ-2C-TCD-VP analyzer, and the surface area and pore size were calculated with the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and the Barrett–Joyner-Halenda model, respectively. Plate reader data was collected using a Tecan Infinite 200 Pro microplate reader.

The synthesis of porous RuSe2 nanoparticles (P-RuSe2) was carried out using KIT-6 silica templates. The chemicals and materials used in the synthesis included RuCl3·xH2O, selenium powder, ethanol, n-butanol, hydrofluoric acid (40%), hydrochloric acid (37%), o-phenylenediamine (OPD), and polyethylene oxide–polypropylene oxide–polyethylene (PEO-PPO-PEO, P123). All these reagents were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Hydrogen peroxide (30%), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), 2,2′-azinobis(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) (ABTS), and 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine dihydrochloride (TMB) were obtained from Aladdin Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemical reagents were utilized as received without any further purification. All aqueous solutions were prepared using deionized water (18.2 MΩ•cm, Millipore).

The synthesis of mesoporous KIT‑6 silica templates was carried out according to the previous literature. Briefly, 20 g of P123 and 34 mL of HCl solution were added to 720 mL of deionized water and stirred in a polypropylene bottle. After the P123 dissolved, 20 g of n-butanol was added and stirred at 34 °C for 1 h. The solution was stirred at 34 °C for another 24 h after adding 43 g of TEOS. The product was collected by filtration and washed with deionized water. KIT-6 silica was obtained after calcination with 2 °C/min ramp to 550 °C for 5 h. The final product was dried overnight.

For the synthesis of P‑RuSe2, 1 g of RuCl3·xH2O was dissolved into 10 mL of ethanol. Then, 1 g of calcined KIT-6 template was added into RuCl3 solution under stirring. The temperature of the solution was raised to 60 °C and stirred until ethanol evaporated. After loading into KIT-6 templates, the RuCl3 salt was placed in one crucible, and 0.5 g selenium powder was placed in another crucible. These two crucibles were loaded into a quartz tube furnace, where the selenium powder was placed upstream. Then, the sample was heated to 550 °C at a ramp rate of 2 °C/min and maintained at 550 °C for 2 h under a forming gas of 10% H2 in argon. Finally, P-RuSe2 was obtained by removing KIT-6 silica templates with HF solution (1 M).

Bulk‑RuSe2 (B‑RuSe2) was synthesized using the same protocol with P-RuSe2 in the absence of the KIT-6 template. The TEM image demonstrated that the porous network nanostructure was composed of spherical nanoparticles with the diameter of about 5 nm.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 15000 nm YVO4 nanoparticles. However, it does detail the preparation of YVO4 flower-like microstructures via a hydrothermal process. 

In this process, 1.0 mmol of NH4VO3 and 1.0 mmol of Y(NO3)3⋅6H2O were dissolved in 30 mL of Milli-Q water under continuous stirring to form solution A and B, respectively. Then solution B was slowly added into solution A with continuous stirring to obtain a suspension. After adjusting the pH of suspension to 1 and 10 min stirring, the suspension would be transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. Subsequently, the autoclave was sealed and maintained in an air dry oven at 180 ℃ for 24 h, which was naturally cooled to room temperature after the hydrothermal process. Afterwards, yellow precipitates would be gathered by filtration, successively washing by Milli-Q water and ethanol many times, and drying at 60 ◦C in air for 8 h. At last, YVO4 flower-like microstructures were obtained and denoted as YVFPs.

The crystal structure, morphology, chemical compositions and surface properties of YVO4 materials were analyzed by X-ray diffractometer (XRD), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), automatic nitrogen adsorption specific surface and pore size distribution analyzer, and zeta potential measuring instrument.

However, the specific size of the synthesized YVO4 structures is not mentioned in the article. The article only mentions that YVO4 presented a flower-like structure with a size of approximately 15 µm, which was assembled by many quadrangular prisms with a length of about 7 µm. These quadrangular prisms were attached with each other at each bottom and orderly arranged in certain direction, pointing at a common center.

The synthesis of nanoparticles decorated Ce2(WO4)3 nanosheets (CWNSs) was achieved through a facile hydrothermal process. The reagents used for the synthesis included 1.0 mmol of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 1.5 mmol Na2WO4·2H2O, which were added into 30 mL Milli-Q water under vigorous magnetic stirring, respectively. 

Following this, the Na2WO4 solution was added dropwise into the Ce(NO3)3 solution slowly under continuous stirring. This resulted in the formation of a suspension, and the pH was then adjusted to 7.0 by adding 2.0 M NaOH or 2.0 M HNO3. 

Subsequently, the suspension was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was sealed and maintained at 200 °C for 24 hours. After being cooled to room temperature naturally, the precipitates were collected by centrifugation, thoroughly rinsed repeatedly with Milli-Q water and ethanol several times, and dried at 60 °C in air for 6 hours. 

Finally, nanoparticles decorated Ce2(WO4)3 nanosheets were obtained and denoted as CWNSs. The morphology and microstructure of Ce2(WO4)3 were characterized by FESEM and HRTEM. The FESEM images showed Ce2(WO4)3 a uniform two-dimensional (2D) sheet-like structure with about 500 nm in size and about 50 nm in thickness. Besides, some small nanoparticles with the size of about 20 nm were seen dispersed on the surface of the nanosheets. 

The crystal structure, morphology, elemental compositions, and surface properties of Ce2(WO4)3 samples were characterized by X-ray diffractometer (XRD), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), selected area electron diffraction (SAED), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), specific surface area, and zeta potential.

The synthesis of nanoparticles decorated Ce2(WO4)3 nanosheets (CWNSs) was achieved through a facile hydrothermal process. The reagents used for the synthesis included 1.0 mmol of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 1.5 mmol Na2WO4·2H2O. These were added into 30 mL Milli-Q water under vigorous magnetic stirring, respectively. 

Afterwards, the Na2WO4 solution was added dropwise into the Ce(NO3)3 solution slowly under continuous stirring. This resulted in the formation of a suspension, and the pH was then adjusted to 7.0 by adding 2.0 M NaOH or 2.0 M HNO3. 

Subsequently, the suspension was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was sealed and maintained at 200 °C for 24 hours. After being cooled to room temperature naturally, the precipitates were collected by centrifugation, thoroughly rinsed repeatedly with Milli-Q water and ethanol several times, and dried at 60 °C in air for 6 hours. 

Finally, nanoparticles decorated Ce2(WO4)3 nanosheets were obtained and denoted as CWNSs. The crystal structure, morphology, elemental compositions, and surface properties of the Ce2(WO4)3 samples were characterized by X-ray diffractometer (XRD), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), selected area electron diffraction (SAED), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), specific surface area, and zeta potential. 

The FESEM images showed Ce2(WO4)3 a uniform two-dimensional (2D) sheet-like structure with about 500 nm in size and about 50 nm in thickness. Some small nanoparticles with the size of about 20 nm were seen dispersed on the surface of the nanosheets. The TEM image gives a detailed microstructure of Ce2(WO4)3. The Ce2(WO4)3 samples were composed of thin nanosheets with the size of about 500 nm, loading with some small nanoparticles on the surface, which is consistent with the FESEM image. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of nanoparticles decorated Ce2(WO4)3 nanosheets (CWNSs) was achieved through a facile hydrothermal process using Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and Na2WO4·2H2O as the main reagents. The process involved adjusting the pH of the solution, transferring the suspension to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, and maintaining the temperature at 200 °C for 24 hours. The resulting nanoparticles were characterized using various techniques to confirm their structure and composition.

The synthesis of CuS nanoclusters (NCs) with a size of 6.0 ± 0.4 nm was performed using Bovine serum albumin (BSA) as a template under mild conditions. The synthesis was carried out in an aqueous solution at room temperature. 

In a typical synthesis procedure, sodium citrate solution (5.0 mL, 8 mM) was added to CuCl2 solution (5.0 mL, 8.0 mM), which was stirred for 5 min. Then, Na2S solution (5.0 mL, 16.0 mM) was dropwise syringed into the above solution under vigorous stirring for 15 min at 37 ◦C. Afterwards, BSA solution (5.0 mL, 50 mg mL− 1) was added to the above mixture solution and incubated at 37 ◦C for 8 h. Finally, the solution was dialyzed against water for 24 h. The thus-yielded CuS was stored in darkness at 4 ◦C. 

The obtained nanoparticles were water-soluble, which were uniformly dispersed from Transmission electron microscopic (TEM) images with the size of 6.0 ± 0.4 nm, typical of nanoclusters. The TEM images were observed on an F20 S-TWIN instrument (FEI, USA). 

The chemicals and materials used in the synthesis included Bovine serum albumin (BSA), O-phenylenediamine (OPDA), copper chloride (CuCl2), trisodium citrate dihydrate and sodium sulfide nonahydrate (Na2S⋅9H2O) which were bought from J&K Scientific Ltd. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of CuS NCs was achieved using BSA as a template, sodium citrate, CuCl2, and Na2S as reagents, and the process was carried out in an aqueous solution at room temperature. The resulting CuS NCs were water-soluble and uniformly dispersed with a size of 6.0 ± 0.4 nm.

The synthesis of ZnS nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the provided text. The preparation of ZnS NPs involves the use of ionogels as precursors. In PPCT-Zn2+ ionogels, the Zn2+ is fixed at the fibrillar framework, which can be used as a precursor to prepare uniformly distributed zinc-based materials. The detailed preparation of ZnS nanomaterials using PPCT-Zn2+ ionogels as precursors is shown in the Supporting Information. The PPCT/Zn2+ ionogels are viscoelastic soft quasi-solid materials. 

The synthesis process involves the gradual release of Zn2+ from the ionogels by introducing NaHS into the ionogels, and ZnS precipitates are obtained. The XRD pattern of the obtained products indicates an fcc symmetry, which is in good agreement with the ICPDS files of ZnS (JCPDS NO. 65-5476). The crystal structure is refined to the F 4 3 space group with the lattice parameters of a = b = c = 5.404 Å. 

The TEM images reveal that the as-prepared ZnS NPs have a homogenous size distribution with an average diameter of about 10 nm. The N2 adsorption/desorption analysis of ZnS was performed, as shown in Figure 8e. The N2 sorption isotherm shows an obvious hysteresis loop in the range of P/P0 = 0.8 - 1.0 that can be classified as type (III), which confirms the formation of porous materials. 

For the preparation of ZnS Nanoparticles (NPs), Na2S, NaHS or TAA solution was added to the ionogels (30 mmol∙L−1 PPCT/60 mmol∙L−1 ZnCl2, 8 mL) to make the molar ratio of Zn2+ to S2- of 1:1. The deposition reactions occurred in the mixtures. After the reaction was completed, the ionogels were destroyed and the products at the bottom of the tube were collected by centrifugation and washed several times with alcohol and deionized water.

The specific BET surface area and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) adsorption pore volume were determined to be 102.25 m2∙g−1 and 0.54 cm3∙g−1, respectively, which are larger than those of other ZnS nanomaterials. The pore size has a uniform distribution of around 4.0 nm. The high surface areas and uniform pore sizes of ZnS provide a feasible environment to tolerate expansion and shrinkage that are caused by the adsorption of small molecules; thus, this material is a candidate catalyst to catalyze reactions.

The synthesis of ZnS Nanoparticles (NPs) with an average diameter of about 10 nm is described in the provided text. The preparation of ZnS NPs involves the use of ionogels (30 mmol∙L−1 PPCT/60 mmol∙L−1 ZnCl2, 8 mL) as precursors. The Zn2+ is fixed at the fibrillar framework of the ionogels, which can be used to prepare uniformly distributed zinc-based materials. Na2S, NaHS or TAA solution is added to the ionogels to make the molar ratio of Zn2+ to S2- of 1:1. The deposition reactions occur in the mixtures. After the reaction is completed, the ionogels are destroyed and the products at the bottom of the tube are collected by centrifugation and washed several times with alcohol and deionized water.

The XRD pattern of the obtained products indicates an fcc symmetry (Figure 8a), which is in good agreement with the ICPDS files of ZnS (JCPDS NO. 65-5476). The crystal structure is refined to the F 4 3 space group with the lattice parameters of a = b = c = 5.404 Å. The TEM images in Figure 8b reveal that the as-prepared ZnS NPs have a homogenous size distribution with an average diameter of about 10 nm. 

The N2 adsorption/desorption analysis of ZnS was performed, as shown in Figure 8e. The N2 sorption isotherm shows an obvious hysteresis loop in the range of P/P0 = 0.8 - 1.0 that can be classified as type (III), which confirms the formation of porous materials. The specific BET surface area and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) adsorption pore volume were determined to be 102.25 m2∙g−1 and 0.54 cm3∙g−1, respectively, which are larger than those of other ZnS nanomaterials. The pore size has a uniform distribution of around 4.0 nm (Figure 8f). 

The high surface areas and uniform pore sizes of ZnS provide a feasible environment to tolerate expansion and shrinkage that are caused by the adsorption of small molecules; thus, this material is a candidate catalyst to catalyze reactions. The obtained ZnS has an ideal architecture and can be used as a catalyst to catalyze chemical reactions. The catalytic oxidation of peroxidase substrate, 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethlbenzidine (TMB), in the presence of H2O2 was examined to evaluate the catalytic efficiency of ZnS NPs. The TMB-oxidized product can be traced by its maximum absorbance at 652 nm.
