The synthesis of hollow copper sulfide nanocubes (h-CuS NCs) of about 50 nm size was carried out using cuprous oxide nanoparticles as a template. The following reagents were used: 85.2 mg of copper(II) chloride dehydrate (CuCl2 2H2O), 0.5 g of polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), 2.5 mL of 0.2 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH), 2.5 mL of 0.1 M L-ascorbic acid, and 2.0 mL of 1.0 M sodium hydrogen sulfide nonahydrate (Na2S 9H2O). All solutions were prepared with ultrapure water.

In a typical experiment, firstly, CuCl2 2H2O and PVP were dissolved into 200 mL of water. After the solution was stirred for 5 minutes, NaOH was added dropwise. Then, L-ascorbic acid was dropwise added into the solution just 5 min after all NaOH was added. The mixture was continuously stirred for 5 min at room temperature. The solution was heated to 60 °C by heating in a water bath. Then, Na2S aqueous solution was added to the above solution, and the solution immediately became black and reacted at 60 °C for 3 h under stirring. 

The unreacted impurity was washed out by three centrifugation steps with water and ethanol (12000 rpm for 8 min). The product was dried for future research. The morphology of the as-prepared and h-CuS NCs was studied using a FEI-Tecnai G2 F30 transmission electron microscope (TEM) operating at an acceleration voltage of 100 kV. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) were recorded on a Bruker D8A25 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. 

The h-CuS NCs were successfully prepared with peroxidase-like activity using the freshly prepared Cu2O nanoparticles as a template by one pot method. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the synthesized h-CuS NCs and the standard diffraction peaks were presented. It is ascertained that all the peaks of the freshly prepared sample coincide with the hexagonal phase of the covellite structure. The results showed the h-CuS NCs are favorable crystallinity and the high purity of CuS samples. The XRD pattern of Cu2O nanocubes as precursor of h-CuS NCs can be assigned perfectly to cubic cuprous oxide, confirming the pure phase of Cu2O. The Cu2O samples appeared cubical and homogeneous with an expected size of about 50 nm. 

To further scrutinize the morphology and crystallographic characteristics of the h-CuS NCs, the morphology and nanoparticles size of the as-prepared h-CuS NCs were obtained using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). The TEM image of the synthesized h-CuS NCs showed hollow cube-like crystals uniformly dispersed with a size of 50 nm. The HRTEM image of the h-CuS NCs revealed two distinct lattice fringes, where d=0.305 nm is assigned to the (102), and d=0.322 nm is assigned to the (101), which are well consistent with the XRD results of h-CuS NCs.

The synthesis of apoferritin paired gold clusters (Au–Ft), which are gold nanoparticles (NPs) with a diameter of less than 2 nm, is described in the article. The preparation of Au–Ft was carried out in an aqueous solution. To begin, 300 μL of 5 mM HAuCl4 was added to 300 μL of horse spleen apoFt (49 mg/mL). To avoid apoFt subunit dissociation under acidic conditions, HAuCl4 was first adjusted to pH 7 before mixing with apoFt. 

After the mixture was mixed for 2 min, 20 μL of 1 M NaOH was added to the solution, followed by incubation for 12 h at 37 °C. The reaction solution was then ultrafiltered with a centrifugal filter device (Amicon Ultra-15; 30,000 molecular weight cut off) and washed three times with 3 mL of ultrapure water. The concentration of Au–Ft was measured by the bicinchoninic acid method (BCA). 

For the characterization of the synthesized Au–Ft, an aliquot of 4 μL of Au–Ft was applied to a glow-discharged grid coated with a layer of amorphous carbon film, and excess fluid was gently blotted off with filter paper. The HRTEM images were recorded on an FEI Tecnai F20 U-TWIN electron microscope. TEM analysis was performed on a JEOL JEM-1200EX model transmission electron microscope. For negative staining, a dispersion of Au–Ft clusters was dropped onto a carbon-coated copper grid, dried in air at room temperature, and stained with 2% uranyl acetate.

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of other sizes of gold nanoparticles. However, it is likely that the size of the nanoparticles can be controlled by adjusting the reaction conditions, such as the concentration of the gold precursor, the reaction temperature, and the reaction time.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 70 nm Pt3Ni nanoparticles (NPs). However, it does describe the synthesis of ultrathin PtNi nanowires (NWs), which might be similar. The synthesis of these PtNi NWs involves several steps and materials.

The materials used in the synthesis include Pt(acac)2 (20 mg), Ni(acac)2 (10 mg), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 75 mg), 4 mL oleylamine, and 10 mg of W(CO)6. These materials were added into a 30 mL vial. The resulting mixture was preheated in an oil bath and kept at 170°C for 5 minutes. Then, W(CO)6 was rapidly added into the solution to initiate the reaction, which was allowed to proceed for 2 hours. The product was collected by centrifugation and subsequently washed three times with ethanol and hexane (1:2, v/v). It was then transferred into a mixture solution containing 4 mL ethanol and 1 mL diethylamine for 24 hours, and then centrifuged. The final product was dispersed in ethanol for further use.

The synthesis of streptavidin modified ultrathin PtNi NWs (SA-PtNi) was also described. 100 µL of SA (1 mg mL-1) was added into 1 mL of PtNi NWs aqueous suspension (0.5 mg mL-1), and the mixed solution was shook gently for 12 hours at 4°C to make SA immobilize onto the PtNi NWs via the Pt-NH2 bond. The SA-PtNi was obtained by centrifugation and then washed with ultrapure water to remove the unbound SA. Finally, the SA-PtNi was redispersed in 500 µL Tris-Hcl buffer and stored at 4°C for further experiment.

The article also mentions the use of a UV-vis spectrophotometer for assessing the peroxidase-like activity of the ultrathin PtNi NWs. The steady-state kinetic assays were performed in time-course mode, and all measurements were monitored by the absorbance change at 652 nm. The kinetic parameters were calculated according to the typical Michaelis-Menten equation.

In conclusion, while the article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 70 nm Pt3Ni NPs, it does provide a detailed procedure for the synthesis of ultrathin PtNi NWs.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 70 nm Pt3Ni nanoparticles (NPs). However, it does describe the synthesis of ultrathin PtNi nanowires (NWs), which might be similar. 

The synthesis of ultrathin PtNi NWs was carried out with minor modifications from a previous method (Li et al., 2018a). The reagents used were Pt(acac)2 (20 mg), Ni(acac)2 (10 mg), cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 75 mg), and 4 mL oleylamine. These were added into a 30 mL vial. The resulting mixture was preheated in an oil bath and kept at 170°C for 5 minutes. Subsequently, 10 mg of W(CO)6 was rapidly added into the above solution to initiate the reaction, and the reaction was allowed to proceed for 2 hours. The product was collected by centrifugation and subsequently washed three times with ethanol and hexane (1:2, v/v). It was then transferred into a mixture solution containing 4 mL ethanol and 1 mL diethylamine for 24 hours, and then centrifuged. The final product was dispersed in ethanol for further use. The synthesis of Pt NWs followed a similar procedure, except for the absence of Ni precursors.

The synthesis of streptavidin modified ultrathin PtNi NWs (SA-PtNi) was also described. 100 µL of SA (1 mg mL-1) was added into 1 mL of PtNi NWs aqueous suspension (0.5 mg mL-1), and the mixed solution was gently shaken for 12 hours at 4°C to make SA immobilize onto the PtNi NWs via the Pt-NH2 bond (Cui et al., 2018; Xu et al., 2018). The SA-PtNi was obtained by centrifugation and then washed with ultrapure water to remove the unbound SA. Finally, the SA-PtNi was redispersed in 500 µL Tris-Hcl buffer and stored at 4°C for further experiments.

The elemental mapping images of the prepared samples demonstrated that Pt and Ni were homogeneous throughout the whole structure. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the PtNi NWs showed a typical fcc structure and all characteristic diffraction peaks had a slight blue shift relative to the Pt NWs due to the coupling of partial Ni atoms (Zhang et al., 2019), further illustrating that the alloy structure was synthesized successfully. Moreover, as determined by the inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES), the atomic ratio of Pt and Ni was proved to be about 2.99:1.00. 

Please note that the synthesis process described in the article is for ultrathin PtNi NWs, not for 70 nm Pt3Ni NPs. The size, shape, and composition of nanoparticles can be influenced by the synthesis conditions, and the article does not provide specific information on how to adjust these parameters to obtain 70 nm Pt3Ni NPs.

The synthesis of reduced Co3O4 nanoparticles (R-Co3O4) in this study is achieved through a step-by-step procedure using the metal-organic framework ZIF-67 as the precursor. The specific size of the nanoparticles is not mentioned in the article.

The first step involves the synthesis of ZIF-67. This is achieved using a simple one-step hydrothermal process. Specifically, 2-methylimidazole (1642 mg, 20.0 mmol) and Cobalt nitrate (III) hexahydrate [Co(NO3)3·6H2O] (1164 mg, 4.0 mmol) are separately dissolved in 100 mL of methanol. Both solutions are then mixed and stirred for 24 hours. The resulting violet precipitate is collected by filtration, washed thrice using ethanol, and dried overnight at 80 °C.

The as-prepared ZIF-67 is then used as a sacrificial precursor to prepare pristine Co3O4 (P-Co3O4). This is achieved by placing the ZIF-67 in a porcelain boat and heating it to 500 °C at a heating rate of 1 °C min−1 for 1 hour under an O2 atmosphere. The result is a black powder, P-Co3O4.

Finally, R-Co3O4 is obtained by soaking the P-Co3O4 powder in 100 mL of 1 M NaBH4 for 1 hour. The resulting product is R-Co3O4, which shows a remarkably enhanced peroxidase-like activity compared to P-Co3O4.

The characterization of the synthesized nanoparticles is performed using various techniques and equipment. The sample morphologies are characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010) and field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, JEOL JSM-6700F). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is conducted using a scanning X-ray microprobe (Thermo Scientific, ESCALAB 250Xi). The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 300 nm Co3O4 nanoparticles. However, it does describe a method for synthesizing reduced Co3O4 nanoparticles (R-Co3O4) using a step-by-step procedure with ZIF-67 as the precursor.

The synthesis of ZIF-67, which is the precursor for the Co3O4 nanoparticles, was performed using a simple one-step hydrothermal process. Specifically, 2-methylimidazole (1642 mg, 20.0 mmol) and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (1164 mg, 4.0 mmol) were separately dissolved in 100 mL of methanol. Both the solutions were mixed and stirred for 24 hours. The resulting violet precipitate was collected by filtration, washed three times using ethanol, and dried overnight at 80 °C.

The as-prepared ZIF-67 was then used to prepare pristine Co3O4 (P-Co3O4) under an oxygen atmosphere at 500 °C. The SEM images show that the polyhedral morphology of ZIF-67 transforms into that of a coral-like nanocomposite after pyrolytic treatment, which is most likely due to the transformation of the organic ligands into carbonaceous materials.

Finally, the reduced Co3O4 nanocomposite (R-Co3O4) was obtained by soaking the P-Co3O4 powder in 100 mL of 1 M NaBH4 for 1 hour. The TEM and SEM images indicate that R-Co3O4 presents a morphology featuring flowerlike structures of uniform sizes and petal widths of ∼14 nm.

The characterization of the synthesized nanoparticles was performed using various techniques such as transmission electron microscopy (TEM), field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), UV−vis spectra, and N2 adsorption−desorption measurements.

In conclusion, while the article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 300 nm Co3O4 nanoparticles, it does describe a method for synthesizing reduced Co3O4 nanoparticles using ZIF-67 as the precursor. The synthesized nanoparticles were characterized using various techniques to confirm their structure and composition.

The synthesis of Au NPs (nanoparticles) was carried out using a liquid-phase reduction method. The reagent used was HAuCl43H2O (25 mM), which was diluted with 10 mL of deionized water. This solution was then heated to 100 C. Following this, 1 mL of trisodium citrate dihydrate (10 mg mL-1) was quickly added, which allowed for a 10-minute reaction. After cooling down to room temperature, the product was separated by centrifugation and redispersed in deionized water to form a dispersion (0.442 mg mL-1).

The morphology of the NPs was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20 U-TWIN). The crystal structure of the NPs was determined by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 focus). The composition of the NPs was measured by the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Thermo Scientific iCAP 6300). The surface analysis for NPs was completed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi). Zeta potential data was collected by a nanoparticle analyzer (Malvern zetasizer Nano ZS).

For the synthesis of Au@Ptx NPs, 1.0 mL of the above Au NP dispersion was diluted with 8 mL of deionized water, followed by the addition of the required volume of H2PtCl66H2O aqueous solution (20 mM) and 0.1 M of ascorbic acid (AA, AA/Pt4+ = 5). The mixture was heated at 80 C for 30 minutes with stirring. Finally, the product was separated by centrifugation, washed repeatedly, and redispersed in deionized water to obtain a dispersion.

The article does not specify the exact size of the Au NPs synthesized, but it mentions that the diameter of the NPs had a tendency to increase as the Pt/Au feed ratio increased. The Au@Pt3.15 NPs, for example, had an average diameter of about 25 nm. The size of the NPs can likely be controlled by adjusting the Pt/Au feed ratio and other parameters of the synthesis process.

The reagent used for this process was HAuCl43H2O (25 mM), which was diluted with 10 mL of deionized water. This solution was then heated to 100 C. Following this, 1 mL of trisodium citrate dihydrate (10 mg mL-1) was quickly added, which allowed for a 10-minute reaction. After cooling down to room temperature, the product was separated by centrifugation and redispersed in deionized water to form a dispersion (0.442 mg mL-1).

The morphology of the nanoparticles was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20 U-TWIN). The composition of the nanoparticles was measured by the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Thermo Scientific iCAP 6300). The surface analysis for the nanoparticles was completed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi). Zeta potential data was collected by a nanoparticle analyzer (Malvern zetasizer Nano ZS). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements were carried out at ambient temperature in a Bruker EMX EPR spectrometer (Billerica, MA).

The synthesis of Au@Ptx NPs was also described. Briefly, 1.0 mL of the above Au NP dispersion was diluted with 8 mL of deionized water, followed by the addition of the required volume of H2PtCl66H2O aqueous solution (20 mM) and 0.1 M of ascorbic acid (AA, AA/Pt4+ = 5). The mixture was heated at 80 C for 30 minutes with stirring. Finally, the product was separated by centrifugation, washed repeatedly, and redispersed in deionized water to obtain a dispersion.

The size of the nanoparticles was controlled by adjusting the feed of Pt precursors. By fixing the amount of Au seeds and simply adjusting the feed of Pt precursors, a series of Au@Ptx NPs (x = 1, 5, 7.5, 10, 12.5, 15) were synthesized, where x represents the molar ratio of Pt/Au. The diameter of the nanoparticles had a tendency to increase as the Pt/Au feed ratio increased. The larger feed ratio also resulted in more Pt content in the products, as determined by the composition analysis by ICP-OES.

The mixture is heated at 80°C for 30 min with stirring. Finally, the product is separated by centrifugation, washed repeatedly, and redispersed in deionized water to obtain a dispersion.

The morphology of NPs is characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F20 U-TWIN). The crystal structure of NPs is determined by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8 focus). The composition of NPs is measured by the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Thermo Scientific iCAP 6300). The synthesis of Pd-Pt core-shell nanocubes (NCs) of different sizes, including 9 nm, was achieved through a two-step seed-mediated growth process. 

Firstly, monodispersed Pd NCs were initially synthesized and utilized as seeds according to the method published by the research group. For the 7.0 and 18.1 nm Pd NCs, the procedure consisted of 60 mg of AA, 105 mg of PVP, different amounts of KBr and KCl depending on the desired size (8 mg of KBr and 180 mg of KCl for 9.0 nm Pd NCs; 600 mg of KBr and 180 mg of KCl for 18.1 nm Pd NCs) all together in a vial and then it was pre-heated to 80 C for 10 min in an oil bath under magnetic stirring. Next, 3 mL of Na2PdCl4 aqueous solution with a concentration of 19 mg/mL was rapidly added. Lastly, the mixture was allowed to react for 3 h and then it was cooled down to room temperature to be washed three times and the final product was redispersed in 8 mL of deionized (DI) water for future use.

Secondly, in a standard synthesis of Pd-Pt core-shell NCs, the aqueous solution of K2PtCl4 as the Pt precursor was quickly injected into the mixture containing 40.3 nm Pd NCs as seeds, citric acid as reducing agent and poly (vinylpyrrolidone) (Mw  55,000) as surfactant, which was mixed under magnetic stirring and preheated to 95 C in a vial through the oil bath. The reaction was allowed to proceed for 24 h. After the successful deposition of Pt layers on the surface of the Pd NCs, they kept the overall cubic shape and increased the average edge length to 42.3 nm. The molar ratio of Pt to Pd was determined to be ~0.155 using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). 

The same procedure was followed to synthesize the 9.0 and 20.3 nm of Pd-Pt except for the use of different sizes of Pd seeds (7.0 and 18.1 nm) with a 3 mL K2PtCl4 solution with concentrations of 0.75 and 1.95 mg/mL, respectively. The size of the Pd-Pt core-shell NCs can be controlled by using Pd NCs of different sizes as seeds. 

The synthesized Pd-Pt NCs were characterized using a JEOL 1011 microscope operated at 200 kV for transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images, an Agilent Cary 60 UV-vis spectrophotometer for UV-vis spectra, a PANalytical Empyrean diffractometer for X-ray Diffraction (XRD) patterns, and an Oakton pH 700 benchtop meter for pH value of the buffer solution. The Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, JY2000 Ultrace ICP atomic emission spectrometer equipped with a JYAS 421 autosampler and 2400 g/mm holographic grating) was used to determine the concentrations of Pd and Pt ions.

The synthesis of Pd-Pt core-shell nanocubes (NCs) of 9 nm or other sizes was achieved through a two-step seed-mediated growth process. The first step involved the synthesis of monodispersed Pd NCs, which were then used as seeds. The synthesis of the Pd NCs was achieved according to a method previously published by the research group. For the 7.0 and 18.1 nm Pd NCs, the procedure involved combining 60 mg of AA, 105 mg of PVP, different amounts of KBr and KCl depending on the desired size (8 mg of KBr and 180 mg of KCl for 9.0 nm Pd NCs; 600 mg of KBr and 180 mg of KCl for 18.1 nm Pd NCs) in a vial. This mixture was then pre-heated to 80 C for 10 min in an oil bath under magnetic stirring. Subsequently, 3 mL of Na2PdCl4 aqueous solution with a concentration of 19 mg/mL was rapidly added. The mixture was allowed to react for 3 h and then it was cooled down to room temperature, washed three times, and the final product was redispersed in 8 mL of deionized (DI) water for future use.

For the 40.3 nm Pd NCs, Pd NCs of 18.1 nm were used as seeds to mediate the growth into larger NCs. The procedure involved combining 90 mg of AA, 150 mg of PVP, 450 mg KBr and 0.72 mL of the previously synthesized Pd seeds in a flask. This mixture was then pre-heated to 40 C for 20 min in an oil bath under magnetic stirring. Subsequently, 5 mL of Na2PdCl4 aqueous solution with a concentration of 19 mg/mL was rapidly added. The mixture was allowed to react for 24 h and then it was cooled down to room temperature, washed three times, and the final product was redispersed in 5 mL of deionized (DI) water for future use.

The second step involved the synthesis of Pd-Pt NCs. After the synthesis of the Pd NCs, they were used as seeds to deposit a thin layer of Pt atoms as shell, following a previously reported method with minor modifications. The standard synthesis procedure consisted of 60 mg of citric acid, 35 mg of PVP and 5 mL of previously synthesized 40.3 nm Pd NC solution, dissolved in a total volume of 10 mL DI water in a glass vial. This mixture was then preheated to 95 C for 10 min under magnetic stirring. Subsequently, 3 mL of K2PtCl4 solution with a concentration of 4.33 mg/mL was rapidly added. The mixture was allowed to react for 24 h and then it was cooled down to room temperature, washed three times, and the final product was redispersed in 5 mL DI water. The same procedure was followed to synthesize the 9.0 and 20.3 nm of Pd-Pt except for the use of different sizes of Pd seeds (7.0 and 18.1 nm) with a 3 mL K2PtCl4 solution with concentrations of 0.75 and 1.95 mg/mL, respectively.

Subsequently, 5 mL of Na2PdCl4 aqueous solution with a concentration of 19 mg/mL was rapidly added. Next, the mixture was allowed to react for 24 h and then it was cooled down to room temperature to be washed three times and the final product was redispersed in 5 mL of deionized (DI) water for future use.

After the synthesis of the Pd NCs, they were used as seeds to deposit a thin layer of Pt atoms as shell, following the previously reported method with minor modifications. The standard synthesis procedure consisted of 60 mg of citric acid, 35 mg of PVP and 5 mL of previously synthesized 40.3 nm Pd NC solution, dissolved in a total volume of 10 mL DI water in a glass vial and then preheated to 95 C for 10 min under magnetic stirring. Subsequently, 3 mL of K2PtCl4 solution with a concentration of 4.33 mg/mL was rapidly added. The synthesis of irregular-shaped platinum nanoparticles (ISPtNP) of approximately 7 nm in size was carried out using a seed-growth method, with some modifications. The glassware used in the procedure was thoroughly cleaned in a bath of freshly prepared solution (1:3 HNO3–HCl), thoroughly rinsed with double-distilled water, and dried prior to use.

Initially, 100 mL of H2PtCl6 aqueous solution (0.234 mM) was added into a 250-mL round-bottom flask equipped with a condenser, and heated to 100 ◦C. Following that, 1.25 mL of trisodium citrate (38.8 mM) was introduced quickly into the boiling solution, and continuously stirred for 90 min at 750 rpm until the color of the mixture turned from pale yellow to black. The aim of this step is to form small-size platinum nanoparticles for the seed growth.

Afterwards, the mixture was cooled down to room temperature (RT), and 0.5 mL of H2PtCl6 solution (23.4 mM) and 0.625 mL of trisodium citrate (38.8 mM) were simultaneously added into the resulting mixture. Subsequently, the resultant mixture was heated again to 100 ◦C, and kept for 90 min under stirring. 

The obtained ISPtNP were finally confirmed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM; Hitachi H-7650, Japan), and stored at 4 ◦C in a dark-colored glass bottle (C[Pt] ≈ 0.35 mM) when not in use. The TEM image of the newly prepared ISPtNP showed a homogeneous distribution with a mean length of ∼7.0 nm and a narrowing width from 2.0 to 5.0 nm along.

In summary, the synthesis of 7 nm platinum nanoparticles requires the use of a round-bottom flask, a condenser, and a transmission electron microscope. The reagents used include H2PtCl6 aqueous solution, trisodium citrate, and double-distilled water. The process involves heating, stirring, and cooling steps, and the final product is stored at 4 ◦C.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 18 nm or other size Au0.1/Co3O4-CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs). However, it does detail the synthesis of Au/Co3O4-CeOx nanocomposites and Co3O4-CeOx nanomaterials. 

For the synthesis of Co3O4-CeOx nanomaterials, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 M) and Ce(NO3)2·6H2O (0.5 M) aqueous solutions were slowly added into a Na2CO3 solution under stirring at 60 °C. The pH of this mixed solution was adjusted to 10 using NaOH (0.5 M), followed by aging for 5 hours at this temperature. The obtained precipitate was washed with distilled water and redispersed into water, then an appropriate amount of H2O2 was added into the suspension and aged for another 2 hours. The products were collected after washing, drying at 120 °C, and roasting at 270 °C.

The synthesis of Au/Co3O4-CeOx nanocomposites involved dispersing 0.4 g Co3O4-CeOx nanomaterials in 50 mL deionized water to form a uniform suspension. Meanwhile, 0.20 g HAuCl4·4H2O was dissolved in 20 mL water to obtain a HAuCl4 solution (20 mM). Both the HAuCl4 solution and Co3O4-CeOx suspension were adjusted to pH 8 using Na2CO3 (0.5 M). HAuCl4 and sodium citrate were then successively added into the Co3O4-CeOx suspension under stirring at 60 °C. The Au/Co3O4-CeOx nanocomposites were obtained through washing with distilled water, filtering, and drying at 80 °C for 24 hours.

The characterization of the as-prepared Au/Co3O4-CeOx NCs was done using a transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL, Japan). The elemental composition of the complex was identified by using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was applied to evaluate the product’s crystalline structure using Cu Kα radiation with the 2θ range varying from 10° to 80°. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were obtained with a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI electron spectrometer (Thermo, USA) using 150W Al Kα radiation. The Au contents of the prepared samples were determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) analysis with an IRIS Intrepid II XRP instrument. 

Please note that the specific size of the nanoparticles and the exact molar ratio of Au to Co3O4-CeOx are not specified in the provided text.

The synthesis of urchin-like Mn3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) involves several steps and requires specific reagents and equipment. The initial step involves dissolving 1.0 g of KMnO4 (6.3 mmol) in 500 mL of ultrapure water and stirring vigorously for 30 minutes. Following this, 20 mL of oleic acid (0.063 mmol) and 10mM of ammonium fluoride (NH4F) are added into the KMnO4 solution. The resulting mixed solution is then aged for 10 hours at room temperature.

After aging, the solution is placed in an ultrasonic bath and sonicated for one hour at a power of 5 W/cm2. The mixed solution is then stirred vigorously for 10 hours at 50 °C. The precipitate is washed with ultrapure water and then with ethanol to remove the unreacted starting materials. The washed precipitate is dried at 80 °C for 12 hours to obtain precursor granules. These granules are then calcined in air at 200 °C for 5 hours to obtain the urchin-like Mn3O4 particles.

The average diameter of the urchin-like Mn3O4 particles is about 700-800 nm. The growth time of the particles is a crucial factor in determining their size. When the growth time was 4 hours, the diameter of Mn3O4 nanoparticles was about 100 nm. When the growth time was extended to 12 hours, some nanoneedles, with the length of 20-30 nm, were grown irregularly on the surface of the Mn3O4 nanoparticles core. When the growth time continued from 18 hours to 24 hours, the urchin-like morphology was gradually formed. Therefore, the final growth time was determined to be 24 hours in this work.

The molar ratio of KMnO4 to oleic acid also influences the structure and morphology of the urchin-like Mn3O4 particles. When the molar ratio was 100: 1, the nanoneedles were grown vertically on the surface of urchin-like Mn3O4 particles. However, the urchin-like Mn3O4 particles began to agglomerate and stick when the ratio was not maintained.

The addition of NH4F plays an important role in the nucleation and growth of the nanoneedles. Without adding NH4F, the Mn3O4 particles were not the shape of urchin-like and the nanoneedles were arranged in disorder and grown randomly. Therefore, NH4F was identified to play an important role in nucleation and growth of the nanoneedles.

The synthesis of Pt/CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the manuscript. However, the manuscript does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 300 nm Pt/CeO2 NPs. The size of the Pt nanoparticles on the surface of CeO2 nanorods was reported to be 2.6 ± 0.4 nm. 

The CeO2 nanorods were prepared by a hydrothermal method. Briefly, 0.654 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL ultrapure water in a 50 mL round bottom flask. Then, 20 mL 10 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution was drop added into the flask under vigorous stir at room temperature. The white slurry was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-line stainless steel autoclave and held at 100°C for 24 hours. After hydrothermal treatment, the obtained CeO2 nanorods were washed with deionized water by centrifugation until the pH value of supernatant was 7. The precipitate was dried at 120°C for 12 hours in air to obtain yellow CeO2 nanorods powder.

For the preparation of Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites, 50 mg CeO2 powder was dispersed in 25 mL EG with ultrasonic treatment for 30 min. 250 µL NaOH EG solution (1 M) and 1 mL H2PtCl6·6H2O EG solution (30 mM) were both added into the above dispersion under vigorous stir. After 30 min stirring, the mixture was heated and held at 180°C for 2 hours with oil bath. The color of reaction solution changed from light yellow to grey indicating the formation of Pt nanoparticles. The reaction solution was cooled to room temperature naturally, and the precipitate was centrifuged and washed for three times with ultrapure water. The obtained gray precipitate (Pt/CeO2) was re-dispersed into water for further use. The Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites with different Pt loading were prepared by changing the amount of H2PtCl6·6H2O.

The morphology and component of the prepared Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites were characterized using various techniques. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), Energy Dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and elemental mapping analysis were carried out on a transmission electron microscope (FEI Tecnai G2 F20, USA) operated at 200 kV. The samples for TEM analysis were prepared by depositing one droplet of ethanol dispersion of catalysts onto carbon-coated Cu-grids and dried in atmosphere. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was also used to characterize the morphology of Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites (Hitachi SEM-4800, Japan). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer (D/MAX-TTRⅢ-CBO, Rigaku, Japan) with a scan rate of 4°/min over the 2θ range of 20°-60°. The samples for XRD patterns were prepared by dropping the dispersion of Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites onto silicon wafers and dried in air at room temperature to form films of catalysts. The chemical states of Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using an XPS spectrometer (ESCALAB 250X, ThermoFisher Scientific, UK). The concentrations of as-prepared catalysts were obtained by the inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Thermo Scientific, USA). The absorbance intensity and absorption spectra of reaction solution were evaluated by an EnVision Multimode Plate Reader (PerkinElmer, USA) at room temperature.

The article describes the synthesis of Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites, but it does not specify the size of the nanoparticles. However, the average size of Pt nanoparticles on the surface of CeO2 nanorods was reported to be 2.6 ± 0.4 nm.

The synthesis of CeO2 nanorods was done by a hydrothermal method. 0.654 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL ultrapure water in a 50 mL round bottom flask. Then, 20 mL 10 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) solution was added into the flask under vigorous stir at room temperature. The mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-line stainless steel autoclave and held at 100°C for 24 hours. After hydrothermal treatment, the obtained CeO2 nanorods were washed with deionized water by centrifugation until the pH value of supernatant was 7. The precipitate was dried at 120°C for 12 hours in air to obtain yellow CeO2 nanorods powder.

For the preparation of Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites, 50 mg CeO2 powder was dispersed in 25 mL EG with ultrasonic treatment for 30 min. 250 µL NaOH EG solution (1 M) and 1 mL H2PtCl6·6H2O EG solution (30 mM) were both added into the dispersion under vigorous stir. After 30 min stirring, the mixture was heated and held at 180°C for 2 hours with oil bath. The reaction solution was cooled to room temperature naturally, and the precipitate was centrifuged and washed for three times with ultrapure water. The obtained gray precipitate (Pt/CeO2) was re-dispersed into water for further use.

The characterization of the prepared Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites was done using various techniques. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution TEM (HRTEM), Energy Dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) and elemental mapping analysis were carried out on a transmission electron microscope (FEI Tecnai G2 F20, USA) operated at 200 kV. The samples for TEM analysis were prepared by depositing one droplet of ethanol dispersion of catalysts onto carbon-coated Cu-grids and dried in atmosphere. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was also used to characterize the morphology of Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites (Hitachi SEM-4800, Japan). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Rigaku X-ray diffractometer (D/MAX-TTRⅢ-CBO, Rigaku, Japan) with a scan rate of 4°/min over the 2θ range of 20°-60°. The samples for XRD patterns were prepared by dropping the dispersion of Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites onto silicon wafers and dried in air at room temperature to form films of catalysts. The chemical states of Pt/CeO2 nanocomposites were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using an XPS spectrometer (ESCALAB 250X, ThermoFisher Scientific, UK). The concentrations of as-prepared catalysts were obtained by the inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Thermo Scientific, USA). The absorbance intensity and absorption spectra of reaction solution were evaluated by an EnVision Multimode Plate Reader (PerkinElmer, USA) at room temperature.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 2700 nm or other size CoMn2O4/Mn2O3 nanoparticles. However, it does detail the synthesis of Co/Mn-BTC and mixed Mn/Co oxides, which could potentially be used to create nanoparticles of varying sizes.

The Co/Mn-BTC was synthesized with some modifications from the literature. Initially, 10 g of PVP (Mw=30,000) was dissolved in a 40 mL ethanol/water (1:1, v/v) mixture under stirring. Then, 1.125 mmol Mn(CH3COO)2∙4H2O and 0.375 mmol Co(CH3COO)2∙4H2O were added into the solution to form a pink transparent solution A. Subsequently, 2.15 mmol of BTC was dissolved into a 40 mL ethanol/water (1:1, v/v) mixture solution to form a colorless solution B. Solution B was then added to solution A slowly under vigorous stirring for 20 minutes. The final mixture was left at room temperature without interruption for one day. After centrifuge separation, the pale pink product was obtained and treated with C2H5OH several times. The product was then dried at 60 oC and was denoted as Co/Mn-BTC-0.33 (molar ratio of Co to Mn = 1:3) for convenience.

The synthesis of mixed Mn/Co oxides involved placing the Co/Mn-BTC-0.33 powders in a muffle furnace and annealing at 500 oC for 2 hours. The samples were then cooled naturally down to room temperature to obtain the final product named CMO-0.33. Other metal oxides products were obtained by the same calcination process, including Mn2O3, CMO-0.25, CMO-0.5, CMO-1.0 and Co3O4, corresponding to Mn-BTC, Co/Mn-BTC-0.25, Co/Mn-BTC-0.5, Co/Mn-BTC-1.0 and Co-BTC, respectively.

The morphologies and microstructures of precursor Co/Mn-BTC-0.33 and the calcined product CMO-0.33 were investigated by SEM and TEM. The atomic molar ratio of Mn/Co was found to be 10.6 : 1 by XPS analysis, which is basically consistent with the ICP-OES result (is 9.3 : 1), further confirming the existence of cobalt in CMO-0.33.

The synthesis of CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) and Pr-modified CeO2 NPs was carried out following a specific procedure. The concentrations of Ce and Pr precursors were adjusted to Pr concentrations of 5, 10, 15 and 20mol.%. For example, 10%Pr-CeO2 NC was synthesized using a mixture of 0.094 M Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 0.01 M Pr(NO3)3·6H2O (Sigma Aldrich, 99.99%). The samples were then washed several times and once with ethanol (Panreac, Absolute Ethanol). Finally, the samples were dried at 80 oC for 24 h in an oven. A yellowish powder was obtained for CeO2 NPs, and a reddish powder was obtained for 10%Pr-CeO2 NPs.

Physical and Compositional Characterization of the samples was carried out using various techniques. X-Ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a D8 ADVANCE diffractometer of Bruker using the Cu Kα radiation, with a range of 5-110o, a step of 0.02o and a step time of 1s. The software DiffracPlus was used to measure the width of the {111} diffraction peak of ceria in order to calculate the particle size using the Scherrer equation. ICP measurements were carried out using an ICP-AES Iris Intrepid equipment of Thermal Elemental to determine the actual Pr content of the Pr-modified nanocubes. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of the samples were determined in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 via nitrogen adsorption at -196 oC. Prior to the analysis, the samples were degasified at 150 oC for 2 h under vacuum.

The surface chemical composition in Ce and Pr of the samples was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The analyses were performed on the as-synthesized CeO2 NC and the other Pr-modified CeO2 NC, excluding the 20%Pr-CeO2 NC+NR sample. The edge lengths of CeO2 NC are mainly comprised in the range from 5 to 45 nm. Nanocubes larger than 50 nm are only observed in the Pr-modified ceria nanocubes, but with very small frequencies (less than 5%).

In summary, the maximum Pr concentration which could be incorporated into the ceria nanocube structure was up to 15mol.%. The chemical composition of the Pr-modified CeO2 NCs was determined at macroscopic level by ICP, with the molar concentrations of Pr determined being 4.4, 9.7, 14.4 and 19.2%, which are very close to the expected values. The Pr concentration of 10%Pr-CeO2 NC is very similar to the ICP results, which represent the average bulk composition of the sample. 

However, the article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 22 nm CeO2 NPs. The sizes mentioned range from 5 to 45 nm, with larger sizes observed less frequently.

The article does not provide specific instructions for synthesizing 500 nm Co(OH)2 nanoparticles. However, it does describe a method for creating Co(OH)2 nanocages, which may be similar in size. 

The synthesis of Co(OH)2 nanocages is performed using a template-assisted route based on Pearson’s hard and soft acid-base principle. The process begins with the synthesis of Cu2O nanocubes, which are then used as a template for the formation of the Co(OH)2 nanocages. 

The specific procedure involves adding 1.665 g of PVP (MW: 40,000) into an ethanol/water solution (1:1 by volume, 50 mL). This is followed by the addition of 0.025 g of cubic Cu2O templates and 0.0085 g of CoCl2·6H2O. The mixture is stirred for 10 minutes at room temperature, after which 20 mL of 0.6 M Na2S2O3 is added over a period of 20 seconds. The reaction is allowed to proceed for 3 minutes, during which the suspension changes color from red to emerald. The final products are then washed and stored in 10 mL of methanol.

The Co(OH)2 nanocages are then used in a kinetic experiment with TMB as a substrate. The experiment involves using 150 μM of Co(OH)2 with different concentrations of TMB (0.13, 0.67, 1.33, 2, 2.67, 3.33, and 4 mM). The change in absorption peak values at 652 nm is monitored over time, and the enzymatic constants are calculated using the Michaelis-Menten equation from Lineweaver-Burk plots.

The materials used in the experiment include sodium hydroxide (NaOH), cupric chloride dihydrate (CuCl2·2H2O), ascorbic acid (AA), sodium acetate anhydrous, cobalt chloride hexahydrate (CoCl2·6H2O), and 3,3',5,5'-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB). The equipment used includes a transmission electron microscope (TEM), a scanning electron microscope (SEM), an Energy Dispersive Spectrometer, a Fourier Infrared Spectrometer, and an X-ray diffraction machine.

Please note that the article does not provide specific details on the size of the Co(OH)2 nanocages produced using this method. Therefore, adjustments may be needed to produce nanoparticles of a specific size.

The synthesis of boron nitride nanosheet and copper sulfide nanohybrids (BNNS@CuS) was carried out using a facile solvothermal approach. The materials used for the synthesis included boron nitride powder, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), 3,3,5,5-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB), Triton X-100, cholesterol, cholesterol oxidase (CHOx, 100UN) and cholesterol esterase (1KU) which were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Other reagents such as CuSO4, Na2S, cysteine, serine, histidine, uric acid, glucose, glycerin, phenol and ascorbic acid were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All the chemical reagents used were at least of analytical grade.

In a typical procedure, 0.5 g hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) powder was immersed in 500 mL N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), followed by high-power (700W) ultrasonication for 6 h. The upper milky white solution was poured out after sedimentation overnight. The BNNSs were collected by centrifuging the solution, and washed for three times with ethanol to remove NMP.

10 mg as-prepared BNNS was dispersed well in 25 mL purified water by ultrasonic treatment before the BNNS dispersion was stirred with 5 mL of 0.03 g/mL sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) solution for 1 h, and then 5 mL of 20 mM copper sulfate aqueous solution was added, followed by magnetic stirring under refluxing for 2 h. Subsequently, 2 mL of 60 mM sodium sulfide aqueous solution was dropped into the above pale blue suspension under nitrogen atmosphere. The reaction mixture continued to reflux for 15 min until a dark green dispersion was obtained. After natural cooling, the dark green precipitate was collected by centrifugation, rinsed thoroughly with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 65 ◦C for 10 h in vacuum drying oven for characterization and further use.

The morphology of the synthesized nanohybrids was analyzed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Zeiss, Jena, Thuringia, Germany). The average lateral size of BNNSs is approximately 200 nm. The BNNSs served as templates for the growth of nanosized CuS on their surface, and the size distribution of CuS is less than 30 nm. The dark parts are generally the overlapped sections of the BNNSs.

The synthesis of boron nitride nanosheet and copper sulfide nanohybrids (BNNS@CuS) was carried out using a facile solvothermal approach. The materials used for the synthesis included boron nitride powder, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), 3,3,5,5-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB), Triton X-100, cholesterol, cholesterol oxidase (CHOx, 100UN) and cholesterol esterase (1KU) which were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Other reagents such as CuSO4, Na2S, cysteine, serine, histidine, uric acid, glucose, glycerin, phenol and ascorbic acid were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All the chemical reagents used were at least of analytical grade.

In a typical procedure, 0.5 g hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) powder was immersed in 500 mL N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), followed by high-power (700W) ultrasonication for 6 h. The upper milky white solution was poured out after sedimentation overnight. The BNNSs were collected by centrifuging the solution, and washed for three times with ethanol to remove NMP.

10 mg as-prepared BNNS was dispersed well in 25 mL purified water by ultrasonic treatment before the BNNS dispersion was stirred with 5 mL of 0.03 g/mL sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) solution for 1 h, and then 5 mL of 20 mM copper sulfate aqueous solution was added, followed by magnetic stirring under refluxing for 2 h. Subsequently, 2 mL of 60 mM sodium sulfide aqueous solution was dropped into the above pale blue suspension under nitrogen atmosphere. The reaction mixture continued to reflux for 15 min until a dark green dispersion was obtained. After natural cooling, the dark green precipitate was collected by centrifugation, rinsed thoroughly with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 65 ◦C for 10 h in vacuum drying oven for characterization and further use.

The morphology of the synthesized nanohybrids was analyzed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Zeiss, Jena, Thuringia, Germany). The average lateral size of BNNSs is approximately 200 nm. The BNNSs served as templates for the growth of nanosized CuS on their surface, and the size distribution of CuS is less than 30 nm. The dark parts are generally the overlapped sections of the BNNSs.

The synthesis of high-index {hk0} faceted platinum concave nanocubes (HIF-Pt-CNCs), which are a type of platinum nanoparticles (Pt NPs), is described in the article. The HIF-Pt-CNCs were synthesized using a one-pot synthesis method. 

Initially, 400 mg of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), 75 mg of glycine, and 2.0 mL of 20 mM hexachloroplatinic (IV) acid hexahydrate (H2PtCl6) were mixed together with 6.0 mL water. The mixture was stirred for 10 minutes at room temperature to obtain a homogeneous yellow solution. 

Following that, the yellow solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave with a capacity of 20 mL. The sealed vessel was heated from room temperature to 200 °C in around 30 minutes and kept at this temperature for 6 hours before it was cooled to room temperature. 

After being washed with ethanol twice and water three times via centrifugation, the HIF-Pt-CNCs were stored in 8 mL of water for future use. The final Pt concentration was approximately 0.79 mg mL-1, and the particle concentration was approximately 7.62 × 1011 particles mL-1 or ~1.27 × 10-9 M. 

The average apex-to-apex diameter of the HIF-Pt-CNCs, determined by counting more than 200 nanoparticles, was approximately 43.9 nm. The nanoparticles displayed a uniform cubic shape with a yield above 90%, and appeared to have a concave feature under careful observation. 

The successful synthesis of HIF-Pt-CNCs was confirmed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The SEM images showed that each face of the nanocubes was excavated by a square pyramid in the center, indicating the presence of a concave feature in the nanocubes. The TEM images further confirmed the formation of the concave cube structure in the nanoparticles. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of 43 nm Pt NPs (in this case, HIF-Pt-CNCs) involves the use of specific reagents (PVP, glycine, and H2PtCl6), specific equipment (a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, SEM, and TEM), and specific conditions (temperature, time, and washing steps).

The synthesis of Nickel-Platinum nanoparticles (Ni-Pt NPs) is described in the article. However, the synthesis of pure Platinum nanoparticles (Pt NPs) is also mentioned. In a standard synthesis of Ni−Pt NPs, Ni(II) acetate and Pt(II) acetylacetonate with the same molar amounts were coreduced by acetaldehyde in tetraethylene glycol. The atomic ratio of elemental Ni to Pt in the NPs was determined to be 49/51 (∼1:1) by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). The size of the Ni−Pt NPs was measured to be 13.9 ± 2.4 nm by randomly analyzing 200 particles.

If no Ni precursor was added to the synthesis, pure Pt NPs of ∼14.6 ± 3.1 nm as final products were obtained. The article does not provide specific details on the amounts of reagents used or the exact procedure for the synthesis of pure Pt NPs. However, it can be inferred that the synthesis likely involves the reduction of a Pt precursor in a suitable solvent, possibly in the absence of a Ni precursor.

The article also mentions that NPs of different Ni/Pt atomic ratios could be obtained by simply varying the amounts of Ni and Pt precursors in a standard synthesis while keeping all other conditions unchanged. For example, NPs with Ni/Pt = 33/67 (Ni−Pt2 NPs) and 62/38 (Ni−Pt0.5 NPs) were obtained when the molar ratio of Ni and Pt precursors were changed from 1:1 in the standard synthesis to 1:2 and 2:1, respectively.

The synthesized NPs were characterized by electron microscopes and XRD. The sizes of Ni−Pt2 and Ni−Pt0.5 NPs were 12.7 ± 2.1 and 14.9 ± 2.2 nm, respectively. Both NPs had Ni-rich cores and Pt-rich shells, similar to that of Ni−Pt NPs. An X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis shows that Pt 4d and 4f peaks were clearly seen from all the three NPs of different Ni/Pt atomic ratios, while noticeable Ni signals could only be observed from Ni−Pt0.5 NPs. High-resolution XPS spectra indicates that Pt on the surface of all three NPs is primarily in the form of Pt(0).

In conclusion, the synthesis of Pt NPs or Ni-Pt NPs involves the reduction of Pt and Ni precursors in a suitable solvent, with the molar ratio of the precursors determining the atomic ratio of Ni to Pt in the resulting NPs. The synthesized NPs are then characterized using various techniques such as electron microscopy, XRD, and XPS.

The synthesis of Ni−Pt nanoparticles (NPs) with Ni-rich cores and Pt-rich shells is described in the article. In a standard synthesis of Ni−Pt NPs, Ni(II) acetate and Pt(II) acetylacetonate with the same molar amounts were coreduced by acetaldehyde in tetraethylene glycol. The atomic ratio of elemental Ni to Pt in the NPs was determined to be 49/51 (∼1:1) by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). 

The growth mechanism of these NPs was monitored at different stages during the synthesis using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and ICP-AES. Small nuclei of ∼1 nm and Pt/Ni = 4:96 were observed at the initial stage (180 °C), suggesting the preferential reduction of Ni precursor. Thereafter, coreduction of Ni and Pt precursors promoted the increase of particle size to ∼11.5 nm (at 220 °C), where the Pt/Ni ratio was increased to 13:87. A core−shell structure could be observed when reaction temperature had been elevated to 240 °C. The particle size (ca. 14 nm) and Pt/Ni ratio (ca. 50:50) became stable after the temperature reached 280 °C.

It should be emphasized that the NPs of different Ni/Pt atomic ratios could be obtained by simply varying the amounts of Ni and Pt precursors in a standard synthesis while keeping all other conditions unchanged. For example, NPs with Ni/Pt = 33/67 (Ni−Pt2 NPs) and 62/38 (Ni−Pt0.5 NPs) were obtained when the molar ratio of Ni and Pt precursors were changed from 1:1 in the standard synthesis to 1:2 and 2:1, respectively. If no Ni precursor was added to the synthesis, pure Pt NPs of ∼14.6 ± 3.1 nm as final products were obtained. 

The sizes of Ni−Pt2 and Ni−Pt0.5 NPs were 12.7 ± 2.1 and 14.9 ± 2.2 nm, respectively. Both NPs had Ni-rich cores and Pt-rich shells, similar to that of Ni−Pt NPs. Compared to Ni−Pt2 NPs, the Ni−Pt0.5 NPs had much thinner Pt-rich shells and a higher Ni content on the surface. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of Ni−Pt NPs involves the coreduction of Ni(II) acetate and Pt(II) acetylacetonate by acetaldehyde in tetraethylene glycol, with the growth of the NPs monitored using TEM and ICP-AES. The size and composition of the NPs can be controlled by adjusting the molar ratio of the Ni and Pt precursors and the reaction temperature.

The synthesis of Ni−Pt nanoparticles (NPs) with a size of approximately 13.9 nm was achieved through a standard synthesis process. In this process, Ni(II) acetate and Pt(II) acetylacetonate were used in equal molar amounts and were co-reduced by acetaldehyde in tetraethylene glycol. The atomic ratio of elemental Ni to Pt in the NPs was determined to be 49/51 (∼1:1) by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). 

The synthesis process was monitored at different stages using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and ICP-AES. At the initial stage (180 °C), small nuclei of ∼1 nm and Pt/Ni = 4:96 were observed, suggesting the preferential reduction of Ni precursor. Thereafter, co-reduction of Ni and Pt precursors promoted the increase of particle size to ∼11.5 nm (at 220 °C), where the Pt/Ni ratio was increased to 13:87. A core−shell structure could be observed when the reaction temperature had been elevated to 240 °C. The particle size (ca. 14 nm) and Pt/Ni ratio (ca. 50:50) became stable after the temperature reached 280 °C.

It should be emphasized that the NPs of different Ni/Pt atomic ratios could be obtained by simply varying the amounts of Ni and Pt precursors in a standard synthesis while keeping all other conditions unchanged. For example, NPs with Ni/Pt = 33/67 (Ni−Pt2 NPs) and 62/38 (Ni−Pt0.5 NPs) were obtained when the molar ratio of Ni and Pt precursors were changed from 1:1 in the standard synthesis to 1:2 and 2:1, respectively. If no Ni precursor was added to the synthesis, pure Pt NPs of ∼14.6 ± 3.1 nm as final products were obtained.

The synthesized NPs were carefully characterized by electron microscopes and XRD. The sizes of Ni−Pt2 and Ni−Pt0.5 NPs were 12.7 ± 2.1 and 14.9 ± 2.2 nm, respectively. Both NPs had Ni-rich cores and Pt-rich shells, similar to that of Ni−Pt NPs. Compared to Ni−Pt2 NPs, the Ni−Pt0.5 NPs had much thinner Pt-rich shells and a higher Ni content on the surface.

The synthesis of amorphous Cu(OH)2 nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the Experimental Section of the article. The approach used was developed by the authors' group based on a previous strategy. The process involves reacting CuCl2 with NaBH4 in ethanol.

In the experiment, CuCl2·2H2O (17 mg), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) with a molecular weight of 55,000 (130.5 mg), and ethanol (40 mL) were added into a 100 mL flat bottom flask one by one. After 10 minutes of ultrasonication and 30 minutes of stirring, 7.7 mg of NaBH4 were dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol and quickly added to the solution under vigorous stirring. The reaction was allowed to proceed for 72 hours.

After this time, the products were collected by centrifugation and washed with ethanol three times. The resulting amorphous Cu(OH)2 nanoparticles were used as the starting materials in a top-down process to create Cu(OH)2 supercages (SCs).

The size of the nanoparticles was not explicitly stated in the article, but it was mentioned that the obtained SCs have a similar size with amorphous Cu(OH)2 NPs (200 nm ~250 nm). This suggests that the size of the nanoparticles synthesized could be in the range of 200 nm to 250 nm.

The article does not provide information on the mmols of the reagents used in the synthesis of the nanoparticles. The equipment used in the synthesis includes a flat bottom flask for the reaction, an ultrasonicator for the ultrasonication step, and a centrifuge for the collection of the products.

The synthesis of amorphous Cu(OH)2 nanoparticles (NPs) is based on a strategy developed by the research group, which involves reacting CuCl2 with NaBH4 in ethanol. In the experiment, CuCl2·2H2O (17 mg), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) (molecular weight 55,000) (130.5 mg), and ethanol (40 mL) were added into a 100 mL flat bottom flask one by one. After 10 min ultrasonication and 30 min stirring, 7.7 mg NaBH4 were dissolved in 10 mL ethanol and quickly added to the solution under vigorous stirring. After 72h, the products were collected by centrifugation and washed with ethanol three times. 

The synthesis of 3D Cu(OH)2 supercages was also described. In a typical experiment, amorphous Cu(OH)2 nanoparticles (9.7 mg) and PVP (molecular weight 1,300,000) (20 mg) were dispersed in 20 mL DI-water by ultrasonication for 15 min in a 100 mL flat bottom flask. The solution was vigorously stirred for 15 min. A copper-ammonia complex solution was prepared from 5 mL Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (24.16 mg) aqueous solution plus 15 mL NH3·H2O solution (400 µL NH3·H2O (29 %) plus 14.6 mL DI-water). Then, 20 mL of copper-ammonia complex solution were added to the above mixture of amorphous Cu(OH)2 nanoparticles in 1 minute and stirred for 10 minutes. The products were collected by centrifugation and washed with acetone and methanol three times.

Using the same strategy, Cu(OH)2 supercages were disassembled by the addition of 200 µL, 600 µL and 800 µL NH3·H2O (29 %) to form a solution of copper-ammonia complex. 

The size of the nanoparticles and supercages was determined using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The crystal phase of the hollow nanocages was determined to be orthorhombic Cu(OH)2 from the corresponding powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern. The specific surface area of the supercages was measured to be 172 m2g-1 according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) model and the data in Figure S3.

The information provided in the article is about the synthesis of mesoporous iron oxide using a block copolymer-templated method, but it does not specify the size of the nanoparticles produced. The method involves the use of poly(styrene-b-acrylic acid-b-ethylene glycol) (PS-b-PAA-b-PEG) triblock copolymer, which forms tri-functional micelles in the aqueous solution. The PS, PAA, and PEG blocks act as core, shell, and corona, respectively.

The effect of calcination temperature was investigated to determine the optimized condition for the fabrication of well-defined mesoporous iron oxide. The composition, morphology, and textural characteristics of the as-synthesized mesoporous iron oxide materials were characterized with various analytical techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and nitrogen (N2) adsorption-desorption isotherms.

The peroxidase-like feature of the synthesized mesoporous iron oxide was used to develop a proof-of-concept glucose sensor, in which the enzymatic oxidation of glucose with glucose oxidase (GOx) was synergized with TMB/H2O2 catalytic reaction. The in-situ production of H2O2 from the former system was used in the latter for the oxidation of TMB in the presence of mesoporous iron oxides. This results in a blue-colored complex solution which facilitated the colorimetric detection.

However, the article does not provide specific details on the quantities of reagents used, the exact process of synthesis, or the size of the nanoparticles produced. Therefore, it is not possible to provide a detailed procedure for the synthesis of 39 nm Fe2O3 nanoparticles based on the information given in the article.

The article does not provide specific instructions for synthesizing 100 nm Co3O4/Rh0.125 nanoparticles. However, it does describe the synthesis of 2D Co3O4@Rh NC, which involves Rh nanoparticles with a diameter of 4-6 nm dispersed on the surface of 2D Co3O4 NS.

The target 2D Co3O4@Rh NC was constructed by one-pot surfactant-aided oxido-reduction. Concentrated CTAB solution with 55.0 mmol/L is apt to form bilayer CTAB micelles, onto whose surface lots of OH– groups hydrolyzed from NaBH4 were absorbed and then Co2+ in turn to form curly Co3O4 NS, due to the strong electrostatic interaction between OH– and Co2+. At the same time, Rh3+ would be reduced to be Rh nano particles by virtue of the higher oxidation potential of Rh3+/Rh0 than Co2+/Co0, which were evenly attracted onto the surface of curly Co3O4 NS.

To further illustrate the structure of 2D Co3O4@Rh NC, Co3O4 NS and Rh NPs were prepared according to the similar synthetic procedure under the same conditions except using 1.0 mmol (0.291 g) Co (NO3)2∙6H2O or 0.2 mmol (0.0418 g) RhCl3∙3H2O to replace the mixture of RhCl3∙3H2O and Co(NO3)2∙9H2O respectively.

The synthesized 2D Co3O4@Rh NC was characterized by TEM, HR-TEM, EDS, XRD and XPS. The TEM image of 2D Co3O4@Rh NC clearly demonstrates that the resultant Rh NPs with 4–6 nm in diameter are well dispersed on the surface of 2D Co3O4 NS. The corresponding high-resolution TEM images express two different lattice fringe spacings of 0.227 nm and 0.244 nm, attributed to Rh NPs and Co3O4 NS respectively. EDS image indicates the presence of Rh, Co and O elements in the resulting 2D Co3O4@Rh NC with 1:5 feed ratio of Rh to Co, which was further confirmed from X-ray photoelectron wide-angle spectra (XPS) with all the presence of Co, Rh, and O elements in 2D Co3O4@Rh NC.

In conclusion, while the article does not provide specific instructions for synthesizing 100 nm Co3O4/Rh0.125 nanoparticles, it does provide a detailed description of the synthesis and characterization of 2D Co3O4@Rh NC, which involves Rh nanoparticles with a diameter of 4-6 nm dispersed on the surface of 2D Co3O4 NS.

The article does not provide a detailed step-by-step procedure for the synthesis of 8 nm Pt nanoparticles (NPs). However, it does mention that the size of the PVP55-capped Pt cubes can be tuned by varying the amount of PVP55 added in the standard synthesis. Specifically, the sizes of PVP55-capped Pt cubes could be changed to 8.16 nm when 8 mg PVP55 was added to the reaction solution.

The synthesis of these Pt cubes involves the use of PVP55 as the stabilizer and ionic Br- (from KBr) as the capping agent for Pt{100}. The surface property of these Pt cubes is different from that of conventional CTAB/TTAB-capped Pt cubes. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted to examine chemical ligands on the surface, which indicated the adsorption of PVP molecules on the surface. In addition, the Br 3p peak could also be seen, suggesting the presence of Br- ions on the surfaces.

The formation mechanism of the PVP55-capped Pt cubes was studied by taking aliquots of the reaction solution from a standard synthesis at different stages and examining them by TEM. In the initial stage of the reaction, nanoparticles with sizes of several nanometers were formed. As the reaction proceeded, the size of the nanoparticles increased and their shape evolved, eventually forming cubes of ~7 nm as the final products.

The PVP55-capped Pt cubes have several distinctive advantages over conventional CTAB/TTAB-capped Pt cubes. They can be synthesized in a short period, can be produced in large quantities, and their size can be tuned by simply varying the amount of PVP55 added in the standard synthesis. 

The peroxidase-like activity of the PVP55-capped Pt cubes was determined by the apparent steady-state kinetic assay, in which the oxidation of 3,3’,5,5’-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB, a typical peroxidase substrate) by H2O2 was employed as a model catalytic reaction. All the kinetic assays were carried out at room temperature in cuvettes with a path length of 1.0 cm. UV-vis spectrophotometer was used for determining the concentration of colored products (i.e., oxidized TMB with λmax = 653 nm) and thereby the initial reaction velocities.

However, the article does not provide specific details about the quantities of reagents used (in mmols) or the exact equipment used for the synthesis of the Pt NPs.

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 4 nm Pt nanoparticles. However, it does describe the synthesis of PVP55-capped Pt cubes, which are a type of nanoparticle. The size of these nanoparticles can be tuned by varying the amount of PVP55 added in the standard synthesis. For example, the sizes of PVP55-capped Pt cubes could be changed to 8.16 and 6.45 nm, respectively, when 8 and 200 mg PVP55 (instead of 40 mg PVP55) were added to the reaction solution. 

In the synthesis of these PVP55-capped Pt cubes, Pt atoms from the reduction of precursor first nucleated and grew into truncated octahedra or cuboctahedra enclosed by both {100} and {111} facets. The selective binding of Br- ions to the {100} facets made these facets thermodynamically more stable than {111} facets. As a result, the addition of consequent Pt atoms preferentially occurred on {111} facets, resulting in the shrinkage of {111} facets and eventually the formation of Pt cubes mainly covered by {100} facets. 

The PVP55-capped Pt cubes have several distinctive advantages over conventional CTAB/TTAB-capped Pt cubes. They can be synthesized in a short period, can be produced in large quantities, and their size can be tuned by simply varying the amount of PVP55 added in the standard synthesis. 

The article does not provide specific details on the equipment used in the synthesis process. However, it does mention that aliquots of the reaction solution were taken from a standard synthesis at different stages and examined by TEM. Also, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted for the Pt cubes, and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis was carried out for both the Pt cubes and pure PVP powder. 

The article does not provide specific details on the mmols of the reagents used in the synthesis process. However, it does mention that the synthesis can be easily scaled up by ten times to reach a production of ~67 mg per batch.

The article does not provide a detailed step-by-step procedure for the synthesis of Pt nanoparticles (NPs), but it does provide some information on the materials and methods used. 

The synthesis of Pt NPs, specifically PVP55-capped Pt cubes, was conducted using Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP55) as the stabilizer and ionic Br- (from KBr) as the capping agent for Pt{100}. In previous studies, Pt cubes were typically synthesized in the presence of cetyl￾trimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) or tetradecyl￾trimethylammonium bromide (TTAB) as both the stabilizer and Pt{100} facet specific capping agent. However, in this work, the authors used PVP55 and ionic Br- instead, which resulted in a different surface property for the Pt cubes compared to conventional CTAB/TTAB￾capped Pt cubes.

To examine the chemical ligands on the surface of the Pt cubes, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted. The XPS analysis indicated the adsorption of PVP molecules on the surface. In addition, the Br 3p peak could also be seen, suggesting the presence of Br- ions on the surfaces. The existence of Pt(II) species on the surface can be ascribed to the chemisorption of Br- ions. 

The authors also carried out Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis for both the Pt cubes and pure PVP powder. The FTIR spectrum taken from the Pt cubes matched well with that of pure PVP powder, indicating the presence of pyrrolidone species on Pt surface. 

The formation mechanism of the PVP55-capped Pt cubes was studied by taking aliquots of the reaction solution at different stages and examining them by TEM. The authors observed that Pt atoms from the reduction of precursor first nucleated and grew into truncated octahedra or cuboctahedra enclosed by both {100} and {111} facets. The selective binding of Br- ions to the {100} facets made these facets thermodynamically more stable than {111} facets. As a result, the addition of consequent Pt atoms preferentially occurred on {111} facets, resulting in the shrinkage of {111} facets and eventually the formation of Pt cubes mainly covered by {100} facets.

The authors also noted that the size of the PVP55-capped Pt cubes could be tuned by simply varying the amount of PVP55 added in the standard synthesis. The authors conducted X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis for the Pt cubes to examine chemical ligands on the surface. In the initial stage of the reaction, nanoparticles with sizes of several nanometers were formed. As the reaction proceeded, the size of the nanoparticles increased and their shape evolved, eventually forming cubes and a small portion of anisotropically truncated cubes of ~7 nm as the final products.

The authors note that the PVP55-capped Pt cubes have several distinctive advantages over conventional CTAB/TTAB-capped Pt cubes. They can be synthesized in a short period (20 min versus 6-7 hours for CTAB/TTAB-capped Pt cubes), they can be produced in large quantities (~6.7 mg of Pt cubes could be obtained in a standard synthesis), and their size can be tuned by simply varying the amount of PVP55 added in the standard synthesis. For example, the sizes of PVP55-capped Pt cubes could be changed to 8.16 and 6.45 nm, respectively, when 8 and 200 mg PVP55 (instead of 40 mg PVP55) were added to the reaction solution.

The synthesis of Rhodium nanoparticles (RhNPs) was carried out according to the experimental procedure described in a previous work. The RhNPs were synthesized by reducing 0.25 mM of RhCl3·3H2O with 2.5 mM borohydride in the presence of 0.25 mM citrate ions as stabilizers and mixing for 10 min under stirring. 

The characterization of RhNPs was performed with Atomic force microscopy (AFM) and Dynamic light scattering (DLS). AFM images were obtained in tapping mode with a Multimode Nanoscope 3D using Tap300G silicon cantilevers with a force constant of ≈20–75 N m−1 and tip radius < 10 nm. DLS measurements were performed on a Malvern Zetasizer Nano ZS instrument, using a red laser at 25 °C.

The AFM images show relatively uniform RhNPs without aggregates. Based on the topographical height profile (section analysis) the size of the particles lied between 4.0 and 8.0 nm with an average size of 6.5 nm (depth profile analysis) while the average hydrodynamic diameter of the particles, calculated by DLS, was equal to 9.2 nm. 

The concentration of RhNPs was calculated according to the method described previously assuming the complete reduction of RhCl3 and that each nanoparticle has a spherical shape with a uniform face centered cubic (fcc) structure. The molar concentration of RhNPs of 7 nm size was calculated to be 1.4 nmol L−1 which corresponds to 8.4 × 1011 nanoparticles per mL (nps mL−1) of solution. 

All reagents used were of analytical grade. L-Cysteine, glutamine (Gln), creatinine, uric acid, D(+)-glucose, glucose oxidase, horseradish peroxidase (HRP), bovine serum albumin (BSA), sodium borohydride, sodium acetate, glacial acetic acid and urea were purchased from Sigma Aldrich. Glycine (Gly), Lysine (Lys) and Valine (Val) were supplied by Serva Electrophoresis GmbH. Arginine (Arg), Rhodium (III)-chloride trihydrate (RhCl3 x 3H2O, 38–40% metal basis) and H2O2 (Perhydrol®) were obtained from Merck. Citric acid was obtained from Mallinckrodt and 3,3′,5,5′ – Tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) was purchased from Alfa Aesar.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 63 nm Pd@Pt nanoparticles. However, it does describe the general procedure for the preparation of Pd@Pt bimetallic nanoplates. 

Pd nanosheets (Pd NSs) were first prepared according to a previously reported method. Pd(acac)2 (50.0 mg), PVP (160.0 mg) and TBAB (160 mg) were mixed together with DMF (10.0 mL) and water (2.0 mL) in a glass pressure vessel. The vessel was then charged with CO to 1 bar and heated from room temperature to 90 °C in 1 h, and then kept at 90 °C for another 3 h before being cooled to room temperature. The obtained dark blue products were precipitated by acetone, and purified by an ethanol−acetone mixture for further use.

For the preparation of Pd@Pt bimetallic nanoplates with different Pt/Pd ratios, a similar procedure was applied except that different mass of Pt(acac)2 (2 mg mL−1 in DMF) was used to replace AuPPh3Cl and the solution was left undisturbed at 100 °C for more than 12 h. The amounts of Pd, Au and Pt were also measured by ICP-MS (the mass ratios of Pt/Pd from a to e are 1.3:1, 2.9:1, 5:1, 8:1 and 12:1, respectively).

The article does not provide specific details on the size of the nanoparticles produced using this method, nor does it provide specific molar amounts for the reagents used. The equipment used in this process includes a glass pressure vessel, a heating device to control the temperature, and a centrifuge for the separation of the products. The reagents used include Pd(acac)2, PVP, TBAB, DMF, water, acetone, ethanol, and Pt(acac)2.

The article provides a detailed procedure for the preparation of Co3O4-MMT nanocomposites, but it does not specify the size of the Co3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) produced. However, it does mention that the Co3O4 nanoparticles with ca. 10-20 nm in size were dispersed well on the surface of MMT sheets.

The Co3O4-MMT nanocomposites were prepared as follows: Firstly, 0.3000g MMT was dissolved in 13mL alcohol aqueous solution (H2O2:C2H5OH=1:1) under stirring violently for 18h to form a homogeneous suspension. Secondly, 0.2910g of the Co(NO3)2 (1mmol) were added into the above suspension under vigorous stirring for another 2h. The resulting solution was assigned as solution A. 

Thirdly, 1.25 ml ammonium hydroxide was cautiously dropwise added into the solution A and stirred for 1h. Subsequently, the above solution was sealed in an autoclave and heated at 170℃ for 8h. Finally, the products were collected by centrifugation, washed with distilled water for three times and subsequently ethanol, and then dried at 60 ℃ for 8 h in air.

The peroxidase-like activity of Co3O4-MMT nanocomposites was investigated via the results of catalytic oxidizing the substrate TMB by H2O2. In a typical procedure, 0.2 mL of TMB (1 mM) in sodium acetate buffer solution (pH=4.0) was dealt with different reaction systems, listed in Table 1. The total reaction volume was 2 mL. The absorption spectra of different experimental systems were measured by recording the absorption spectra in wavelength mode (500-800nm).

In order to determine the influence of the reaction time on the preparation of nanocomposites, experiments were carried out for different reaction times (2h, 4h, 6h, 8h, 10h). The obtained nanocomposites were characterized by XRD and SEM. From the XRD patterns, it can be seen that Co3O4 nanoparticles have been formed after reaction for 2h. The diffraction peaks at 19.04°, 31.32°, 36.89°, and 44.87° agreed well with that of peak of Co3O4 (JCPDS card no.42-1467). Moreover, from the XRD data, it can be found that the longer the experimental time, the more the intensity of the peaks of Co3O4 nanoparticles. It can be found that when experiments have carried out for 8 h, the intensity of diffraction peaks of Co3O4 nanoparticles have reached maximum.

The synthesis of Cu2(OH)3Cl-CeO2 nanoparticles (NPs) was achieved through a co-precipitation method in an aqueous solution. The reagents used for this process included cerium chloride (CeCl3 ·7H2O), copper chloride (CuCl2·2H2O), and ionic liquids of 1-Ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride. The molecular ratio of copper salt to cerium salt was maintained at a fixed constant ion concentration (2:1). The exact quantities of the reagents used were 0.4672 g of CeCl3 ·7H2O and 0.4276 g of CuCl2·2H2O, dissolved in 200 mL of distilled deionized water. Additionally, 2.3945 g of ionic liquids were rapidly added to the solution.

The solution was then heated to 95 °C under nitrogen in an oil bath while being stirred magnetically in a round bottom flask fitted with a reflux condenser. After two hours, 50 mL of 90 mM hexamethylenetetramine was added to the solution drop by drop over a period of 30 minutes. The solution was further reacted for 5 hours with constant fluxing under nitrogen and magnetic stirring.

After the reaction was completed, the samples were separated by filtration and further washed with water. They were then naturally dried at room temperature and stored until use. When needed, the material was redispersed in water.

The equipment used in this process included a scanning electron microscope (SEM) for recording, a JSM-6610 scanning electron microscope (Japan) for imaging, a Rigaku DLMAX-2550 V diffract meter for collecting X-ray powder diffract meter (XRD) data, a UV-2450 Shimadzu Vis-spectrometer for kinetic measurements and UV–vis absorption spectra, a Canon G11 digital camera for taking photographs, a Guohua SHA-C constant-temperature shaker, and a Jingli Ld4-2 low-speed centrifuge.

It's important to note that the article does not specify the size of the nanoparticles synthesized. Therefore, adjustments may be needed in the synthesis process to achieve 1000 nm Cu2(OH)3Cl-CeO2 NPs.
