The synthesis of Cu2(OH)3Cl-CeO2 composite material, which includes nanoparticles, was achieved through a co-precipitation method in an aqueous solution. The reagents used for this process were cerium chloride (CeCl3 ·7H2O), copper chloride (CuCl2·2H2O), and ionic liquids of 1-Ethyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride. All reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. The molecular ratio of copper salt to cerium salt was at a fixed constant ion concentration (2:1). Specifically, 0.4672 g of CeCl3 ·7H2O and 0.4276 g of CuCl2·2H2O were dissolved in 200 mL distilled deionized water.

The solution was then brought to oil bath heating at 95 °C while magnetic stirring in a round bottom flask fitted with a reflux condenser, and 2.3945 g of ionic liquids were rapidly added to the solution. The solution was heated to 95 °C under nitrogen. Two hours later, 50 mL 90 mM hexamethylenetetramine was added to the solution drop by drop over a period of 30 min. The solution was additionally reacted for 5 h with constant fluxing under nitrogen and magnetic stirring.

After the reaction was completed, the samples were separated by filtration and further washed with water. They were then naturally dried at room temperature. The final product was a very fine green powder that could be well dispersed in water. The material was stored at room temperature and redispersed in water when used.

The morphology, shape, and size of the samples were characterized by a Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM). The phase and structures of the as-prepared powders were characterized by X-ray powder diffract meter (XRD). The SEM images indicated that the spheres with a diameter of about 0.8 μm were adhered to the large crystals with a diameter of 5–10 μm. The XRD data showed that all the diffraction peaks of the powders matched well with the Cu2(OH)3Cl Phase and cerium oxide Phase, indicating the formation of a pure Cu2(OH)3Cl-CeO2 composite material. 

Please note that the article does not specify the exact size of the nanoparticles synthesized, but the SEM images indicated that the spheres had a diameter of about 0.8 μm (800 nm).

The synthesis of Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) was carried out using several procedures. First, oleic acid-stabilized MNPs were synthesized using thermal decomposition of Fe-oleate in high-boiling-point solvents using procedures developed by Hyeon and co-workers [19]. The exact size of the nanoparticles is not specified in the article.

Two different approaches were applied to disperse oleic acid-stabilized MNPs in aqueous media. The first is cap exchange by poly(ethylene glycol)-derivatized phosphine oxide (POPEG), which has a PEG segment and a surface-coordinating phosphine oxide head group, for displacing the oleic acid on the nanoparticles. Briefly, 10 mg of nanoparticles were dispersed in 3 mL of THF solution containing 50 mg of POPEG. After removing THF by evacuation, the sticky mixture was incubated at 80 °C under a vacuum for 3 h. DI water was added, and the dispersed nanoparticles were purified by syringe and centrifugal filters. The MNPs obtained in this manner were denoted as POPEG-MNPs.

The other approach was the preparation by encapsulation via a hydrophobic interaction between alkyl chains in Lipid PEG and oleic acid on the nanoparticles. Here, 10 mg of oleic acid-stabilized MNPs were dispersed in 2 mL of chloroform. Then, it was mixed with 1 mL of chloroform solution containing 10 mg of mPEG-2000 PE. After evaporating the solvent, it was incubated at 80 °C in a vacuum for 1 h. After the addition of DI water, Lipid PEG-stabilized MNPs were purified by filtration and ultra-speed centrifugation. The MNPs obtained in this manner were denoted as Lipid PEG-MNPs.

Bare MNPs with the hydroxyl group were synthesized using the reported procedure [20]. Briefly, a 1 M sodium hydroxide solution was added to a 0.25 M Fe3+ and Fe2+ aqueous salt solutions (2:1 M ratio) while stirring at 80 °C for 40 min (pH 10). The MNPs obtained in this manner were washed several times with water and ethanol and dried at 70 °C under a vacuum. 

MNPs modified with APTES (APTES-MNPs) were synthesized using the procedures reported by Gao et al. [21]. The MNPs were dispersed in water to make a 10 mg·mL−1 stock solution and stored at 4 °C until use. 

The synthesized MNPs were analyzed by transmission electron microscopic (TEM) images on a Jeol EM-2010 microscope (Jeol Co.). The hydrodynamic diameters (HDs) of MNPs were determined by light-scattering analysis using a Zetasizer Nano-ZS (Malvern Co.). Iron concentrations in MNPs were also measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) (model: Polyscan 60E, Thermo Jarrell).

The synthesis of Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) was carried out using several methods as described in the article. 

Firstly, oleic acid-stabilized MNPs were synthesized using thermal decomposition of Fe-oleate in high-boiling-point solvents using procedures developed by Hyeon and co-workers [19]. The exact size of the nanoparticles is not specified in the article, but this method is known to produce monodisperse nanoparticles.

Two different approaches were then applied to disperse these oleic acid-stabilized MNPs in aqueous media. The first approach involved a cap exchange by poly(ethylene glycol)-derivatized phosphine oxide (POPEG), which has a PEG segment and a surface-coordinating phosphine oxide head group, for displacing the oleic acid on the nanoparticles. Briefly, 10 mg of nanoparticles were dispersed in 3 mL of THF solution containing 50 mg of POPEG. After removing THF by evacuation, the sticky mixture was incubated at 80 °C under a vacuum for 3 h. DI water was added, and the dispersed nanoparticles were purified by syringe and centrifugal filters. The resulting MNPs were denoted as POPEG-MNPs.

The second approach involved the preparation by encapsulation via a hydrophobic interaction between alkyl chains in Lipid PEG and oleic acid on the nanoparticles. Here, 10 mg of oleic acid-stabilized MNPs were dispersed in 2 mL of chloroform. Then, it was mixed with 1 mL of chloroform solution containing 10 mg of mPEG-2000 PE. After evaporating the solvent, it was incubated at 80 °C in a vacuum for 1 h. After the addition of DI water, Lipid PEG-stabilized MNPs were purified by filtration and ultra-speed centrifugation. The resulting MNPs were denoted as Lipid PEG-MNPs.

In addition, bare MNPs with the hydroxyl group were synthesized using a reported procedure [20]. Briefly, a 1 M sodium hydroxide solution was added to a 0.25 M Fe3+ and Fe2+ aqueous salt solutions (2:1 M ratio) while stirring at 80 °C for 40 min (pH 10). The MNPs obtained in this manner were washed several times with water and ethanol and dried at 70 °C under a vacuum. 

MNPs modified with APTES (APTES-MNPs) were synthesized using the procedures reported by Gao et al. [21]. The MNPs were dispersed in water to make a 10 mg·mL−1 stock solution and stored at 4 °C until use. 

The synthesized MNPs were analyzed by transmission electron microscopic (TEM) images on a Jeol EM-2010 microscope (Jeol Co.). The hydrodynamic diameters (HDs) of MNPs were determined by light-scattering analysis using a Zetasizer Nano-ZS (Malvern Co.). Iron concentrations in MNPs were also measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) (model: Polyscan 60E, Thermo Jarrell).

The synthesis of RuTe nanoparticles (NPs) involves two main steps: the preparation of Te nanorods (TeNRs) and the synthesis of Ru-Te nanorods.

For the preparation of TeNRs, a 50 mL transparent borosilicate glass vial is used. To this vial, 1g of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) with a molecular weight of 40 kDa, 92.2 mg of sodium tellurite (Na2TeO3), and 0.5 mg of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) are added to 40 mL of ethylene glycol. This mixture is stirred to create a homogeneous solution without the need for ultrasonication. Then, 1.3 mL of hydrazine monohydrate (64-65%) is added. The mixture is heated in a 70 °C water bath for 3 hours under vigorous stirring. The resulting deep-blue colored TeNRs are cooled down to room temperature naturally and are used in the following reaction without any purification and storage.

The synthesis of Ru-Te nanorods is carried out in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave vessel. To this vessel, 20 mL of the as-synthesized TeNRs in ethylene glycol and 2.5 mL of a 10 mM ruthenium(III) chloride (RuCl3) stock solution are added. After gentle mixing to ensure a homogeneous mixture, the Teflon-lined autoclave in a stainless steel reactor is heated at 200 °C for 2 hours. The resulting black colored product is cooled down to room temperature and purified by centrifugation at 9000 rpm for 10 minutes. Additional washing steps with deionized (DI) water are performed at least 3 times and the product is finally re-dispersed in 20 mL DI water.

The morphology and size of the nanoparticles are observed using an energy-filtering transmission electron microscope (LIBRA 120, Carl Zeiss, Germany). High-resolution imaging and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping are performed by a Cs-corrected scanning transmission electron microscope. According to the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images, hollow nanorods with lengths of 130 ± 13 nm and widths of 14 ± 2 nm (n = 30) are synthesized with a relatively monodisperse distribution.

The colloidal stability of the particles is confirmed using simulated physiological fluid and their biocompatibility is confirmed using cyto-, hemo- and organ-toxicity analyses. This study serves as a basis for future material chemistry and biomedical research on the formation of Ru-based nanocomposites that exhibit multi-nanozymatic activity and high surface-to-volume ratios.

The synthesis of Cu2-xTe nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the research article. The Cu2-xTe NPs were synthesized via the reaction of copper(I) chloride with trioctylphosphine telluride (TOPTe). The as-prepared Cu2-xTe NPs are hydrophobic with oleic acid as surface ligands. 

Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images reveal that the Cu2-xTe NPs are typical cuboid structure with average dimensions of 17 nm × 11 nm × 9 nm. Element mapping results demonstrate the uniform distributions of Cu and Te in Cu2-xTe NPs. The electron diffraction pattern and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data show that the Cu2−xTe NPs are polycrystalline rickardite. The distance between adjacent lattice fringes is around 0.38 nm, corresponding to the (051) plane of Cu2−xTe. 

According to the energy dispersive spectrum (EDS), the atomic ratio of Cu to Te in Cu2−xTe NPs is close to 1.2:1, indicative of their nonstoichiometric composition. The elemental compositions and purity of Cu2-xTe NPs were further checked through X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Characteristic binding energy peaks of both Cu(I) and Cu (II) can be clearly observed.

To increase the dispersion stability of Cu2-xTe NPs in physiological environment, 1, 2-distearoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoethanolamine-poly(ethylene glycol) (DSPE-PEG) was coated at the surface of Cu2-xTe NPs. The obtained Cu2-xTe NEs exhibit characteristic infrared absorption of DSPE-PEG in the Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrum, demonstrating their successful coating. 

The average hydrodynamic diameter of Cu2-xTe NEs is around 30 nm, which show similar morphology to Cu2-xTe NPs. The steric hindrance and hydrophilicity of DSPE-PEG endow Cu2-xTe NEs with stable dispersion stability in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) for over two weeks; whereas Cu2-xTe NPs are prone to form aggregation with micrometer size under the same condition.

Unfortunately, the article does not provide specific details on the quantities of reagents used or the exact parameters of the synthesis process.

The synthesis of CuO nanoparticles (NPs) of around 200 nm size involves a series of steps and requires specific reagents and equipment. The process begins with the addition of 12 mL of water into 25 mL of an aqueous solution of PAN (0.05 g/mL) with continuous stirring. Following this, 0.16 g of PVP and 2.5 mL of ammonium hydroxide are added to the mixture. The mixture is then stirred magnetically for 20 minutes, after which 17.5 mL of sodium hydroxide solution (1.0 M) is added. The mixture is then stirred continuously for 2 hours at 60 °C and then centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 20 minutes. The obtained precipitate is washed with ethanol three times and dried at 50 °C for 12 hours. The final product is pure and clear brown-colored PAN-CuO nanoflowers, which are stored at 4 °C for further use.

The growth mechanism of PAN-CuO nanoflowers was investigated using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). When the reaction time was 10 minutes, the CuO nanoneedles began to grow onto the surface of PAN nanoflowers, and the size of PAN-CuO nanoflowers was about ∼200 nm. As the reaction progressed, the average size of PAN-CuO nanoflowers reached ∼280 nm within 120 minutes and tended to be uniform. More and more CuO nanoneedles were grown onto the surface of PAN-CuO nanoflowers. When the reaction time was increased to 150 minutes, the size distribution (300−340 nm) and the morphology of the nanostructures were not uniform.

The effects of temperature and the amount of copper nitrate on the formation of nanostructures were also determined. When the temperature was 40 °C, very little CuO nanoneedles were grown on the surface of PAN nanoflowers. When the temperature was increased to 50 °C, flowerlike nanoparticles began to appear in some areas. When the temperature reached 60 °C, uniform nanoflowers (about 300 nm) were obtained. When the temperature was increased to 70 °C, the sample consisted of CuO nanorods and PAN. Therefore, 60 °C was chosen in the next experiment.

The effect of mass ratio of copper nitrate and PAN on the morphology of PAN-CuO nanoflowers was investigated. When the mass ratio of copper nitrate and PAN was 1.25:1, CuO nanoneedles were formed and tended to aggregate together rather than growing onto the surface of the PAN nanoflowers. When the ratio was reduced to 1:1, small amounts of CuO nanoneedles were grown on the surface of PAN, and when the ratio reached 1:1.25, flowerlike nanoballs were formed (about 300 nm). As the ratio reached 1:1.5, the sample still contained uniform nanoflowers. However, the diameter increased to 350 nm. Thus, the best ratio of copper nitrate and PAN was 1:1.25.

The influence of pH on the formation of PAN-CuO nanoflowers was also studied. When ammonium hydroxide was added into the reaction system, CuO nanoneedles could grow on the surface of PAN nanoflowers in an orderly manner, and the PAN-CuO nanoflowers formed gradually (about 300 nm). On the contrary, when ammonium hydroxide was not added into the system, large particles of CuO were formed, which did not grow on the surface of PAN nanoflowers but scattered on the side. Thus, after the addition of ammonium hydroxide in the reaction system, pure PAN-CuO nanoflowers were prepared.

The growth mechanism of PAN-CuO nanoflowers was investigated using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The size of PAN-CuO nanoflowers was about ∼200 nm when the reaction time was 10 min. The effect of mass ratio of copper nitrate and PAN on the morphology of PAN-CuO nanoflowers was investigated. When the ratio was reduced to 1:1, small amounts of CuO nanoneedles were grown on the surface of PAN, and when the ratio reached 1:1.25, flowerlike nanoballs were formed (about 300 nm). On the contrary, when ammonium hydroxide was not added into the system, large particles of CuO were formed, which did not grow on the surface of PAN nanoflowers but scattered on the side. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of CuO nanoparticles involves a variety of parameters including the amount of reagents, temperature, pH, and reaction time. The synthesis of RhPt nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out using a simple, one-pot wet chemical method. The materials used for the synthesis included citric acid (CA), rhodium(III) chloride hydrate (RhCl3·xH2O), chloroplatinic acid hydrate (H2PtCl6·xH2O), and sodium borohydride (NaBH4). These were obtained from various suppliers including Sigma-Aldrich, Samchun Chemical Co., Ltd, Junsei Chemical Co., Ltd, and Alfa Aesar.

The process began with the addition of 1 mL of H2PtCl6 (10 mM) and the same amount of RhCl3 (10 mM) to deionized (DI) water (16 mL). The mixture was incubated for 10 min under vigorous stirring. Then, 2 mL of CA (10 mM) was added. After incubation for 10 min, 1 mL of NaBH4 (60 mM) was quickly added under continuous stirring. The mixture was incubated for 30 min and centrifuged (13 000 rpm, 25 min) to precipitate the CA-RhPt NPs. Then, the precipitate was washed with ethanol and water. Finally, the precipitate was redispersed in DI water and stored at 4 °C before use.

The morphology and structure of the nanoparticles were confirmed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010, USA) and an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D/MAX-2500, Rigaku, USA), respectively. The introduction of CA to RhPt NPs was investigated using zeta potential measurements (zeta-potential analyzer, Zetasizer Nano ZS90, Malvern Instruments Ltd., U.K.) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, K-ALPHA, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., U.K.). 

The crystalline sizes of RhPt NPs and CA-RhPt NPs, which correspond to the peak of the (111) plane, were calculated using Scherer’s formula and estimated to be 3.30 and 2.90 nm, respectively. The reduced crystalline size of CA-RhPt NPs was due to the high dispersity of nanoparticles. The TEM image shows that the CA-RhPt NPs are well-dispersed with an average diameter of 3.5 ± 0.5 nm. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of RhPt NPs involves a simple one-pot wet chemical method using specific reagents and equipment. The size of the nanoparticles can be controlled by adjusting the parameters of the experiment, such as the concentration of the reagents and the incubation and centrifugation times.

The synthesis of RhPt nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out using a simple, one-pot wet chemical method. The reagents used for the synthesis included rhodium(III) chloride hydrate (RhCl3·xH2O), chloroplatinic acid hydrate (H2PtCl6·xH2O), citric acid (CA), and sodium borohydride (NaBH4). 

Initially, 1 mL of H2PtCl6 (10 mM) and the same amount of RhCl3 (10 mM) were added to deionized (DI) water (16 mL). The mixture was incubated for 10 min under vigorous stirring. Then, 2 mL of CA (10 mM) was added. After incubation for 10 min, 1 mL of NaBH4 (60 mM) was quickly added under continuous stirring. The mixture was incubated for 30 min and centrifuged (13 000 rpm, 25 min) to precipitate the CA-RhPt NPs. Then, the precipitate was washed with ethanol and water. Finally, the precipitate was redispersed in DI water and stored at 4 °C before use.

The morphology and structure of nanoparticles were confirmed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2010, USA) and an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, D/MAX-2500, Rigaku, USA), respectively. The introduction of CA to RhPt NPs was investigated using zeta potential measurements (zeta-potential analyzer, Zetasizer Nano ZS90, Malvern Instruments Ltd., U.K.) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, K-ALPHA, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., U.K.). 

The crystalline sizes of RhPt NPs and CA-RhPt NPs, which correspond to the peak of the (111) plane, were calculated using Scherer’s formula and estimated to be 3.30 and 2.90 nm, respectively. The reduced crystalline size of CA-RhPt NPs was due to the high dispersity of nanoparticles. 

The TEM image shows that the CA-RhPt NPs are well-dispersed with an average diameter of 3.5 ± 0.5 nm. The chemical composition of CA-RhPt NPs was investigated using ICP−AES, and the molar ratio of Rh/Pt was 49:51. This molar ratio was very similar to the precursor ratio and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy analysis results.

The synthesis of citrate-capped platinum nanoparticles (PtNPs) of approximately 2.5 nm in size is described in the article. The process involves the use of several reagents and equipment, and follows a specific procedure.

The reagents used in the synthesis include H2PtCl6·(H2O)6, trisodium citrate (Na3C6H5O7·2H2O), and sodium borohydride (NaBH4), all of which were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China). Other reagents and chemicals used were of at least analytical reagent grade and used without further purification. Solutions were prepared with water purified by a Milli-Q purification system (Millipore, USA).

The synthesis of PtNPs was performed in a glass ware with the magnetic stir. Aqueous solutions of H2PtCl6 (1 mL, 16 mM) and trisodium citrate (1 mL, 40 mM) were mixed with 38 mL water and stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Subsequently, NaBH4 (200 µL, 50 mM) was added dropwise into the mixture. The colorless reactant mixture immediately turned into brownish yellow. Finally, the mixture was allowed to react and stirred at ambient temperature for 1 h.

The size and morphology of the nanoparticles was analyzed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The platinum nanoparticles were largely monodispersed and roughly spherical. The average particle diameter is found to be approximately 2.5±0.4 nm. High-resolution TEM indicates the continuous lattice spacing of 0.223 nm corresponding to the (111) facet of the face-centered cubic (fcc) Pt crystal.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed for the surface elemental analysis. The whole spectrum clearly revealed that platinum, carbon, oxygen, and sodium were present at the surface of PtNPs, indicating that the PtNPs are capped by citrate. The Pt 4f7/2 of citrate-capped PtNPs could be deconvoluted into two distinct components centered at binding energies of 72.82 and 74.71 eV, which could be assigned to Pt0 and Pt4+, respectively.

In conclusion, the synthesis of PtNPs involves the use of specific reagents, equipment, and procedures. The resulting nanoparticles are approximately 2.5 nm in size and are capped by citrate.

The synthesis of Fe-doped CoO nanoparticles (NCs), specifically 0.15Fe-CoO NCs, was achieved through a two-step process involving solvothermal and roasting processes. 

In the first step, 1 mmol of Co(NO3)2 was added into a homogeneous mixture containing glycerin and isopropanol (16 and 60 mL, respectively) and vigorously stirred for 1 hour. Following this, n mmol of Fe(NO3)3 (n = 0.05, 0.1, 0.15, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8, and 1.0) was added and continuously mixed for another 10 hours. The mixture was then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon container with a stainless-steel autoclave and treated under 180 °C for 6 hours. The obtained precipitate was purified by alternately washing with water and ethanol (6 times in total) and then dried overnight at 60 °C.

In the second step, the precursor was roasted at 400 °C for 2 hours with the protection of N2 flow. The final samples were recorded as nFe-CoO NCs. Pure CoO nanoparticles (NPs) were prepared using a similar method without adding Fe3+ salt. However, without Co2+ salt, the Fe3+ ions cannot crystallize to be FeO or Fe3O4 NPs.

The article does not provide specific information on the synthesis of 450 nm Fe0.15-CoO NPs. The size of the nanoparticles is typically controlled by the conditions of the synthesis, such as the concentration of the precursors, the temperature, and the duration of the reaction. However, these parameters are not specified in the article for the synthesis of 450 nm Fe0.15-CoO NPs.

The Fe3O4 nanoparticles were synthesized using the solvothermal method with some modifications. For the synthesis of Fe3O4 nanoparticles, FeCl3$6H2O (0.82 g) was dissolved in 40 mL ethylene glycol. When the solution became clear, NaAc (3.6 g) was added under continuous vigorous stirring for 30 minutes. The mixture was then sonicated for 10 minutes, after which it was transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and reacted at 200 C for 12 hours. 

After the reaction was completed, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature. The products obtained were then washed several times with ethanol and dried at 60 C. The morphology and structure of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles were characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-1400 120 kV), scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss Supra55) and dynamic light scattering (DLS, DynaPro Titan). 

Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles was conducted using the Tecnai G2 F30 instrument. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed using the X'Pert pro Philips X-ray powder diffractometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed by the ESCALab220i-XL high-performance electron spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Ka source. 

The TEM images of the as-prepared Fe3O4 nanoparticles showed a typical spherical morphology with an average size of 89.8 ± 7.9 nm. The SEM images also confirmed the spherical morphology of the nanoparticles. The XRD patterns indicated that the Fe3O4 nanoparticles were well crystallized.

The Co-doped Fe3O4 nanoparticles (Co@Fe3O4) used in this study were synthesized by the solvothermal method. For the synthesis of Fe3O4 nanoparticles, FeCl3$6H2O (0.82 g) was dissolved in 40 mL ethylene glycol. When the solution became clear, NaAc (3.6 g) was added under continuous vigorous stirring for 30 min. The mixture was sonicated for 10 min, then transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and reacted at 200 C for 12 h. After the reaction was completed, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature. Then, the products obtained were washed several times with ethanol and dried at 60 C.

Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) of the Fe3O4 and Co@Fe3O4 nanoparticles was conducted using the Tecnai G2 F30 instrument. The synthesis of H2TCPP functionalized hydrophilic magnetite nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out using a simple one-step method. The reagents used in the synthesis included 5 mg of H2TCPP, which was dissolved in a dilute basic aqueous solution tuned by NaOH. About 0.1 mg of NaOH was dissolved in 1 mL of water to achieve a pH of 8. Following this, 16 mg of NaOH and 1.7 g of NaNO3 were dissolved in 19 mL of water, and the above porphyrin solution was added. Finally, a solution of FeSO4·7H2O (1 mL, 0.2 M) was rapidly added.

The characterization of the nanoparticles was performed using various techniques. The crystal structures of the products were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (D/Max2500PC, Rigaku). The dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurement of the nanoparticles was performed on a Malvern particle size analyzer (Malvern, UK). Zeta potential was obtained on an electrophoresis apparatus (JS94H, China). The morphologies of the as-prepared H2TCPP-γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles were investigated by a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, JEOL, Japan). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a NICOLET 380 FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet Thermo, USA) by detecting the compressed pellet obtained by mixing the sample with KBr. Absorption spectra were recorded on a UV-vis spectrophotometer (UV-3200PC) (Shanghai, China). Fluorometric measurements were carried out by a Cary Eclipse spectrofluorophotometer (Varian, Inc., USA). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a PHI Quantera SXM spectrometer with an Al Kα=280.00 eV excitation source, and binding energies were calibrated by referencing the C1 speak (284.5eV) to reduce the sample charge effect.

The SEM images of the H2TCPP-γ-Fe2O3 NPs showed that the products are composed of a large quantity of nanospheres with a diameter range from ca. 20 nm to ca. 200 nm. The average size of the nanoparticles was ca.122.4 nm. The DLS measurements were carried out to investigate the distribution of these regular nanospheres. The obtained H2TCPP-γ-Fe2O3 NPs could be stably dispersed in aqueous solution, as shown in Fig. 4A. The stability of the nanocomposites in the aqueous solution was verified by zeta potentials (-55.403 mV). The high value of zeta potentials indicated the good stability of the nanocomposites in water.

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 35 nm Fe2O3 nanoparticles. However, it does describe a general method for the synthesis of morphologically different iron oxide nanoparticles using Schiff base (SB) templates. 

The synthesis process involves the use of four different SBs, generated from the permutative combination of two different aldehydes (glyoxal and glutaraldehyde) and two different amines (ethylenediamine and triethylenetetramine). These SBs serve as templates for the synthesis of the iron oxide nanoparticles. Mohr’s salt is used as the iron source and hydrazine is used as the hydrolyzing reagent. The reaction is carried out at a refluxing temperature of 373 K. Under these conditions, morphologically different Fe2O3 nanoparticles are produced in 1 hour as a consequence of dehydration.

The refluxing condition for an hour and the N2 bubble formed from the decomposition of hydrazine effects the crystallisation process by formation of a large number of nucleation sites in the reaction medium. This facile synthesis leads to gram level production of phase pure crystalline γ-Fe2O3 or α-Fe2O3, depending upon the variable SB templates' nature. Oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ is a spontaneous process in the ambient condition. Considering Mohr’s salt as precursor, the transformation of Fe2+ ions is controlled, which further act as catalyst showing peroxidase-like activity. The effect of SB templates in the phase specific formation of Fe2O3 has been elaborated here. Advantageous imine group in SBs accelerates the hydrolysis of the metal hydroxide. This supports the benefit of SB template for the synthesis of Fe2O3 nanoparticles under refluxing condition.

The article also discusses the magnetic properties of the synthesized nanoparticles. As the particle size decreases to nanoregime, tinier than the magnetic domain; nanoparticles are considered to be completely magnetised. The term “superparamagnetism” is used to emphasis the magnetic behaviour for paramagnetic nanoparticles which arises from the coupling of several thousands of atoms in comparison to the paramagnetism of a single atom. This magnetization can reach nearly the saturation magnetization of ferromagnetic iron oxide, but in contrast to ferromagnetic iron the particles no longer show magnetic interactions after elimination of the magnetic field. The magnetic data of all these TemFes are examined and discussed thoroughly to decipher the linear relationship between the particle size and size dependent magnetism. 

In conclusion, while the article does not provide specific details for the synthesis of 35 nm Fe2O3 nanoparticles, it does provide a general method for the synthesis of iron oxide nanoparticles using Schiff base templates.

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 35 nm Fe2O3 nanoparticles. However, it does describe a general method for the synthesis of Fe2O3 nanoparticles using a Schiff base (SB) template. The SB is a condensation product of aldehyde and amine, and it serves as a prospective template for the synthesis of morphologically different iron oxide. Four different SBs, generated from the permutative combination of two different aldehydes (glyoxal and glutaraldehyde) and two different amines (ethylenediamine and triethylenetetramine), have been employed for this purpose. Mohr’s salt is used as the iron source and hydrazine as the hydrolyzing reagent. The reaction is carried out at a refluxing temperature of 373 K. Under these conditions, morphologically different Fe2O3 nanoparticles are produced in 1 hour as a consequence of dehydration.

The refluxing condition for an hour and the N2 bubble formed from the decomposition of hydrazine affect the crystallisation process by forming a large number of nucleation sites in the reaction medium. This facile synthesis leads to gram-level production of phase pure crystalline γ-Fe2O3 or α-Fe2O3, depending on the variable SB templates' nature. The oxidation of Fe2+ to Fe3+ is a spontaneous process in the ambient condition. The effect of SB templates in the phase-specific formation of Fe2O3 has been elaborated in the article. The advantageous imine group in SBs accelerates the hydrolysis of the metal hydroxide, supporting the benefit of the SB template for the synthesis of Fe2O3 nanoparticles under refluxing conditions.

The PXRD patterns of the synthesized nanoparticles were indexed to γ-Fe2O3 and α-Fe2O3, confirming the phase purity in the system. The sharp peaks indicate the crystallinity of α- or γ-Fe2O3. The nature of the SB governs the formation of specific phases along with a definite size distribution of particles. However, the article does not provide specific details on how to control the size of the nanoparticles to achieve a specific size such as 35 nm. 

In terms of magnetic properties, as the particle size decreases to the nanoregime, particles with single-magnetic-domain are formed. The term “superparamagnetism” is used to emphasize the magnetic behaviour for paramagnetic nanoparticles which arises from the coupling of several thousands of atoms. This magnetization can reach nearly the saturation magnetization of ferromagnetic iron oxide, but in contrast to ferromagnetic iron, the particles no longer show magnetic interactions after elimination of the magnetic field. The magnetic data of all these synthesized nanoparticles are examined and discussed thoroughly to decipher the linear relationship between the particle size and size-dependent magnetism.

The article does not provide specific instructions for synthesizing Si-CoO nanoparticles of 1000 nm size. However, it does detail the process for creating Si-CoO nanorods with a width of 50-100 nm. 

The synthesis of Si-CoO nanorods was carried out based on a previously published method with minor modifications. The reagents used in the synthesis included cobalt nitrate (0.6926 g), urea (0.6 g), and deionized water (50 mL). These were mixed with different volumes of tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) (50, 100, 150, 200, 250, 300, and 400 uL). The mixture was then transferred into Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves (100 mL) and heated at 100 oC for 3 hours. 

After the heating process, the raw products were centrifuged and washed with pure water and ethanol in turn for 5 times. The raw products were then heated in a nitrogen atmosphere from 20 to 500 oC and maintained at 500 ℃ for 2 hours with a ramp rate of 5 oC min-1. 

The morphology of the Si-CoO was imaged by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM). The Si-CoO nanorods, with a width of 50-100 nm, were found to be composed of many nanoparticles approximately 15 nm in size. The lattice fringe with approximately 0.21 nm in d-spacing corresponds to the (111) lattice plane of CoO. 

The Si-CoO nanocomposite was found to possess excellent peroxidase-like activity. It quickly catalyzed the colorless substrate 3,3,5,5-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) to be oxidized into blue oxTMB by H2O2 only in 20 seconds. 

In conclusion, while the article does not provide specific instructions for synthesizing 1000 nm Si-CoO nanoparticles, it does provide a detailed method for creating Si-CoO nanorods of 50-100 nm width. The method involves the use of cobalt nitrate, urea, deionized water, and TEOS, and requires the use of Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves, a centrifuge, and a heating process in a nitrogen atmosphere. The resulting Si-CoO nanorods were found to possess excellent peroxidase-like activity.

The article does not provide specific instructions for synthesizing Si-CoO nanoparticles of 1000 nm size. However, it does describe the synthesis of Si-CoO nanorods with a width of 50-100 nm. 

The synthesis of Si-CoO nanorods was based on a publication with a minor modification. The reagents used were cobalt nitrate (0.6926 g), urea (0.6 g), and deionized water (50 mL). Different volumes of TEOS (50, 100, 150, 200, 250, 300, and 400 uL) were also used. These were mixed thoroughly and transferred into Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclaves (100 mL) at 100 oC for 3 hours. 

After this, the raw products were centrifuged and washed with pure water and ethanol in turn for 5 times. The raw products were then heated in a nitrogen atmosphere from 20 to 500 oC and maintained at 500 ℃ for 2 hours with a ramp rate of 5 oC min-1. 

The Si-CoO nanorods were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS). The results suggest that Si element uniformly distributed onto CoO nanorods with a diameter of 50-100 nm. 

The Si-CoO nanorods were also evaluated for peroxidase-like activity by catalyzing the oxidation of the chromogenic substrate TMB by H2O2. The maximum absorbance of oxTMB was tested at 652 nm. Typically, 0.3 mg mL-1 of Si-CoO was mixed in acetate buffer solution (1.4 mL, pH 5.0), followed by adding of 200 uL of 1 mM TMB solution and 200 uL of 0.25 M H2O2. The absorbance of reaction systems were measured by the UV-vis absorption spectroscopy. 

The kinetic test of Si-CoO was performed by varying concentration of TMB while keeping H2O2 concentration unchanged and vice versa. A series of initial reaction rates were calculated according to the Michaelis-Menten equation. 

In conclusion, while the article does not provide specific instructions for synthesizing 1000 nm Si-CoO nanoparticles, it does provide a detailed procedure for synthesizing Si-CoO nanorods of 50-100 nm size.

The article does not provide specific details on the synthesis of 63 nm SiO2@Co3O4 nanoparticles. However, it does describe a general method for the synthesis of SiO2@Co3O4 core-shell nanorattles. 

The synthesis process involves several steps. Initially, Co2+ ions from the solution are adsorbed on the surface of SiO2 through electrostatic interactions. Urea decomposes to produce NH3 and CO2 and the released NH3 readily reacts with the available Co2+ ions on the surface of SiO2 to form a complex (i.e. Co(NH3)y; y ≤ 2) which reduces the concentration of free Co2+ ions in the solution. After attaining the optimum temperature (e.g. 85 oC), OH– ions are steadily produced through the hydrolysis of urea, which is favorable for nucleation and formation of Co(OH)2 on the surface of SiO2 spheres based on the coalescence mechanism. The Co(OH)2 further undergoes Ostwald ripening to produce flowerlike hierarchical Co(OH)2 on the surface of SiO2.

In the final step, calcination of SiO2@Co(OH)2 in air at 500 oC for 3 h leads to the formation of SiO2@Co3O4 coreshell nanorattles through selftemplate route retaining its 3D hierarchical flowerlike morphology for Co3O4 nanoparticles.

To understand the mechanism of formation of nanorattle structures further, time dependent TEM analysis was performed at different time intervals for SiO2@-Co(OH)2 (S1) (e.g. 2 h, 4 h and 6h) and SiO2@Co3O4 (e.g. 1 h and 3 h). Initially (e.g. 2 h), -Co(OH)2 nanoparticles are formed around the SiO2 spheres. As the reaction proceeds from 2 h to 4 h, inside-out Ostwald ripening process dominates which starts the hollowing process by dissolving the smaller crystallites of -Co(OH)2 present in the interior region. At 6 h, the outer - Co(OH)2 crystallites become larger which creates an interstitial space with the formation of a compact shell. Calcination of SiO2@-Co(OH)2 at 500 oC leads to the formation of SiO2@Co3O4 core-shell nanorattles with the retention of core￾shell nanorattles morphology.

The article does not provide specific details on the quantities of reagents used or the exact equipment utilized in the synthesis process.

The synthesis of MoS2/Fe3O4 nanocomposites, where Fe3O4 nanoparticles (NPs) mostly grew along the edge of 3D MoS2 “petals”, was achieved via a solvothermal route. The 3D MoS2 nanoflowers were obtained through a hydrothermal method, which was followed by the interaction with FeCl3·6H2O in ethanol solution, leading to the formation of MoS2/Fe3O4 nanocomposites.

The synthesis of MoS2 nanoflowers involved the use of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O) and thiourea (CH4N2S). These were added into 30 mL of ultrapure water, and the blue uniform solution was formed under continuous magnetic stirring for 30 minutes. This solution was then subjected to a hydrothermal reaction for 24 hours at 180 °C in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. The products were cooled to room temperature, filtered through a 0.22 μm water-phase filter membrane, subsequently washed by ultrapure water three times and dried in vacuum at 60 °C for 12 hours to obtain black MoS2 nanoflowers.

The preparation of MoS2/Fe3O4 nanocomposites involved the use of the as-prepared MoS2 nanoflowers and iron (III) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O). In the presence of 30 mL ethanol absolute, 0.10 g of the MoS2 nanoflowers were mixed with 0.24 g FeCl3·6H2O for 15 minutes for sonication to obtain better dispersity. Then the solution was stepwise added 5 mL ultrapure water and 0.72 g sodium acetate (CH3COONa) followed by 1 hour continuous stirring and solvothermal reaction for 24 hours at 200 °C. The products were cooled to room temperature, magnetically separated, and then washed alternately with ultrapure water and ethanol three times each. The final dark brown magnetic MoS2/Fe3O4 nanocomposites were obtained through vacuum drying at 60 °C for 12 hours.

The micro-morphology of the samples was analyzed using Field-Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi, S-4800) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin). The samples for TEM were firstly dispersed to ethanol absolute, followed by 10 minutes of sonication and addition on the copper grids support. The surface elements, composition and chemical state of the samples were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (ThermoFisher, ESCALAB 250Xi) with an Al Kα source. The absorbance determination and enzyme kinetics analysis were performed on Microplate Readers (Model Super-Max 3500FL). Mott-Scottky curves were recorded on CHI 660D electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments, Inc., Shanghai) with the usual three-electrode system (Na2SO4 electrolyte (0.1 M), 1 k Hz).

The article does not specify the size of the nanoparticles synthesized, but the methods described could potentially be adapted to synthesize nanoparticles of different sizes by adjusting the reaction conditions.

The synthesis of MoS2@MgFe2O4 nanoparticles (NPs) involves several steps and requires a variety of materials and equipment. 

Firstly, the materials required for the synthesis include Ferric(III) trichloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), magnesium chloride hexahydrate (MgCl2·6H2O), dodecylamine (DDA), ammonium tetrathiomolybdate ((NH4)2MoS4, ATTM), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), hydrazine hydrate (N2H4·H2O), and ethylene glycol (EG). All these materials were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company and used as received. 

The synthesis process begins with the preparation of MgFe2O4. In this process, 5.6 mmol FeCl3·6H2O, 2.8 mmol MgCl2·6H2O and 7 mmol DDA are dispersed in 70 mL EG and continuously stirred at room temperature. The obtained transparent solution is then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 200 oC for 18 hours. After cooling to ambient temperature naturally, the black precipitate is collected by centrifuge, washed several times with ethanol and DI water, and then dried at 60 oC overnight.

To prepare MoS2@MgFe2O4, 132 mg ATTM is dissolved in 60 mL DMF, and 1 mL N2H4·H2O is slowly added to the solution and sonicated for 1 hour. Then, 50 mg of the prepared MgFe2O4 is homogeneously dispersed in the mixture. The mixture is then transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and held at 200 oC for 10 hours. After cooling to ambient temperature naturally, the precipitate is centrifuged, washed several times with ethanol and DI water, and then dried at 70 oC overnight. Pure MoS2 nanoparticles are prepared using the same steps without adding MgFe2O4.

The synthesized MoS2@MgFe2O4 NPs are then characterized using various instruments. SEM was recorded on an S-4800 field-emission scanning electron microanalyzer (Hitachi, Japan). TEM was carried out on a Tecnai 12 transmission electron microscope (Philips, Netherlands). XRD patterns were obtained by a Bruker D8 advance X-ray diffractometer (Bruker-AXS, Germany) with 2θ ranging from 5 to 70°. XPS measurements were examined with an ESCALAB 250 Xi photoelectron spectrometer using Al Kα radiation (Thermo-Fisher Scientific, US). Zeta potentials were obtained via a Nano ZS90 Malvern Zetasizer.

The article does not specify the size of the synthesized MoS2@MgFe2O4 NPs. However, the synthesis process and the materials used can be adjusted to control the size of the NPs.

The next step is the preparation of MoS2 and MoS2@MgFe2O4 composite. The synthesis of MoS2-Pt0.74Ag0.26 nanoparticles (NPs) involves several steps and requires various reagents and equipment. The process begins with the preparation of MoS2 nanosheets through a liquid exfoliation method. Commercial MoS2 powder is first ground and then intercalated with concentrated H2SO4, which breaks the van der Waals interaction forces in bulk MoS2. The H2SO4-intercalated intermediate is collected by centrifugation and repeatedly washed with ultrapure water to remove residual H2SO4. After that, the obtained intermediate is functionalized with a highly hydrophilic surfactant polyallylamine hydrochloride (PAH) through physical adsorption in water under bath sonication condition, followed by probe sonication treatment to give MoS2-PAH nanosheets.

The next step is the preparation of MoS2-Pt0.74Ag0.26 hybrids. After 3 mL of MoS2-PAH solution (about 0.1 mg mL-1) was dispersed in 1 mL of ultrapure water, the solution was sonicated for 10 min, followed by adding 0.3 μmol of AgNO3, 0.9 μmol of H2PtCl6 and 10 μL of aqueous solution of HCHO solution (40 %). Then the resulting mixture was transferred to a 10-mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and was heated at 180°C for 4 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the obtained hybrid material was separated by centrifugation at 12000 r.p.m. for 10 min, washed with ultrapure water, and then dispersed into ultrapure water.

The characterization of the prepared MoS2-Pt0.74Ag0.26 NPs was performed using various techniques. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a FEI Tecnai G2 20 S-TWIN transmission electron microscope operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The synthesis of MoS2-Pt0.74Ag0.26 nanoparticles (NPs) involves several steps and requires specific reagents and equipment. The process begins with the preparation of MoS2 nanosheets through a liquid exfoliation method. Commercial MoS2 powder is first ground and then intercalated with concentrated H2SO4, which breaks the van der Waals interaction forces in bulk MoS2. The H2SO4-intercalated intermediate is collected by centrifugation and repeatedly washed with ultrapure water to remove residual H2SO4. After that, the obtained intermediate is functionalized with a highly hydrophilic surfactant polyallylamine hydrochloride (PAH) through physical adsorption in water under bath sonication condition, followed by probe sonication treatment to give MoS2-PAH nanosheets.

To prepare the MoS2-Pt74Ag26 hybrids, H2PtCl6·6H2O and AgNO3 as metal precursors are reduced by HCHO under hydrothermal conditions and PtAg alloys are formed on the MoS2-PAH nanosheets. The as-prepared MoS2-PtAg nanohybrids are then characterized in detail. The average size of PtAg NPs is about 13 nm with narrow size distribution. The analysed atomic ratio (Pt/Ag) by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) is 74 : 26, which is very close to the Pt/Ag feeding ratio of 3 : 1. According to the analysed ICP result, the loading amount of Pt74Ag26 NPs on MoS2-PAH nanosheets is 29.0 wt%.

The equipment used in this process includes a FEI Tecnai G2 20 S-TWIN transmission electron microscope, a Hitachi S-4800 field-emission scanning electron microscope, a Bruker D8 focus for X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 U-TWIN for high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), a JEOL JEM 2100F transmission electron microscopy, a Shimadzu SPM￾9600 microscopy for atomic force microscopy (AFM) characterization, a Thermo Scientific iCAP 6300 inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), a Malvern Zetasizer Nano system for zeta potential measurement, a PerkinElmer Lambda 950 UV/VIS spectrophotometer for UV-Vis absorption spectroscopic measurements, a PerkinElmer Spectrum One FT-IR spectrometer for FT-IR spectra, a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi X￾ray photoelectron spectrometer for X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), a JEOL JES-FA200 ESR spectrometer for electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra, and a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer for fluorometric measurement.

The reagents used in the synthesis include MoS2 powder, concentrated H2SO4, polyallylamine hydrochloride (PAH), H2PtCl6·6H2O, AgNO3, HCHO, and ultrapure water. The specific amounts of reagents used are 3 mL of MoS2-PAH solution (about 0.1 mg mL-1) dispersed in 1 mL of ultrapure water, 0.3 μmol of AgNO3, 0.9 μmol of H2PtCl6, and 10 μL of aqueous solution of HCHO solution (40 %).

The synthesis of nitrogen-doped titania nanoparticles (NPs) was carried out using a freeze-drying method. The process began with the preparation of a titanium precursor solution. To do this, 5 mmol of titanium isopropoxide was dissolved in 30 mL of isopropanol. This solution was then stirred for 1 hour at a moderate magnetic stirring rate. 

Next, varying amounts of urea (2, 4, and 6 g) were added as a nitrogen doping precursor to the solution and stirred for another hour. After stirring, the solution was transferred to a Petri dish and frozen at -30°C before being subjected to freeze-drying treatment. In the freeze-drying process, the samples were placed in a freeze dryer for 24 hours at -35°C. 

After freeze-drying, the sol was converted into a fluffy powder which was further ground into a fine powder. Finally, to remove any bound moisture, solvents, and impurities, these samples were calcined at 400°C for 3 hours at a ramp of 5°C/min.

The imidazole-based ionic liquid (IL) namely 1-H-3-methylimidazolium acetate (HMIM OAc) was synthesized using the neutralization route of synthesis. Equimolar volume of acetic acid was added drop-wise into 1-methylimidazole medium under cooling conditions and subsequently, the resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 hours to obtain the desired IL. After stirring, the IL was subjected to a rotary evaporator for six hours under low pressure to remove the moisture and unreacted reactants.

The preparation of ionic liquid-based nitrogen-doped titania was carried out as follows: Three different concentrations of N-doped TiO2 (4.5 mg) were added into the protic IL 1-H-3-methylimidazolium acetate (HMIM OAc) (1 mL) and mechanically ground for 30 minutes in a pestle-mortar until a well-dispersed ionic liquid-based N-doped TiO2 was achieved.

The peroxidase-like activity of the IL coated N-doped TiO2 was analyzed through colorimetric detection of H2O2, in the presence of TMB dye as a catalytic substrate. The absorption spectrum was monitored by a double beam UV–Vis. spectra at a wavelength of 652 nm, under varying concentrations of H2O2.

The article does not specify the size of the synthesized nanoparticles, so it is not possible to provide specific instructions for synthesizing 100 nm 4N-TiO2 NPs based on the information given.

The synthesis of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) is described in the provided text. However, the specific size of 200 nm is not mentioned. The synthesis process involves several steps and uses various materials and equipment.

The synthesis of rGO is carried out following a typical procedure, but without the use of Na2PdCl4. The materials used for the synthesis are not specified in the text. The characterization of the materials involves the use of a Shimadzu RF-6000 spectrofluorometer for fluorescence spectra, a UV-8000 spectrophotometer for UV-vis absorption spectra, and a JEM-1400 transmission electron microscope (TEM) for size and morphology characterization. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) are recorded on a JEM-2010 (HR) microscope. The thickness of the Pd nanoplates is characterized by an atomic force microscopy (AFM) operating in contact mode with standard silicon nitride tips at room temperature under ambient conditions.

The synthesis of {100} PdSP@rGO involves the use of KBr, AA, PVP, and GO in a glass pressure vessel. The mixture is preheated at 80 °C under stirring for 10 min, and then Na2PdCl4 in water is quickly added. The vessel is capped and kept at 80 °C for 3 h. After the reaction, the mixture is cooled to room temperature in an ice bath. The product is washed with water and ethanol several times.

The synthesis of Pd nanoplates on rGO enclosed by {111} facets [{111} PdNP@rGO] is similar to the synthesis of {100} PdSP@rGO, except for replacing KBr with KCl. Pd nanocubes are prepared according to previous literatures. PVP, AA, and KBr are dissolved in water and pre-heated in air under stirring at 80 °C for 10 min. Then, an aqueous Na2PdCl4 solution is added. After the vial has been capped, the reaction is allowed to proceed at 80 °C for 3 h.

The morphologies of the Pd nanomaterials are initially determined by TEM. The {100}PdSP@rGO presents a uniform square-like morphology with an average edge length of ca. 200 nm and 3 nm in thickness. The HRTEM image indicates that nanoplates are single crystal with well-defined fringes. A lattice spacing of 0.20 nm can be attributed to the {100} facets of Pd with fcc structure. The TEM image of Pd nanoplates enclosed with {111} facets shows clear lattice fringes with interplanar spacing of 0.22 and 0.24 nm, corresponding to the {111} basal planes and 1/3 {422} planes of the {111}PdNP@rGO, respectively. Pd nanocubes and rGO nanosheets are also successfully obtained.

The synthesis of Pd nanoparticles (NPs) is described in the provided text. The synthesis of Pd NPs enclosed by {100} facets, referred to as {100}PdSP@rGO, involves several steps and reagents. In a typical synthesis, KBr (120 mg), AA (12 mg), and PVP (50 mg) are dissolved into 8 mL of water which contains 12.96 mg GO in a glass pressure vessel. The mixture is preheated at 80 °C under stirring for 10 minutes. Then, 12 mg Na2PdCl4 in 3 mL water is quickly added. The vessel is then capped and kept at 80 °C for 3 hours. After the reaction, the mixture is cooled to room temperature in an ice water bath. The product is washed with water and ethanol several times.

The synthesis of Pd NPs enclosed by {111} facets, referred to as {111}PdNP@rGO, is similar to the synthesis of {100}PdSP@rGO, except for replacing KBr with 74.55 mg KCl. 

Pd nanocubes can also be synthesized. PVP (105 mg), AA (60 mg), and KBr (600 mg) are dissolved in 8.0 mL of water and pre-heated in air under stirring at 80 °C for 10 min. Then, an aqueous Na2PdCl4 solution (3 mL, 57 mg of Na2PdCl4) is added. After the vial has been capped, the reaction is allowed to proceed at 80 °C for 3 h.

The morphologies of the Pd nanomaterials were initially determined by TEM. As demonstrated in Figure 1A, {100}PdSP@rGO presents uniform square-like morphology with an average edge length of ca. 200 nm and 3 nm in thickness. The HRTEM image indicates that nanoplates are single crystal with well-defined fringes. A lattice spacing of 0.20 nm can be attributed to the {100} facets of Pd with fcc structure, similar to the observation in previous studies. 

In the absence of GO, Pd nanocubes instead of Pd nanoplates can be obtained. And rGO could be synthesized in the absence of Pd salt precursor. The thickness of the Pd nanoplates was characterized by an atomic force microscopy (AFM) (Nanoscopt 8 Multimode Scanning Probe microscope (Vecco)) operating in contact mode with standard silicon nitride tips at room temperature under ambient conditions.

The synthesis of Pd-Ir NPs, including those of 3 nm size, was achieved through a two-step, seed-mediated growth method previously published by the group. In the first step, Pd NPs of different sizes as seeds were synthesized in one-pot synthesis. In the second step, the Pd NPs were coated with Ir shells of roughly the same thicknesses (2-3 atomic layers in this study). 

Taking the synthesis of 5.9 nm Pd-Ir NPs as an example, monodispersed Pd NPs were first synthesized. The Pd NPs had a slightly truncated octahedral shape and displayed a great uniformity. The sizes of the Pd NPs was measured to be 4.8 ± 0.6 nm. Then, the Pd NPs were coated with Ir, where an ethylene glycol solution of Na3IrCl6 as Ir precursor was slowly introduced into a mixture containing the 4.8 nm Pd NPs as seeds, L-ascorbic acid as reductant and poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP55000) as stabilizer. 

The resultant Pd-Ir NPs as products maintained the truncated octahedral shape, implying a conformal coating of Ir on Pd NPs. The sizes of the Pd-Ir NPs was measured to be 5.9 ± 0.7 nm. The increase of overall particles size of 1.1 nm indicated the Ir shell thickness was about 0.55 nm, corresponding to approximately 2-3 Ir atomic layers. 

Size control of the Pd-Ir NPs can be conveniently achieved by using Pd seeds of different sizes. During the synthesis, the thickness of Ir shells can be tuned by varying the amounts of Pd seeds and Ir precursor. Pd-Ir NPs of 3.3 ± 0.5 nm, 9.8 ± 0.9 nm and 13.0 ± 1.0 nm, respectively, were synthesized when Pd NPs of 2.3 ± 0.3 nm, 8.7 ± 1.0 nm and 12.1 ± 1.2 nm were used as seeds. It should be noted that the thickness of Ir shell for all these Pd-Ir NPs was controlled to be roughly the same (ca. 0.5 nm), which can be estimated by measuring the increase of particle size after Ir growth.

The molar ratio of Ir to Pd for this sample was determined to be about 1:3.5 by using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping image of an individual NP confirmed the elemental distributions of Pd core and Ir shell, which is consistent with the characterization data of previous studies. 

The article does not provide specific details on the mmols of the reagents used or the specific equipment used for the synthesis. However, it is clear that the synthesis process involves the use of ethylene glycol solution of Na3IrCl6 as Ir precursor, L-ascorbic acid as reductant, poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP55000) as stabilizer, and Pd NPs as seeds. The sizes of the Pd-Ir NPs are controlled by the sizes of the Pd seeds used and the amount of Ir precursor. The characterization of the synthesized NPs involves the use of high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping.

The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping image of an individual NP confirmed the elemental distributions of Pd core and Ir shell, which is consistent with the characterization data of our previous studies. The molar ratio of Ir to Pd for this sample was determined to be about 1:3.5 by using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). 

Size control of the Pd-Ir NPs can be conveniently achieved by using Pd seeds of different sizes. During the synthesis, the thickness of Ir shells can be tuned by varying the amounts of Pd seeds and Ir precursor. Pd-Ir NPs of 3.3 ± 0.5 nm, 9.8 ± 0.9 nm and 13.0 ± 1.0 nm, respectively, were synthesized when Pd NPs of 2.3 ± 0.3 nm, 8.7 ± 1.0 nm and 12.1 ± 1.2 nm were used as seeds. It should be noted that the thickness of Ir shell for all these Pd-Ir NPs was controlled to be roughly the same (ca. 0.5 nm), which can be estimated by measuring the increase of particle size after Ir growth. 

In conclusion, the synthesis of Pd-Ir NPs involves a two-step process, using Pd NPs as seeds and coating them with Ir shells. The size of the NPs can be controlled by using Pd seeds of different sizes and varying the amounts of Pd seeds and Ir precursor. The molar ratio of Ir to Pd is about 1:3.5. The synthesis process involves the use of HR-TEM, EDX, and ICP-AES for characterization and measurement.

The text does provide some information on the characterization of the nanoparticles. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the PtNPs show that they are composed of aggregates of small nanoclusters (2-3 nm). The MnO2 nanosheets form a 3-dimensional scaffold adhered to the PtNPs, so as to encapsulate them. The diameter of the PtNPs@MnO2 is approximately 250 nm with the PtNPs having a diameter of ca. 45 nm and the MnO2 nanosheet being ca.100 nm. The structure of PtNPs@MnO2 in solution was analysed by cryo-EM. The images were recorded at the tilt angle from -60° to +60° and reconstruction of the tomograms of the nanocomposite was applied to generate the structure.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to further analyse the composition and valence states of the PtNPs@MnO2. The XPS full spectrum of the PtNPs@MnO2 reveals the presence of O, Mn and Pt. Strong peaks at 653.9 and 642.1 eV are observed in the high resolution XPS of Mn, with a spin-energy separation of 11.8 eV, which can be assigned to Mn(IV) from MnO2, and is consistent with the XPS of MnO2 nanosheets prepared similarly.

In terms of the catalytic activity of the PtNPs@MnO2, an aqueous TMB solution and the PtNPs@MnO2 stock solution were added to NaAc buffer at room temperature. UV-vis spectra were recorded over a period of 30 min. The influence of temperature (20-70°C) and pH (3.0-6.0) were investigated. In a steady-state kinetic assay, the catalytic reaction of the PtNPs@MnO2 was determined by varying the concentration of TMB under the standard conditions. The concentration of oxidized TMB (oxTMB) was calculated by applying the Beer-Lambert law using a molar absorption coefficient of 3.9×104 M-1 cm-1. The apparent steady-state reaction velocity was obtained by calculating the slopes of initial absorbance change with time. By plotting the reaction velocity against the concentration of the TMB, typical Michaelis-Menten curves were obtained. A Lineweaver-Burk plot was fitted from the Michaelis-Menten curves. The steady-state kinetic parameters were calculated using the Lineweaver-Burk plot of the double reciprocal of the Michaelis-Menten equation.
